PAGE: 1
HEADING: HABERLE

Haan, Willem de (1801-1855), Dutch biologist at Leiden. (<em>Haan</em>).

<sm>COLLECTIONS</sm>: Rijksmuseum voor natuurlijke Historie, Leiden.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Aa 8 (1): 16-17; AKL 1855: 170-171; BM 2: 756; CSP 3:
104; JW 3: 352; LS 10669-10670; PR 3670 (<em>d</em>. 1850) (ed. 1: 4002); Quenstedt p. 180 (<em>d</em>.
1853).

2224. Commentatio in quaestionem, ab ordine disciplinarum mathematicarum et physi-
carum Academiae Lugduno-Batavae, ex historia naturali, a. mdcccxx. propositam: "<em>Qui-
nam sunt limites inter vitam animalium et vegetabilium</em>." Quae praemium reportavit d. viii. mensis
februarii a. mdcccxxi. [Leiden, independently paged issue of Annales Academiae lugduno-
batavae, Leiden (S. et J. Luchtmans) 1821]. Qu. (<em>Limites vit. anim. veg.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 8 Feb 1821, p. [1]-43. <em>Copy</em>: KNAW.

Haartman, Johan Gustav (1777-1799), Finnish botanist; born in Sauvo. (<em>Haartm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Dryander 4: 148; Saelan p. 146; TR 509.
Eriksson, G., Bot. hist. Sverige 283. 1969.
Hjelt, O. E. A., Naturhistoriens studium i Finland under sjuttonde och adertonde seklet,
	Helsingfors 1868, p. 193-194. (= Bidrag till kännedom af Finlands Natur och Folk 12: i-
	vi, 1-198). This paper of Hjelt is referred to below as <em>Naturhistoriens studium i Finland</em> (inf. I.
	Kukkonen); Naturhistoriens Studium vid Åbo Universitet, Helsingfors 1896, p. 378 (inf.
	Bo Peterson). (= Skrifter utgifne af Svenska Litteratursälskapet i Finland 32: i-iv, 1-446).

2225. <em>De Tussilagine</em> commentarii botanici particula i. Quam cons. ampliss. fac. phil.
aboens. publicae censurae submittunt stipendiarii Haartmanniani Joh. Gust. Haartman,
philos. mag. et Andreas Johannes Orrström, aboënsis. In audit. min. die xxi junii, mdccxcvii
horis a.m. solitis. Aboae (typis Frenckellianis) [1797]. Qu. (<em>De Tussilag</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 21 Jun 1797, p. [i], [1]-22. <em>Copies</em>: H, MO.

Haberle, Karl Konstantin Christian (1764-1832), German botanist; first at Jena; from
1813 at Budapest. (<em>Haberle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 249; Barnhart 2: 106; BM 2: 759; Bossert p. 157;
CSP 3: 105-106; Jackson p. 4, 35; Kanitz no. 123; LS 10669-10670; NI p. 205, 308; Plesch p.
247; PR 3671-3672 (ed. 1: 4007-4009); Rehder 5: 356.
Pax, F., Grundz. Pflanzenverbreit. Karpathen 1: 11, 28. 1898 (Veg. Erde 2(1)).
Priszter, Ann. Univ. Sci. Budapest Rolando Eötvos, Biol. 12: 191-206. 1970 (some of H's
	plant names treated on p. 205-206).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Haberlea</em> Frivaldszky (1835).

2226. <em>Das Gewächsreich</em>. Oder characterisirende Beschreibung aller zur Zeit bekannten
Gewächse, als Commentar zu den Bertuchschen Tafeln der allgemeinen Natur-Geschichte.
Ein Handbuch für Naturfreunde zu eigenem Unterrichte, bei dem Gebrauche dieser Tafeln
von D. Carl Constantin Haberle. Ersten Bandes erster Theil. Pilze und Schwämme. Weimar
(im Verlag des F.G. privil. Landes-Industrie-Comptoirs) 1806. Oct. † (<em>Gewächsreich</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1806 (p. viii: 11 Apr 1806), p. [i*], [i]-viii, [3]-280. <em>Copy</em>: FH. – For Friedrich Justin
	Bertuch (1747-1822), who was one of the first to publish large scale natural history
	illustrations for use in schools, see NI p. 204.

2227. <em>Succincta rei herbariae</em> hungaricae et transsilvanicae <em>historia</em>, auctore doctore C. C.
Haberle ... Budae [Budapest] (Typis regiae universitatis hungaricae) 1830. Oct. (<em>Succ. rei
herb. hist.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jul-Dec 1830 (p. 6: 6 Jun 1830), p. [1]-66. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Pritzel cites: LINN.

PAGE: 2
HEADING: HABIRSHAW

Habirshaw, Frederick (<em>fl</em>. 1877), American diatomologist. (<em>Habirshaw</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unkown. Issued: <em>Collectio diatomaceae</em>, New York, s.d.; set at FH. For
catalogue see no. 2228. Further diatom material at AWH and S.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 75-76. 1969.
	Fryxell, G., Nova Hedwigia Beih. 35: 361. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 1: 338, 2: 759; De Toni 1: lvii, 2: lxi; Kew 2: 543;
Jackson p. 159.

2228. <em>Catalogue of the Diatomaceae</em> with references to the various published descriptions and
figures ... New York (Reproduced by the Edison electric pen process) 1877. Qu. (in fours). (<em>Cat. Diatom.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: Nov 1877 (preface 20 Oct 1877, p. 264: Mai 1877; copy at G forwarded on 1 Dec 1877;
	Hedwigia Feb 1878), p. [i-xi], [1]-[264], sign. A, B, 1-66. <em>Copies</em>: FH, G, NY, UC. –
	Number of copies printed: 50 (distributed free).
<em>Ed. 2, part 1</em>: 1881-1882 (Nat. Nov. 1881), cover, p. [i]-xxii, [1]-58. <em>Copies</em>: NY, UC. –
	"Catalogue of the Diatomaceae with references to the published descriptions and figures
	by Frederick Habirshaw, F.R.M.S. Edited and published by Romyn Hitchcock,
	F.R.M.S." New York (Thompson &amp; Moreau, ...) 1881-1882. Qu. Title on cover
	"<em>Catalogue of the Diatomaceae part 1</em> ..." – <em>Editor</em>: Romyn Hitchcock (1851–1923).
<em>Ed. 2</em>, completed, in 4(?) parts, 1881-1885 (p. 343: 1 Oct 1885; Nat. Nov. Feb 1886; Bot. Zeit.
	30 Jul 1886), lvs. [i], [1]-343, A-K [= 10 p. add.] (all single cross-stitched leaves). <em>Copies</em>:
	FH, NY, UC. – "Habirshaw's Catalogue of the Diatomaceae. H.H. Chase, M.D. Geneva,
	New York 1885" All lvs. by the "Edison electrical pen process" repr. by lithography. –
	<em>Editor</em>: Harvey Henderson Chase (1849-1915).
<em>Ed. 3</em>: prepared by H. H. Chase ... type-written to order for Julien Deby. New York 1888
	("unique" copy, see De Toni 1891); see also the handwritten copy by David Boyd Ward
	(1853-1907) at NY, 2 vols., 1891.
<em>French ed</em>.: Catalogue des diatomées, edit, française revue et augmentée par J. Pelletan. Paris
	1879 (Nat. Nov. 1879) (n.v.). <em>Translation</em> by Jules Pelletan (1833-?). FH has a hand written
	text "<em>Catalogue des Diatomées</em> avec indications bibliographiques relatives à chaque espèce
	par Frederick Habirshaw F.R.M.S. New York 1877" p. [i]-vi, [1]-264.

<em>Precursors</em>: see J. Microgr. 3: 410-414, 453-455, 497-500. 1872, 4: 40-42, 98-101. 1873.
<em>Ref</em>.: Deby, J., Bibl. micr. microgr. studies 3: 30. 1882.

Hackel, Eduard (1850-1926), Bohemia-born Austrian agrostologist and high school tea-
cher at St. Pölten (1871-1900); from 1904 at Graz. (<em>Hack</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; dupl. e.g. BM, GB, K.
<em>Ref</em>.: Hackel, E., Bot. Centralbl. 9(9): 327. 1882 (sale of parts of his herbarium).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 380, 5(3): 51; Backer p. 250; Barnhart 2: 106; BJI
1: 24, 2: 65; BM 2: 759, 6: 422; CSP 7: 882, 10: 106, 12: 302-303, 15: 558-559; DTS 1: 99-
100, 6(4): 145; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hack."); IH 2: 247; Jackson p. 341; Kew 2: 544;
Klašterský p. 85; KR p. 252; Langman p. 344; LS 10672; Maiwald p. 278; MW p. 149; NW
p. 47; Rehder 5: 356; Saccardo 1: 87, 2: 57; TL-2/978, 1592, 1835; Tucker 1: 309; Zander
ed. 10, p. 666.
Anon., Bot. Jahrb. 1: 502. 5 Apr 1881 (on H's publ. on <em>Spirachne</em> (1880)); Bull. Soc. bot.
	Deux-Sèvres 21: <em>pl. 4.</em> 1910 (portr.).
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. Länder 34. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4) (bibl.).
Dörfler, I., Botaniker-Porträts 2: 15. 1906 (portr.).
Druce, G. C, Bot. Soc. Exch. Cl. Brit. Isles 8(1): 93-97. 1927.
Fritsch, Mitt, naturw. Ver. Steiermark 1927: xxiv-xxx.
Huxley, L., Life letters J. D. Hooker 284, 285bis, 287-288. 1918.
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 141-142. 1947.
Parodi, Physis 8: 620-625. 1927 (portr., selected bibl.).
Pax, F., Grundz. Pflanzenverbr. Karpathen 28, 50, 275, 279. 1898 (Veg. Erde 2(1)) (bibl.).

HEADING: HACQUET

Reiche, K., Grundz. Pflanzenverbr. Chile 32, 372. 1907 (Veg. Erde 8) (bibl.).
Roshewitz, Bull. Jard. bot. Leningrad 28(3/4): 411-420. 1929 (bibl., portr.).
Stieber, M. T., Taxon 27: 270. 1978 (portr.).
Urban, I., Fl. bras. 1(1): 176. 1906.
Willkomm, M., Grundz. Pflanzenverbr. Iber. Halbinsel 21, 25. 1896 (Veg. Erde 1).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>:(1) <em>Monographia Andropogonearum, in</em> Alph. de Candolle, <em>Monogr. pl. 6</em>: 1-
716. <em>pl. 1-2.</em> Apr 1889 (Nat. Nov. Jul 1889) (TL 2/978).
(2) <em>Gramineae</em> (echtz Gräser), <em>in</em> E.P 2.2:. 1-97, 126 (p. 1-48 Jul 1887, 49-96 Nov, p. 97 and 126,
Jan 1888), Nachtr. 2-4(1): 39-47. Jul 1897, 2: 3-7. 8 Oct 1900 (TL 2/1710).
(3) with F. Pax, <em>in</em> EP, <em>Die natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien, Cyperaceae und Gramineae</em>, reprint Dec
1887, Leipzig (Engelmann) 130 p., <em>1 pl</em>., 426 figs.
(4) <em>Gramineae brasilienses</em> V, <em>in</em> Martius, <em>Flora brasiliensis</em>, fasc. 90, 1 Jul 1883, vol. 2(3): 245-
326. <em>pl. 59-74.</em> (see also under J. C. Döll).
(5) <em>Gramineae gesammelt auf der Forschungsreise der Gazelle</em> [Berlin 1890], 11 p., 4 pl., see Engler,
no. 1705; see also Bot. Jahrb. 6: 233-248. 1885.
(6) See Durand et Pittier, <em>Primit. fl. costaric.</em>, TL 2/1592.
(7) Contributed to H. W. Reichardt, <em>Flora der Insel Jan Mayen</em>, 21 p., in vol. 3 (7a) of <em>Die
internationale Polarforschung</em> 1882-1883, Wien, 1886; see under Reichardt.
(8) <em>Gramineae</em>, with J. Ch. Doell, <em>in</em> Warming, E., <em>Symb</em>. nos. 37-38, publ. 3 Mai 1892.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hackelochloa</em> O. Kuntze (1891).

2229. <em>Catalogue raisonné des Graminées du Portugal</em> ... Coimbre [Coimbra] (Imprimerie de
l'Université) 1880. Oct. (<em>Cat. rais. Gramin. Portugal</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai-Jun 1880 (Nat. Nov. Jul 1880; Bot. Zeit. 9 Jul 1880; J. Bot. Aug 1880), p. [1]-34.
	<em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Engler, A., Bot. Jahrb. 1: 302. 12 Oct 1880.

2230. <em>Monographia Festucarum europearum</em> ...Kassel und Berlin (Verlag von Theodor Fi-
scher) 1882. Oct. (<em>Monogr. Festuc. eur.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Mai 1882 (p. ix: Oct 1881; Nat. Nov. Mai 1882; Bot. Zeit. 26 Mai 1882), p. [i]-ix,
	[1]-216, <em>pl. 1-4</em>, uncol. liths. by the author. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY, U, US(2), USDA.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Micro methods Ltd., and Johnson Reprint Corporation 1964 (as orig.) <em>Copies</em>:
	MICH, USDA.
<em>Ref</em>.: Peter, Bot. Zeit. 41: 314-315. 11 Mai 1883.
	Engler, A., Bot. Jahrb. 4: 89-91. 22 Mar 1883.

2231. <em>The true grasses</em>... Translated from die natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien by F. Lamson-
Scribner and Effie A. Southworth .... New York (Henry Holt and Company) 1890. Oct. (<em>True grasses</em>).

<em>Translators</em>: Frank Lamson-Scribner (1851-1938); Effie Almira Soutworth (1860-?) (later
	Mrs. Volney Morgan Spalding).
<em>Orig. ed.</em>: 1890 (p. iv: 1 Feb 1890; TBC 1 Jul 1890), front., p. [i]-viii, [1]-228. <em>Copies</em>: MO,
	NY, US (2), USDA. The second US copy has a loose errata slip.
"<em>New edition</em>": Westminster (Constable) 1896 (Nat. Nov. Dec (2) 1896), p. [i]-viii, [1]-228,
	"a re-issue of the old sheets with a slightly different binding" (Rendle); "the sooner our
	systematists recognize the fact that ability to read German is an essential towards good
	work, the better for them and the better for botany" (id.)
<em>Ref</em>.: Rendle, A. B., J. Bot. 35: 60-61. Feb 1897.
	Holm, Bot. Gaz. 15(8): 212-213. Aug 1890.

Hacquet, Belsazar (Balthasar) (1739-1815), Bretagne (Brittany) born French-Austrian
physician, botanist and geologist; born at Conquet (Bretagne); high school teacher at
Laibach (Ljubljana); 1788 prof. natural history at Lemberg (Lwow); later mining counsel at
Vienna; explorer of Croatia and the Carpathians. (<em>Hacq</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown, "nel museo agrario di Lubiana" (Saccardo).
<em>Note on name</em>: Dalla Torre (DTS 6 (4): 145) corrects the generally used later (Austrian)
Balthasar to the (Brittany) Belsazar.

PAGE: 4
HEADING: HACQUET

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6 (1): 20; Backer p. 250; Barnhart 2: 106; BM 2: 759;
Bossert p. 158; CSP 3: 109-110; DTS 1: 100; Dawson p. 379; Dryander 5: 264; GR p. 325;
Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hacq."); Jackson p. 265; Kanitz no. 174; Kew 2: 544; LS 10674-10675;
NI 771; PR 3673 (ed. 11401 1-4015); Quenstedt p. 181; Rehder 5: 357; Saccardo 1: 87-88, 2:
57, cron. p. xxiv; WU 7: 163; Zander ed. 10, p. 660.
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. Länder 3, 35. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4).
Hoelzl, Verh. zool.-bot. Ges. Wien 11: 433-446. 1861 (on H's observations in the Carpathian
	Mts.).
J., Dict. Sci. méd. 5: 10-12. 1822 (bibl.).
Kanitz, A., Pl. roman. xx. 1881.
Pax, F., Grundz. Pflanzenverbr. Karpathen 7-8, 31. 1898 (Veg. Erde 2(1)).
Szafer, W., Concise hist. bot. Cracow 41, 48. 1969.
Voss, W., Jahresber. Staats- Oberrealschule Laibach 1884: 20-24 (n.v., fide DTS 1: 100).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hacquetia</em> Necker ex A.P. de Candolle (1830).

2232. <em>Plantae alpinae carniolicae</em>. Collegit et descripsit Balth. Hacquet.... Viennae [Wien]
(Sumptibus bibliopolae Joannis Pauli Kraus) 1782. Qu. (<em>Pl. alp. carniol.</em>).

<em>Orig</em>.: 1782, p. [1]-16, <em>pl. 1-5</em>, uncol. copper engr. Joseph Pallnstorff (sign, on <em>pl. 1</em>). <em>Copies</em>: G,
	NY, Teyler, USDA, WU.
<em>Other edition</em>: 1782, Viennae (Sumptibus bibliopolae Joannis Pauli Kraus), p. [1]-31, <em>pl. 1-5</em>
	(as in original issue). <em>Copy</em>: WU. – This 31 p. edition has a different, more elaborate, text;
	on the t.p. the author is given as "Hacquet" (16 p. ed.: "Balth. Hacquet"); the word
	<em>Carnioliae</em> is in italics fancy letters (16 p. ed. roman, traditional). PR mentions a Wappler
	imprint for the 16 p. ed.; this has not been traced by us.

2233. Hacquet's neueste <em>physikalisch-politische Reisen</em> in den Jahren 1788 und 1789 durch <em>die
dacischen und sarmatischen</em> oder nördlichen <em>Karpathen</em>. Nürnberg (im Verlag der Raspischen
Buchhandlung) 1790-1796, 4 vols. Oct. (<em>Reis. dac. sarm. Karpathen</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1790, frontisp., xxiv, 207 p., <em>pl. 1-7</em> (col. copper engr.).
	<em>2</em>: 1791, xxvi, 249, [6, err.], <em>pl. 1-6</em> (id.).
	<em>3</em>: 1794, xxvi, 247, 3 charts, <em>pl. 1-7</em> (1-6 col., 7 maps).
	<em>4</em>: 1796, xvi, 254, [2, err.], <em>pl. 1-6</em> (4-6 col.).

<em>Copy</em>: WU (analysis: W. Gutermann).
Hacquet's other travelogues were "<em>Mineralogisch-botanische Lustreise von dem Berge Terglou in
Krain bis zu dem Berge Glockner in Tyrol im Jahr 1779</em>" (Wien 1784, Oct.), "<em>Physikalisch-politische
Reise aus den dinarischen durch die julischen ... Alpen in den Jahren 1781 und 1792 unternommen</em>"
(Leipzig, 4 vols., 1785-1787, Oct.); <em>Reisen durch die norischen Alpen</em>,... (Nürnberg, 2 vols.,
1791, Oct.). (all n.v.). Motto on frontisp. of present work, on the Carpathians:
	"An diesen Felsen gränzt in wilder Wüsteney
	Der Muselmannen Reich die Moldau, Wallachey
	Dort wohnet Christ und Türck, und zeigt durch rohe Sitten
	Der sey Barbar getauft und der Barbar beschnitten."

Haeckel, Ernst Heinrich Philipp August (1834-1919), German evolutionary zoologist
and popularizer of biology. (<em>Haeckel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: at JE and in the Ernst Haeckel House, Jena.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 87; Ainsworth p. 33, 321; Barnhart 2: 106; BM 2: 759-
761, 6: 422; Bossert p. 158; CSP 3: 109, 6: 680, 7: 882-883, 10; 106-107, 12: 303, 15: 562-563,
16: 506; De Toni 2: lxi; DSB 6: 6-11; Kew 2: 546; KR p. 252; Moebius p. 363; NI p. 1, 221,
308; Quenstedt p. 182; Rehder 5: 357; SO 1256.

<em>Note</em>: No attempt is made to cite here the secondary literature on Haeckel. The references
below are to some general biographical studies, to modern evaluations and to publications
dealing with H's rôle in botany.

HEADING: HAECKEL

	Morphologie

2233a. <em>Natürliche Schöpfungsgeschichte</em>. Gemeinverständliche wissenschaftliche Vorträge über
die Entwicklungslehre im Allgemeinen und diejenige von Darwin, Goethe und Lamarck im
Besonderen, über die Anwendung derselben auf den Ursprung des Menschen und andere
damit zusammenhängende Grundfragen der Naturwissenschaft. Berlin (Verlag von Georg
Reimer) 1868. Oct. (<em>Nat. Schöpf.-Gesch.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1868, front., p. [i]-xvi, [1]-240, 240b-c, 241-568, <em>pl. 1-8. Copies</em>: G, M, Teyler.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1870 (p. xxx: 3 Mai 1870), front., p. [i]-xxxii, [1]-688, <em>pl. 1-15. Copy</em>: G. – "Zweite,
	verbesserte und vermehrte Auflage". Berlin (id.).
<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1872 (p. xliv: 18 Mar 1872; Bot. Zeit. 20 Sep 1872), front. (= <em>pl. 1</em>), [i]-xlvi, [1, h.t.],
	[1]-688, <em>pl. 2-15. Copy</em>: M. – Berlin (id.).
<em>Ed. 4</em>: 1873 (p. xliv: 24 Jun 1873), front., [i]-xlvi, [1, h.t.], [1]-688, <em>pl. 1-15. Copy</em>: Kon. Bibl.
	(The Hague). – Berlin (id.).
<em>Ed. 5</em>: 1874, p. [i]-xlvi, [1]-688, <em>pl. 1-16. Copy</em>: HBG. – "Fünfte verbesserte Auflage ..."
	Berlin (id.).
<em>Ed. 6</em>: n.v.

	In two parts, division at 370/371. Berlin (Georg Reimer). Oct.

2234. <em>Plankton-Studien</em>. Vergleichende Untersuchungen über die Bedeutung und Zusam-
mensetzung der pelagischen Fauna und Flora ... Jena (Verlag von Gustav Fischer) 1890.

Haenke, Thaddaeus (Tadeáš) Peregrinus Xaverius (1761-1816), Czech botanist and
explorer on the Malaspina expedition. (<em>Haenke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR. – <em>Reliquiae haenkeanae</em> were distributed from Prague after 1816.
<em>Ref</em>.: IH 2: 248; SK 1: 209-210, 5: cclxxxiii, 8: xl.
	Lamson-Scribner, Rep. Missouri Bot. Gard. 10: 35-59, <em>pl- 54</em>. 1899 (on H's grasses in
	Bernhardi herbarium, descr. by Presl).
	Miller, Taxon 19: 524. 1970.

Zander ed. 10, p. 660.

Hagenbach, Carl [Karl] Friedrich (1771-1849), Swiss botanist; from 1795 practicing
physician at Basel; from 1802-1820 professor of anatomy and botany at Basel University.
(<em>Hagenb</em>.).

Hagenbach's work contains a key to Casper Bauhin's (q.v.) names. The Werner de Lachenal
(1736-1800) and Johann Jakob Hagenbach (1595-1649) herbaria used by C. F. Hagenbach
for his <em>Tentamen</em> are also at BAS.

	the supplement).

Hagerup, Olaf (1889-1961), Danish botanist; educated at Copenhagen University under
Warming; Dr. phil. Copenhagen 1930; travelled to Greenland (1924) and Niger (1927);
from 1927-1935 lecturer at a pharmaceutical college; from 1935 curator at the Copenhagen
Botanical Museum. (<em>Hagerup</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM and TYPES</sm>: C.

Haines, Henry Haselfoot (1867-1945), British forester in India; Indian Forest Service
(1888), Imperial forest botanist (1906); at Imperial Forest College 1907; Conservator of
forests (1909-1919). (<em>Haines</em>).

Halácsy, Eugen von [Eugène de] (1842-1913), Austrian botanist of Hungarian descent,
from 1859 in Wien; Dr. med. Wien 1865; practising physician 1865-1896; from 1896 part
time medical consultant for an insurance company; Dr. phil. h.c. Athens 1912; 1899
Kaiserlicher Rat, 1913 Regierungsrat; explorer of the Greek flora. (<em>Halácsy</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W (herb. Graec., on permanent loan from WU); European herb. at
WU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 761, 5(1): 588, 6(1): 150, 697, 12(1): 218; Backer p.
651; Barnhart 2: 112; BFM 916, 1499; BM 2: 769, 6: 425; Bossert p. 159; Clokie p. 176; CSP
12: 304, 15: 575; DTS 1: 100-101; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Halácsy"); IF p. 700; IH 2: 249; Kew 2:
553; ÖBL 2: 156; Rehder 5: 358; SK 4: clxxxv; Tucker 1: 310-311; Zander ed. 10, p. 666.
Adamović, L., Vegetationsverh. Balkanländer 18. 1909 (Veg. Erde 11) (bibl.).
Anon., Bot. Not. 1914: 31.
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. Länder 34. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4).
Degen, A., Magy. bot. Lap. 13: 1-9. 1914 (Hungarian), 10-17. 1914 (German), (portr.)
	(born in Wien ("Bècs") 11 Nov 1842).

Hall, Charles Albert (1872-1965), English clergyman who held pastorates at Hull, Bristol,
Paisley, Southport and London (1896-1935); popular writer on British wild flowers. (<em>C. A.
Hall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Hall, Elihu (1822-1882), American botanist at Athens, Ill.; botanical explorer of the Rocky
Mountains with C. C. Parry and J. P. Harbour; one of the organizers of the Illinois Natural
History Society at Bloomington (1858). (<em>E. Hall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: F. – Duplicates in many herbaria, see IH. Hall sold various sets of
American plants. See also Ewan (1950) and Sayre (1975).
<em>Ref</em>.: Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 417. 1880.
	Groff, Bartonia 23: 48. 1945 (material at DWC).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 331. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 252; Barnhart 2: 113; BM 2: 771; Bossert p. 159;
CSP 7: 891, 12: 304-305, 15: 582; IH 2: 250; Kew 2: 557; Lenley p. 192; LS 10723; ME 1:
191, 2: 211, 3: 279, 316; Pennell p. 608; Rehder 1: 320, 323; Tucker 1: 311.
Allison, Univ. Colorado Studies 6: 63. 1908.

Hall, Franklin Wilson (1852-1888), American botanist at New Haven, Conn. (<em>F. Hall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: material at LIV, PH.

2275. <em>Catalogue of a collection of ferns</em> made in Southern Mexico, mainly at Chiapas, by A.
Ghiesbrecht, in the years 1864-1870; by Franklin W. Hall, s.l.n.d. [New Haven 1873]. Oct.
(size). (<em>Cat. coll. ferns</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mar-Dec 1873 (p. [1: 1 Mar 1873) p. [1]-10. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Daniel C. Eaton, in a footnote
	on p. [1], states that Hall did the work of identifying these ferns "under my constant
	supervision." The collector was Auguste Boniface Ghiesbrecht (1810-1893), see IH 2:
	223.

Hall, Harvey Munroe (1874-1932), Californian pioneer biosystematist, at Berkeley, later
at Carnegie Institution of Washington at Stanford; inspired the work of Clausen, Keck and
Hiesey; took the first initiatives (1930) towards the establishment of an International Bureau
of Plant Taxonomy and the compilation of the Index Herbariorum and type registers. (<em>H.
M.Hall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: IC (nos. 10.921-x), UC (1-10.920), with duplicates at B, BH, BM,
DS, E, GH, K, L, LAM, LE, MIN, MO, NA, NMC, NY, P, POM, S, SI, US, WELC. –
Distributed sets of plants under the titles <em>Plants of Southern California, Plants of California, Plants
of the Sierra Nevada Mountains</em> and similar series.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 113; BL 1: 165, 168, 299; BM 6: 426; Bossert p.
159; Hirsch p. 111; Hortus 3: 1194 ("H. M. Hall"); IH 2: 250; Kew 2: 557; Langman p.
345; NW p. 47; TL-2/781; Zander ed. 10, p. 666; see also notes under W. M. Hiesey and A. S.
Hitchcock in this volume.
Anon., Botanical journeys of Harvey Monroe Hall 1895-1931, mimeographed document,
	undated, distributed by Carnegie Institute of Washington, Biology Div. Stanford. <em>Copies</em>:
	MO, NY, FAS (detailed record of botanical trips based on H's field note books); Palo Alto
	Times 11 Mar 1932, p. I.
Babcock, Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 17(12): 355-368, <em>pl. 66.</em> 1934 (portr., bibl.) (see p. 361 for
	Hall's proposed International Bureau of Plant Taxonomy ... "valuable suggestions ...
	that sooner or later ... will doubtless be realized.").
Cantelow, Leaflets western Bot. 8: 92. 1957.

	Stanford, Calif. July 1969.

	U.S. 111, 112, 118, 1969.

Johansen, Desert (Pasadena, Calif.) 3: 135. 1932 (fide Ewan 1950).

Hall, Herman Christiaan van (1801-1874), Dutch botanist and agronomist at Gron-

<em>Note</em>: <em>Neohallia</em> W. B. Hemsley (1882) is "dedicated to Mrs. Eardley Hall (a daughter of ...
W. Borrer), of Barrow Hill, Henfield, Sussex, through whose kind help the author [i.e.
Hemsley] was enabled to follow his inclination for the study of botany."

2281. Hermanni Christiani van Hall, ... responsio ad quaestionem botanicam: elaboretur
<em>historia et</em> in ea <em>accurata descriptio, viginti ad minimum plantarum indigenarum</em>, in qua singulae partes
ad legem regularum, a Linnaeo in Philosophia botanica propositarum atque a Willdenowo
emendatarum sunt definiendae. In certamine literario civium academiarum belgicarum, die
viii. mensis februarii a. mdcccxix, ex sententia ordinis disciplinarum mathematicarum et

<em>Copies</em>: BR, G, FAS, MO, NY, U. – Miquel did the Hepatics and the genera <em>Hypnum, Bryum,
Dicranum, Didymodon, Fissidens</em>, and <em>Leucodon</em> for vol. 2(1); the rest of the mosses and all the
vascular cryptogams (incl. Equisetaceae) were done by Michiel Dassen (1809-1852). Wach-
ter published a revision of Dassen's mosses in 1941. For an extensive bibliographical study of
van Hall's <em>Flora</em> see Margadant (MD).

	Bolhuis Hoitsema). Actually compiled by Gozewinus Acker Stratingh (1804-1876),
	Rembertus Westerhoff (1801-1874) and J. Bosman Tresling.

Hall, Herman van (1830-1890), Dutch botanist and botanical lexicographer; son of H. C.
van Hall; curator at the Rijksherbarium; from 1866 high school teacher at Middelburg. (<em>H.
Hall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Not traced. Some material possibly at L.

HEADING: HALL, H. VAN

2293. <em>De Kruidtuin</em> van's Rijks Hoogere Burgerschool te Middelburg. Systematische lijst van

Middelburg (H. A. Boudewijnse) 1871. Oct. (<em>Kruidtuin</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1871, p. [1]-400, [1, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: L, Prov. Bibl. Zeeland. – Important as a botanical
	dictionary with many notes on derivation of names, biographical details on botanists and
	historical notes on cultivated plants. Forerunner of Gerth van Wijk and Backer's botanical
	dictionaries.

Hall, James (of Albany) (1811-1898), American geologist and palaeobiologist; pupil of
Amos Eaton; leader of the New York Geological Survey 1843-1898. (<em>J. Hall</em>).

<sm>COLLECTIONS</sm>: Herbarium specimens at F.

Haller, Albrecht von (1708-1777), Swiss naturalist, poet and novelist; studied medicine
at Tübingen (1723-725), Leiden (with Boerhaave, 1725-1727), London and Paris; practic-
ing physician at Bern (1729-1736) and Goettingen (1736-1753); "Ammann" at Bern 1753-
1756; supervisor Salt Industry Bex (1756-1764); at Bern 1764-1777. (<em>Haller</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main herbarium at P (59 vols., 10.000 species; taken from Pavia by
French troops in 1796 and never reclaimed), with collections by Haller, C. Allioni, C.
Bauhin, J. G. Gmelin, A. Gouan, J. F. Gronovius, B. de Jussieu, N. J. Jacquin, L. G.
Lemonnier, C. Linnaeus and Ortega in addition to Swiss collections by G. D. Duvernoy, A.
Gagnebin, J. Gessner, A. Huber and P. Thomas. Haller founded the Göttingen University
herbarium (see Zoller 1958).
	Haller was among the first botanists to realize the importance of herbaria to study
variation in plants and he therefore purposely include material from different localities,

PAGE: 25
HEADING: HALLER

habitats and developmental phases. Haller also grew many plants from the Alps himself.
	The herbarium of Haller fil. (at G) also contains material collected by Haller sen. ("les
débris" Briquet); other material is at B, GOET, KIEL, LINN, MW, OXF, PH, SBT.
<em>Ref</em>.: Bonnet, J. de Bot. 354-360. 1889.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 10: 420-429; AG 2(1): 204, 1: 62, 12(3): 149; Ains-
worth p. 115, 197, 226, 251, 254, 263, 311; Backer p. 251; Barnhart 2: 115; BM 2: 774-775;
Bossert p. 160; Clokie p. 176; Dawson p. 214, 936 [index]; Dryander 5: 266-267; Frank
3 (Anh.): 40; GFB p. 58; GR p. 632, cat. p. 643, <em>pl</em>. [<em>21</em>]; Henrey 2: 165, 243, 720, 3: 51;
Hortus 3: 1194 ("Haller"); HU 506, 535, 546, 622; Jackson p. 6, 305, 341, 342; Kew 2: 561;
Kirschleger 2: xxxviii-xli; Krempelh. 2: 37; KR p. 260; Lasègue p. 67, 570; LS 10735-10749,
34023; Moebius p. 46, 450; NI 773-775, 775n; 3: 37; Plesch p. 248; PR 3713-3729 (ed. 1:
4065-4085); Rehder 5: 359; RS p. 86; Saccardo 1: 88, 2: 57; SO 650add., 1276, 1820, 2461c,
2468, 2502a, add. 2526b, 2537, 2545, 3625; Sotheby p. 315-317; TL-2/see 2285 and index
TL-2/1; Tucker 1: 312; Zander ed. 10, p. 666.

<em>Note</em>: The literature on Haller is enormous and spreads through the sciences, arts and
humanities. We list a number of papers dealing more especially with H's botanical work.
Many other references to such contributions will be found in the book treatments below.

Amoreux, Mém. Soc. Linn. Paris 1: 695-697. 1822.
Anon., Haller-Feier in Bern am 15. und 16. Oktober 1908. Festbericht. Bern (K. J. Wyss)
	1908, 123 p., Leben der berühmtesten vier Gelehrten unseres philosophischen Jahrhun-
	derts Rousseau's, Lambert's, Haller's und Voltaire's. Frankfurt und Leipzig 1779 (n.v.
	but see Steck 1963); [Condorcet], Hist. Acad. roy. Sci., Paris 1777: 127-154. 1780; Bull.
	Linn., Paris 6: 58. 1825 (on portr.).

2311. Alberti v. Haller <em>Historia stirpium indigenarum Helvetiae inchoata</em> ... Bernae (Sumptibus
Societatis typographicae) 1768, 3 vols. Fol. (<em>Hist. stirp. Helv.</em>).

<em>1</em>: [i*-iv*], i-lxiv, [1]-444, <em>pl. 1-20</em>, publ. 17 Mar-8 Aug 1768.
<em>2</em>: [i], [1]-323, <em>pl. 21-44, 37b.</em> 1768 ["hic tomus Lausanne editus 1767" Haller in copy at P], <em>pl.
	30</em> and <em>34</em> on one plate.
<em>3</em>: [i]-204, <em>pl. 45-48.</em> 1768 ["ex prelo prodiit 25 mart. 1768 et eodem tempore Lausannae"
	idem].

<em>Copies</em>: BR, G, MICH, MO, NY, U. The plates are uncoloured copper engravings, some signed
	C. J. Rollinus. All three volumes were reviewed in Jenaische Zeit. gel. Sachen of 8
	Aug 1768. The dates of publication can be accepted to be 1: 17 Mar-8 Aug 1768; 2: 1767;
	3: 25 Mar 1768. – The names only (with some amendments) were published in <em>Nomenclator
	stirpium Helvetiae indigenarum</em>, Bern 1769, see no. 2312.

	Suter, Flora Helvetica, Zurich 1802 (provides binary names for Haller's species described
	in the Historia).

	annotated by Haller).
	Wilmott, J. A., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1935: 90 (proposal to treat names in this work as not
	validly published (not accepted)).
	De Beer, Ann. Sci. 9: 1-46. 1953.

2312. <em>Nomenclator ex Historia plantarum indigenarum Helvetiae</em> excerptus auctore. Bernae (Sum-
ptibus Societatis Typographicae) 1769. Oct. (<em>Nomenclator</em>)

<em>Publ</em>.: 1769 (p. iv: 8 Jun 1768), p. [i]-iv, [1]-216. <em>Copies</em>: BR, FH(2), G (interleaved), MICH,
	MO, NY, US. – No binary names. According to NZgS of 11 Aug 1768 the book was to be
	available at the Michaelis-Messe, late Sep 1768. There is no indication that the book was
	actually published in 1768. The Nomenclator lists the names of the <em>Historia</em> (1768) (2311)
	with several amendments.

Haller, Albrecht von, filius (1758-1823), Swiss botanist at Bern; son of A. von Haller;
studied at Bern; followed a political and administrative career at Bern (temporarily at
Interlaken) paralleling a scientific career as professor of botany at the Bern medical institute
(1798) and director of the Bern botanical garden (1806). (<em>Haller f.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G. – Another, small, herbarium is at BERN. The main herbarium at
G, willed by Haller to the "Bibliothèque de Genève" is mainly central European; it is
incorporated in the general herbarium. This gift led to the establishment of the Genève
Conservatoire botanique.
<em>Ref</em>.: Crépin, F., Annu. Jard. Cons. bot. Genève I: 12-31. 1897 (<em>Rosa</em>).
	Arvet-Touvet, J. M. C., ib. 1: 68-89. 1897.
	Wettstein, R. von, ib. 5: 127-130. 1901. (<em>Gentiana</em>).
	Hackel et Briquet, ib. 10: 26-98. 1907. (<em>Gram</em>.).
Cavillier, F. G., <em>in</em> J. Briquet, Bull. Soc. bot. Suisse 50a: 254-255. 1940.
	Miège &amp; Wuest, Saussurea 6: 130. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 10: 642, 2(1): 405; Barnhart 2: 115; BM 2: 775; Bossert
p. 160; Dryander 5: 70; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Haller f."); IH 2: 251; Kew 2: 561; PR post 3729.
Briquet, J., Bull. Inst. natl. Genevois 37: 178-198. 1907 (portr.); Bull. Soc. bot. Suisse 50a:
	248-258. 1940 (bibl.).
Burdet, H., Musées de Genève 179: 13-16. 1977 (portr.).
Candolle, A. P. de, Mém. souvenirs 300, 353. 1862.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 30: 386. 1975.

Haller, Gottlieb Emmanuel von (1735-1786), Swiss statesman and botanist at Bern; son
of Albrecht von Haller senior. (<em>G. Haller</em>).

Hallier, Ernst Hans (1831-1904), German botanist and parasitologist, professor of botany
at Jena but mostly living in Münich; nephew and pupil of Schleiden. (<em>Hallier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

GR p. 85; Hortus 3: 1194 ("E. Hallier"); Kew 2: 562; Jackson p. 555 [index]; Langman p.
345; LS 10742-10824, 34024; NAF ser. 2. 4: 43; NI 776; Plesch p. 249; Ratzeburg p. 221-
222; Rehder 5: 360; TL-2/1592; Tucker 1: 312.

2324. <em>Deutschland's Flora</em> oder Abbildung und Beschreibung der daselbst wildwachsenden
Pflanzen. In naturgetreu colorirten Abbildungen. Vollständig in einhundert Lieferungen.
Achte vollständig umgearbeitete und vermehrte Auflage. Leipzig (Wilhelm Baensch Ver-
lagshandlung) 1868-1870. Qu. (<em>Deutschl. Fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1868-1870, in 100 parts, p. [i*-iii*], [i-xxxvi], <em>pl. 1-500</em>, (col. liths.). <em>Copy</em>: NY.
	Published anonymously. See 2325 for ed. 9, published under Hallier's name. For <em>Flora von
	Deutschland</em> see above under composite works.

2325. <em>Deutschlands Flora</em>, oder Abbildung und Beschreibung der wildwachsenden Pflanzen
in der mitteleuropäischen Flora. Mit fünfhundert colorirten Kupfertafeln. Neunte durchaus
neu bearbeitete Auflage. Text von Dr. Ernst Hallier ... Leipzig (Wilhelm Baensch Verlags-
handlung) s.d. [1873-1875]. Qu. (<em>Deutschl. Fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In parts, 1873-1875, p. [i*-iii*], [i]-xxi, [I, h.t.], [1]-224, <em>pl. 1-500</em>, unsigned hand-
	coloured engraved plates. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, US. – The original covers (at least
	some) have an imprint "Dresden. Wilhelm Baensch Verlagshandlung".
It is most likely that the title goes back to J. Sturm, <em>Deutschlands Flora</em> (1798-1861) q.v. –
Anonymous editions of "Deutschlands Flora" (ed. 7 and ed. 8) were published Leipzig 1864-
1868 (7) and ib. 1868-1870 (8). These anonymous editions are also attributed to Ernst
Hallier, e.g. by Collins (Sotheby 318: ed. 8) (see 2324).

2326. <em>Excursionsbuch</em>, enthaltend praktische Anleitung zum Bestimmen der im Deutschen
Reich heimischen Phanerogamen. Jena (Verlag von Hermann Dufft) 1874. Oct. (<em>Exkursions-
buch</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1874 (Bot. Zeit. 10 Jul. 1874), n.v.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: Mai 1876 (p. iv: Feb 1876; "soeben" Mai 1876 in Bot. Zeit. 34: 368 and in Flora 59:
	256. 1 Jun 1876), p. [i]-xvi, [1]-288. <em>Copies</em>: B, NY. – "Zweite vermehrte Ausgabe" Jena
	(id.) 1876. Oct.

2327. <em>Flora der Wartburg</em> und der Umgegend von Eisenach. Für natursinnige Besucher der
Wartburg und zum Schulgebrauch ausgearbeitet von Ernst Hallier ... Jena (Verlag von
Gustav Fischer, vormals Friedrich Mauke) 1879. Oct. (<em>Fl. Wartburg</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun-Jul 1879 (p. viii: Apr 1879; Nat. Nov.Jul(2) 1879, Bot. Zeit. 25 Jun 1880) p. [i]-
	viii, [1]-84. <em>Copy</em>: G.
<em>Ref</em>.: N.L., Bot. Zeit. 38: 462. 1880 (rev.).

2328. <em>Untersuchungen über Diatomeen</em> insbesondere über ihre Bewegungen und ihre vegetative

<em>Publ</em>.: 1880 (p. vi: Feb 1880), p. [i]-vi, [7]-32, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (col. liths. auth.). <em>Copy</em>: FH.

HEADING: HALLIER, H. J. G.

Hallier, Hans [Johannes] Gottfried (1868-1932), German botanist who collected in
Indonesia and the Philippines and who settled ultimately (Nov 1908) at Leiden; son of Ernst
Hallier. (<em>H. Hallier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBG; duplicates of his Indonesian collection in many herbaria, e.g.
BO; mosses e.g. at H.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 251-252; Barnhart 2: 116; BJI 1: 24, 2: 66-67; BM
2: 776, 6: 428; BL 1: 113, 299; CSP 15: 592; GR p. 85; Hortus 3: 1194 ("H. G. Hallier"); IH
2: 251; Kew 2: 562-563; JW 2: 191; Langman p. 345-346; Moebius p. 145, 206; MW p. 149-
150; Rehder 5: 360; SBC p. 121 ("Hall."); SK 1: 212-214 (portr., itin. Indon.); Tucker 1:
312-314.
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2: 25, 127. 1941.
Hallier, H., Das proliferierende persönliche und das sachliche, konservative Prioritätsprin-
	zip in der botanischen Nomenklatur. (aus: Ueber Kautschuklianen und andere Apo-
	cyneen ... Jahrb. Hamb. Wiss. Anst. 17: 55-64. 1899. 3. Beiheft: Arbeiten des Bot.
	Museums) Hamburg 1900, (on the absence of a mechanism to weed out individual
	legalistic nomenclatural decisions not supported by taxonomic knowledge; an essay very
	characteristic of this colourful scientist), (see also Hallier's <em>Néue Vorschläge</em>, Jahrb. Hamb.
	Wiss. Anst. 22: 33-46. 1905); Short sketch of the life and scientific education of Hans
	Hallier, Ph.D., Leiden 1910 (handwritten text at L and U; copy FAS).
Herzog, Th., Pflanzenw. Boliv. Anden 17. 1923 (Veg. Erde 15).
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 142. 1947.
Sirks, M. J., Ind. natuurond. 171, 181, 212. 1915.
Wulff, E. V., Intr. hist, pl-geogr. 173, 197, 200. 1943.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Convolvulaceae, <em>in</em> Durand et Pittier, <em>Primitiae florae costaricenses</em> 1(3),
1896, TL 2/1592; cf. also Bull. Soc. Bot. Belg. 35 (Mém.): 268-276. 1896.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Fl. males. ser. I. 1: cl. 1950; Taxon 19: 908. 1970.

Halsted, Byron David (1852-1918), American botanist and pioneer phytopathologist;
graduate of Michigan Agricultural College; D.Sc. Harvard 1878; amateur baseball pitcher;
at Iowa Agricultural College 1885-1889; one of the original members of the Advisory board
for the North American Flora; professor of botany at Rutgers College and botanist at the New
Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station 1889-1918.
(<em>Halst</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Herbarium material collected in C. America at CS, K, ILL, MASS,
MICH, NY, PUR, UTC, VT, WVU. Halsted also distributed (1893) "a century of weed
seeds" in vials with printed labels.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 116; BL 1: 197, 299; Bossert p. 160; CSP 10: 122,
14: 824, 15: 596-598; IH 2: 251; Kew 2: 564; Lenley p. 209; LS 10829-11056, 34025-34091
(major source of bibl. details!); NAF 7(15): 1067; NW p. 47; Rehder 5: 360; Stevenson p.
1244 ("Halst."); Tucker 1: 314.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1919: 152, 1921: 14; Nature 102: 93-94. 1918; Torreya 18(8): 176. 7 Sep
	1918; Proc. Iowa Acad. Sci. 19: 33-35. 1912, 20: 31-33. 1913.
Boone, W., Hist. bot. W. Virg. 34. 1965.
Cook, Bot. Gaz. 67(2): 169-170. 1919 (portr.).
Britton, N. L., J. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 221. 1918.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 83. 1969.
Fairchild, Phytopathology 9(1): 1-6. 1919 (portr.).
Hesler, Biogr. Sketches North Amer. mycol. 1975, mss.
Murrill, W. A., Mycologia 10(6): 293-294. 1918; Historic found. bot. Florida 35. 1945.
Philips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 132, 450, 1963.
Rickett, H. W., Index Bull. Torrey bot. Club 42-43. 1955.
Rodgers, A. D., Liberty Hyde Bailey 495 [index]. 1949.
Stevens et al., Amer. J. Bot. 7: 305-317. 1920.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 179. 1903, 3(3): 196. 1905.
Wood, R. D., Monogr. Charac. 1: 813. 1965.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>American agriculturist</em>, managing editor 1879-1885.
(2) <em>Bulletin Torrey bot. Club</em>, Associate editor (1890-1893).
(3) Associate editor to <em>Systematic flora of North America</em> (later North American Flora) 1890-
1893.

<sm>THESIS</sm>: Classification and description of the American species of Characeae, Proc. Boston
Soc. nat. Hist. 20: 169-190. 5 Mar 1879.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Halstedia</em> F. L. Stevens (1920).

Hamberg, Knut Herman Rudolf (1873-1920), Swedish insurance inspector and botanist

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; some Scandinavian cryptogams at C. Exsiccatae: <em>Kryp-

alger, 25 arter lavar och 30 arter svampar. Stockholm (Gullberg &amp; Hallbergs boktr.) 1895,
sets at LD, H, O, S, S-PA, and UPS.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 27-28. 1969.

Hamel, Gontran Georges Henri (1883-1944), French algologist; studied at Lille (lic.sc.
1912); connected with the oceanographic stations of the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle from
1918, from 1927 at its Laboratoire de Cryptogamie, Paris; died while trying to reach Paris by
bicycle just before its liberation in August 1944. (<em>Hamel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC. <em>Exsiccatae</em>:
(1) <em>Algues de France</em>, fasc. 1-3, nos. 1-50; fasc. 4, nos. 151-200 issued by Mme. A. Hamel-
	Joukov. Fasc. 1: Dec 1929, 2: Feb 1930, 3: Jun 1931, 4: Oct 1959. Sets at B, C, DW, FH,
	MICH, PC, WPS. (100 sets published of fasc. 1).
(2) <em>Algues des Antilles françaises</em>, collected by G. Hamel and A. Hamel-Joukov, 20 sets issued,
	fasc. 1-3, nos. 1-150, Paris 1931 (publ. late 1932). Sets at B, BM, C, FH, L, MICH, NY,
	PC.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 76-77. 1969.
	Koster, J. T., Taxon 18: 553. 1969.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 117; IH 2: 251; Kew 2: 565.
Feldmann, J., Rev. algol. ser. 2. 1(1): 3-10. 1954 (portr., bibl.).

Hamilton, Francis (né Buchanan) (1762-1829), Scottish physician and botanist in the
Bengal medical service 1795-1815; superintendent Botanic Garden Calcutta 1814-1815. (<em>F.
Ham.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main collections at BM, E, and K; further material at AWH, CAL,

2340. <em>Prodromus plantarum Indiae occidentalis</em> hucusque cognitarum, tam in oris Americae

Hammer, Christopher (1720-1804), Norwegian botanist and administrator; studied

Hampe, Georg Ernst Ludwig (1795-1880), German botanist; pupil of K. P. J. Sprengel;
apothecary at Blankenburg (Harz) 1825-1876; Dr. phil. h.c. Goettingen 1875. (<em>Hampe</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The original bryophyte herbarium of about 25.000 specimens is at
BM. Hampe issued series of exsiccatae (<em>Florae herciniae; Vegetabilia cellularia in Germa-
nia septentrionale praesertim in Hercynia lecta</em>) which are in many herbaria. The British Museum
(Natural History) also possesses copies of Hampe's published works with manuscript notes by
the author. Lichens at BREM and WRSL (fide GR); fungi also at G (fide Hawksworth);
bryophytes also at FH, G, GOET, H, L, PC.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 64: 240, 272, 288. 1881 (sale herb.); J. Bot. 19: 192. 1881 (herb. bought by
	BM).
	Murray, G. R. M., Hist. Coll. BMNH 153. 1904.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 56; Barnhart 2: 119; BM 2: 779-780; Bossert p.
161; CSP 3: 154-155, 7: 896, 10: 125-126, 12: 308; DTS 1: 371; Frank 3(Anh.); 40; GR p.
17, cat. p. 64 ("Hampe"); Hawksworth p. 183; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hampe"); IH 2: 252; Kew
2: 568; Jackson p. 153, 305, 373, 375; KR p. 263; Lenley p. 210; LS 11066-11078; NAF ser.
2. 9: 122-123; NI 780; PR 3752-3754 (ed. 1: 4106-4108); Rehder 5: 362; SBC p. 121
("Hampe"); TL-2/451, see index; Tucker 1: 314; Urban-Berl. p. 287, 301; Zander ed. 10, p.
667.
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 7: 52. 1882; Bot. Not. 1881: 39; Bot. Zeit. 39: 21, 359, 360 (sic). 1881, 45:
	112. 1887 (sale of Hampe material from Wigand herb.); Flora 63: 546. 1880; J. Bot. 19:
	223-224. 1881.
Bescherelle, É., Rev. bryol. 8: 55-56. 1881.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Edited eds. 8-11 of the <em>London catalogue of British plants</em>, 1886-1925 (see under H. C.
Watson). Hanbury bought the copyright of the <em>Catalogue</em> from Boswell-Syme in 1888. After
the latter's death Hanbury purchased his herbarium, which was later presented to BM.

(published by the author) 1889-1898, 8 parts. Qu. (<em>Ill. monogr. Brit. Hieracia</em>).

Issued with coloured plates (6/-per part), and uncoloured plates (4/-); (hand-coloured) liths.
by Miss G. Lister and Mrs F.J. Hanbury. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY. –Even though parts 9-12 were
announced by Nat. Nov. Jun(1) 1899 and Bot. Zeit. (1 Aug 1899), these were never
published; see note by Britten (J. Bot. 42: 54. 1904) "so far as we can ascertain, there is no
prospect of the continuance of the work".

<em>Co-author</em>: Edward Shearburn Marshall (1858-1919), vicar of Milford, Surrey.
<em>Publ</em>.: early Jun 1899 (p. vi: Mai 1899; Nat. Nov.Jun(2) 1899; J. Bot. Jun 1899; Bot. Zeit. 1
	Jul 1899), 2 maps, p. [i]-lxxxiv, [1]-444 (introduction and historical summary, p. lvi-
	lxxvi, by Benjamin Daydon Jackson). <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten J., J. Bot. 37: 275-279. 1899.

Hanbury, Sir Thomas (1832-1907), British horticulturist and botanist; from 1852-1867/71
merchant at Shanghai; settled in Italy at La Mortola, Ventimiglia (1867/71-1907); founder
of the Hanbury Botanical Institute at Genoa; brother of Daniel Hanbury. (<em>T. Hanb.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some herbarium material and letters at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 120; BB p. 137; BM 2: 781, 6: 431; Bossert p.
161; Desmond p. 283; IH 2: 252; Kew 2: 569; MW p. 151; Plesch p. 249; Rehder 5: 363;
Saccardo 1: 88; Tucker 1: 315, 361, 436.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1907: 167; Gard. Chron. 1054: 172. 1907 (portr.); Florida mortolensis.
	Ventimiglia 1905, 91 p.; Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1907: 132-136; Bot. Zeit. 65(2): 160. 1907;
	Proposed congratulatory address to Sir Thomas Hanbury, April 1907, s.l., 8 p. (prepared
	for H's 75th birthday on 21 Jun 1907; H. died 9 Mar 1907).

HEADING: HANBURY, T.

Hance, Henry Fletcher (1827-1886), British botanist; vice-consul at Whampoa, Canton
and Amoy (1844-1886). (<em>Hance</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (ca. 23.000). Other Chinese material in B, BR, CGE, CN, FI,
GRA, K, LE, MO, P, S, U, W, YU.-Letters at K.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten, J. Bot. 22: 96. 1884 (rumored destr. herb.).

<em>Note</em>: Britten (1884) commenting on the rumored destruction of Hance's library and
herbarium "during the serious riot of the natives on the British concession at Canton last
year" reasssured the readers of the Journal of Botany that recent letters "make no mention of
such a calamity, although he must have passed a <em>mauvais quart d'heure</em> during the disturbance"
[question: who go out in the midday sun together with the mad dogs?]. Actually Hance had
indeed lost his books and herbarium during the burning of the foreign factories at Canton in
December 1884. During the Shameen riot at Canton in 1883 Hance wrote home: "Inter
arma silent Musae and I am afraid Britten will find my reed very voiceless this year."
Hance, J. Bot. 5: 136. 1867: "Mainly occupied with matters unconnected with Botany [he
was on his honeymoon] ... in the month of June, 1852, I gathered a heath ... an Erica
which I determined at that time ..."

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 253; Barnhart 2: 120; BB p. 137; BJI 1: 24; BM 2:
781; Bret. p. 365, 532, 632-652; CSP 3: 156, 7: 898-900, 10: 127-129, 15: 614; DTS 1: 102;
Desmond 283; DNB 24: 272-273; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hance"); IF p. 701; IH 2: 252; Kew 2:
569; Jackson p. 555; Langman p. 347; MW p. 151-156; Plesch p. 249; Rehder 5: 363; RS p.
86; SK 1: 214-215, 5: cclxxxiii; TL-2/427, 1814; Tucker 1: 315; Zander ed. 10, p. 667.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1887: 47; Bot. Jahrb. 8 (Beibl. 19). 1887; Bot. Gaz. 11: 251. 1886; J. Bot. 24:
	256. 1886; Nat. Nov. 1887: 176; Proc. Linn. Soc. London 1886/87: 40-41. 1887.
Bentham, G., Fl. Hongk. 9*-10*. 1861.
Cox, E. H. M., Plant-hunting in China 42. 1945.
Hadfield, M., Pioneers in gardening 184-185. 1951.
E.H.P., J. China Branch Roy. Asiat. Soc. ser. 2. 21: 309-313. 1886 (bibl.).
Kanitz, A., Magy. növ. Lap. 10: 136-144. 1886 (bibl.).
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg 3(3): 85, <em>pl. 146.</em> 1905 (portr.).

HEADING: HANDEL-MAZZETTI

Handel-Mazzetti, Heinrich, Freiherr von (1882-1940), Austrian botanist and ex-
plorer; Dr. phil. Wien 1907; in China 1914-1919; from 1903-1925 connected with the
University of Vienna, from 1925-1931 at the Natural History Museum; pupil of Richard
Wettstein; died in a car accident on 1 Feb 1940. (<em>Hand.-Mazz.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: at W and WU. The first set of the moss collections from Iraq and
China is at H. W has the main set of the Chinese and Iraq plants, WU of the Central
European collections. Further types at FI in the Giraldi and Silvestri collections. FI has also
many isotypes of other Handel-Mazzetti taxa.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 331. 1975; Bryologist 80: 509. 1978.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 27; Backer p. 652; Barnhart 2: 121; BFM 814,
1566; BJI 2: 67; BM 6: 431; BL 2: 405, 664; Bossert p. 162; DTS 6(4): 76, 77, 80, 146-147;
Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hand.-Mazz."); IF suppl. 3: 210; IH2: 253; Kew 2: 570-572; Langman p.
347; Lenley p.210; LS 11087; MW p. 156-157, suppl. p. 83-84; SBC p. 121 ("Hand.-
Mazz."); Tucker 1: 316.
Anon., Rev. bryol. lichén. 16: 131. 1947.
Collander, R., Hist. bot. Finland 40. 1965.
Handel- Mazzetti, H. von, <em>in</em> Fedde, Rep. Spec. nov. 46: 82-94. 1939 (ideas on botanical
	nomenclature).
Janchen, E., Richard Wettstein 180. 1933; Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 57: (179)-(201). 1939 (1940)
	(portr., extensive bibl.).
Janchen, E., Catal. fl. austr. 1: 43, 47. 1956, 890, 968. 1960.
Stapf, O., Nature 115: 996. 1925.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Asclepiadaceae und Apocynaceae</em>, in R. v. Wettstein, <em>Ergebnisse der
botanischen Expedition ... nach Südbrasilien</em> vol. 1, Denkschr. Akad. Wiss. Wien 79(2): 377-388,
preprints distributed 1910; vol. 79(2) was completed only in 1931.
(2) Part 10, cent. 37-40, of R. v. Wettstein et al. <em>Schedae ad floram exsiccatam Austro-Hungaricum</em>,
Wien, 1913, 132 p.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Handelia</em> Heimerl (1922); <em>Handeliella</em> Skuja (1937); <em>Handeliobryum</em> V. F. Brotherus
(1925); <em>Handeliodendron</em> Rehder (1935); <em>Mazzettia</em> Iljin (1955); <em>Pseudohandelia</em> Tzvelev
(1961).

Hanstein, Johannes Ludwig Emil Robertvon (1822-1880), German botanist, at first in
Berlin; studied in Berlin with Link and Klotzsch; Dr. phil. Berlin 1848; high school teacher
at Berlin 1849-1859; curator at the Berlin herbarium 1860-1865; from 1865, professor of
botany in Bonn; creator of the Bonn Botanical Institute; outstanding plant anatomist and
developmental morphologist. (<em>J. Hanst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 49: 768-770; Backer p. 652; Barnhart 2: 124; BM 2:
784; CSP 3: 172, 6: 681, 7: 905-906, 10: 138, 12: 310; De Toni 1: lx; Frank 3(Anh.): 40-41.
1886; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hanst."); IF p. 701 ; IH 2: 254; Kew 2: 576-577; Jackson p. 18, 71,
73, 75, 80, 83, 87, 94, 100, 487; KR p. 265; Langman p. 347-348; Moebius p. 179, 451; PR
3768-3775, 10571; Ratzeburgp. 222-224; Rehder 5: 365; Urban-Berl. p. 353; Zander ed. 10,
p. 667.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1881: 39; Flora 63: 418. 1880.
Dechen, Verh. naturh. Ver. preuss. Rheinl. Westf. 37: 118-127. 1880.
Fitting, H., Decheniana 105/106: 5. 1952 (portr.).

Urban, I., Jahrb. kön. bot. Garten Berlin 1: 111-114. 1881; Fl. bras. 1(1): 176-177. 1906.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 128. (<em>pl. 28</em>). 1903 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Martius, <em>Fl. bras., Gesneriaceae</em>, 8(1): 341-424, <em>pl. 58-68.</em> 1 Dec 1864.

HEADING: HARDWICKE

Hardwicke, Thomas (1757-1833), British zoologist and botanist; soldier in the Bengal
Artillery (1778); major-general in the Indian army (retired 1823); collected in India,
Mauritius, South Africa and St. Helena. (<em>Hardw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM and K; other material at G. – BM also has 22 water-colour
drawings of Indian plants and a volume of <em>Sketches of plants growing about Pletterburg Bay on the
coast of Africa</em>, Cape Town 1812 (see BM 2: 786; NI 790).– Hardwicke employed British and
Indian artists to make drawings of natural history items. – Letters at K, LINN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 254; Barnhart 2: 126; BB p. 138-139; BM 2: 785-
786; CSP 3: 175-176; Dawson p. 140, 395, 851; Desmond p. 286; Hortus 3: 1194
("Hardw."); IH 2: 255; Lasègue p. 128, 138, 191, 302, 504; NI 798; Rehder 5: 365; Tucker
1: 317; Zander ed. 10, p. 667.
Britten, J., J. Bot. 44: 235-241. 1906 (H's botanical drawings).
Burkill, I. H., Chapt. hist. bot. India 27, 29, 77, 232. 1965.
Dawson, W. R., Smith papers 51-52. 1934 (calendar of letters to J. E. Smith); J. Soc. Bibl.
	Nat. Hist. 2: 55-69. 1946.
Hardwicke, Th., Asiat. Res. 6: 309-381. 1799 (narrative of a journey to Srinagar, plants on p.
	348-381).
Hooker, W. J., Bot. Misc. 1: 89-91. 1830.
Miller, H. S., Taxon 19: 525. 1970 (material in Lambert herb.).
Smith, Lady P., Memoir corr. J. E. Smith 2: 118-121. 1832.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hardwickia</em> Roxburgh (1811).

Hardy, Apollon Joseph (1846-1929), Belgian botanist and high school teacher at Gilly,
Tournai and, from 1884, at the middle school of Visé (<em>Hardy</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR and LG; parts of the original herbarium were destroyed in 1914.

the cryptogamic department of the Muséum d'histoire naturelle, Paris; botanist on the

2400. <em>Vorschlag zur Ergänzung der "Lois de la nomenclature botanique de 1867"</em> dem in Wien 1905
tagenden Nomenclatur-Kongress zur Annahme empfohlen. Leipzig (In Commission bei
Wilhelm Engelmann) 1904. Oct. (<em>Vorschlag</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Jun 1904, p. [1]-37. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Appendix 13, Notizblatt des Königl. botanischen
	Gartens und Museums zu Berlin, 1904. – Main proposal to accept Linnaeus, Species
	plantarum, ed. 1, 1753 as the starting point of botanical nomenclature and to set up a list of
	<em>nomina generica conservanda et rejicienda</em>. The list contained in this proposal formed the basis of
	the present list of conserved generic names of Spermatophyta.

Harper, Robert Aimer (1862-1946), American botanist; pupil of Brefeld and Strasbur-
ger; professor of botany at Madison (Wisc.) (1898-1911); Torrey professor at Columbia
University (1911-1930); specialist on the cytology of fungi and on phytopathology. (<em>R. A.
Harper</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY and WIS. – Reprint collection (15.000) donated to NY (1945).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 123, 283, 301, 322-323; Barnhart 2: 128; BJI 2:
69; Bossert p. 164; CSP 15: 649; DSB 6: 121-122; Hirsch p. 113; IH 2: 256; Kew 2: 585;
Lenley p. 212-213; LS 11286-11296, suppl. 10740-10744; Moebius p. 102, 104; NW p. 47;
SO 907c.
Anon., Phytopathology 38(4): 328. 1948.
Bessey, Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a: 17-19. 1955.
Dodge, B. O., Amer. philos. Soc. Year Book 1946: 304-313. 1947; Proc. Linn. Soc. London
	158(2): 134-136. 1947.

practicing physician at Oudewater 1835-1841, from 1841-1843 at Franeker; from 1843
professor of natural philosophy, later of zoology at Utrecht University. (<em>Harting</em>).

Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hartinger"); Jackson p. 417, 488; Kew 2: 594; LS 11439; NI 799-802;
Plesch p. 250-251; PR 3799-3801 (ed. 1: 4176); Rehder 5: 371; Sotheby 323; Tucker 1: 323.
Nissen, C., Philobiblon 6(8): 302. 1933.

2417. Endlicher's <em>Paradisus vindobonensis</em>, Abbildungen seltener und schönblühender Pflan-
zen der Wiener und anderer Gärten und Museen von Anton Hartinger ... erläutert von Dr.
Berthold Seemann ... Illustrations of rare and ornamental plants of the Viennese and other
gardens and museums by Anton Hartinger described by Berthold Seemann... Band I,
Volume I. 1844-1860. Wien (Wallishauser Buchhandlung [Joseph Klemm]), Leipzig
(J. G. Schrag's Verlag [A. G. Hoffmann]), London (Trübner &amp; Comp.), Paris (Fr.
Klincksieck), New York (Westermann &amp; Comp.) 1844-1860. Fol. (<em>Parad. vindob.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In 20 parts (a 21 ste part was published separately) 1844-1860 (preface 1 Jan 1860) p.
	[i], [iii-v], [1]-48, [I, dedic. lith.], <em>pl. 1-80</em>, partly coloured liths. <em>Copy</em>: MO.

HEADING: HARTINGER

Lief.	plates	dates	Lief.	plates	dates
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1	1, 2, 3, 4	Aug 1844	12	45, 46, 47, 48	Jun 1846
2	5, 6, 7, 8	Oct 1844	13	49, 50, 51, 52	Aug 1846
3	9, 10, 11, 12	Dec 1844	14	53, 54, 55, 56	Oct 1846
4	13/14, 15, 16	Feb 1845	15	57, 58, 59, 60	Dec 1846
5	17, 18, 19, 20	Apr 1845	16	61, 62, 63, 64	Jan 1847
6	21, 22, 23, 24	Jun 1845	17	65, 66, 67, 68
7	25, 26, 27, 28	Aug 1845	18	69, 70, 71, 72	Sep 1848
8	29, 30, 31, 32	Oct 1845	19	73, 74, 75, 76	Sep 1848
9	33, 34, 35, 36	Dec 1845	20	77, 78, 79, 80	1858
10	37, 38, 39, 40	Feb 1846	21	81/82, 83, 84	1860
11	41, 42, 43, 44	Apr 1846

Volume 1 contained originally fasc. 1-15 (<em>pl. 1-60</em>; 4 folio text sheets per Lieferung),
	volume 2 then started with fasc. 16. The title of the first Lieferung reads: <em>Auswahl der
	seltesten und ausgezeignetsten Blumen in naturgetreuen Abbildungen</em>. This was later changed to the
	title as cited above. Endlicher prepared manuscript for six of the plates. Fenzl, although
	cited in the title of the Lieferungen, contributed nothing. In 1858 B. Seemann continued
	the publication with the 20th Heft as the final Lieferung of Band I (originally scheduled to
	contain 15 Lieferungen) and changed the title to that given above. Seemann published
	another fascicle (21) in 1860, with three plates (81/82, 83 and 84) but publication then
	ceased. In the "new" make-up the collation is Band 1, pp. [ii], 48, [1] with 78 coloured
	plates, numbered <em>1-80</em> and Band 2 part 1, pp. 4 with 3 coloured plates, numbered <em>81-84</em>.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 30: 511. 1846, 31: 179. 1847, 35: 552. 1850.
	Haidinger, Ber. Mitt. Freund. Naturw. Wien 1: 78. 1846, 2: 21, 190, 403. 1847, 5: 16.

2418. <em>Die essbaren und giftigen Schwämme</em> in ihren wichtigsten Formen. Als Erläuterung der
von Anton Hartinger nach der Natur gezeichneten und in Farbendruck ausgeführten, von
M. A. Becker, k.k. Schulrath, unter obigem Titel herausgegebenen Schulwandtafeln. Im
Auftrage des k.k. Ministeriums für Kultur und Unterricht beschrieben von Johann Georg
Bill, ... Wien (Im k.k. Schulbücher-Verlage) 1858. Oct. (<em>Essb. gift. Schwämme</em>).

<em>Author of text</em>: Johann Georg Bill (1813-1870); publisher of the <em>Wandtafeln</em>: Moritz Alois
	Baron von Becker (1808?-1887).
<em>Publ</em>. (text only): 1858, p. [i]-vi, [1]-150, [1-4, table]. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – For Becker's plates see his
	<em>Die essbaren und giftigen Pilze in ihren wichtigsten Formen</em>... Olmütz 1855, fol. (n.v.) and his
	<em>Die Schwämme in ihren wichtigsten Formen</em>... Wien 1858. fol. (n.v.), <em>6 pl</em>. without text (cf. BM
	2: 791; NI 802). Hartinger is the artist who painted for Becker. Bill published the above
	text. For ed. 2 of this text and later editions of the plates see 2419 and 2420.

2419. <em>Die essbaren und giftigen Schwämme</em> in ihren wichtigsten Formen. Als Erläuterung der von
Anton Hartinger, k.k. Hofchromolithographen, nach der Natur gezeichneten und in
Farbendruck ausgeführten, von M. A. Becker, k.k. Landesschulinspector, zur Förderung des
Schulunterrichtes angeordneten Wandtafeln. Im Auftrage des k.k. Ministeriums für Cultus
und Unterricht beschrieben von Johann Georg Bill, Doctor der Medecin, ö. o. Professor der
Botanik und Zoologie am st.st. Joanneozu Graz. Wien (Verlag der k.k. Hofchromolithogr. und
artist. Verlagsinstitute von Ant. Hartinger &amp; Sohn) 1875. Oct. (<em>Essb. gift. Schwämme</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1858 see no. 2418.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1875, p. [i-iv], [1]-59. <em>Copies</em>: USDA, WU.

2420. <em>Die essbaren und giftigen Schwämme</em> in ihren wichtigsten Formen. Nach der Natur

verbesserte und vermehrte Ausgabe. Wien (Druck und Verlag des artistisch-lithografischen

Hartman, Carl (1824-1884), Swedish botanist; high school teacher at Gävle (1852-1859);
lecturer at the teacher's college of Örebro; son of C. J. Hartman. (<em>C. Hartm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS; other material at B, C and H.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 132; BL 2: 475, 520, 534, 665; BM 2: 792-793;

Rehder 5: 371; SO 184, 185, 186, 3457, 3462; Tucker 1: 323.

Hartman, Carl Johan (1790-1849), Swedish physician and botanist, pupil of Thunberg at
Uppsala, ultimately government physician in Gästrikland. (<em>Hartm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS. – Hartman's considerable private herbarium went first to his
son Carl (1824-1884) and is now incorporated in the general herbarium of UPS. Other
material in C, H and in the Thunberg herbarium (UPS).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 212-213; Barnhart 2: 133; BL 2: 475, 665; BM 2:
793; Bossert p. 165; CSP 3: 200, 7: 915, 10: 151, 15: 666; Hortus 1194 ("Hartm."); IF p. 701;
IH 2: 258; Kew 2: 594-595; Jackson p. 331; KR p. 268-270; NAF ser. 2. 3: 36; PR 3802-3804
(ed. 1: 4168-4171); Rehder 5: 371; SBC p. 121 ("Hartm."); SO 848, 850a; Tucker 1: 323-
324; Zander ed. 10, p. 669.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1843: 31, 32, 1849: 148, 1882: 164; Bot. Zeit. 7: 808; Generalreg. Bot. Not.
	29-30. 1939; J. Bot. 21: 64. 1883.
Collander, R., Hist. bot. Finland 96. 1965.
Hartman, C., <em>in</em> C. J. Hartman, Handb. skand. Fl. ed. 5, p. xii-xxii. 1849 (portr.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 27 Nov. 1819, p. [i], [1]-10. <em>Copies</em>: G, USDA. – Even though in many cases the

PAGE: 66
HEADING: HARTMANN, C. J.

	promotor (C. P. Thunberg) was responsible for the text of academic dissertations defended
	at Uppsala, this dissertation should be attributed to the defendant, C. J. Hartman,
	who is identified as "auctor" on the title page.

Hartman, Carl Vilhelm (1862-1941), Swedish botanist, ethnographer and archeologist,
son of Carl Hartman; curator at the Carnegie Museum at Pittsburgh 1903-1908, later at the
Stockholm Riksmuseum. (<em>C. V. Hartm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; possibly Costa Rican coll. at CM.

... Stockholm (Sigfrid Flodins Förlag) [1884]. Oct. (<em>Växtnomenclatur</em>).

Hartman, Robert Wilhelm (1827-1801), Swedish botanist, son of C.J. Hartman; teacher
at Gävle; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1854. (<em>R. Hartm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS. – Exsiccatae: <em>Bryaceae Scandinaviae exsiccatae</em> (fasc. 1-15, nos. 1-

Lindholm), complete sets at BM, LD, S, UPS and W, other sets at B, BM, BR, C, CU, FH,
FJ, GB, H, K, L, MANCH, PC. – Most sets were noticed by Bot. Not.

is dedicated to Jos. Adolph Hartmann (<em>fl</em>. 1739), ... traveller in California.

2435. <em>Hortus carlsruhanus</em> oder: Verzeichnis sämmtlicher Gewächse welche in dem grossher-

HEADING: HARTWEG

Hartweg, Carl Theodor (1812-1871), German botanist; son of Andreas Hartweg; botani-
cal collector for the Horticultural Society of London in North, Central and South America
1836-1843 and 1845-1847; afterwards inspector of the ducal gardens at Schwetzingen
(Baden). (<em>Hartw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (first set of Hartweg's own collections), LD (orig. herb.). Sets of
plants collected by Hartweg are in many herbaria, see IH. Letters and reports in library,
Royal Horticultural Society, London. Hartweg's plants were described by Bentham (<em>Pl.
Hartw.</em>), see TL 2/424.
<em>Ref</em>.: McVaugh, R., <em>in</em> G. Bentham, Plantae hartwegianae, facsimile ed. (see e.g. for
	itinerary) (TL 2/424).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 49; Backer p. 255; Barnhart 2: 134; BB p. 141; Clokie
p. 179; CSP 3: 203; Desmond p. 291-292; Hemsley 4: 126-127; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hart-
weg"); IH 2: 259; Jackson p. 556; Kew 2: 596; Langman p. 351, 927-928; Lasègue p.
207-209; ME 1: 192, 3: 592; PR (s.n.); Rehder 5: 371; TL-2/424.
Alden and Ifft, Occ. Papers Calif. Acad. Sci. 20: 47-48. 1943.
Anon., J. Hort. Soc. London 1: 169-170. 1846 (prel. report on 1845-1846 trip to Mexico and
	California); Bull. Soc. bot. France 18: 189. 1871; J. Bot. 9: 224. 1871; Gard. Chron. 1871:
	313, 904.
Brewer, W. H., <em>in</em> S. Watson, Bot. Calif. 2: 556. 1880.
Coats, A. M., Quest for plants 317-319, 344-346. 1969.
Cox, J. Roy. Hort. Soc. 80: 275-276. 1955.
C.S., Gartenflora 7: 360. 1858.
Eastwood, A., California hist. Soc. Quart. 18: 342-343. 1939.
Ewan, J., <em>in</em>: Cent. Progress nat. Sci. 51. 1955.
Gray, J. L., Letters A. Gray 150. 1893.
Hartweg, J. Hort. Soc. London 1: 180-185. 1846, 2: 121-125, 187-191. 1847, 3: 217-228.
	1848 ("journal of a mission to California in search of plants"); Trans. Hort. Soc. London
	ser. 2. 3: [115]-162, pl. 3. 1848 (Notes of a visit to Mexico, Guatemala, and Equatorial

Howell, J. T., Marin flora 29. 1949; see also Leafl. West. Bot. 1(15): 180-181. 1935(note on

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hartwegia</em> J. Lindley (1837); <em>Hartwegiella</em> O. E. Schulz (1933).

Harvey, William Henry (1811-1866), Irish botanist; colonial treasurer at the Cape 1836-
1841; curator of TCD 1843; professor of botany Dublin 1856; traveller in the United States
(1849-1850), South Africa (1835-1841), and Australia, New Zealand and Fiji (1853-1856).
(<em>Harv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TCD. – Duplicates in many herbaria. <em>Exsiccatae</em>:
<em>(1) Australian algae</em>, nos. 1-601. Sets at BM, DWC, FH, FMC, L, MEL, NY.
(2) <em>Ceylon algae</em>, nos. 1-106. Sets at FH, FMC, L, NY.
(3) <em>Friendly Island Algae</em>, nos. 1-124. Sets at FH, G, L, NY (collected at Tongatabu, Lifuka or
	Hapai, and Vavan). Important sets of Harvey's Australian algae are also e.g. at BM,
	DWC, MEL, NSW and STA; for further details see Ducker (1977), Blackler (1977) and

PAGE: 71
HEADING: HARVEY

	May (1977). The main part of the Sonder herbarium used for the <em>Flora Capensis</em> is at S (at
	least 60.000 specimens, fide B. Nordenstam in litt.); Gandoger (1913) claimed to have a
	large share of the Sonder/Fl. cap. originals (now at LY). See also under Sonder. A
	Harvey manuscript and 10 original plates is at FH. Letters at BM.
<em>Ref</em>.: Gandoger, M., Bull. Soc. bot. France 60: 415. 1913.
	Lindman, C. A. M., Riksmuseets uppkomst och utveckling 103. 1916.
	Womersley, H. B. S., Austral. J. mar. freshw. Research 7(3): 346. 1956.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 77. 1969; Bryologist 80: 509. 1978.
	Gordon, R. B., Taxon 24: 628. 1975.
	Ross, R. R., Taxon 25: 525-526. 1976.
	Ducker, Sc. C., Taxon 26: 166-168. 1977 (extensive details on Austral. alg.).
	Blackler, H., Taxon 26: 495-496. 1977.
	May, V., Taxon 26: 496. 1977.

2436a. <em>A manual of the British algae</em>: containing generic and specific descriptions of all the
known British species of sea-weeds, and of Confervae, both marine and fresh-water ...
London (John van Voorst, ...) 1841. Oct. (<em>Man. Brit. alg.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jul-Oct 1841 (p. lvii: 5 Oct 1840; Hooker, J. Bot. Jul 1841 "advancing"; 3 Nov 1841
	rd. by Boston Nat. Hist. Soc.), p. [i]-lvii, [1]-229. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY, USDA; IDC 6371.
[<em>Ed. 2</em>]: Jul-Dec 1849 (p. v: 30 Jun 1849; Torrey received his copy, at NY, Apr 1850), portr.
	author, p. [i]-lii, [1]-252, <em>pl. 1-27</em>, with [54 p.] text, handcol. liths. by author. <em>Copies</em>: G,
	NY, US. – "A manual ... sea-weeds. With plates to illustrate all the genera ..." London
	(John van Voorst, ...) 1849. Oct.

2437. <em>Algae antarcticae</em>, being characters and descriptions of the hitherto unpublished species
of algae, discovered in Lord Auckland's Group, Campbell's Island, Kerguelen's Land,
Falkland Islands, Cape Horn and other southern circumpolar regions, during the voyage of
H.M. discovery ships "Erebus" and "Terror"; by Dr. J. D. Hooker and W. H. Harvey, Esq.
M.D. [London 1845]. Oct. (<em>Alg. antarct.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Joseph Dalton Hooker (1817-1911).
<em>Publ</em>.: Mai-Jun 1845, p. 1-32. <em>Copies</em>: FH, MO. – Reprinted with independent pagination
	from London J. Bot. 4: 249-276. Mai 1845, 293-298. Jun 1845.

2438. <em>Algae Novae Zelandiae</em>; being a catalogue of all the species of Algae yet recorded as
inhabiting the shores of New Zealand, with characters and brief descriptions of the new
species discovered during the Voyage of H.M. discovery ships "Erebus" and "Terror", and
of others communicated to Sir W. Hooker by Dr. Sinclair, the Rev. W. Colenso, and M.
Raoul. By Dr. Hooker, and W. H. Harvey, Esq. [London 1845-1848]. Oct. (<em>Alg. Nov. Zel.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Oct 1845-Aug 1848, (in journal), p. [1]-31. <em>Copy</em>: FH.- Reprinted from London J. Bot.
	4: 521-551. Oct 1845 and 7: 443-445. Aug 1848.

2439. <em>Phycologia britannica</em>: or history of British sea-weeds, containing coloured figures,
generic and specific characters, synonymes, and descriptions of all the species of algae
inhabiting the shores of the British Islands. In three volumes. London (Reeve Brothers)
1846-1851, 3 vols. (<em>Phycol. brit.</em>).

PAGE: 73
HEADING: HARVEY

<em>Publ</em>.: Published in 60 parts or 6 plates at monthly intervals from Jan 1846 until June 1849
	with some irregularity after this (Dixon). Originally the work was delivered in three
	volumes with their own title pages and the plates in numerical order. <em>Copies</em>: Teyler, US
	(signatures of 8 p. accompanied by 4 pl.).

<em>1</em>: 1846 (t.p.), p. [i]-xv, [i]-viii, plates with text <em>1-120</em>. 1846 (preface 3 Dec 1845);
<em>2</em>: 1849 (t.p.), p. [i*] [i]-vi, plates with text <em>121-240</em>. 1849;
<em>3</em>: 1851 (t.p.), p. [i]-xxxix [or-xlv], [i-xiv] or [i-x], plates with text <em>241-360</em>. 1851 (pref. 30 Jul
	1851).
Barnhart, in an unpublished memoir at NY provided the following tentative data on
publication (compiled 4 Aug 1932).

Subsequently the plates were issued in four volumes with new title-pages (all four "1846-51",
see below). The later issues appear to have contained the plates in systematic order, they
came out on two paper formats.
	The Teyler and US copies have the plates numbered <em>1-360</em> with no numbers missing or
double. Nissen (no. 806) reports, that the four volume issue has 382 plates of which <em>148, 264,
328, 348, 352, 357</em> and <em>385</em> are missing and <em>24, 114, 141, 169</em> and <em>207</em> double.
<em>Ed. 1846-1851</em>: reissue in four volumes, published by 1863: "In four volumes ... " London
	(Reeve and Benham) 1846-1851 (on each of the four title-pages). <em>Copies</em>: G, Dale E.
	Johnson, MO, NY, USDA.

	<em>Vol. 1</em>: p. [i]-xlv, [iii*, dedic.], [v*], vi*-viii*, [ix*], x*-xv*, index [i**], -viii* *, <em>pl. 1-40,
	42-97</em>, with text.
	<em>Vol. 2</em>: [i*-iii*], index [i]-vi, <em>pl. 98-189</em>, id.
	<em>Vol. 3</em>: [i-vii], <em>pl. 190-279</em> (<em>231, 241</em> double), (id.).
	<em>Vol. 4</em>: [i*], [i]-iv, <em>pl. 280-360</em> (<em>289, 338</em> double), (id.).

PAGE: 74
HEADING: HARVEY

	volumes dated 1871, plates in systematic order. <em>Copies</em>: BR, MICH.
	<em>Vol. 1</em>: [i*], [i]-xli, <em>97 pl</em>. with text. (numbers mixed).
	<em>Vol. 2</em>: [i], <em>92 pl</em>. id.
	<em>Vol. 3</em>: [i, iii], <em>90 pl</em>. id.
	<em>Vol. 4</em>: [i], <em>109 pl</em>. id.
	<em>Copies</em>: BR (<em>388 pl</em>. in all); MICH (<em>plates</em> see below); NY (<em>360 pl</em>.).

Two extracts of the <em>Phycologia</em> appeared (BM 2: 795):

(1) <em>Synopsis of British Seaweeds</em>, compiled from Prof. Harvey's Phycologica Britannica, see no.
	2445.
(2) Gatty, Mrs. Alfred, <em>British Sea-Weeds</em>. Drawn from Prof. Harvey's "Phycologia britan-
	nica," 2 vols. London (Bell and Daldy) 1872. Qu. (<em>vol. 1</em>: [i]-xlix, <em>pl. 1-37</em>, with text; <em>vol. 2</em>:
	[i], <em>pl. 38-80</em>, id., plates as in original. <em>Copy</em>: MICH).
<em>Ref</em>.: Dixon, P. S., Brit, phycol. Bull. 3(1): 115-116. 1966.

2440. <em>Algae tasmanicae</em>: being a catalogue of the species of algae collected on the shores of
Tasmania by Ronald Gunn, Esq. Dr. Jeanneret, Mrs Smith, Dr. Lyall, and Dr. J. D.
Hooker; with characters of the new species, by J. D. Hooker; M. D., and W. H. Harvey.
[London 1847]. Oct. (<em>Alg. Tasman.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1847, p. [i]-20. <em>Copy</em>: FH.- Reprinted from London J. Bot. 6: 397-417. Aug 1847.

2441. <em>Nereis australis</em>, or algae of the Southern Ocean: being figures and descriptions of
marine plants, collected on the shores of the Cape of Good Hope, the extra-tropical
Australian colonies, Tasmania, New Zealand, and the antarctic regions; deposited in the
herbarium of the Dublin University ... London (Reeve, Brothers, ...) 1847, 2 parts. Qu. † (<em>Nereis austral</em>.).

<em>1</em>: 1848 (t.p.: 1847; p. viii: 24 Mai 1847; orig. cover dated 1848), p. [i*-iii*], [i]-viii, [1]-64,
	<em>pl. 1-25.</em>
<em>2</em>: 1849, before Nov (date on cover; Am J. Sci. Nov. 1849), p. 65-124, <em>pl. 26-50, pl. 45</em> double.

<em>Copies</em>: G (has covers of parts), L, NY. – The book was never completed; the advertisement
on the back cover of the wrapper of part one announces four parts, each containing 25 plates.
The text ends abruptly on p. 124. Harvey continued the subject with his <em>Phycologia australica</em>
(no. 2446) (1858-1863). The plates are handcoloured liths., by the author.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Weinheim (J. Cramer) 1965, Hist. nat. class. 40, ISBN 3-7682-0261-5. <em>Copies</em>:
	FAS, MICH, J. Norris. – See also Taxon 17: 82.
<em>Ref</em>.: Pocock, M. A., Taxon 17: 725. 1968.

PAGE: 75
HEADING: HARVEY

2442. <em>The sea-side book</em>: being an introduction to the natural history of the British coasts ...
New edition. London (John van Voorst, ...) 1849. Oct. (<em>Sea-side book</em>).

2443. <em>Nereis boreali-americana</em>; or, contributions towards a history of the marine algae of the

	The plates in this and following issues are coloured liths. (some handcol. parts) of drawings
	by the author. – Part 3 with headline "Smithsonian contributions to knowledge".

	sonian Institution) New York (D. Appleton and Co.).

	"Smithsonian Contribution to knowledge" on t.p. Part 3 of second issue identical with
	part 3 of first issue.

	<em>Part 2</em>: in vol. 5, art. 5 (id.).

2446. <em>Phycologia australica</em>; or, a history of Australian seaweeds; comprising coloured figures
and descriptions of the more characteristic marine algae of New South Wales, Victoria,
Tasmania, South Australia, and Western Australia, and a synopsis of all known Australian
algae ... London (Lovell Reeve, ...) 1858-1863, 5 vols. Qu. (<em>Phycol. austral.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 300 plates with accompanying text, published in 50 parts of 6 coloured plates each.
	Each plate accompanied by 2 p. text. Full details still wanting. Plates not dated. – <em>Copies</em>:
	G, MO, NY, US,; IDC 451.

HEADING: HARVEY

<em>1</em>: [i]-xi, <em>pl. 1-60</em>, with text, index [v]-viii. 1858.

2447. <em>Thesaurus capensis</em>: or, illustrations of the South African flora, being figures and brief
descriptions of South African plants, selected from the Dublin University Herbarium.
Dublin (Hodges, Smith, and Co.), London (John van Voorst), Capetown (A. S. Robertson)
1859-1863, 2 vols. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Thes. cap.</em>).

<em>Vol. 1</em>: [1]-68, <em>pl. 1-100</em> (<em>61/62</em> comb.).
<em>Vol. 2</em>: [i-iii], [1]-68, <em>pl. 101-200</em> (<em>137/138</em> and <em>187/188</em> comb.).
<em>Plates</em>: lithographs by W. H. Harvey.

<em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY; IDC 5948. – According to the preface and the review of "Vol. 1,
no. 1" in Bonplandia 7: 201 (1 Aug 1859) this book was published in "quarterly" parts of 25
plates. Part 1 contained 16 pages and 25 plates. Volume 1 was finished in 1860 (fide
Schlechtendal, Bot. Zeit. 18: 356-357. 9 Nov 1860). It may be assumed that the contents of
the parts of vol. 1 were as follows: 1 (p. 1-16, <em>pl. 1-25</em>) publ. before 1 Aug 1859, 2 (p. 17-32, <em>pl.
26-50</em>), 3 (p. 33-48, <em>pl. 51-75</em>), 4 (p. 49-68, <em>pl. 76-100</em>); a similar division is possible for vol. 2.
Information on exact dates, however, is still lacking. "The impression is limited to 250 copies,
of which 150 are reserved for colonial sale." (Preface). The plates are uncol. liths. by the
author.

Caffraria and Port Natal ... Dublin, London, Capetown (imprints see below) 7 vols. 1860-
1933. (<em>Fl. cap.</em>).

	<em>Vol. 2</em>: <em>first issue</em>: 1894, Ashford, Kent (L. Reeve &amp; Co., Ltd.), p. [i]-ix, [1]-621. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
	<em>second issue</em>: [1894], London (L. Reeve and Co.), p. [i]-ix, [1]-621. <em>Copy</em>: US.
	<em>Vol. 3</em>: <em>first issue</em>: 1894, Ashford, Kent (L. Reeve &amp; Co., Ltd.), p. [i]-ix, [1]-633. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
	<em>second issue</em>: [1894], London (L. Reeve and Co.), p. [i]-ix, [1]-633. <em>Copy</em>: US.
	<em>Note</em>: the dated first issue of vols. 1-3 was probably later than the undated second issue.
	<em>Vol. 4(1), 4(2), 5(1), 5(2), 5(3)</em>: 1973, Codicote, Herts. (Wheldon &amp; Wesley Ltd.), Lehre
	(J. Cramer), facsimile reprint of original ed. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
	<em>Vol. 5, sect. 2, suppl.</em> and <em>6</em>: no reprint.
	<em>Vol. 7</em>: 1958, Ashford, Kent (L. Reeve &amp; Co., Ltd.), only difference with original:
	"Reprinted 1958" on p. [ii]. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
<em>Distribution</em>: from vol. 4 onward 50 copies were sent to the Government of Cape Colony; 20 to
	that of Natal "as long as it contributed its grant", on lapsing transferred to the Transvaal
	government; 30 copies were distributed from Kew. The remainder of the issue was for sale.
	(Thiselton-Dyer 1925).

<em>Ref</em>.: Fournier, Bull. Soc. bot. France 10: 619-621. Jun 1864 (vols. 1-2, rev.).
	Hiern, W. P., J. Bot. 18: 263-264. 1880.
	Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 18: 356-357. 1860 (extensive review).

Harzer, Carl August Friedrich (1784-1846), German naturalist and artist at Dresden;
initiator and co-founder of the Dresden society "Isis". (<em>Harzer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: All Harzer's collections and further possessions were destroyed by fire
in 1845. Seven autographs still at LZ (University Library).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 136; BM 2: 796; LS 11496-11498; NI 811; PR
