Hasse, Hermann Edward (1836-1915), German-born physician and botanist who stu-
died at St. Louis and settled again in the United States in 1861; Dr. med. Würzburg 1861;
serving as a surgeon during the Civil War; practicing medicine in Wisconsin, Arkansas and,
ultimately (from 1879) in California, surgeon to the Soldier's Home near Santa Monica
1889-1905. (<em>Hasse</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH; 4500 lichens at NY; duplicates in many herbaria, see IH. <em>Lichenes
exsiccati ex herb. Dr. H. E. Hasse relicti</em>, distributed for the Sullivant Moss Society by C. C. Plitt.
Fasc. 1-10, nos. 1-250, Baltimore, Md., 1916-1918 (Charles Christian Plitt, 1869-1933); sets
at BPI, CM, LIV, NY, O, OC, S, US, WELC. Hasse also collected flowering plants: a set of
his early collections (Arkansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Wisconsin) is at NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Plitt, Bryologist 19(3): 48-49. 1916, 19(6): 96. 1916.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 131. 1969.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 137; CSP 15: 679; GR p. 17-18, <em>pl</em>. [<em>14</em>], cat. p.
64 ("Hasse"); Hawksworth p. 183; IH 2: 260; Kew 2: 601; Lenley p. 216; LS 11506-11513,
34251-34254, suppl. 10903-10912; NW p. 48; Pennell p. 609; SBC p. 122 (Hasse");
Stevenson p. 1244 ("Hasse").
Collins, Bull. S. Calif. Acad. Sci. 15(1): 8-9. 1916.
Crum, H. A., The Bryologist, index to volumes 1-60, p. 93. 1959 (bibl.).
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 93, 95. 1969.
Fink, Mycologia 8(5): 243-248. 1916 (portr., bibl.).

Plitt, Bryologist 19(2): 30-33. 1916 (portr., bibl.).

HEADING: HASSELQUIST

Rickett, H. W., Index Bull. Torrey bot. Club 45. 1955.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hassea</em> A. Zahlbruckner (1902); <em>Hasseanthus</em> J. N. Rose (1903).

2456. <em>Lichens of Southern California</em> by H. E. Hasse. Second edition. Los Angeles (B.R.
Baumgardt &amp; Co.) 1898. (<em>Lich. S. Calif.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Dec 1898 (pref. Mai 1898; TBC 16 Jan 1899; Bot. Gaz. 18 Mar 1899; Nat. Nov.
	Apr(1) 1899), p. [1]-18, [1, err.]. <em>Copies</em> G, MICH, MO, NY(2), USDA. –The indication
	"second edition" might refer to the treatment of the lichens in McClatchie, <em>Seedless plants of
	California</em> (1897). A note by E. S. Steele in the USDA copy states that "Dr. Hasse" in a
	letter states that "second edition" in this work is a printers blunder, there was no "first
	edition." The list was preceded by a series of papers (<em>Lichens of the vicinity of Los Angeles</em>) in
	the journal <em>Erythea</em>:

	<em>1</em>: in Erythea 3: 41-44. 1895 (several named by Stizenberger).
	<em>2</em>: in 4: 96-98. 1896 (id.).
	<em>3</em>: in 4: 106-108. 1896 (id.).
	<em>4</em>: in 4: 150-151. 1896 (mostly named by W. G. Farlow).

	<em>See also</em> Hasse, Bull. Torrey bot. Club 24: 445-449. 1897, 25: 632-633. Dec 1898 (id.
	determined by Nylander) and Hasse, Bull. S. California Acad. Sci. 2: 23-26, 32-35, 54-55,
	58-60, 71-73. 1903 as well as 4: 123-125. 1906, 5: 38-45. 1906 for further additions.

2457. Smithsonian Institution, United States National Museum. Contributions from the
United States National Herbarium volume 17, part I. <em>The lichen flora of Southern California</em> ...
Washington (Government printing office). 1913. Oct. (<em>Lich. fl. S. Calif.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 9 Jun 1913 (p. ii), p. [1]-v, [1]-132, [vii]-xii. <em>Copies</em>: BR, MO, NY, Stevenson, US.
Precursor papers and additions: 11 papers in the Bryologist 11: 6-7, 55-57 1908; 12: 101-104.
	1909; 12: 60-62, 111-112. 1910; 14: 2-4, 100-102. 1911; 15: 45-48. 1912; 16: 1-2. 1913; 17:
	61-63, 92. 1914; 18: 22-23, 76-78, 92-94. 1915.

Hasselquist, Fredric (1722-1752), Swedish explorer of the Levant, pupil of Linnaeus at
Uppsala 1741-1749, travelled in the Orient 1749-1752, died at Smyrna. (<em>Hasselq</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS. – Dupl. LINN, S[?], SBT. – Hasselquist's collections were
confiscated at his death by his creditors but bought by Queen Louisa Ulrika, who kept them
at Drottningholm, but put deplicates at the disposal of Linnaeus. These duplicates (often
Linnaean types) are in the Linnaean herbarium (LINN), and the main collection is now at
UPS, given to the University in 1803. They form the basis of Thunberg's <em>Museum naturalium
Academiae Upsaliensis</em> part 25, Uppsala 1804. Thunberg supplied the annotations on the
herbarium sheets: originally there were none. Juel gives a summary of Linnaean species
based on Hasselquist specimens. A few Hasselquist specimens are also in Bergius herbarium
(SBT) but certainly not the original collection as erroneously stated in IH.
<em>Ref</em>.: Juel, H. O., Sv. Linné-Sällsk. Årsskr. 1: 95-125. 1918, see also J. Bot. 56: 357. 1918.

<em>BIBLIOGRAPHY</em> and <em>BIOGRAPHY</em>: Barnhart 2: 137; BM 2: 797-798, 6: 440; Dryander 1: 124, 2:
30, 90, 123, 539, 3: 336, 447; IH 2: 260; Kew 2: 601; Jackson p. 394; KR p. 272-273; Lasègue
p. 344, 570; PR 3841 (ed. 1: 4207); Rehder 5: 372; SO 302, 1279, 1461-1468, 3577-3586;
TL-2/see Bergius; Tucker 1: 325; Zander ed. 10, p. 667.
Baeck, A., Aminnelsetal öfver Fredric Hasselquist. Stockholm 1758 (<em>n.v</em>.).
Bodenheimer and Uggla, Sv. Linné-Sällsk. Arsskr. 35: 18-30. 1952 (on H's "Album itineris"
	with autographs of well-wishers).
Eriksson, G., Bot. hist. Sverige 247, 262, 288. 1969.
Fries, Th. M., Bref och Skrifv. Linné 1(1): 58, 141. 1907; 1(2): 370 [index]. 1908; 1(3): 25,
	234. 1909; 1(4): 361 [index]. 1910; 1 (5): 6, 18, 20, 40, 165. 1911; 1(6): 206, 215. 1912;
	1(7): 1-68. 1917 (corr. Linnaeus).
Hasselquist, Hamburg. Magaz. 7(2): 160-208. 1751 (letters H. to Linnaeus; see also Iter
	palaest. p. 569-593).
Hulth, J. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(8): 84, 86, 1922; 2(1): 2, 3, 6, 277, 288. 1916; 2(2): 92.
	1943.

HEADING: HASSELQUIST

Jourdan [A.L.-J.J.], Dict. Sci. méd. 5: 98-100. 1822.
Scheutz, N. J. W., Bot. Not. 1863: 69.
Schildt, Resenärer i Floras rike. Reseber. Linnés lärjungar. Stockholm p. 73-98. 1960.
Schildt, Pehr Kalm, Fredrich Hasselquist ... Stockholm 1960.
Stafleu, F. A., Linnaeus and the Linnaeans 144, 149. 1971.
Uggla, Sv. Linné-Sälsk. Årsskr. 35: 5-17. 1952 (memorial address).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hasselquistia</em> Linnaeus (1755).

2458. B.c.D. <em>Vires plantarum</em>, dissertatione academica, cum cons. ampliss. facult. medicae in
regiae academia upsaliensi sub praesidio viri experientissimi et celeberrimi, Dr. Doct. Caroli
Linnaei, ... examini publico subjectae a Friderico Hasselquist, O-Gotho, stipendiar. regio.
in auditor. gustaviano, die [xx] junii anni mdccxlvii horis ante meridiem solitis. Upsaliae
[1747]. Qu. (<em>Vires pl</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Jun 1747, p. [1]-37, [38-40]. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, NY. – For later publications see SO
	1461-1468. This is one of the Linnaean dissertations of which Krok (KR) assumes that the
	defendent (here Hasselquist) had a major share in the drafting of the text.
<em>Reprint</em>(1): <em>in</em> Linnaeus, Amoen. Acad. 1: 389-428. 1749.

2459. Fredric Hasselquists ... <em>Iter palaestinum</em> eller resa til heliga landet, förrätad ifrån år 1749
til 1752, med beskrifningar, rön, anmärkningar,,öfver de märkvärdigstaste naturalier, ...
utgiven av Carl Linnaeus. Stockholm (Trykt på Lars Salvii kåstnad) 1757. Oct. (<em>Iter
palaest</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 23 Mai 1757 (Lärda Tidningar 1757 (40): 157) p. [i-xvi], [1]-619, [620 cont.]. <em>Copies</em>:
	HU, MICH, MO, NY, USDA; IDC 2586. For full bibliographical details of original
	publication and further editions and translations see SO 3577-3586. – Botanical infor-

<em>German</em>: Jul 1762 (NZgS; p. 606: printed 1761), p. [i-xviii], [1]-606. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY. –
	"D. Friedrich Hasselquists ... <em>Reise nach Palästina</em> in den Jahren von 1749 bis 1752. Auf
	Befehl Ihrer Majestät der Königinn von Schweden herausgegeben von Carl Linnäus. Aus
	dem Schwedischen." Rostock (verlegts Johann Christian Koppe) 1762. Oct. – German
	translation of itinerary on p. 1-180, followed by letters by H. to Linnaeus and by the
	materia medica of the area. (<em>Reise Palästina</em>).
<em>English</em>: Jan 1766 (Gent. Mag.), p. [i*-ii*], map, [iii*-viii*], [i]-viii, [1]-456. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY.
	– " <em>Voyages and Travels in the Levant</em>; in the years 1749, 50, 51, 52. Containing observations in
	natural history, physick, agriculture, and commerce: particularly on the Holy Land, and
	the natural history of the Scriptures. Written originally in the Swedish language, by the
	late Frederick Hasselquist, M. D. Fellow of the Royal Societies of Upsal and Stockholm.

<em>French</em>: 1769 (p. 203, priv. 21 Nov 1768), p. [i-iii], [1]-201, [202-203], <em>Copy</em>: G.–"<em>Voyages dans
	le Levant</em>, dans les années 1749, 50, 51 &amp; 52. Contenant des observations sur l'histoire
	naturelle, la médecine, l'agriculture &amp; le commerce, &amp; particulièrement sur l'histoire
	naturelle de la Terre Sainte. Par Frédéric Hasselquist ... publiés par ordre du Roi de
	Suède, par Charles Linnaeus ... traduit de l'Allemand par M.***". Paris (Chez
	Delalain) 1769. – N.B. this is a translation based on the German translation. (<em>Voy. Levant</em>).
<em>Dutch</em>: <em>Vol. 1</em>: 1771, p. [i]-lx, [1]-315 (err. "115"). <em>Vol. 2</em>: 1771, p. [i], [iii], [1]-426, <em>pl. 1-5</em>.
	<em>Copy</em>: U. –Dr. Fred. Hasselquist's <em>Reize naar Palestina</em>, of het H. Land; op hoog bevel van de

Hasselt, Arend Ludolf van (1848-1909), Dutch soldier and later civil administrator on
Java and Sumatra, leader of the Central Sumatra Expedition of 1877-1879. (<em>A. Hasselt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L.

Hasselt, Johan Coenraad van (1797-1823), Dutch surgeon and biologist, member of the
"Natuurkundige Commissie" for the Dutch East Indies together with Kuhl. (<em>J. Hasselt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L; some duplicates in K and U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 255; Barnhart 2: 137; BM 2: 798; CSP 3: 209-210;
IH 2: 260; JW 1: 443, 2: 191, 3: 353, 5: 241 (many details); Rehder 5: 372; SK 1: 219-221,

Anon., Alg. Konst. Letterbode 1825 (1): 198-202, 212-218, 230-233; 1829 (1): 369-370.
Sirks, M. J., Ind. natuurond. 99-106, 298 [index]. 1915.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See Breda, <em>Gen. Sp. Orchid. Asclep</em>. 1827, TL 2/728.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hasseltia</em> Humboldt, Bonpland &amp; Kunth (1825); <em>Hasseltia</em> Blume (1827); <em>Hassel-
tiopsis</em> Sleumer (1938); <em>Kuhlhasseltia</em> J. J. Smith (1910, also dedicated to Heinrich Kuhl
(1796-1821), q.v.).

Hasskarl, Justus Karl (1811-1894), German botanist; studied in Bonn; in Java 1837-
1843 and 1846 at the Bogor garden; from 1852-1856 involved in introducing <em>Cinchona</em> into the
Netherlands East Indies; Dr. phil. h.c. Greifswald 1858; from 1856 as private scientist at
Cleve, Germany. (<em>Hassk</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (donated by H. in 1892); other material at B, BO, H, K and NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 255-256; Barnhart 2: 137; BM 2: 798; BL 1:
112, 300; Bossert p. 167; CSP 3: 211-213, 6: 682, 7: 919, 10: 156, 15: 681; Frank 3(Anh.): 42;
Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hassk."); IF p. 701-702; IH 2: 260; Kew 2: 601-602; Jackson p. 556
[index]; JW 1: 443, 2: 191-192, 3: 353, 4; 388, 5: 241; Langman p. 352; Moebius p. 421;
MW p. 161, suppl. p. 90; Plesch p. 251; PR 3842-3850 (ed. 1: 4208-4210); Rehder 5: 372-
373; RS p. 86; SBC p. 122 ("Hassk."); SK 1: xxv, 221 (ext. det.), 4: clxxv; Sotheby p. 324;
Tucker 1: 325; Zander ed. 10, p. 667-668.

Hassler, Émile (1861-1937), Swiss botanical collector and physician who settled in
Paraguay (1885-1937) with several prolonged stays in Europe; Dr. phil. h.c. Ascunsión 1930.
(<em>Hassl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Paraguay herbarium (35.000) at G; second largest set of collections at
K (7075), other major sets at B (no longer extant), P, S and W. Hassler issued various sets of
exsiccatae, some collected by T. Rojas:
(1) <em>Plantae paraguarienses</em> (1898-1913, distributed in various series by year).
(2) <em>Plantae a custode herbarii mei T. Rojas in chaco septentrionali lectae</em>.
(3) <em>Florula Cordillerae villaricensis</em>.
(4) <em>Comision argentino-paraguaya de limites</em> (1906).
(5) <em>Plantae pilcomayenses a ... Theodore Rojas lectae</em>.
(6) <em>Itinera in Paraguaria septentrionali</em> (T. Rojas leg.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Verdoorn, F., Chron. bot. 4: 170. 1938.
	Stafleu, F. A., Monogr. Vochysiac. 532. 1948.
	Miège &amp; Wuest, Saussurea 6: 133. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 652; Barnhart 2: 137; BJI 2: 70; BL 1: 234, 252,
253, 300; BM 2: 799, 6: 440; Bossert p. 167; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hassl."); IH 2: 260; Kew 2:
602; Plesch p. 251; TL-2/303-304; Tucker 1: 325, 335; Urban-Berl. p. 354; Zander ed. 10, p.
668.
Hassler, E., Bibliografia del Dr. E. Hassler ofrecida a la Universidad nacional de Ascunción
	al entregársele et primer diploma de "doctor honoris causa" otorgado por la misma.
	Ascunción, 26de octubre de 1934. Buenos Aires (Casa Coni), 1934, 6 p. (<em>n.v.</em>), reprinted
	Darwiniana 3(1): 82-87. 1937.
Hochreutiner, B. P. G., Boissiera 3: [11 p.]. 1939 (portr., bibl.).
Molfino, J. F., Physis 5: 332-337. 1922 (bibl.); Anal. Soc. ci. Argentina 113(3): 138-140.
	1932.

Hauck, Ferdinand (1845-1889), Austrian algologist (born at Brünn, Brno); post office
official stationed at Trieste 1866-1889; Dr. phil. h.c. Zürich 1883. (<em>Hauck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (via herb. Weber-van Bosse); further material at W and WRSL.
<em>Exsiccatae</em> (with Paul Richter): <em>Phykotheka universalis</em> (Fasc. 1-15; P. Richter from fasc. 7 on;
750 nos., Leipzig (Kummer) 1885-1896), complete sets at B, BM, C, FH, HAL, KBG, K, L,
LD, NY, S, STR, UPS, W, WRSL. Fryxell (1975) refers to Hauck diatoms at S, Hauck and
Richter id. at W. – Diagnoses in Hedwigia. – Hauck also contributed specimens to V.
Wittrock and O. Nordtstedt, <em>Algae aquae dulcis exsiccatae</em> and to P. T. Cleve and J. D. Möller,
<em>Diatomeen</em>.
<em>Ref</em>.: Dodel, Bot. Centralbl. 42: 362-367. 1890 (on <em>Phykotheka</em>).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 78. 1969.
	Koster, J. T., Blumea 2(3): 231. 1936, Taxon 18: 553. 1969.
	Fryxell, G., Nova Hedwigia Beih. 35: 361. 1975.

Hauman, Lucien (1880-1965), Belgian botanist; educated at Gembloux; pupil of Leo
Errera; at the Faculty of Agronomy in Buenos Aires, Argentina, from 1904-1926; professor of
botany at the Université libre de Bruxelles 1928-1950; Dr. agron. h.c. Buenos Aires 1949.
(<em>Haum</em>.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hausmannia</em> Dunker (1846) is dedicated to Johann Friedrich Ludwig Hausmann
(1782-1859), German mineralogist.

2483. <em>Flora von Tirol</em>. Ein Verzeichniss der in Tirol und Vorarlberg wild wachsenden und
häufiger gebauten Gefässpflanzen. Mit Berücksichtigung ihrer Verbreitung und örtlichen
Verhältnisse verfasst und nach Koch's Synopsis der deutschen Flora geordnet. [Heft 3 and
1854 general t.p.:]. Mit einem Anhange, enthaltend: Die Literatur der Flora des Landes und
Notizen über die zu selber Bezug habenden Botaniker – zweifelhafte und irrige ältere
Angaben – Höhenmessungen – einen Vergleich mit den Nachbar-Floren in tabellarischer
Uebersicht – einen Linnéischen Schlüssel – ein vollständiges Synonymen-Register – und
Nachträge zur Flora ... Innsbruck (Im Verlage der Wagner'schen Buchhandlung) 1851-
1854. Oct. (<em>Fl. Tirol</em>).

Heft pp.	date	Heft pp.	date
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1	[i-viii], [1]-576 Jul-Sep 1851	3	[i]-xiv, [1085]-1614 Jun-Jul 1854
2	[i-ii], 577-1084 1852

<em>Copies</em>: B, G, L, M, MO, NY, USDA (Heft 1 until p. 548).
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 9: 764-765. 24 Oct. 1851; 12: 531-534. 28 Jul
	1854 (Heft 2, 3).
	Fürnrohr, A. E., Flora 27: 665-668. 14 Nov 1854.
	Hausmann, F. von Verh. zool. bot. Ver. Wien 8: 371-380. 1858 (Nachträge).

2484. <em>Gagea und Lloydia</em>. Eine Monographie von Franz Hausmann. Wien (gedruckt bei Carl
Ueberreuter) 1841. Oct. (<em>Gagea Lloydia</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1841, p. [i]-vi, [7]-58. <em>Copy</em>: WU. – The BM copy has the title <em>Dissertatio inauguralis
	medico-botanica exponens species generum plantarum Gageae et Lloydiae</em> ... (see also PR). The
	WU copy is the trade edition.

Haussknecht, Heinrich Carl (1838-1903), German botanist of independent means at
Weimar; botanical explorer of the Orient. (<em>Hausskn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: JE ("Herbarium Haussknecht"). Duplicates in A, AK, B, BM, BB,
CN, E, G, K, L, LE, LY, MANCH, MN, OXF, P, W. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: sets issued as e.g. <em>Iter Syriaco-
Armeniacum</em> (1864-1866), <em>Iter kurdicum</em> (1866-1869), <em>Iter graecum</em> (1885), <em>Iter orientale</em> (1867-
1868). – Haussknecht's library is also at JE. The "Herbarium Haussknecht" was originally
housed in Weimar in a building, erected in 1895, designed to house H's collections. After H's
death this institution was continued as an independent foundation managed by Joseph
Bornmüller under the auspices of the Thüringische botanische Gesellschaft. Bornmüller was
succeeded by O. Schwarz in 1946 who transferred the collections to the new Institut für
spezielle Botanik at Jena in 1949.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 333-334. 1975.

PAGE: 104
HEADING: HAUSSKNECHT

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 277, 5(2): 163, 5(2): 488; Backer p. 652; Barnhart 2:
140; BM2: 802; Bossert p. 167; CSP 7: 925, 10: 162, 12: 317, 15: 690; Clokie p. 179; DTS 1:
106-107, 6(4): 63, 70, 71, 148; GR p. 86; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hausskn."); IH 2: 261; Kew 2:
606-607; Langman p. 352; LS 11534-11535; Maiwald p. 117, 124; MW p. 162; NAF ser. 2.
5: 241; NI 813; Rehder 5: 373; Saccardo 1: 88, 2: 57; TL-2/see K. G. Baenitz; Urban-Berl.
p. 265, 301, 354; Zander ed. 10, p. 668.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1904: 46; Bot. Zeit. 61 (2): 240. 1903; Bull. Soc. bot. France 16 (bibl.): 46-
	47, 239. 1869.
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. Länder 35. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4).
Frison, Ed., Henri Ferdinand Van Heurck 45. 1959.
Hergt, Mitt. thür. bot. Ver. ser. 2. 18: 1-14. 1904 (portr., bibl.); Ber. Deut. bot. Ges. 22: (31)-
	(39). 1905.
Meyer, F. K. und H. Manitz, <em>in</em>: Reichtümer und Raritäten, Jenaer Reden und Schriften
	88-95. 1975 (on the "Herbarium Haussknecht").
Pax, F., Grundz. Pflanzenverbr. Karpathen 38, 42. 1898 (Veg. Erde 2(1)).
Volkens, Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 51: (85). 1910.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Haussknechtia</em> Boissier (1872).

2485. <em>Monographie der Gattung Epilobium</em> ... Jena (Verlag von Gustav Fischer) 1884. Qu. (<em>Monogr. Epilobium</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1884 (p. viii: Mai 1884; Nat. Nov. Jun 1884; Bot. Zeit. 25 Jul 1884; id. "soeben"
	27 Jun 1884; J. Bot. Jul 1884), p. [i]-viii, [1, cont.], [1]-318, 3 charts, <em>pl. 1-23</em>, uncol. liths.

<em>Ref</em>.: Murbeck, Bot. Not. 1884: 189-199. 18 Dec 1884.

Havaas (Havås), Johan Jonson (1864-1956), Norwegian farmer and lichenologist at
Bergen. (<em>Hav</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BG; other material at DUKE and O. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>:

(1) <em>Lichenes exsiccati Norvegiae</em>, a Museo Bergensi editi. Fasc. 1-23, nos. 1-725, Bergen 1901-
1952, sets at BG, C, H, O, UPS.
(2) <em>Lichenes Norvegiae occidentalis exsiccati</em>, a Museo Bergense editi. Fasc. 1-12, nos. 1-300.
Bergen 1912-1954. Sets at BG, FH, LD, LE, O, PC, S, UPS; for incomplete sets see IH.

<em>Index</em>: Lynge, B., Index sp. var. lich. 241-248. 1915-1918; suppl. p. 234.

<em>Note</em> (by P. M. Jorgensen): Havaas was for a very long time "stipendiat" at BG, a position
which allowed him to continue his lichenological studies at his farm at Granvin. Under this
arrangement Havaas had to deliver the first set of his collections to BG and to keep only
duplicates for his personal use. All specimens on which Havaas published are at BG. Upon
Havaas' death his son sold the private herbarium kept at home to DUKE. This collection
contained mainly duplicates of what was already at BG but also some material collected in
later years which had not yet been identified. In addition to these main collections there are
Havaas collections not necessarily duplicating the holdings at BG, at TUR (via Vainio), H
(via G. Lång), UPS (through Magnusson), and at O (only few, mainly material sent to
Lynge). The location of regular sets of exsiccatae is mentioned above.
<em>Ref</em>.: V.A., Rev. bryol. lichén. 34: 376. 1966 (on acquisition by DUKE of "the cryptogamic
	herbarium" of Havaas).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 131-133. 1969.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 140; BL 2: 448, 666; GR p. 712-713, <em>pl</em>. [<em>36</em>], cat.
p. 64 ("Hav."); Hawsksworth p. 183; IH 2: 261; Kleppa p. 324; LS 11542-11543, 34270-
34271, suppl. 10943-10944; Rehder 5: 374; SBC p. 122 ("Hav."); Tucker 1: 326.
Dahl, Blyttia 14: 71-77. 1956.
Faegri, K., Naturen 78: 354-360. 1954 (portr.); Univ. Bergen Årsmelding 1955-56: 23-24.
Holmboe, J., Norsk. biogr. Leks. 5: 538-539. 1931.
Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 6: 56. 1957.

Havard, Valéry (1846-1927), French-born American physician and botanist; at Man-
hattan College, New York 1865; at San Francisco 1869; surgeon U.S. Army 1871; president
of the Army Medical School 1906-1910. (<em>Havard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main set at US; duplicates B, F, GH, MICH, MO, NY, SPH. For
travels see McVaugh 1957.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 140; BL 1: 216; CSP 10: 165, 15: 692; IH 2: 261;

<em>Publ</em>.: 1880, p. [1]-20. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – Appendix SS of the Annual Report of the Chief of

Haworth, Adrian Hardy (1768-1833), British gardener and entomologist, originally at
Cottingham nr. Hull, in 1792-1812 at Little Chelsea, London, from 1812-1817 again at
Cottingham; from 1817 or 1818 again at Chelsea; died of cholera; leading authority on
succulent plants. (<em>Haw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Haworth's herbarium was bought by Fielding who used it for study
and threw away most of the specimens. Some specimens of <em>Aloe, Apicra, Gasteria</em> and <em>Haworthia</em>
labelled by Haworth are still in the Fielding herbarium (OXF). Haworth had a garden in
Chelsea where he grew succulent plants (1817-1833). It may be assumed that, as was not
unusual with botanists working with succulent plants, Haworth did not always make
herbarium specimens of the new species he grew. Desmond mentions also Haworth plants at
K. – Letters at K, LINN, Teyler.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 69; Backer p. 256; Barnhart 2: 142; BB p. 143; Blunt
p. 211; BM 2: 804; Bossert p. 168; Clokie p. 180; CSP 3: 235-236, 15: 694; Desmond p. 295
(q.v. for further references); DNB 25: 246-247; Dryander 3: 288; Frank 3(Anh.): 42; Henrey
2: 389, 425, 434-435, 632, 429, 432-434, 720, 3: 52-53; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Haw."); Kew 2:
611; Jackson p. 556 [index]; Langman p. 354; MW p. 162; PR 3856-3861 (ed. 1: 4218-
4223); Rehder 5: 374; RS p. 87; TL-2/135; Tucker 1: 327; Zander ed. 10, p. 668.
Allan, M., The Hookers of Kew 35, 41. 1969.
Faulkner, Th., An historical and topographical description of Chelsea and its environs ii,
	Chelsea 1829, p. 11-13 (fide Rauschenberg; contemp. view of H's later years).

HEADING: HAWORTH

Hayden, Ferdinand Vanderveer (1829-1887), American geologist and explorer; leader
of the "Hayden Survey" of the U.S. Geological Survey in the Rocky Mountains, and of the
Western U.S. Expedition (1871-1873); professor of mineralogy Univ. Pennsylvania 1856-
1872; L.L.D. h.c. Univ. Rochester 1876, id. h.c. Univ. Penn. 1886, "the-man-who-picks-up-
stones-running" (Sioux name). (<em>Hayden</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>.: US; geol. coll. at PH.; further herbarium material at MO and PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 143; BM 2: 804-805; CSP 3: 237-238, 7: 927, 10:

Hayek, August (Edler) von (1871-1928), Austrian botanist and physician; dr. med. Wien
1895; dr. phil. Wien 1905, from 1912 at the Universität Wien.
(<em>Hayek</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>.: GB (90.000); some types. probably also in other herbaria from which
Hayek used material. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Centaureae exsiccatae criticae</em> (fasc. 1-4, 1913-1924) sets at
BM, C, G, GB, K, L, LAU, W.
(2) <em>Flora stiriaca exsiccata</em> (fasc. 1-26, 1904-1912, nos. 1-129) sets at B, BM, G, GB, GH, GZU,
KRAM, L, LAU, LE, MANCH, W. – For <em>Schedae</em> see no. 2502.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 134, 12(2): 39, 12(3): 57; Backer p. 652; Barnhart
2: 143; BFM 889, 890, 1126, 1500, 2006; BJI 2: 71; BM 6: 444-445; CSP 15: 698-699; DTS
1: 108, 6(4): 148-150; GR p. 451; Hirsch p. 1 16; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hayek"); IH 2: 262; Kew

2507. <em>Termini botanici</em> iconibus illustrati oder botanische Kunstsprache durch Abbildungen
erläutert von Friedrich Gottlob Hayne ... mit einer Vorrede versehen von D. Carl Ludwig
Willdenow ... Berlin (bey Wilh. Oehmigked. Jüngern) 1799-1812. 2 vols. Qu. (<em>Term. bot.</em>)

<em>Orig. issue</em>: In 14 Parts between 1799 and 1812; contents and dates of Parts incompletely
	known.
	<em>Vol. 1</em>: 10 Parts, 1799-1804[1806], [i*-vi*], [i]-ii, [1]-104, <em>pl. 1-50</em>. (p. ii: 3 Mar 1799).
	<em>Vol. 2</em>: 4 Parts, 1807-1812, p. [i-iii], engr. t.p. 1807, 105-182, err. slip, <em>pl. 51-69</em>.
	<em>Copies</em>: B, (Heft 1: [i*-vi*], [i]-ii, [1]-10, <em>pl. 1-5</em>), BR, G, L, James White (Copy with Hefte
	1-9), MO (see below), NY, USDA. – A printed title and a newly engraved page for vol.
	1, dated 1807, were issued with Heft 11.
	<em>Plates</em>: handcol. copper engr. by Hayne and Friedrich Guimpel; engraved t.p.'s idem.
	<em>Copy in orig. covers</em> (Hefte 1-10), MO. Heft covers Partly undated, contents: 1(1-10, <em>pl. 1-5</em>),
	2(11-22, <em>pl. 6-10</em>), 3(23-30, <em>pl. 11-15</em>), 4(31-42, <em>pl. 16-20</em>), 5(lacking), 6, dated 1802(51-
	62, <em>pl. 26-30</em>), 7, dated 1802 (63-70, <em>pl. 31-35</em>), 8, dated 1803(71-82, <em>pl. 36-40</em>), 9, dated
	1803(79-90, <em>pl. 41-45</em>), 10, dated 1804(89-101, <em>pl. 46-50</em>).
<em>Reissue</em>: 1817, Berlin (Neue Societäts-Verlag-Buchhandlung), n.v., see Sotheby no. 326 (with
	repr. of t.p.).

2508. <em>Getreue Darstellung und Beschreibung der in der Arzneykunde gebräuchlichen Gewächse</em>, wie
auch solcher, welche mit ihnen verwechselt werden können. Berlin [imprints see below],
1805-1846. Qu. 14 Bände in 8 Volumes. (<em>Getreue Darstell. Gew.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: each Band (except Bd. 14) contains 48 (Bd. 14: 24) beautifully coloured plates showing
	only one species (mostly phanerogams; some cryptogams in Bd. 5, 6, 8). In each Band the
	plates are numbered <em>1-48</em> (Bd. 14: <em>1-24</em>). Each plate is accompanied by a text-leaf,
	numbered in each B and (1)-(48) (Bd. 14: (1)-(24) (recto; verso not numbered). Each
	Volume (except 7 and 8) contains a combined register to both Bände in that Volume.
	Band 13 contains a "Vorwort" by Emilie Hayne-Fischer, dated "Berlin, im März 1838",
	and a "General-Register" for Bd. 1-13. The volumes were Published in Hefte, possibly 6
	per vol.
	Title of <em>Band 13</em>: "Dr. Friedrich Gottlob Hayne's, ... <em>Getreue Darstellung</em> ... verwech-
	selt werden können, fortgesetzt von Dr. J. F. Brandt, ... und Dr. J.T.C. Ratzeburg, ..."
	<em>Band 14</em>: no general title page seen; title on title page of wrapper of Heft 2 is the same as title
	of B and 13, except: "fortgesetzt von Dr. J.F. Klotzsch, ..."

Heckel, Édouard Marie (1843-1916), French naval apothecary and botanist; Dr. sci. nat.
Montpellier 1875; from 1877 professor of botany and (founder and) director of the botanic
garden at Marseille. (<em>Heckel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MARS(?), W.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Heckel died on 21 Jan 1916 at Marseille, fide Rev. gén. bot. 28: 224; however Cavillier
(1941) gives 22 jan 1916, Chevallier (1916) 22 Jan 1915 and Jumelle (1915, i.e. 1916) 20 Feb
1916. The éloge by Jumelle, in H's own journal, is perhaps more likely to be correct than the
other sources because of the author's narrow acquaintance with the deceased.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 652; Barnhart 2: 146; BL 1: 97, 229, 251, 300; BM
2: 807-808; CSP 7: 932; 10: 172-174, 12: 320, 15: 711-713; De Toni 1: lxii; IH 2: 264;

165; Rehder 5: 375-376; TL-2/1600; Tucker 1: 328-329; Zander ed. 10, p. 668.

	(portr.); Torreya 16(4): 101. 1916; Rev. gén. Bot. 28: 224. 1916.

Hedwig, Johann (1730-1799), German bryologist, born in Kronstadt (Brassó, hist.
Hungary); Dr. med. Leipzig 1759; physician at Chemnitz (1762-1781), later at Leipzig;
ultimately professor of botany and director of the botanic garden at Leipzig. (<em>Hedw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G. – Johan Hedwig's herbarium went, after his death, to his son R. A.
Hedwig. In 1810 Schwägrichen bought the Hedwig moss herbarium. The Hedwig-Schwäg-
richen herbarium was sold by auction and came to the hands of J. E. Duby, after whose death
the collections were again put up for sale. Duby's exotic mosses and some of the European
collections went to William Barbey for the Boissier herbarium (1886) together with what was
then already called the Schwägrichen-Hedwig type herbarium. This herbarium was trans-
ferred to the general collection of G in 1958. In addition, A. P. de Candolle had acquired
duplicates of musci directly from Hedwig. These are also at G. The other European mosses of
Duby went to L. Motelay at Bordeaux. Their present location is unknown.
<em>Ref</em>.: Briquet, Bull. Soc. bot. Suisse 50a: 214-215. 1940.
	Duby, Rev. bryol. 1(4): 50. 1874.
	Florschütz, P. A., Introduction to Hedwig's Species muscorum, in <em>facsimile</em> ed. Weinheim
	1960, pp. xviii-xix.
	Barbey, W., List of collections bought from Mme Duby in 1886 (mss. Genève).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 11: 230-231; Ainsworth p. 62, 66, 68, 312; Barnhart 2:
148; BM 2: 809-810; Bossert p. 169; DTS 1: 108; Dawson p. 404-405, 937 [index]; DSB 6:
218-220 (bibl.); Frank 3(Anh.): 42; GR p. 433, <em>pl</em>. [<em>22</em>], cat. p. 64; Hortus 3: 1194 ("J.
Hedw."); IF p. 702; Jackson p. 148, 150, 153, 192; Kanitz no. 68; Kew 2: 624; Lenley p.
216; LS 11683-11687; MD p. 139-144; Moebius p. 163, 451; NAF 1(1): 160, ser. 2. 3: 36;
NDB 8: 191-192; NI 826-832; Plesch p. 252-253; PR 3878-3885 (ed. 1: 4255-4262); Rehder
5: 376; SBC p. 122 ("Hedw."); SO 692, 693, add. 719a, 761; Stevenson p. 1244; TL-2/350.
Anon., Neue Schr. Ges. naturf. Freunde Berlin 2: 440-449. 1799; Proc. Linn. Soc. London
	1888/90: 36. 1891.

2532. Joannis Hedwig ... <em>Species muscorum frondosorum</em> descriptae et tabulis aeneis lxxvii
coloratis illustratae. Opus posthumum editum a Friderico Schwaegrichen ... Lipsiae
[Leipzig] (sumtu Joannis Ambrosii Barthii), Parisiis (apud Amand Koenig) 1801. Qu. (<em>Sp.
muse. frond.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Jan 1801, conventional date, accepted at IXth International Botanical Congress,
Montreal 1959; ICBN Art. 13. 1(b). Actual date of publication (at least p. 1-260) 19 Apr
1801, p. [i]-vi, [1]-17, 19-352, 353 (post publ. add.), chart, <em>pl. 1-77. Copies</em>: G, MICH,
MO, NY, U. - Designated as starting point work for the nomenclature of names of Musci
(excl. Sphagnaceae). An extensive bibliographical analysis, accompanied by detailed infor-
mation on the book and an evaluation of the various nomenclatural problems connected
with it, is given by Margadant (MD). – The editor was Christian Friedrich Schwägrichen
(1775-1853), who published supplements which are in fact an independent work (see
Schwägrichen). – The 77 coloured plates are coloured copper engr. by Hedwig himself. For
notes on p. 353 (post publication addition) see v.d. Wijk 1952 and MD.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Weinheim (J. Cramer) 1960, Historiae naturalis classica vol. 16, ISBN 3-7682-
7055-6, with an introduction by P. A. Florschütz. <em>Copies</em>: G, FAS, U. – See also Taxon 10: 30.
1961. – Contains p. 353.
<em>Ref</em>.: BM 2: 810; MD p. 139-144; DTS 1: 108; NI 830; PR 3885; SY p. 9-10; IDC 5022.
	Wijk, R. v.d., Trans. Brit, bryol. Soc. 2: 82-83. 1952 (on omission of p. 353 from most
	copies); Taxon 6: 55. 1957.
	Sayre, G., Hedwig, 1801, and the nomenclature of mosses. VIIIe Congres lnt. Bot., Paris
	1954, Rapports comm. Sect. 14-16: 108-113. 1954; Taxon 6: 10-12. 1957 (dates).

Hedwig, Romanus Adolf (1772-1806), German botanist; from 1801 professor of botany
in Leipzig; son of Johannes Hedwig. (<em>R. Hedw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: R. A. Hedwig's herbarium was sold by auction after his death. Some
of the material may have been incorporated in his father's herbarium (see above).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 148; Backer p. 652; BM 2: 810; CSP 3: 247;
Dawson p. 405; De Toni 1: lxii; Hortus 3: 1194 ("R. Hedw."); Kew 2: 624; Jackson p. 113;
LS 11688-11689; PR 3886-3890 (ed. 1: 4263-4271); Rehder 5: 376; SBC p. 122 ("Hedw.
f."); Stevenson p. 1244 ("Hedw. f.").
Dawson, W. R., Smith papers 53. 1934.
Jourdan, Dict. Sci. méd. 5: 125-126. 1822 (bibl.).
MacPhail, I., Cat. Redout. 16. 1963.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed "<em>Observations de plantes calyptrates</em>, ..." to Weber und Mohr,
<em>Beiträge zur Naturkunde</em>, vol. 1, Kiel 1805 (publ. 7 Dec 1805-4 Aug 1806 fide SY p. 24).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For the unpublished "<em>Descriptio et adumbratio microscopico-analytica fungorum</em> aliarumque
plantarum cryptogamicarum ad eorum familiam pertinentium", now in mss. at G, see A. P.
de Candolle, Mémoires et souvenirs 143 (1862) and Arthur, Torreya 4(2): 21-23. 1904. This
manuscript is the basis of references to "Hedw. f." and "Hedw. f. Fung, ined." given for
several names of Uredinales first published in Candolle, Fl. Franç. (1805).

literarum universitate lipsiensi ad summos in arte medica honores capessendos d. iv mensis
septembr. a. mdcciic. publice defendet auctor Romanus Adolph Hedwig ... Lipsiae [Leip-
zig] (ex officina Bueschelia) s.d. Qu. (<em>Tremella nostoch</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 4 Sep 1798, p. [i-vii], [1]-71, [72, expl.], <em>1 pl. Copies</em>: G, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Hedwig, <em>in</em> Roemer, Arch. Bot. 2: 256-257. 1801.

2534. <em>Aphorismen über die Gewächskunde</em>. Zum Gebrauch meiner Vorlesungen mit besonderer
Rücksicht auf die Lehrsätze meines Vaters entworfen von Romanus Adolph Hedwig ...
Leipzig (in der Schäferischen Buchhandlung) 1800. Oct. (<em>Aphor. Gewächsk.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1800 (p. viii: Feb 1800), p. [i]-xiv, [1]-102. <em>Copies</em>: G, L, M. – <em>Note</em>: see also above, no.
2530, for J. Hedwig's <em>Aphorismen</em>.

d. 8. Octob. 1793. Lipsiae [Leipzig] (ex officina Breitkopfia). [1793]. Qu. (<em>Epistola</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 8 Oct 1793, p. [1]-16. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – See also Usteri, Neue Ann. Bot. 1: 125-126. 1794.

	Qu.

HEADING: HEER

Heer, Oswald von (1809-1883), Swiss palaeobotanist, entomologist and theologist; from
1834 connected with the University of Zürich; from 1855 also with the ETH, professor of
botany and director of the botanical garden. (<em>Heer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Z; further material at B, GRA, K, HAL, LE. – Fossil material at the
Geological Institute of the Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 229, 4: 306, 12(3): 162; Andrews p. 276-277; Backer
p. 257; Barnhart 2: 148; BJI 1: 25; BM 2: 810-813, 6: 447; BL 2: 561, 666; Bossert p. 169;
CSP 3: 248-249, 6: 684, 7: 933-935, 10: 176-177, 12: 320-321, 15: 721; DSB 6: 220-222; DTS
1: xx, 108, 6(4): 31; Frank 3(Anh.): 42; GR p. 641, <em>pl</em>. [<em>21</em>]: Hortus 3: 1294 ("Heer"); IH 2:
264; Jackson p. 557 [index]; Kew 2: 625-626; Kleppa p. 324; KR p. 279-280; Langman p.
355; LS 11690-11691; ME p. 378-379; Moebius p. 380, 382; MW p. 165-166; NI 833-835;
PR 3891-3899, 10573-10574; Quenstedt p. 194-195 (q.v. for further biogr. refs.); Rehder 5:
377; Saccardo 2: 58; TL-2/1020; Tucker 1: 329-330; Zander ed. 10, p. 668.
Anon., Jahresber. naturf. Ges. Graubünden ser. 2. 27: xvii-xx. 1884; Bot. Gaz. 8: 340. 1883;
	Bot. Zeit. 41: 695. 1883; Gard. Chron. 20: 509-510. 1883; Verh. schweiz. naturf. Ges. 91:
	37-40. 1908; Generalregister Bot. Not. 1839-1938: 98. 1939.

	Asa Gray's obituary in Amer. J. Sci. 1884).

2540. <em>Ueber die fossilen Pflanzen von St. Jorge</em> in Madeira von Dr. Oswald Heer. Der natur-

<em>Publ</em>.: 1857 (submitted 5 Nov 1855), p. [1]-40, <em>pl. 1-3</em>, uncol. liths. <em>Copies</em>: G, M, USGS. -
	Neue Denkschr. allg. Schweiz. Ges. Naturw. 15. – According to Flora 42: 112. 21 Feb
	1859 volume 15 of the Neue Denkschriften, dated 1857, was received in Feb 1859. The
	article may well have been preprinted but we have no information on its precise date of
	publication. Malloizel (p. 29), however, cites two reviews of the publication, both from
	1856; he dates the publication nevertheless at 1857.

2541. <em>Die miocene Flora von Spitzbergen</em>. Vorgetragen von Oswald Heer, professor in Zürich,
bei der Versammlung der Schweizerischen naturforschenden Gesellschaft. Den 23 August
1860 in Solothurn. Solothurn (Druck von J. Gassmann, Sohn) s.d. [1860]. Oct. (<em>Mioc. Fl.
Spitzbergen</em>).

	by Heer on this subject see Malloizel p. 36.

Hegelmaier, Christoph Friedrich (1833-1906), German physician and botanist; Dr.
med. Tübingen 1857; until 1862 military physician at Ulm; from 1862-1863 with A. Braun
at Berlin; habil. Tübingen 1864, later professor of botany at Tübingen (extraordinary 1866;
honorary 1902). (<em>Hegelm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; material at B, BR, C, L, LY. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Iter gallo-
hispanicum</em> (1875).

627; Langman p. 355; Lenley p. 217; LS 11696-11698, 34364; Maiwald p. 123; MWp. 166;
NDB 8: 223-224; PR 3900-3901; Rehder 5: 377; Tucker 1: 330.

Hegetschweiler-Bodmer, Johannes (1789-1839), Swiss botanist; Dr. med. Zürich 1813.
(<em>Hegetschw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Hegetschweiler was an ecological botanist who grew
many plants in his garden for experimental taxonomic purposes. It is not known whether he
made herbarium specimens, if so they may be expected in Carl Hegetschweiler's herbarium
now at Z. Hawksworth cites mycological material at BERN and Z.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 191, 12(3): 320; Barnhart 2: 149; BM 2: 813; BL 2:
561, 562, 666; Blunt p. 221; CSP 3: 250; DTS 1: 108, 6(4): 31; Frank 3 (Anh.): 43; GR p.
632, cat. p. 64; Hawksworth p. 183; Hortus 3: 1194 ("Hegetschw".); Jackson p. 342; Kew 2:
627; KR p. 280; LS 11699-11700; NAF 28B(2): 334; NI 838-839; PR 3902-3907 (ed. 1:
4273-4278); Rehder 5: 377; SBC p. 122 ("Heg."); Zander ed. 10, p. 668.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1840: 144.
Candolle, A. P. de, Mémoires et souvenirs 362. 1862.
Furrer, Vierteljahrsschr. naturf. Ges. Zürich 116: 502-503. 1971 (d. 9 Sep 1839).
Pritzel, G. A. Linnaea 19: 454. 1847.
Schröter, C, Neujahrsblatt zum Besten des Waisenhauses in Zürich 76: 1-81. 1913 (portr.,
	bibl.) (Engler coll. DS).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hegetschweilera</em> Heer &amp; Regel (1842).

"<em>Basel issue</em>": 1 Nov 1824 – 25 Jan 1834, 478 texts and <em>480 plates. Copy</em>: G (in 8 vols.) [See
	Wheldon and Wesley, Cat. 139, 1977, no. 30].-Original title: <em>Abbildungen der Pflanzen des
	Kantons Basel</em>. – An index, "Übersicht," was published by Orell Füssli in Zürich in 1841
	(see below); the anonymous author was O. Heer. From Senn's study it is likely that this
	"Basel issue" consisted strictly speaking only of the first 6 parts; from November onward
	publication took place from Zürich.
"<em>Zürich issue</em>": published in 80 parts of <em>6 pl</em>. each between 1825 and 1834, t.p. and <em>481</em>
	unnumbered plates (hand-coloured liths.) with text. <em>Copy</em>: NY (bound in two vols.).
	<em>Imprint</em>: Zürich (bei J. Esslinger Praeceptor).
<em>St. Gallen re-issue</em>: "<em>Sammlung von Schweizer-Pflanzen</em>. Nach der Natur gezeichnet von J. D.
	Labram. Text von Dr. J. Hegetschweiler. Zusammengetragen nach dem System
	Linné's." St. Gallen (Werner Hausknecht), [1841-1847], 100 Lieferungen, 10 Ab-
theilungen. <em>Plates</em> as in orig. <em>Copy</em>: MO.

1: [i], pl. 1-52 with text.	6: [i], pl. 227-282, id.
2: [i], pl. 53-109, id.	7: [i], pl. 283-340, id.
3: [i], pl. 110-139, id.	8: [i], pl. 341-392, id.
4: [i], pl. 140-184, id.	9: [i], pl. 393-444, id.
5: [i], pl. 185-226, id.	10: [i], pl. 445-477, id.

<em>Neue Folge</em>, 100 parts of <em>4 pl</em>., [1838-1846], <em>400 pl</em>., by K. F. Hagenbach. <em>Copy</em>: G (plates only,
	vols. 9-12). For details see Senn (1940).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 9: 442-444. 28 Jul 1826.
	Burckhardt, Verh. naturf. Ges. Basel 19: 1-36. 1907 (on Labram).
	Senn., Verh. naturf. Ges. Basel 51(2): 179-195. 1940, 54: 304-326. 1963 (important
	studies, q.v. for further details).

2564. <em>Die Giftpflanzen der Schweiz</em> beschrieben von Joh. Hegetschweiler M.D. gezeichnet von
J. D. Labram lithographirt von C. J. Brodtmann. Zürich (bey Johannes Esslinger Praecep
tor) s.d. [1828-1834]. Oct. (<em>Giftpfl. Schweiz</em>).

<em>Artist</em>: Johann Daniel Labram.

<em>Fasc. 1</em>: early 1828, p. [i*], [i]-xxvi, [1]-14., <em>pl. 1-6</em>.
<em>Fasc. 2</em>: early 1828, p. [15]-30, <em>pl. 7-12</em>.
<em>Fasc. 3</em>: 1830, p. [31]-46, <em>pl. 13-18</em>.
<em>Fasc. 4</em>: 1830, p. 47-52, <em>pl. 19-24.</em>
<em>Fasc. 5-6</em>: 1833, or early 1834, p. 53-84, [1, Warnung], <em>pl. 25-38.</em>

<em>Copies</em>: FH, G, NY, USDA (fasc. 1-3). – The final leaf [1], contains a warning against Taxus
	<em>baccata</em>. The plates are hand-coloured liths. of drawings by J. D. Labram.
<em>Issue in bookform</em>: Zürich (A. Unflad), 1834 sem. 2 or 1835 (n.v.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Senn, Verh. naturf. Ges. Basel 54: 312-326. 1943.
	Tecoz, Librarian 15(3): 166-179. 1972.

HEADING: HEGETSCHWEILER-BODMER

2565. <em>Beyträge zu einer kritischen Aufzählung der Schweizerpflanzen</em> und einer Ableitung der
helvetischen Pflanzenformen von den Einflüssen der Auswelt ... Zürich (bey Orell, Füssli
und Compagnie) 1831. Oct. (<em>Beitr. Aufz. Schweizerpfl.</em>).

	Regensburg, USDA.

2566. <em>Die Flora der Schweiz</em> von Dr. Joh. Hegetschweiler, weiland Staatsrath des Cantons
Zürich (Druck und Verlag von Fr. Schulthess) 1840. Duod. (in sixes). (<em>Fl. Schweiz</em>).

Part	pages	dates
------------------------------------------------------
1	[1]-144	late Mai 1838
2	145-456	Dec 1838-Jan 1839
3	457-684	Feb-Jul 1839
4	685-905	Sep 1840
5	906-1008, [1-3, err.]	Sep 1840
	[1]-xxviii, [1, h.t.]

<em>First issue</em>: as above, preface p. xxvi signed by Heer, 7 Apr 1840. Oswald von Heer (1809-
	1883) edited the greater part of the manuscript, and included a biography of Hegetsch-
	weiler in his preface. <em>Plates</em>: <em>1-8</em>, uncol. liths. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY.
<em>Second issue</em>: "Flora der Schweiz von Joh. Hegetschweiler, Dr. med. und Staatsrath des Cantons
	Zürich. Fortgesetzt und herausgegeben von Osw. Heer, Dr. Philos., Professor der Natur-
	geschichte in Zürich." Zürich (Druck und Verlag von Fr. Schulthess.) 1840. Duod. (in
	sixes), p. [i*], [i]-xxviii, [1]-1135, [1-3, err.], <em>pl. 1-8</em>, id. <em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, NY, USDA.-
	This issue has an "Extra Beilage," by Heer p. 1009-1135, publ. Sep (or later?) 1840, and a
	different t.p. The "Beilage" was also published separately by Heer as "<em>Analytische Tabellen</em>
	zur Bestimmung der Phanerogamischen Pflanzengattungen der Schweiz." Zürich 1840
	(see 2538).
<em>Ref</em>.: Buser, Neujahrblatt zum Besten des Waisenhauses in Zürich für 1913: 73-75.
	Thellung, ib. pp. 75-81 (synonymy).

2567. <em>Übersicht der uon J. D. Labram und Dr. J. Hegetschweiler herausgegebenen Schweizerpflanzen</em>.
Nach den Systemen Linné's de Candolle's und Bartling's geordnet. Zugleich als Erläuterung
der Abbildungen dienlich. Zürich (gedruckt bei Orell, Füssli et Comp.) s.d. [1841]. Duod. (<em>Übers. Schweizerpfl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1841, compiled by Oswald Heer (1809-1883), p. [i-iv], [1]-60. <em>Copy</em>: G. – See Senn,
	Verh. naturf. Ges. Basel 51(2): 186-187. 1940.

Hegi, Gustav (1876-1932), Swiss botanist; studied at Zürich with Schinz; from 1902
curator, later lecturer and professor of botany (1910) at München; consul-general for
Switzerland at München. (<em>Hegi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M. — Several types probably also in other herbaria from which Hegi
studied material.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 149; Backer p. 652; BFM 9, 1167; Blunt p. 258;
BM6: 448; BL 1: 23, 300, 2: 559, 562, 574, 591, 666; DTS 6(4): 151; GR p. 641; Hortus 3:
1194 ("Hegi"); Hirsch p. 117; IH 2: 264; Kew 2: 627; LS 11701, 34365-34366; NI 840-841;
Plesch p. 253; Zander p. 668.
Aellen, H., Schweiz. Zeitgen.-Lex. ed. 2. 394. 1932.
Beger, Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 51: (201)-(207). 1934 (bibl.).
Familler, I., Denkschr. Regensb. bot. Ges. 11: 17-18. 1911.
Gentner, Mitt. bay. bot. Ges. 4(13): 222-225. 1923 (portr.; incompl. bibl.).
Kahnt-Hegi et al., Ber. schweiz. bot. Ges. 42(1): 7-10. 1933 (bibl.).
Schinz, Neue Zürcher Zeit. 1156. 21 Jun 1932 (sse also J. Bot. 70: 237. 1932).
Schinz und Ulrich, Vierteljahrsschr. naturf. Ges. Zürich 77: 266-273. 1932 (bibl.).
Wulff, E. V., Intr. hist. pl. geogr. 25, 27, 103, 162, 206. 1943.

HEADING: HEGI

dargestellt. Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der philosophischen Doktorwürde vor-

Schinz. Extrait du Bulletin de l'Herbier Boissier. Genève (Imprimerie Romet,...) 1902.
Oct. (<em>Tösstal</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Feb-Jan 1902 (Nat. Nov. Jul (2) 1902; as reprint), p. [i, iii, v], [1]-434, 2 maps. <em>Copy</em>:

2571. <em>Illustrierte Flora von Mittel-Europa</em>. Mit besonderer Berücksichtigung von Oesterreich,
Deutschland und der Schweiz. Zum Gebrauche in den Schulen und zum Selbstunterricht.
München (Verlag von J. F. Lehmann) [1906-1931], 7 vols, in 13. Oct. (<em>Ill. Fl. Mitt.-Eur.</em>).

<em>Cover Lieferung I</em>: "... von Dr. Gustav Hegi ... illustriert unter künstlerischer Leitung von
	Gustav Dunzinger ... Das Werk erscheint in 70 monatlichen Lieferungen ... Jeder Heft
	enthält 4 Tafeln und erklärenden Text."
<em>Illustrations</em>: Gustav Dunzinger (1869-1940).
<em>Vernacular names</em>: Heinrich Marzell (1885-x) (vols. 2-6).
<em>Later collaborators of ed. 1</em>: Albert Thellung (1881-1928) [4(1), 5(1)], Emil Schmid (1891-x)
	[4(1), 4(2)], Robert Keller (1854-1939) [4(2)], Josias Braun-Blanquet (1884- x) [4(2),
	5(1)], Helmut Gams (1893-1976) [4(2), 4(3), 5(1), 5(4), 6(2)], Werner Lüdi (1888-1968)
	[5(1)], Herbert K. E. Beger (1889-1955) [5(1), 5(2), 5(3), 6(2)], Heinrich Marzell (1885-
	x) [5(4)], August von Hayek (1871-1928) [6(1), 6(2)], Hermann Jahn [6(2)]. Hegi
	himself was responsible for almost two thirds of the 7800 pages (Gentner 1933).

Heimans, Eli (1861-1914), Dutch botanist; from 1882 teacher at Amsterdam; leading
popularizer of biology; longtime editor of –De Levende Natuur.– (<em>E. Heimans</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NBV.

PAGE: 138
HEADING: HEIMANS

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM 1418; BL 2: 423, 666; IH 2: 265; JW 1: 443, 2: 192, 3:
354; Kew 2: 631; Rehder 5: 378.
Brouwer, F. I., Leven en werken van E. Heimans en de opbloei der natuurstudie in
	Nederland in het begin van de 20ste eeuw. Groningen 1958, 402 p. (portr., biogr.).
Westhoff, V., Jaarboek Kon. Ned. Bot. Ver., Amsterdam 1965, p. 9-13; Grote Winkler Prins
	9: 238-239. 1969; Mens en Natuur 25(3): 93-98. 1974.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Heimans published a –<em>Geillustreerde flora van Nederland</em>– together with Jac. P. Thijsse
(q.v.) on 6 Mar 1899. From ed. 2 (publ. 12 Mai 1909) onward Hein Willem Heinsius (x-
1939) was added to this team; from ed. 5 onward Jacobus Heimans (1889-x) acted in various
capacities as co-author and editor. We have insufficient information on the many editions
through which this popular flora went up to the present in order to treat this book in any
detail.

Heimans, Jacobus (1889-1978), Dutch botanist; son of Eli Heimans; specialized on
Desmidiaceae, the genus <em>Mentha</em> and the phytogeography of the Netherlands. (<em>J. Heimans</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AMD, NDB.

	<em>Copy</em>: G. – –Brixen a. E.– or Brixen am Eisack is a town in Southern Tirol which became

Hein, Heinrich (<em>fl</em>. 1877), German gardener (–Kunstgärtner–) in Hamburg (<em>H. Hein</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Exsiccatae: <em>Oekonomische Flora</em>, Hamburg 1881; <em>Sammlung

2583. <em>Gräserflora von Nord- und Mittel-Deutschland</em>. Eine genaue Beschreibung der Gattungen
und Arten der im obgenannten Gebiete vorkommenden Gramineen, Cyperaceen und
Juncaceen, mit ganz besonderer Berücksichtigung der Synonymen und Bemerkungen über
den Werth der einzelnen Arten für die Landwirthschaft. Nebst einem Anhange ... Ein
Hülfs- und Nachschlagebuch für Gutsbesitzer, Forst- und Landwirthe, Samenhändler,
Kunst- und Handelsgärtner, Gartenbesitzer, Naturfreunde, Lehrer und Schüler. Weimar
(Bernhard Friedrich Voigt) 1877. Oct. (<em>Gräserfl. N.-Mitt.-Deutschl.</em>).

2592. Laurentii Heisteri ... <em>Descriptio novi generis plantae rarissimae</em> et speciosissimae afri-
canae ex Bulbosarum classe cui in honorem atque sempiternam memoriam serenissimi

nantis tanquam rei herbariae summi promotoris et fautoris munificentissimi Brunsvigiae
illustre nomen imposuit. In qua simul multae botanicorum quorundam hallucinationes
indicantur et emendantur cum tribus magnis tabulis aeneis hujus plantae coloribus natu-
ralibus repraesentatae. Brunsvigae [Braunschweig] (Typis Orphanotrophei) 1753. Fol. (<em>Descr. nov. gen.</em>).

2593. Lorenz Heisters ... <em>Beschreibung eines neuen Geschlechts</em> von einer sehr raren und überaus
schönen Afrikanischen Pflanze aus der Familie der Zwiebelgewächse, welche er zu Ehren
und immerwährenden Andenken des durchlauchigsten Fürsten und Herrn, Herrn Karls isst
regierenden Herzogs zu Braunschweig und Lüneburg als des mildreichesten Beförders aller
und besonders auch der Kräuterwissenschaft den Namen Brunsvigia beygeleget wobey
zugleich viele Irrthümer einiger Kräuterkenner angezeignet und verbessert werden, nebst
drey grossen Kupferplatten worauf obige Pflanze mit lebendigen Farben nach dem Leben
dargestellet wird. Braunschweig (gedruckt im grossen Waysenhause) 1755. Fol. (<em>Beschr. neu.
Geschl</em>.).

	the pre-linnaean 1753 latin version.

Heldreich, Theodor von (1822-1902), German-born botanist; in Greece from 1843-1849
and 1851-1902; plant collector and director of the Athens botanical garden and natural
history museum. (<em>Heldr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: Heldreich distributed many series of exsiccatae which
are enumerated by Index herbariorum and by Briquet (1940). Best known and widespread is
the series <em>Herbarium graecum normale</em> (ser. 1, cent. 1-8, 1854-1861, nos. 1-812, ser. 2, cent. 8-16,
1885-1900, nos. 813-1599).
<em>Ref</em>.: Husnot, T. H., Rev. bryol. 14(4): 52-54. 1887.
	Anon., Bot. Gaz. 32: 379. 1901.
	Greuter, W., Candollea 23(2): 257-265. 1968 (on autograph Herbarium labels).
	Kukkonen, I., Herb. Christian Steven 53. 1971 (1000 specimens).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 334. 1975.
	Steinberg, C., Webbia 32(1): 26. 1977 (material at FI).

152; BJI 2: 73; BM 2: 817; Bossert p. 170; Clokie p. 181; CSP 3: 263, 6: 684, 10: 183-184, 12:

Hellenius, Carl Niclas (from 1816 adl. von Hellens) (1745-1820), Finnish botanist,
professor of economics and natural history at Åbo 1793-1816. (<em>Hell</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Destroyed almost completely in the great fire of Turku (Åbo);
remaining part at H.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kukkonen, I. &amp; Viljamaa, K., Herb. Christ. Steven 53. 1971; Ann. Bot. Fenn. 10: 309-
	336. 1973.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 603; Barnhart 2: 153; BM 2: 818; CSP 3: 264;
Dryander 5: 276; GR p. 617; Kew 2: 638; KR p. 283; LS 11772; MW p. 166; PR 3934-3943
(ed. 1: 4318-4331); Rehder 5: 379-380; Saelan p. 161-164; TR 521-530.
Collander, R., Hist. bot. Finland 14. 1965.
Eriksson, G., Bot. hist. Sverige 283. 1969.
Fries, Th. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(5): 221, 236. 1911.
Hjelt, O. E. A., Naturhistoriens studium i Finland, Helsingfors 1868, p. 168-174 (incl.
	bibliography, p. 169-174); Naturalhistoriens studium vid Åbo universitet, Helsingfors
	1896, p. 327-359 etc.
Scheutz, N. J. W., Bot. Not. 1863: 69.
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 67. 1898.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hellenia</em> A. J. Retzius (1791); <em>Hellenia</em> Willdenow (1797).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Ann. bot. fenn. 10: 333. 1973.

2609. D.D. <em>Hypericum</em>, quod, dissertatione botanico-medica, consens. exper. facult. med.
upsal. praeside viro nobilissimo atque generosissimo, D: no Doct. Carolo à  Linné, ... pro
gradu doctoris, in audit. Carol. maj. die 20 nov. a. 1776. Horis a. et p.m. solitis. Exhibet
Carolus Nicol. Hellenius, Tavastia-Fenno, mag. doc. ad reg. acad. aboënsem. Upsaliae
[Uppsala] (typis Edmannianis) s.d. [1776]. Qu. (<em>Hypericum</em>).

<em>Orig. ed</em>.: 20 Nov 1776, p. [i-iv], [1]-14, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. copper engr. of drawings by Joh.
	Afzelius). <em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY. – Accepted by Krok as having been written by
	Hellenius, in view of the late date. Carl von Linné fil. acted as praeses on behalf of his
	father. (Egenhändiga Anteckningar af Carl Linnaeus 155. 1823) (SO 2459).
<em>Note</em>: last dissertation defended under Linnaeus.
<em>Reprint</em>: <em>in</em> Linnaeus, Amoen. acad., ed. Schreber, 8 (no. 171): 318-332. 1785 (SO 1313).

Heller, Amos Arthur (1867-1944), American plant collector; field agent for USDA 1872-
1896; at the University of Minnesota 1896-1898, from 1908-1913 at the University of
Nevada; from 1913-1938 teacher at Chico high school, Chico, California; founder and
publisher of Muhlenbergia. (<em>A. Heller</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BKL (acquired 1913), WTU (later herb.). Duplicates in many
herbaria, see IH. Many collections with others, especially with his wife Emily Gertrude
Holbach Heller (1869-1939; see Barnhart 2: 153). Early collections at F; Hawaiian col-
lections (1896) at MIN.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: I. <em>Plants of the Hawaiian Islands</em>, coll. 1895, numbered irregularly. See IH for sets.
2. <em>Plants of Porto Rico, Fungi of Porto Rico</em>, see Stevenson (1971).
3. <em>Plants of California</em>, (coll. 1902), <em>California fungi</em> (coll. 1903).
4. <em>North American plants</em> collected chiefly in Southern Virginia in 1893. Richmond 1894 (316
sp.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Gager, Brooklyn Bot. Gard. Record 2: 127. 1913.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 335. 1975.
	Stevenson, J., Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 180-184. 1971.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 153; BL 1: 110, 158, 174, 205, 211, 216, 300; BM
2: 818; Bossert p. 170; CSP 15: 740-741, 18: 791; GR p. 222; Hortus 3: 1195 ("A. Heller");
IF p. 702; IH 2: 267; Kew 2: 638; Langman p. 356-357; Lenley p. 217; LS 11774; NAF
28B(2): 334, ser. 2.2: 16, 5: 241-242; NW p. 48; Pennell p. 609; Rehder 5: 380; Tucker 1:
332; Urban-Berl. p. 267, 355; Zander ed. 10, p. 669.
Anon., Bull. Torrey bot. Cl. 26: 23. 1899 (trip to Porto Rico); J. New York Bot. Gard. 45:
	185-186. 1944.

Heller, Carl Bartholomäus (1824-1880), Moravia-born Austrian traveller and natural-
ist; in Mexico 1845-1848. (<em>C. Heller</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (according to Klášterský in the royal cabinet at Viden
(Bécsben)).

<sm>NAME</sm>: Consistently Carl (not Karl) in his publications. Heller was born 20 Nov 1824 in
	Misliborschitz, Moravia (Czechoslovakia) and died 14 Dec 1880 in Vienna.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 153; BM 2: 818; Futák-Domin p. 242; Jackson
p. 50, 313, 367; Kew p. 638; Klášterský p. 90; Langman p. 357; Rehder 5: 380.
Anon., Flora 64: 16. 1881; Magy. növén. Lap. 5: 15. 1881.
Neilreich, A., Verh. zool.-bot. Ver. Wien 5: 70-71. 1855.
Podpěra,, Květena Hané 1911: 5-11.

Heller, Franz Xaver (1775-1840), German botanist; Dr. med. Würzburg 1800; from 1803
extra-ordinary, from 1805 regular professor of botany at Würzburg University. (<em>F. Heller</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 153; BM 2: 818; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Heller"); IH
2: 267; Kew 2: 638; PR 3944-3946 (ed. 1: 4332-4334); Rehder 5: 380; Tucker 1: 332.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1841: 240.
Steier, Mitt. bayer. bot. Ges. 3(9): 195-206. 1915 (major study, also on his <em>Fl. wirceb</em>.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Helleria</em> C. G. D. Nees &amp; C. F. P. Martius (1824, also dedicated to his brother
Georg Heller, student of the flora of Würzburg). <em>Note: Helleriella</em> A. D. Hawkes (1966), and
<em>Hellerorchis</em> A. D. Hawkes (1959) are dedicated to A. H. Heller, orchidologist, working in
Nicaragua (1956-1966).

2619. <em>Graminum in magno-ducatu wirceburgensi</em> tam sponte <em>crescentium</em>, quam cultorum
enumeratio systematica. In usum auditorum suorum scripsit Dr. F. Xav. Heller, ...
Wirceburgi [Würzburg] (apud Josephum Stahel) 1809. Oct. (<em>Gram. wirceb.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1809 (p. [iv]: 19 Mai 1809), p. [i-iv], [1]-54, [1-2, index]. <em>Copy</em>: NY.

2620. <em>Flora wirceburgensis</em> sive plantarum in magno-ducatu wirceburgensi indigenarum
enumeratio systematica cum earum characteribus generum, specierum differentiis, locis
natalibus et vitae duratione, breviusque descriptionibus in usum tironum dilucidata ...
Wirceburgi [Würzburg] (apud Josephum Stahel) 1810-1815, 2 parts and suppl. Oct. (<em>Fl.
wirceb.</em>).

<em>Pars 1</em>: 1810, p. [i]-xlviii, [1]-586, [index, 1-35].
<em>Pars 2</em>: Jan-Apr 1811, p. [i]-vi, [1]-450, [index, 1-31]. <em>Copies</em>: B (pars 1), BR, G, M, NY; IDC
	916.
<em>Supplementum</em>: 1815 (before Dec, rev. A.L.Z.), p. [i]-iv, [1]-86, [index, 1-5]. <em>Copies</em>: G,
	Regensburg. – "<em>Supplementum florae wirceburgensis</em> continens plantarum genera quaedam
	atque species in magno-ducatu wirceburgensi recenter detecta, nec non observationes
	nonnullas circa plantas indigenas earumque loca natalia. Quod patriae florae cultoribus
	offert Dr. Franc. Xav. Heller ..."

Hellwig, Franz Carl (1861-1889), German botanist; Dr. phil. Breslau (now Wroclaw)
1886; at Karlsruhe with Just 1886-1887; to German New Guinea 1888 as botanist of the New
Guinea Company and head of Kelaua Station. (<em>Hellw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B; further material at BO, L, LE.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 440; Backer p. 259; Barnhart 2: 154; BM 6: 451;
CSP 15: 744-745; DTS 1: 109; IH 2: 267; SK 1: 224-225; Urban-Berl. p. 188, 193.
Cohn, F. J., Jahresber. Schles. Ges. vaterl. Cultur 1889: 154-158.

	185. 1891.

Pax, F., Schlesiens Pflanzenwelt 14. 1915.
Schumann, K. M. &amp; K. Lauterbach, Fl. deut. Schutzgeb. Südsee, Nachtr. 21-23. 1905.
Szweykowski, J., Prodr. fl. hepat. Polon. 561. 1958 (ref. to H's first publ. in Jahresber.
	Westpr. zool.- bot. Ver. 6: 42. 1883 (1884)).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Hempel, Gustav (1842-1904), German-born botanist and forester; studied at the mining
academy of Freiberg 1861-1865 and at the forestry college at Tharand 1866-1868; from
1872-1876 at Giessen University; from 1873 in Austria, at the Mariabrunn Forestry College
and at the Hochschule für Bodenkultur in Wien. (<em>Hemp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 155; BM 2: 821; GF p. 59; Kew 2: 640; NI 845;
Rehder 5: 380; SK 4: clxxxvi.

HEADING: HEMPEL

Bettelheim, A., ed., Biogr. Jahrb. deut. Nekrol. 10: 46*. 1907 (further biogr. refs.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>Centralblatt für das gesammte Forstwesen</em>, co-editor 1875-1877, sole editor
1877-1882; <em>Österreichische Forstzeitung</em>, editor 1882-1894.

US, USDA. – The 60 plates are chromolithographs of paintings by W. Liepoldt; there are
342 figures in the text.

Hemsley, William Botting (1843-1924), British botanist at Kew (1865-1867); worked as
a private scientist 1867-1883, from 1883-1908 again at Kew in various capacities, ultimately
(1899-1908) as keeper of the herbarium and library. (<em>Hemsl</em>.).

<sm>HEBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K. – (British herbarium via Freeman Clarke Samuel Roper 1819-
1896). Letters and mss. also at K.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kent, D. H., Brit. herb. 59. 1957.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 260, 261; Barnhart 2: 155; BB p. 144; BJI 1: 26, 2:
73; BL 1: 34, 77, 86, 87, 89, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95, 96, 99, 100, 102, 114, 115, 117, 125, 126, 128,
146, 237, 300, 2: 270, 667; Blunt p. 212, 272; BM 2: 821, 6: 451; Bret. p. 820-823; CSP 7: 947,
10: 190-191, 12: 324, 14: 306, 15: 752, 16: 535; Desmond p. 299; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Hemsl.");
HR; IF p. 702; Jackson p. 557 [index]; Kew 2: 641-642; Langman p. 357-358; Lenley p.
220; LS 11794; MW p. 167-172, suppl. p. 95; NAF 28B: 334-334; NI 846; Rehder 5: 380-
381; SK p. 225; TL-2/1094, 1176, 1290, 1814; Tucker 1: 332, 333; Zander ed. 10, p. 669.
A.D.C., J. Bot. 63: 21-23. 1925.
Anon., Catal. libr. R.B.G. Kew 268. 1899 (bibl.) (Bull. misc. Inf. Kew add. ser. 3); Bull.
	misc. Inf. Kew 1924: 389-392; Gard. Chron. 76: 275-276. 1924;. Kew Guild 4(32): 331-
	337. 1925 (portr.), J. Bot. 62: 344. 1924.

D.P., Proc. Roy. Soc. ser. B. 98: i-ix. 1925.

2625. <em>Handbook of hardy trees</em>, shrubs, and herbaceous plants. Containing descriptions, native
countries, etc. of a selection of the best species in cultivation. Together with cultural details,
comparative hardiness, suitability for particular positions, etc. Based on the french work of
Messrs. Decaisne and Naudin ... entitled 'Manuel de l'Amateur des Jardins', and including
the original woodcuts by Riocreux and Leblanc. By W. B. Hemsley, ... with an in-
troduction by Edward S. Rand, Junr. ... with nearly 300 illustrations. Boston (Estes &amp;
Lauriat) 1873. Oct. (<em>Handb. hardy trees</em>).

plain lithographs by W. H. Fitch; plate <em>110</em> is a map.

previously described in no. 2626.

	author's "<em>Tabular view of the vegetable kingdom</em>, arranged according to the natural orders.

Hennings, Paul Christoph (1841-1908), German self-taught cryptogamist, originally
employed by the postal services; from 1874-1880 at the Botanical Garden Kiel (with
Eichler); from 1880 onward at the Botanical Museum, Berlin-Dahlem; appointed royal
professor 1902. (<em>Henn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (for the greater part extant); other material at C, H, HBG, K,
KIEL, L, S, W. Exsiccatae: (1) <em>Phycotheca marchica</em> (fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-100, Berlin 1893-1906),
sets at B, BR, FH, KIEL, L, PAD, SI, W. (Hedwigia 32: 104-108. Mar-Apr 1893, Nat. Nov.
Mar 1893); (2) <em>Kryptogamen- Typen</em>, Hamburg 1880 (120 cellular crypt. with some text and <em>22
plates</em>, n.v.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Fischer-Benzon, R. J. D. von, <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schleswig-Holstein 2: 23-24. 1890.
	Dennis, R. W. G., Taxon 1: 64. 1952 (isotypes at K).
	Kohlmeyer in Potztal, Willdenowia 2: 783. 1961 (mycol. herb. extant).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 78-79. 1969.
	Hiepko, P., Willdenowia 8: 391. 1978.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 228, 343; Backer p. 261; Barnhart 2: 158; BJI
1: 26, 2: 73; BM 2: 824, 6: 453; Bossert p. 171; CSP 13: 71, 794, 15: 760-761; De Toni 1: xxix;

<em>Hennings, Paul Christoph</em> (<em>1841-1908</em>), <em>bibl. &amp; biogr. ctd.</em>

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Hennings was an amateur poet; Lindau (1909) reproduces his plattdeutsch hed-
gehock story in addition to some rhymes dealing with idiosyncrasies of botanists such as his
note on the principle of priority: "Eifrigst durchstöbern sie früh bis spät / Vermoderte
Folianten, / Nach denen schon längst kein Hahn mehr kräht, / Die kaum vom Hören sie
kannten- / Sie suchen Autoren der Vorweltzeit, / Verschollene Pflanzennamen, / Die werden
von Staub und Moder befreit, / Gefügt in neue Rahmen." It is perhaps good to take this
poem out of its prehistoric (vorweltlich) dust and mud, by putting it in this more modern
frame-work (Rahmen). Murrill (1945) did not share Lindau's generous opinion of Hen-
nings: "H. was an excitable, unreliable sort of person who perspired over dusty bundles of
fungi sent in from the uttermost parts of the earth to the Berlin Botanic Garden where Engler
was director. He inspired my distrust when he claimed to remember the spore measurements
of scores of species. Maybe he did." See also Dennis (1952). For a critical evaluation of H's
mycological work see e.g. Höhnel (1911).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Henningsia</em> F. A. G. J. Möller (1895); <em>Henningsiella</em> Rehm (1895); <em>Henningsinia</em> F. A.
G. J. Möller (1901); <em>Henningsocarpum</em> O. Kuntze (1891); <em>Henningsomyces</em> O. Kuntze (1898);
<em>Henningsomyces</em> P. A. Saccardo (1905); <em>Neohenningsia</em> S. H. Koorders (1907).

Schmidt &amp; Klaunig) 1876. Oct. (<em>Standorts-Verz. Gefässpfl. Kiel.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Oct-Nov 1876, p. [1]-64, [i]-v, [1, err.]. <em>Copy</em>: HBG. – Reprinted from Schrift. naturw.
	Ver. Schlesw.-Hoist. 2: 147-208. 1876. For a <em>Nachtrag</em> see ib. 4: 71-79. Oct-Nov 1883.

Durieu (1855) and <em>Henophyton</em> Cosson &amp; Durieu (1856) are dedicated to Adrien Hénon (<em>fl</em>.
1849-1859), French military interpreter and later teacher of Arabic in Algeria, who made
botanical collections in that country. <em>Henoniella</em> J. E. Duby (1877) is dedicated to Augustin
Hénon, son of J. L. Hénon, who collected Musci in Japan.

Henrard, Jan Theodor (1881-1974), Dutch agrostologist and malacologist; studied
pharmacy at Groningen (1901-1906) under Eykman; practicing pharmacist at Gorinchem
1909-1915, at the Hague 1915-1922; from 1921-1946 curator of the Rijksherbarium at
Leiden, Dr. phil. (plant taxonomy) Utrecht 1929 under Pulle. (<em>Henr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L; other material B, BR, LAS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12 (2): 404; Backer p. 261; Barnhart 2: 158; BL 2: 423,
667; Bossert p. 171; Kew 2: 646; IH 2: 269; JW 2: 192; Langman p. 359; Lenley p. 220; MW
p. 173, suppl. p. 95.
Kuiper, Basteria 39(3-6): 69-74. 1975 (on H's work as a malacologist).
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30 (1): 148. 1947 (bibl. Pacif. Isl.).
Ooststroom, S. J. van, Blumea 22(2): 156-157. 1975 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Pulle, <em>Flora of Suriname, Gramineae</em> (with G. J. H. Amshoff).

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Blumea, supplement iii, Jubileumdeel voor Dr. J. Th. Henrard Jubilee volume
1946. Leiden, p. [1]-125, [126], with portraits of H., dedication by H. J. Lam, a biographical
sketch by W. A. Goddijn and a botanical bibliography by H. J. v. d. Hee.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Henrardia</em> C. E. Hubbard (1946).

Henriques, Julio Augusto (1838-1928), Portuguese botanist, ultimately professor of
botany and director of the botanical garden at Coimbra. (<em>Henriq</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: Dec 1880 [?, or 1881] (p. [5]: Cal. Dec 1880; Hedwigia Mai 1882), p. [1]-65. <em>Copies</em>:
	BR, MO. – Apart from the late notice by Hedwigia we have no further indication that the
	publication did not come out in 1880; however, De Toni (1891) lists it for 1881.

Henry, Aimé Constant Fidèle (1801-1875), French-born (Douai) artist, lithographer

founded the firm Henry and Cohen; published many illustrated botanical works. (<em>A. Henry</em>).
and publisher; came to Germany in 1816 to work with Arnz &amp; Co., Düsseldorf; later at Bonn,

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 159; BM 2: 824; Bret. p. 774, 1092; CSP 3: 283;

(2) See Nissen (1933) for a list of books with lithographs coming from the Henry &amp; Cohen
firm.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Henrya</em> C. G. D. Nees (1845). <em>Note: Henryettana</em> A. Brand (1929) is dedicated to
Mrs. Augustine Henry (1857-1930), Irish botanist, dendrologist, who collected in China.
<em>Henrya</em> W. B. Hemsley (1889), <em>Henryastrum</em> Happ (1937), and <em>Neohenrya</em> W. B. Hemsley
(1892) are also named after Augustine Henry, but at the same time commemorate the
Reverend Benjamin Couch Henry (1850-1901), who collected in China. <em>Henrica</em> Bouley de
Lesdain (1921) is dedicated to Abbé Joseph Henry (<em>fl</em>. 1903-1914), who worked and
collected in Italy.

	accompanied by the same plates.

Henry, Joseph Kaye (1866-1930), Canadian botanist, at first high school teacher at

Henslow, Rev. George (1835-1925), British clergyman, B. A. Cambridge 1858; teacher,
popular writer and lecturer; son of J. S. Henslow; brother-in-law of J. D. Hooker; curate of
Steyning, Sussex (1858-1861); headmaster of Hampton Lucy Grammar School 1861-1865,
id. at London, Stove Street, 1865-1886; lecturer to St. Bartholomew's medical school (1886-
1890); hon. professor of botany to the Royal Horticultural Society. (<em>G. Hensl</em>.).

Hepp, Johann Adam Philipp (1797-1867), German physician, lichenologist and political
activist who lived in exile in Switzerland 1851-1867. (<em>Hepp</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (2406 lich., 770 bryoph., 1640 algae). Algae also at G. <em>Exsiccatae</em>:
(1) <em>Die Flechten Europas</em> in getrockneten mikroskopisch untersuchten Exemplaren mit Be-
schreibung und Abbildung ihrer Sporen. Vols. 1-16, fasc. 1-32, nos. 1-962. Zürich (Meyer
und Zeller), 1853-1867, vols. 13-16 published by Jean Müller Argoviensis (1826-1896). Sets
in many herbaria, e.g. B, BRN, BM, CM, FH, G, NY, O, PC, S, STR, UPS. Text issued
separately as <em>Abbildungen und Beschreibungen der Sporen</em> ... see no. 2663. A continuation of
Schaerer, <em>Lichenes helvetici exsiccati</em>.
(2) <em>Systematische Sammlung</em> der von Dr. Hepp im Kanton Zürich selbstaufgefundenen Flech-
ten, nebst ihrer mikroskopisch untersuchten Sporen, geordnet nach Schaerer's Enumeratio
critica lichen, eur. fasc. 1, <em>pl. 1-18</em>, nos. 1-250. Zürich 1849-1852. Sets at B, HAL.
<em>Ref</em>.: LS 12087 (dates, numbers of (1)).
	Nylander, Bull. Soc. bot. France 1: 257-259, 319-320. 1854.

Herbert, William (1778-1847), British botanist who entered the Anglican ministry in
1814, active at Spotforth, Yorkshire. (<em>Herb</em>.).

<sm>TYPES</sm>: Hitchcock (List 2: 12) states that Herbert's types are at K. Mr. J. P. M. Brenan kindly
informs us that there are indeed some types of Herbert in the Kew herbarium, mostly
based on other people's collections. No plant collections made by Herbert are known to be at
K. Some drawings are at the Royal Horticultural Society. Further investigation is needed.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 442, 569; Barnhart 2: 162; Backer p. 262; BB p. 146;
BM 2: 827; Bret. p. 284; CSP 3: 305; Dawson p. 509; Desmond p. 303; DNB 26: 234; Frank
3(Anh.): 43; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Herb."); Jackson p. 100, 123, 558; Kew 2: 655; Langman p.
359; Moebius p. 350; MW p. 175; NI 857; Plesch p. 255; PR 3983-3984 (ed. 1: 4381-4382);
Rehder 5: 385; RS p. 87; Zander ed. 10, p. 669.
Anon., Bot. Zeit. 5: 636-637. 1847; Flora 30: 656. 1847.
Dallman and Wood, Trans. Liverpool bot. Soc. 1: 73. 1903.
Guimond, A. A., The honorable and very reverend William Herbert, thesis. Madison, Wisc.
	[not publ.]. (bibl. on p. 218-231) (University Microfilms) (xerox copy FAS); also: <em>in</em> C. C.
	Gillispie, DSB 6: 295-297. 1972 (bibl., q.v. for various refs. not quoted here).
Nelmes &amp; Cuthbertson, Curtis's Bot. Magaz. Dedic. 1827-1927. p. 46. 1932 (portr.).

Herbich, Franz (1791-1865), Austrian military surgeon and botanist, at Naples 1821-1824,
from 1824 active mainly in Galicia and the Bucowina. (<em>Herbich</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; other material at CERN and WRSL. Herbich left his library and

Herder, Ferdinand Gottfried Maximilian Theobald von (1828-1896), German bo-
tanist who studied law at Erlangen but who was denied admittance to the bar on political
grounds; to St. Petersburgh 1856 in various functions (ultimately librarian) at the herbarium.
of the imperial botanical garden; Dr. phil. Leopoldina 1863; returned to Germany (Grün-
stadt) 1892, "Vermittler zwischen den russischen und deutschen Botanikern." (<em>Herder</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE.
<em>Ref</em>.: Lipsky, V. I., Herb. S. Petersb. bot. Sada 95. 1898.

12098-12098a; MW p. 175, suppl. p. 96; PR 3989; Rehder 5: 385; SO 3659; TR 538-551,

2683. <em>De olerum vernalium praestantia</em>. Leipzig 1763. (n.v.). (<em>Oler. vern.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 18 Feb 1763 (preface?; fide Rothmaler).
<em>Ref</em>.: Rothmaler, W., Repert. Sp. nov. 53(1): 35. 1944.

Hermann, Paul (1646-1695), Dutch botanist and explorer of German birth, travelled in
Africa, India and Ceylon, professor of botany at Leiden 1680-1695. (<em>P. Herm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm>: The main Hermann herbarium was acquired by Sir Joseph Banks and is now at
BM. It is the basis of Hermann's <em>Museum zeylanicum</em> and of Linné's <em>Flora zeylanica</em> and contains
many Linnaean types with annotations in Linnaeus's own handwriting. Another Hermann
herbarium of Ceylon plants is at L. (IDC microfiche 8302/1). The Hermann herbarium on
which the <em>Thesaurus zeylanicus</em> of Johannes Burman (TL-2/928) is based is at the Institut de
France. In the absence of Linnaean Flora zeylanica types from the London herbarium, the
Burman herbarium should be consulted. The original collection of plants made by Hermann
at the Cape of Good Hope in 1672 is incorporated in Hortus Siccus 75 of the Sloane
herbarium (BM). For an extensive study of Hermann's activities at the Cape and of his
collections see M. C. Karsten (1967). Another important Hermann herbarium (mainly
Ceylonese) is at Gotha (see Rauschert 1970 who also provides an extensive bibliography on
the Hermann herbaria); several Hermann specimens are in the Thunberg herbarium
(UPS).

PAGE: 172
HEADING: HERMANN, P.

<em>Ref</em>.: Trimen, H., J. Linn. Soc. Bot. 24: 129-155. 1887 (Ceylon herb.).

Herold, Johann Moritz David (1790-1862), German entomologist at Marburg. (<em>Herold</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Herold is a pseudonym for Schoepfer or Schroepfer ("miser quidam librorum
consarcinator, ..." PR), a German plagiarist who also published under the name Edvard
Brandes (q.v.). Schoepfer may well have (mis-)used J. M. D. Herold's name for the
pseudonymous authorship of his <em>Taschenbuch</em> which is attributed to "Professor Dr. Herold."
See Barnhart 2: 162 and PR 4004 (ed. 1: 4409).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 13: 501-502 (J. M. D. Herold); Barnhart 2: 162; PR
4004 (ed. 1: 4409); Rehder 1: 381.

PAGE: 174
HEADING: HEROLD

2689. <em>Taschenbuch der teutschen Flora</em>. Ein Hülfsbuch auf botanischen Excursionen zur mög-
lichst schnellen und sichern Bestimmung der aufgefundenen Pflanzen. Vom Prof. Dr.
Herold. Nordhausen (bei Friedrich Fürst) 1845. Duod. (in sixes). (<em>Taschenb. teut. Fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jul-Auf 1845 (Bot. Zeit. 22 Aug 1845 p. [1]-460. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – A pirated version of
	W. D. J. Koch's <em>Synopsis, not</em> to be attributed to J. M. D. Herold (see Bot. Zeit. 5: 15. 1847).
	Withdrawn from the trade, fide Flora 28: 348-351. 1845.

Herpell, Gustav Jacob (1828-1912), German cryptogamist from the Rhine valley near St.
Goar. (<em>Herp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (exsiccatae and dupl. extant); other material at BP, IBF, KIEL.
H's mosses came to B in 1905 (not extant); his private herbarium is also no longer extant.

BM, FH, HBG, KIEL, MANCH, OXF, S.

4	76-95	Jun 1884 (Bot. Zeit. 29 Aug 1884),
5	96-115	Sep 1888 (Hedwigia Jul-Aug 1888),
6	116-135	Mai 1892 (Hedwigia Jan-Feb 1893).

	1888 (see LS for further refs.).

Herre, Albert William Christian Theodore (1868-1962), American ichthyologist and
botanist; Ph. D. Stanford Univ. 1909; in various functions in Nevada, California, Washing-
ton and Manila 1910-1928; from 1928-1946 curator of the ichthyological collections,
Natural history Museum, Stanford University. (<em>Herre</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LASCA (Rev. bryol. 30: 285. 1961); remaining collection, including
botanical library and correspondence, at DS (acquired 1962); ichthyological correspon-
dence at CAS. (Information J. H. Thomas). For duplicates see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 164; Bossert p. 173; GR p. 190, pl. [43], cat. p.
65; Hawksworth p. 183; 1H 2: 271; LS 12124-12125, 34518-35521, suppl. 11342-11346;
Roon p. 51; SBC p. 122 ("Herre"); SK 1: 227, 5: cclxxv, 8: xliii; Stevenson p. 1244.
Anon., The San Francisco Chronicle, 18 Jan 1962, p. 36; San Francisco Examiner, 18 Jan
	1962, p. 49.
Ewan, J., <em>in</em> Century progr. nat. sci. 51. 1955; Short hist. bot. U.S. 95. 1969.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Herrea</em> Schwantes (1927) and <em>Herreanthus</em> Schwantes (1928) are dedicated to
Adolar Gottlieb Julius (Hans) Herre (1895-x), German horticulturist and botanist, working
in South Africa, specialist in the succulent Aizoaceae. <em>Herreriopsis</em> H. Perrier de la Bâthie
(1934) is related to <em>Herreria</em> Ruiz &amp; Pavon (1794), which commemorates Ildephonso de
Herrera (probably: Gabriel Alonso de Herrera (1470-?), Spanish agricultural writer.

Herter, Wilhelm Gustav Franz (Guillermo Herter) (1884-1958), German botanist; Dr.
phil. Berlin 1908, resided in Uruguay 1907, 1909-1910 and 1923-1939; in Germany 1939-
1941; at Cracow in Poland 1941-1944; later Uruguayan consul at Bern and Basel; ultimately
in Hamburg. (<em>Herter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G; in herb. Stiftung Paul Aellen (20.000 specimens) (G-PAE).
Herter's <em>Plantae uruguayenses exsiccatae</em> (cent. 1427, nos. 1-2700) are in many herbaria.
<em>Ref</em>.: Stevenson, J., Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 185-192. 1971.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 337. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 166; BJI 2: 74; BL 1: 259, 260, 301; Bossert p.
173; GR p. 88-89, <em>pl</em>. [<em>18</em>]; Hortus 3: 1195; IF suppl. 3: 210, 4: 323; IH 2: 272; Jackson p.
259; Kew 2: 661; LS 12130, suppl. 11418-11432; MW p. 176, suppl. p. 97; TL-2/see Aellen,
P.; Urban-Berl. p. 276, 320, 356; Zander ed. 10, p. 669.
Aellen, P., Jahresber. Stiftung "Herbarium Paul Aellen" 1961/2: 11-12. 1962.
Anon., Flora, Quito 1(2): 140-146. 1937.
