Herzer, Herman[n] (1833-1912), German-born American itinerant Methodist minister
and palaeobotanist active in the Geological Survey of the State of Ohio. (<em>Herzer</em>).

<sm>COLLECTIONS</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Invertebrate coll. at Baldwin-Wallace College, Berea, Ohio.
Location of fossil plant coll. unknown, possibly at Marietta College, Ohio (inf. J. M.
Schopf).

Herzfeld, Stephanie (1868-1930), Austrian high school teacher and botanist; Dr. phil.
Wien 1923; for many years honorary collaborator at WU; pupil of Wettstein. (<em>Herzfeld</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Herzog, Theodor [Carl Julius] (1880-1961), German bryologist who collected widely
e.g. in Sardinia (1904, 1906), Ceylon (1905-1908) and Bolivia (1907-1912); Dr. phil.
München 1903; Dr. phil. h.c. Greifswald 1955; professor of botany at München (1920-
1925), at Jena (1925-1948). (<em>Herz</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: JE (26.000); duplicates in many herbaria. The original Bolivian
collections were (are) at B. Herzog left his herbarium, library and preparations to the
University of Jena under the condition that they were to be kept as a unit and that the
collection of hepatics plus literature would always be accessible to his last pupil, R. Grolle.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Rev. bryol. lichén. 30(3/4): 285. 1961 (disposal herb.).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 337-338. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> AND <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 167; BJ1 2: 74; BM 6: 459-460; BL 1: 237, 301;
Bossert p. 173; CSP 15: 810; GR p. 89; IH 2: 272; Kew 2: 662; Langman p. 367; Lenley p.
222; LS suppl. 11443; Moebius p. 123; MW p. 177, suppl. p. 97; NAF ser. 2. 9: 123; NDB 8:
741-742; Rehder 5: 388; Roon p. 51; SBC p. 122 ("Herz."); SK 1: 227, 5: cclxxv; TL-
2/1712, 1983; Tucker 1: 337; Urban-Berl. p. 302, 356.
Benedix, Feddes Report 65(1/2): 1-2. 1962.
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2. 168, 170, 182, 186, 187. 1941.
Bischler &amp; Jovet-Ast, Rev. bryol. lichén. 38(3/4): 329. 1972 (Sardinian hepatics).

Gaertner, Akad. Ski. Club München, Ber. 1961: 6-9 (fide Mägdefrau).
Geheeb, A., Rev. bryol. 33: 48, 64. 1906, 34: 104. 1907.

Hesler, Lexemuel Ray (1888-1977), American mycologist, born in Indiana, graduate of
Wabash College, phytopathologist at Cornell University 1912-1919, at University of Ten-
nessee, Knoxville, Tenn. 1919-x. (<em>Hesler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: TENN; further material at IAC, MICH and NY.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The authors met Dr. Hesler, full of activity, Nov 1976 during a visit to Knoxville,
Tenn. He kindly made available to us a copy of his unpublished "North American
mycologists" (1975), a manuscript quoted many times in TL-2. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, TENN, FAS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> AND <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 167; Bossert p. 173; Hirsch p. 121; IH 2: 272;
Kew 2: 662; LS suppl. 11451-11458; Roon p. 51; Stevenson p. 1245.
Anon., Amer. Men Sci. eds. 3, 4, 5 (fide Barnhart).

Heufler zu Rasen und Perdonegg, Ludwig Samuel Joseph David Alexander,
(later, 1865) Freiherr von Hohenbühel (1817-1885), Austrian cryptogamist and state official
(k.k. wirklicher Kämmerer 1853, Ministerialrath 1864). (<em>Heufl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: Sold after the author's death; present location unknown. However,
Heufler had already deposited much of his herbarium material at IBF during his lifetime.
Further material at B, H, LE, LZ, W, WA (mentioned by Sayre (1978) for Musci).
manuscripts at IBF.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Gaz. 11: 287. 1886 (30.000 specimens); Flora 69: 290, 322, 376. 1886.
	Koster, J. T., Taxon 18: 553. 1969 (algae at IBF).
	Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 509-510. 1978.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Published as "Heufler" until 1865 when he received his baronetcy; from then on H.
used the name Hohenbühel-Heufler in his scientific publications.

	first was the actual author.

2738. <em>Das natürliche Pflanzensystem</em>. Ein Versuch, die gegenseitigen Verwandtschaften der
Pflanzen aufzufinden, durch Andeutung ihrer Bildungsstufen, Uebergänge, Ausnahmen,
mit Berücksichtigung der arzneilichen und überhaupt anwendbaren Gewächse, nebst einer
historischen Einleitung. Gemeinfasslich dargestellt und zunächst für angehende Apotheker,
Aerzte &amp;c. bearbeitet von Gustav Heynhold. Mit einer Vorrede von Dr. Heinrich Ficinus,
professor sc. ... Dresden und Leipzig (in der Arnoldischen Buchhandlung) 1840. Oct. (<em>Nat. Pfl.-Syst.</em>).

<em>Preface</em>: Heinrich David August Ficinus (1782-1817).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1840 (p. v: 16 Jan 1840), p. [i]-viii, [1]-181, [1-2, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: M, NY.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: Leipzig (Arnoldischen Buchhandlung) 1850. Oct. <em>publ</em>.: 1850, p. [i]-viii, [1]-181.
	<em>Copy</em>: B.

2739. <em>Nomenclator botanicus hortensis</em> oder alphabetische und synonymische Aufzählung der in
den Gärten Europa's cultivirten Gewächse, nebst Angabe ihres Autors, ihres Vaterlandes,
ihrer Dauer und Cultur, bearbeitet von Gustav Heynhold nebst einer Vorrede von Dr.
Ludwig Reichenbach. Dresden und Leipzig (in der Arnoldischen Buchhandlung) [1840-
1841], 2 vols. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Nom. bot. hort.</em>).

Vol.	Heft	pages	dates
----------------------------------------------------------------
1	[1]-2	1-408, [i]-xx	27 Sep-3 Oct 1840 (Hinrichs)
2	3[-?]	409-888	Jul 1841 (postface 6 Jul 1841)

<em>Copies</em>: G, L, MO, NY, USDA; IDC 796. – Hinrichs mentions Heft 3 (pp. 409-?) for 7-13
Mar 1841. From this is would seem that volume 2 came out in more than one part. A <em>zweiter
Band</em> was published in 1846 under a separate main title (see no. 2742).
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 6: 13-15. 7 Jan 1848.

2740. <em>Flora von Sachsen</em>. Beschreibung der im Königreiche Sachsen, dem Herzogthume
Sachsen preussischen Antheils, den Grossherzoglich und Herzoglich Sächsischen Landen
Ernestinischer Linie, den Herzoglich Anhaltischen, Fürstlich Schwarzburgischen und
Fürstlich Reussischen Landen wildwachsenden und allgemein angebauten Pflanzen, mit
besonderer Berücksichtigung ihrer Anwendung in der Pharmacie, Technologie und Oeko-
nomie &amp;c. bearbeitet von Dr. Friedrich Holl, ... und Gustav Heynhold, ... Erster Band.
Dresden (Verlag von Justus Naumann) 1842. Oct (<em>Fl. Sachsen</em>).

HEADING: HEYNHOLD

<em>Co-author</em> (of entire work as planned; Heynhold was sole author of the only volume which
	appeared, vol. 1): Carl Friedrich Holl (<em>fl</em> 1840-1850).
<em>Erste Abtheilung</em>: 1842, p. [ii]-x, [1], [1]-348.
[<em>Zweite Abtheilung</em>:] late 1842 (Flora rd. Nov.Dec 1842), p. [i-ii], [349]-862, [1, err.].
<em>Copies</em>: B, G, M, NY, Regensburg, USDA.
<em>Title-pages</em>: (1) With text as above, issued with second part.
(2) As above, but e.g. with "Erster Band. Erste Abtheilung," in all copies seen as p. [ii].
(3) in some copies as p. [iii]: "Flora von Sachsen. Erster Band: Phanerogamie von Gustav
	Heynhold. Erste Abtheilung."
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Lit. Ber. Flora [12]: 101-106. 7 Dec 1842.

2741. <em>Clavis generum zur Flora von Sachsen</em> von Dr. Friedrich Holl und Gustav Heynhold. Eine
synoptische Darstellung der zu diesem Florengebiet gehörigen Gattungen der ersten Ab-
theilung (der Phanerogamen), zum erleichterten Bestimmen, nebst einem deutschen Re-
gister derselben. Bearbeitet von Gustav Heynhold ... Dresden (Verlag von Justus Nau-
mann) 1843. Oct. (<em>Clav. gen. Fl. Sachsen</em>).

<em>Co-Author</em>: Carl Friedrich Holl (<em>fl</em>. 1840-1850).
<em>Publ</em>.: Aug-Jun 1843 (Bot. Zeit. 7 Jul 1843), p. [i], [1], 70. <em>Copies</em>: G, M.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 1: 471-472. 7 Jul 1843.

2742. <em>Alphabetische und synonymische Aufzählung der</em> in der Jahren 1840 bis 1846 in den
europäischen Gärten eingeführtcn <em>Gewächse</em> nebst Angabc ihres Autors, ihres Vaterlandes,
ihrer Dauer und Cultur. Ein Hilf- und Ergänzungbuch zu den Werken von Dietrich,
Dumont-Courset, Loudon, Sweet, Steudel u.s.w. nach dem neuesten Quellen bearbeitet.
Dresden/Leipzig (in der Arnoldischen Buchhandlung) 1846[-1847]. (<em>Alph. Aufz. Gew.</em>).

	<em>Zweiter</em> Band of the above-mentioned <em>Nomenclator botanicus hortensis</em> (2739). Came out in at
	least three parts, possibly more. Pages [i]-viii, [1]-144, were reviewed by Bot. Zeit. 16 Oct.
	1846 (p. viii dated Mai 1846), p. 145-384(?) came out later in 1846, p. 385(?)-774 came

<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 4: 734. 16 Oct 1846, 6: 13-15. 7 Jan 1848.

Hick, Thomas (1840-1896), British botanist who studied and lectured (1861-1876) at the
Lancasterian School at Leeds; from 1876-1886 science master at Pannall College, Har-
rogate, 1886-1896 lecturer at Owens College, Manchester. (<em>Hick</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MANCH; fossil collections also at Manchester Museum. Letters at
Kew.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Hick's <em>Synopsis of the leading natural orders of British flowering plants</em>, ed. 2, London (J. E.
Lornish), was published Apr-Mai 1891 (Nat. Nov. Jun 1891; Bot. Zeit. 26 Jan 1891).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 278; Barnhart 2: 171; BB p. 147; BM 2: 841;

Britten, J., J. Bot. 34: 108. 1896.

Hick, T., J. Bot. 21: 198-200. Dec 1883 (Ranunculus ficaria).

Murray, J. Bot. 34: 488. 1896.

Hicken, Cristóbal Maria (1875-1933), Argentine botanist; founder (1911) of the Instituto
botanico Darwinion at San Martin, later at San Isidro; Dr. sci. Buenos Aires, 1906; Lecturer
at the Collegio militar (1899-1928) and simultaneously at various other schools in Buenos
Aires. (<em>Hicken</em>).

Hiern, William Philip (1839-1925), British botanist of independent means who worked at
Kew and BM; M.A. Oxford 1868. (<em>Hiern</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Hiern's British herbarium is at RAMM; his non-British collections
are at CGE. The types of the <em>Catalogue</em> (see below) are at BM. This set of Welwitsch
specimens was the second one; the first, ("study set") was returned to Lisbon (LISU) upon a
law-suit after Welwitsch's death in 1873.
<em>Ref</em>.: Murray, Hist. Coll. BMNH 190. 1904.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: "I refuse to tamper with Greenwich time" (to Rendle when travelling in Australia
with his watch at G.M.T.).

HEADING: HIERONYMUS

Hieronymus, Georg Hans Emmo (Emo) Wolfgang (1846-1921), German botanist and
plant collector; Dr. phil. Halle 1872; at Cordoba, Argentina, 1874-1883; from 1883-1892
Privatgelehrter at Breslau; at Berlin-Dahlem from 1892. (<em>Hieron</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main collections at B (herb. rd. 1892; fern collection extant), but
much material also at CORD. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Flora argentina</em> (1872-1883) at B, CORD, GH,
L, MO, NY, P, SP. – (2) <em>Herbarium cecidiologicum</em> (later ctd. by R. Dittrich and F. Pax), Lief.
1-15, nos. 1-121, 121a-425. 1892-1907.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 267; Barnhart 2: 172; BJI 1: 26-27, 2: 75-76; BM 2:
842, 6: 463; BL 1: 232, 235, 236, 255, 301; Bossert p. 174; CSP 7: 977, 10: 226, 12: 333, 15:
833-834; De Toni 1 : lxiv, 4: xxix-xxx; DTS 1: 117; Hortus 3: 1195; IF p. 702-703, suppl. 1:
82, 2: 36, 3: 211; IH 2: 274; Jackson p. 127; Kew 2: 678-679; KR p. 295; Langman p. 369;
LS 12278; Moebius p. 127; MW p. 177-178; NAF ser. 2. 2: 160, 5: 242; Nordstedt p. 18;
Rehder 5: 391-392; Tucker 1: 340; Urban-Berl. p. 265, 276, 287, 302, 356; Zander ed. 10, p.
670.
A.C., Physis 5: 346-348. 1922.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1921: 147; Nuov. Notar. 23: 88-89. 1922; Marcellia 19: xxxv. 1922.
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2. 44. 1941.

Maxon, W. R., Amer. Fern. J. 12(1): 31-32. 1922.
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 150-151. 1947.

Pilger, R., Hedwigia 62: [i-iv]. 1921 (portr.).

	(portr.).

	1897.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Hieronymus also published the series <em>Botanische Bilderbogen</em> (als Lehrmittel für den
Unterricht in der Morphologie der Pflanzen) serie I. in 100 Tafeln (15 morph., 85 flower
diagrams), Breslau, January 1884; a series of plates (used for lectures) with which many
present-day continental botanists became acquainted in the early phases of their careers).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hieronymiella</em> Pax (1890); <em>Hieronymusia</em> Engler (1918).

Hiesey, William McKinley [until 5 Feb 1935: Heusi, W.M.] (1903-x), American exper-
imental systematist and plant physiologist; with H. M. Hall, J. Clausen and D. D. Keck
founder of the California school of multidisplinary plant systematics; employed by the
Carnegie Institution, Stanford, in various capacities from 1926-1969; currently emeritus
staff member. (<em>Hiesey</em>).

Hildebrand, Friedrich Hermann Gustav (1835-1915), German botanist; studied with
Caspary and A. Braun, Dr. phil. Berlin 1858; to Bonn 1859 as Privatdocent; to Freiburg im
Breisgau (1868-1907) as successor to Julius Sachs. (<em>Hildebr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Specimens of cultivated <em>Oxalis</em> at K.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with the traveller and collector in Africa Johann Maria Hilde–
brandt (1847-1881), see IH 2: 275. Friedrich Hildebrand's name is often erroneously spelled
Hildebrandt.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 173; BJI 1: 27, 2: 76; BM 2: 843; Bossert p. 175;
CSP 3: 349, 7: 978-980, 10: 228, 12: 333, 15: 838; De Toni 1 : lxiv; Frank 3 (Anh.): 44; Hortus
3: 1195; IH 2: 275; Jackson p. 559 [index]; Kew 2: 680-681; Langman p. 369; LS 12289-
12291; Moebius p. 358, 359, 364; NAF 2(1): 71; PR 4053-4057, 10577; Rehder 5: 392; SK 5:
cclxxxv; Stevenson p. 1245; Tucker 1: 340; Zander ed. 10, p. 670.

Hill, [Sir] Arthur William (1875-1941), British botanist; demonstrator (1899), later
lecturer (1904) at Cambridge; D.Sc. Cantab. 1919; D.Sc. Adelaide 1927; assistant director
of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 1907-1922; director 1922-1941; died in a riding
accident. (<em>A. W. Hill</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: A modest, but historically interesting paper by Hill is: <em>The flora of the Somme battlefield</em>,

Hill, Ellsworth Jerome (1833-1917), American botanist; presbyterian clergyman in
Illinois (1863-1869); high school teacher at Kankakee, Ill. (1870-1874); at Chicago 1874-
1888; from then on working almost entirely as a botanist. (<em>E. J. Hill</em>).

Hill, John (1716-1775), British apothecary and naturalist; author of many compilations
dealing with horticulture, botany or medicine. (<em>J. Hill</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A collection of British plants by Hill is in the British Herbarium of
BM; some mss are at the Royal Society.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Hill obtained the order of Vasa in 1774. It is on this ground that Hill assumed the
prefix "Sir". According to the Gentleman's Magazine 1774: 282 "he was received at Court
with the proper ensigns as Knight", which "affords evidence that the King – a stickler for
etiquette – gave the necessary permission" (Druce 1926).

dedicated to Matthaeus Hiller (1646-1725), German botanist; <em>Hillistrobus</em> M. E. J. Chandler

2767. <em>A general natural history</em>: or, new and accurate descriptions of the animals, vegetables,
and minerals of the different parts of the world; with their virtues, and uses as far as hitherto
certainly known, in medicine and mechanics: illustrated by a general review of the know-
ledge of the ancients, and the improvements and discoveries of later ages in these studies.
Including the history of the materia medica, pictoria, and tinctoria of the present and earlier
ages. As also observations on the neglected properties of many valuable substances known at
present; and attempts to discover the lost medicines, &amp;c. of former ages, in a series of critical
enquiries into the materia medica of the ancient Greeks. With a great number of figures,
elegantly engraved. By John Hill, M.D. ... London (printed for Thomas Osborne, ...)
[1748-] 1751 [-1752], 3 vols. Qu. (in twos). (<em>Gener. nat. hist.</em>).

<em>Vol. 2</em>: [h.t.:] "A history of plants", 1751, p. [i]-xxvi, 1-642, [1-7, ind.], <em>pl. 1-16</em> (uncol.
	copp.). <em>Copies</em>: LC, MICH, NY, PH (2), USDA. – See Henrey 809 for further copies; see
	Collins (Sotheby 345) for an analytical collation. (See also Junk. Catal. 206, no. 139.
	1977). (<em>Hist. pl.</em>).
<em>Second ed</em>.: 1773. – See Kuntze (1891), Proskauer (1958) and Henrey no. 810. Only copies
	known at the Bibliothèque nationale, Paris and at the Library Company of Philadelphia.
	This edition differs in some respects from the original although the greater part of the book
	seems to consist of the old 1751 sheets, re-issued for the occasion. Proskauer and Kuntze
	enumerate the differences. The book as a whole must be regarded as an independent
	publication and has to be taken into account for purposes of botanical nomenclature (as
	far as the date is concerned). The copy at Philadelphia (analyzed by James Mears) is
	indeed almost identical with the 1751 issue. The copy lacks <em>pl. 10</em> but has an extra leaf p.
	643-644 and an additional plate, on <em>Dionaea. Collation</em>: p. [i]-xxvi, [1]-644, [1-7, ind.], <em>pl.
	1-9, 11-16, 1</em> unnumbered (<em>Dionaea</em>).
<em>Ref</em>.: Henrey 809-810; SA 2: 567; SO 345.
	Dandy, J. E., Index gen. names vasc. pl. 14. 1967.

2768. <em>The useful family herbal</em>. Or, an account of all those English plants, which are remark-

the most useful English plants. With an introduction containing ... The whole intended for

	plants." London (George Virtue), Bungay (printed by J. R. and C. Childs). s.d.
<em>Other issue of Bungay edition</em>: Bungay 1822 (Henrey 829) (n.v.)

Hill describes a number of species under their English names and adds Latin names "under
which they are found in every dictionary". These Latin names are sometimes unitary,
sometimes binomials, trinomials, or polynomials. They must be regarded as not validly
published. Binary nomenclature is not consistently applied (ICBN Art. 23); the unitary
designations of species can not be taken as generic names. – The number of issues of <em>The family
herbal</em> is possibly greater than listed here. Our information is incomplete. However, in view of
the relatively modest importance of these later issues we did not pursue our searches beyond
what is reported above. See also Henrey.
<em>Ref</em>.: DA 1967, p. 7; Henrey 824-831; HU 551.
	Willmott, A. J., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1935: 90 (proposal to treat names in the Fam. herb, as
	not validly publ.; proposal rejected at Amsterdam 1935).

raised for beauty. London (Printed for T. Osborne and J. Shipton ...) 1756[-1757]. Fol. (<em>Brit. herb.</em>).

Upon completion the publishers started the issue of a "Royal impression of that elegant and
useful work" (Henrey no. 799) on 29 Jan 1757.
<em>Pagination and pl</em>.: front., p. [i-iv], [1]-533, [534-535, index], <em>pl. 7-75</em>, handcoloured [or plain
	in other copies] copper engr. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO (col. pl.), U (plain), US (plain); IDC
	5225.
The Linnaean system of binary nomenclature for species was not consistently followed
(ICBN Art. 23). The book contains a number of pseudo-binomials. However, the generic
names are designated as such and must be accepted for botanical nomenclature; for an
extensive bibliographical study see HU; for an appraisal of the botanical and nomenclatural
importance see Dandy (DA) and Steam (1967).
<em>Ref</em>.: DA 1967, p. 14; DU 128; Henrey 798-799; HU 557; RS p. 87; Sotheby 346.
	Barnhart, J. H., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 26: 379. 1899.
	Dandy, J. E., Index gen. names vasc. pl. 14. 1967.
	Druce, G. C., Bot. Exch. Cl. Brit. Isles, Rep. 3: 436-440. 1914.
	Wilmott, A. J., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1835: 90 (proposal to declare names in Brit. herb, as
	not validly publ.; proposal rejected at Amsterdam 1935).
	Rothmaler, W., Rep. Sp. nov. 53: 31, 32. 1944.
	Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 10: 87. 1961.
	Stearn, W. T., Taxon 16: 494-498. 1967 (q.v. for a further discussion).

2770. <em>Eden</em>: or, a complete body of gardening. Containing plain and familiar directions for
raising the several useful products of a garden, fruits, roots and herbage; from the practice of
the most successful gardeners, and the result of a long experience. Together with the culture
of all kinds of flowers, according to the methods of the English, French, and Dutch florists.
And the knowledge of curious plants, after the system of Linnaeus. With figures and
descriptions of the flowers and plants proper for a garden. Including the care and culture of
the pleasure-garden. The business of the seminary for every week in the year. Catalogues and
accurate descriptions of the fruits as they come into season; and new and practical directions
for the management of fruit-trees. With the fast methods of culture for the several articles of
the kitchen-garden: and the compleat management of the ground for raising them, in the
natural and artificial manner. Compiled and digested from the papers of the late celebrated
Mr. Hale, by the authors of the compleat body of husbandry. And comprehending the art of
constructing a garden for use and pleasure; the best methods of keeping it in order; and the
most perfect accounts of its several products. London (T. Osborne, T. Trye, S. Crowder and
Co. and H. Woodgate) [1756-] 1757. Fol. (<em>Eden</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 28 Aug 1756-8 Nov 1757, frontisp., [i]-iv, [i], ii, [iii-iv], [1]-714, <em>pl. 1-60. Copies</em>: MO
	(<em>60 pl</em>.); IDC 7353.
	Issued in weekly parts (so indicated), between August 1765 (last week) and October 1757.
According to the preface the book was issued so as to "accomodate the Publication to the
season, that every week shall direct what is that week to be done."
	The book was "compiled and digested from the papers of the late celebrated Mr. Hale by
the authors of the <em>Compleat body of husbandry</em>" which here means evidently John Hill, who
signed the dedication. <em>Eden</em> is a companion volume to <em>A complete body of husbandry</em>, London
1756, Fol., issued in the same way in fascicles. "Thomas Hale" is possibly "a convenient
invention" (HU 557). "The true authorship of these two books is now unlikely to be finally
determined, but as the books remain to us that does not particularly matter. Hill no doubt
was connected in some way with their preparation or claimed to be so, to the confusion of his
contemporaries and his latter critics" (Fussell).
"<em>Enlarged edition</em>": 1773, London (for the author), p. [ii], iv, ii, 714, [1], 714-716; portr. of
	author, front., 60 + 20 <em>pl</em>. (n.v., collation Henrey no. 805). The 20 extra plates (numbered
	<em>1-20 and 61-80</em>) are from Hill's <em>Veg. syst.</em> 12(1767) and 13(1768); also issued in Hill's <em>Twenty
	five new plants</em> (1773).

PAGE: 202
HEADING: HILL, J.

<em>Ref</em>.: GF p. 59; Henrey nos. 776, 805; HU 599 (see also 557).
	Fussell, More old English farming books ... 1731 to 1793, p. 37-38. 1948.

2771. <em>Exotic botany</em>, illustrated in thirty-five figures of curious and elegant plants: explaining
the sexual system, ... London (the author) 1759. Fol. (<em>Exot. bot.</em>).

<em>Orig. ed.</em>: Feb-Sep 1759 (p. iv: 18 Jan 1758; NZgS 4, Oct 1759), p. [i]-iv, <em>pl. 1-33</em> with text, [1-
	2, ind.]. <em>Copies</em>: BM (see collation Henrey no. 806), NY. – Original drawings at Alnwick
	Castle (fide Desmond p. 308).
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1772 (p. iv: 25 Mai 1772), p. [i]-iv, [1], 1-35, [36, ind.], [1, binder], <em>pl. 1-33</em> (uncol.
	copper engr.). <em>Copies</em>: M, MICH, USDA. – "<em>Exotic botany</em> illustrated, thirty-five figures of
	elegant Chinese and American Shrubs and Plants, many of them new. Explaining the
	sexual system; and tending to give some new lights into the vegetable philosophy. The
	second edition. By John Hill, M.D. member of the imperial academy, &amp;c. &amp;c." London
	(printed for the author ...) 1772. Fol.

<em>Ref</em>.: Henrey 806-807; RS p. 87; Sotheby 347.
	Kuntze, O., Rev. gen. 1: cxxx. 1891.

2772. <em>The vegetable system</em>. Or, a series of experiments, and observations tending to explain
the internal structure, and the life of plants; their growth, and propagation ... Including a
new anatomy of plants ... London (printed at the expence of the author ...) 1759. Fol.
[vols. 2-26]: <em>The vegetable system</em>. Or, the internal structure and the life of plants; their parts,
and nourishment, explained; their classes, orders, genera, and species, ascertained, and
described; in a method altogether new: comprehending an artificial index and a natural
system. With figures of all the plants; designed and engraved by the author. The whole
from nature only. London (printed for the author) 1761-1775, vols. 2-26. Fol. (<em>Veg. syst.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: A complete copy of the editio princeps is at BM (Bloomsbury) (King's Library),
	described by Henrey. All other copies known have at least two volumes labelled "the
	second edition: corrected by the author; and with all the plates retouched and improved
	and usually, in addition, several volumes not so labelled but with later t.p. dates." The
	collations below are based on a copy at USDA except for those of vols. 1-2 of the editio
	princeps. In view of the very detailed and informative description by Henrey we refrain
	from repeating all the information on variations etc. encountered in other copies consulted
	by us.

<em>Vol. 1</em>, <em>ed. 1</em>: Aug 1759, p. [i]-iv, [1]-150, <em>pl. 1-21</em> (here and below the plates are hand-coloured
	copper engravings by the author).
	<em>Reissue</em>: Oct-Dec 1761, as above. <em>Copy</em>: WAG.
	<em>ed. 2</em>: 1770 (RHS, 1773 USDA), portr., p. [i]-iv, [1]-150, <em>pl. 1-21</em>, [1-2, ind.].

	<em>87</em>.

	reissued 1773, 1775, p. [i-iii], [1]-51, 51*, 51**, 51***, 53, 64, 65, 58, 57-60, 60**,

	St. James's Street."
	<em>Vols. 22-23</em>, ed. 2, 1786: "London, printed for the honourable Lady Hill, and to be had at
	her house in Curzon Street, May fair, and no where else."
<em>Appendices</em>: The descriptions and plates published in the appendices to vols. 12, 13, and 16,
	with plates <em>1-25</em>, were also published separately as "<em>Twenty-five new plants</em>, rais'd in the
	Royal garden at Kew" London 1773.

	at K. We have seen no other copy.

	Jones; J. Ridley; and L. Davis.) 1824. Copy: MO.
	"<em>The complete vegetable system</em>; or the internal structure ..." [title as in vols. 2-26 of ed.
	princ. except for minor differences in punctuation]. This is almost certainly a reissue of the
	original sheets with new t.p.'s.

2773. <em>Flora britanica</em> [sic]: sive, synopsis methodica stirpium britanicarum. Sistens, arbores
et herbas, indigenas et in agris cultas in classes et ordines, genera et species redactas
secundum systema sexuale: additis nonnullis noviter detectis. Cum classium, ordinum, et
generum characteristicis, specierum descriptionibus, et virium epitome. Tabulis aeneis
illustrata. Post tertiam editionem synopseos Raianae, opere Dillenii concinnatam, nunc
primum ad celeberrimi Caroli Linnaei methodum disposita. Auctore Johanne Hill, M.D.
Societatis regiae Burdigalensis &amp;C. Soc. Londini (Impensis Jacobi Waugh, ...) 1760. (<em>Fl.
brit.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1760, p. [i]-672, <em>pl. 1-11, 13-24. Copy</em>: USDA.
<em>Ref</em>.: PR ed. 1: 4475 ("est synopsis Raji ad methodum Linnaeanam redacta").
	Willmott, A. J., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1935: 90 (proposal to declare names in <em>Fl. brit.</em> as not
	validly published; proposal rejected at Amsterdam 1935).

2774. <em>Hortus kewensis</em>. Sistens herbas exoticas, indigenasque rariores, in area botanica,
hortorum augustissimae principissae Cambriae dotissae, apud Kew, in comitatu Surreiano,
cultas; methodo florali nova dispositas ... Londini (Prostant apud Ricardum Baldwin ...
et Johannem Ridley ...) 1768. Oct. (<em>Hort. kew.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1768 (earliest rev. Monthly Rev. Sep 1769), p. [i, iii, v], table, [1]-458, [1-18, index],
	<em>pl. 1-20</em>, uncol. copper engr. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, US, USDA. – The plates are engravings of
	drawings by Hill, hand-coloured in some copies. The species are designated by binary
	names. – It is possible that the book was published in parts. Sheets L* and M* (p. 172(1)-
	172(24)) must have been printed out of order but before the index.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: "Edition secunda aucta; figuris aeneis viginti illustrata" London (id.) 1769, p. [i, iii,
	v], table, [1]-458, [1-18, index], <em>pl. 1-20</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: G, M, MO, NY. – Not really "aucta"
	but a re-issue.

<em>Ref</em>.: Henrey 812-813, HU 598.
	Pfeiffer, Bot. Zeit. 6: 833-834. 1848.

HEADING: HILLEBRAND

2775. <em>A decade of curious and elegant trees and plants</em>: drawn after specimens received from the
East-Indies and America in the year 1772; and accurately engraved: with their history and
characters, in English and Latin ... London (author) 1773. Fol. (<em>Dec. cur. pl.</em>).

2776. <em>Herbarium britannicum</em> exhibens plantas Britaniae indigenas secundum methodum
floralem novam digestas. Cum historia, descriptione, characteribus specificis, viribus, et usis.
Tabulis aeneis illustratum ... Londini (Sumptibus auctoris. Prostant apud Baldwin, Rid-
ley, Nourse, Becket, Davies, Cambell, Elmsly, Bibliopolas.) 1769-1770, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Herb.

	<em>pl. 93-195.</em>

<em>Copies</em>: G, MO, USDA. – The plates are uncoloured copper engravings after drawings by the
	author. Some copies of vol. 1 have extra p. 96*-99*; additional plates with duplicate nos.
	30, 66, 89, 117, 170 occur.

2777. <em>Horti malabarici pars prima</em>, ... nunc primum classium, generum, et specierum charac-
teres Linnaeanas; synonyma authorum, atque observationes addidit; et indice Linnaeano
adauxit J. Hill ... London (Sumptibus auctoris) 1774. Qu. (<em>Hort. malab.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1774 (before Sep) (Monthly Review 51: 244), p. [i-iii], [1]-110, [1-4, ind.], <em>pl. 1-57</em> (<em>45</em>
	as "<em>46</em>") (uncol. copp. engr.). <em>Copy</em>: NY. – This is the first part of the London edition of
	Rheede's <em>Hortus indicus malabaricus</em>, q.v.

Hillebrand, Wilhelm (1821-1886), German physician, botanist, and traveller who lived
for twenty years in the Hawaiian Islands (1851-1871). (<em>Hillebr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (the ferns and some other material preserved); duplicates BISH,
BM, C, CU, FI, G, GH, K, MANCH, MEL, MO, US, W, WRSL; (in part distributed as
<em>Reliquae Hillebrandianae</em>).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> AND <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 177; BL 1: 110, 301; BM 2: 845; Bossert p. 175;
CSP 15: 850; Hortus 3: 1195; HR; IF p. 703; IH 2: 276; Lenley p. 223; MW p. 178; Rehder
5: 393; SK 1: xxv, 232, 5: cclxxxv; Tucker 1: 341; Urban-Berl. p. 265, 302, 320, 357.
Allen, Science 74: 60-62. 1931 (on H's son, W.F.H., with notes on W.H.).
Anon., Bot. Zeit. 44: 542-543. 1886; Bot. Jahrb. 14 (Beibl. 32): 29-30. 1891 (herb.).
Brewer, W. H., <em>in</em> S. Watson, Bot. Calif. 2: 558. 1880 (Calif, coll.).
Degener, O., Hawaii Weekly 18 Nov 1951, p. 3 (portr.); Asa Gray Bull. ser. 2. 3: 193-198.
	1957 (portr.).
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 10, 144. 1969.
Gray, A., Amer. J. Sci. ser. 3. 33: 164-165. 1887.
Hillebrand, W. F., <em>in</em> W. Hillebrand, Fl. Haw. Isl. vii-xii. 1888 (facs. ed. 1965).
MacCaughey, Haw. Forester Agric. 16(2): 49-50. 1919.
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 338-339. 1975.
Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 15: 328. 1966.
St. John, H., Chron. bot. 7(2): 69-70. Mar 1942 (on a letter by H. to A. Gray).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hillebrandia</em> D. Oliver (1866).

2778. <em>Flora of the Hawaiian Islands</em>: a description of their phanerogams and vascular cryp-
togams by William Hillebrand, M.D. Annotated and published after the author's death by

PAGE: 206
HEADING: HILLEBRAND

W. F. Hillebrand. London (Williams &amp; Norgate), New York (B. Westermann &amp; Co.),
Heidelberg (Carl Winter) 1888. Oct. (<em>Fl. Hawaiian Isl.</em>).

<em>Editor</em>: William Francis Hillebrand (1853-1925), chemist (see Biogr. Mem. Natl. Acad. Sci.
	12: 43-70).
<em>Publ</em>.: Mar 1888 (Bot. Zeit. 30 Mar 1888; Bot. Jahrb. 27 Mar 1888; J. Bot. rev. Apr 1888;
	Nat. Nov. Apr 1888), frontisp., p. [i]-xcvi, [1]-673, 4 maps. <em>Copies</em>: R. S. Cowan, G,
	MICH, MO, NY, U, US, USDA. – In a letter to Asa Gray (GH) Hillebrand recalls that
	he started work on the <em>Flora</em> during the winter of 1871-72 at Cambridge, Mass., with
	Gray's assistance (St. John 1942).
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: New York and London (Hafner Publishing Company) 1965, (half-title added;
	new t.p. and p. [ii]). <em>Copies</em>: FAS, NY.
<em>Supplementary publ</em>.: Heller, A. A., Obs. ferns flow. pl. Haw. Isl., Minn. bot. Stud. 1: 760-922,
	<em>pl. 42-69.</em> 1897 (Bull. Geol. Nat. Hist. Surv. Minn., Bot. ser. 2. 9).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Gaz. 13: 166-167. Jun 1888.
	Britten, J., J. Bot. 26: 122-124. 1888.
	Drude, G. C, Bot. Zeit. 46: 640-643. 5 Oct 1888.

professor of botany at Birmingham 1882-1909. (<em>Hillh</em>.).

Hillmann, Johannes (1881-1943), German lichenologist, high school teacher at Berlin.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: B; other material in herb. Grummann. Hillmann's main herbarium

	<em>Copy</em>: HH. – Himpel's three German floras on the Elsass (Alsace) and Lothringen reflect
	the incorporation of those areas with mixed culture in the German state between 1871 and

Hinterhuber, Rudolph (1802-1892), Austrian botanist and pharmacist at Bolzano and
Mondsee, brother of Julius Hinterhuber. (<em>R. Hinterh.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: Plants of Georg Hinterhuber (1768-1850, father of the above) are at
BR, OXF, P, W and WAG. A mss <em>Flora der Umgebung von Bozen</em>, 1836, is at IBF. Saccardo
states that Rudolph H's herbarium is at the "museo francisco-carolino di Linza D." (now at
LI?).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 179; BM 2: 847; CSP 3: 360; DTS 1: 117-118,

Anon., Bot. Not. 1893: 39.

2784. <em>Prodromus einer Flora des Kronlandes Salzburg</em> und dessen angränzenden Ländertheilen,
als Berchtesgaden, des k.k. Salzkammergutes nebst Mondsee, eines kleinen Theils des
nördlichen Tirol mit Inbegriff des gesammten Zillerthales, von Heiligenblut (im angränzen-
den Kärnthen) nebst der in botanischer Beziehung so interessanten, bei Lienz im Pusterthale
liegenden "Kirschbaumer-Alpe", mit besonderer Uebersicht der Spezialfloren der einzelnen
Gauen, entworfen von Rudolph Hinterhuber, ... und Julius Hinterhuber ... Salzburg
(Druck der Oberer'schen Buchdruckerei) 1851. Oct (<em>Prodr. Fl. Salzburg</em>).

	<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1879 (Nat. Nov. Jun 1879; Flora 11 Jun 1879), p. [i-iv], [1]-313. <em>Copies</em>: B,
	G. – <em>Authors</em>: Julius Hinterhuber (1810-1880) and Franz Pichlmayr (b. 1879). "<em>Prodromus
	einer Flora des Herzogthumes Salzburg</em> und der angrenzenden Ländertheile als: des k.k.
	Salzkammergutes neben Mondsee, von Heiligenblut in Kärnthen nebst der in botani-
	scher Beziehung so interessanten Kirschbaumer Alpe im Pustertale, eines kleinen Theiles
	des Nördlichen Tirol mit dem gesammten Zillerthale und des südöstlichen Baiern bis
	Waging und Chiemsee. Mit besonderer Uebersicht der Specialflora der einzelnen Gaue."
	"Die Angaben ... sind ... theilweise ... anscheinend gänzlich aus der Luft gegriffen."
	(DTS).

	ii], [1]-313. <em>Copy</em>: B. – "<em>Flora des Herzogthumes Salzburg</em> und der angrenzenden Ländertheile.
	Zusammengestellt von Julius Hinterhuber, ... und Franz Pichlmayr, ... Der zweiten,
	gänzlich umgearbeiteten Auflage neue Ausgabe." (<em>Fl. Salzburg</em>).

Hiratsuka, Naohide (1903-x), Japanese botanist, studied at Hokkaido University,
professor botany and phytopathology at Tottori Agricultural College (1929), later at the
Faculty of agriculture, Tokyo University of Education. (<em>Hiratsuka</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main collections at the Laboratory of Phytopathology of Tokyo
University. Further material at MICH, PUR.

	Mem. Tottori Agr. Coll. 4, 1936.

Hirmer, Max (1893-x), German palaeobotanist at München; Dr. phil. München 1917
(under Goebel); extraordinary professor of palaeobotany at München 1928-1936; 1936
released on political grounds; subsequently working at the Preusische Geologische Landes-
anstalt and continuing his father's publishing firm. (<em>Hirmer</em>).

<sm>COLLECTIONS</sm>: Palaeobotanical collections and library in Staatssammlung für Paläontologie
und historische Geologie, München (all information on H. kindly supplied by K. Mägde-
frau).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 278; Barnhart 2: 181; Hirsch p. 124; Kew 2: 692;
Langman p. 371; LS suppl. 11689-11690.
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2. 225. 1941.
Glossner, Deut. allg. Sontagsbl. 31, nr. 11, 12 Mar 1978 (on his 85th birthday, 14 Mar).
Hirmer, M., Verzeichnis der Veröffentlichungen, typescript 9 p. (copies Mägdefrau, FAS).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Editor, <em>Palaeontographica</em>, Abt. B, Palaeophytologie, vols. 78-85.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hirmerella</em> W. W. Jung (1968); <em>Hirmeria</em> A. Fucini (1936); <em>Hirmeriella</em> L. Hörham-
mer (1933).

2788. <em>Ergebnisse der Forschungsreisen Prof. E. Stromers in den Wüsten Ägyptens</em> iv. Die fossilen
Floren Ägyptens. 3. Die fossilen Pflanzen Ägyptens: D. Filicales. München (Verlag der
Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften) 1925. Qu. (<em>Erg. Stromers Ägypt., Filic</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1925 (submitted 8 Nov 1924), p. [1]-18, <em>pl. 1-5. Copy</em>: M. – Abh. bayer. Akad. Wiss.,
	Mat.-naturw. Abt. 30(3). 1925 (listed by Hirmer himself in his bibliography as having
	been published in 1924).

und Dr. Wilhelm Troll. München und Berlin (Druck und Verlag von R. Oldenbourg) 1927.
Oct. (<em>Handb. Paläobot.</em>).

<em>Co-authors</em>: Julius Pia (1887-1943) (contr. Thallophyta); Wilhelm Troll (1897-1977) (contr.
	"Bryophyta").

Hisinger, Wilhelm [von] (1766-1852), Swedish palaeobotanist. (<em>Hising</em>.).

(1792) commemorates his uncle, Johan Hisinger (1727?-1790?), Swedish mining engineer
and promotor of botanical research.

Hitchcock, Albert Spear (né Jennings) (1865-1935), American botanist, leading agrosto-
logist, at Ames (1885-1889), St. Louis (1889-1891), Manhattan, Kansas (1892-1901), USDA
Washington 1901-1935; "eager explorer, far-seeing botanist, and wise promoter of scientific
research in America" (Jepson, Fl. Calif. 1925, in copy presented to Hitchcock). (<em>Hitchc</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US (grass herbarium), older collections partly at MO (e.g. Bahamas
1890) and NY. Duplicates from his many collecting trips in many herbaria (see IH).
Exsiccatae: <em>American grasses</em> (cent. 1-10, 1914-1929) at BM, C, K, L, P, US, W. Sets of 1000
dried specimens entitled <em>Flora of Kansas</em>, Manhattan, Kansas, (25 sets) were announced by
Nat. Nov. Aug(2) 1897. (<em>Flora of Kansas</em>, a series of maps ... Manhattan 1899, was a set of 20
plates with 1298 maps and 3 p. text; Nat. Nov. Sep(1) 1899).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 652; Barnhart 2: 182; BFM 2281; BL 1: 172, 173,
179, 181, 227, 301; BM 2: 849, 6: 468; Bossert p. 177; CSP 15: 869, 16: 943; Hirsch p. 125;
Hortus 3: 1195; IH 2: 277-278; Kew 2: 694-696; Langman p. 371-372; Lenley p. 224; LS
12342-12348, 34632-34633; MW p. 182-182; NAF 28B(2): 335, ser. 2. 2: 160, 4: 43, 5: 242,
7: 40; Plesch p. 265; Rehder 5: 394-395; SK 1: 233; SO 3064, 498, 499, 3507; TL-2/778, 781;
Tucker 1: 343; Zander ed. 10, p. 670.
Allan [H.H.A.], New Zealand J. Sci. Techn. 17(6): 779. 1936; Bull. Acad. int. Géogr. bot.
	9(122): I. 1900 (election as director of this Academy) (portr.); Kansas Industrialist 62
	(no. 24): 25 Mar 1936 (portr.); Sci. News Letter 10 Dec 1938, p. 381.
Boone, W., Hist. bot. W. Virginia 173. 1965.
Chase, A., Address on A. S. Hitchcock, read at meeting Bot. Soc. Washington, 1 Dec 1936,
	mss. (12 p.) at US; Science 83(2149): 222-224. 1936.

HEADING: HITCHCOCK, A. S.

Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 70-71. 1898, 3: 61. 1902.
Verdoorn, F., Chron. bot. 2: 309. 1936 (portr.), 3: 335. 1937.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 197. 1905.
Woodward, C., J. New York Bot. Gard. 37: 26. 1936.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Hitchcock, like his West Coast contemporary H. M. Hall, was one of the early
proponents of setting up an <em>International Bureau for Plant Taxonomy</em>. He tried to implement
Hall's idea at the International Botanical Congresses of Cambridge (1930) and Amsterdam
(1935). At the latter Congress he succeeded in obtaining agreement on the founding of a
"Standing Committee for urgent taxonomic needs" which was charged to start the
compilation of an <em>Index herbariorum</em> (taken on initially by J. Lanjouw) and to further the
compilation of a <em>Type-register</em> as advocated by the Committee on Nomenclature of the
Botanical Society of America (chairman: Hitchcock) (see no. 2819, Hitchcock 1934).
Hitchcock's ideas on nomenclature made him a staunch supporter of the type method and it
is for a great part due to him that this principle was introduced in the International Code of
Botanical Nomenclature.
	Hitchcock died on 16 Dec 1935, on board the SS. City of Norfolk, on his return voyage to
the U.S., after having visited Europe to attend the Amsterdam Botanical Congress and
having spent time in the major European herbaria. His library and manuscripts are at US.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Gramineae</em>, in Jepson, A flora of California 82-189. 30 Apr 1912 (TL-
2/3341).
(2) <em>Gramineae, in</em> A. Gray, <em>Manual</em>, ed. 7. 1908 (TL-2/2124).
(3) Gramineae, <em>in</em> Urban, Symb. ant. 7: 166-170. 15 Jun 1912.
(4) <em>Poaceae, in</em> NAF 17(3): 198-288. 20 Dec 1915; 17(4): 289-354. 14 Aug 1931; 17(5): 355-
418. 17 Mai 1935; 17(6): 419-482. 5 Sep 1935; 17(7): 483-542. 31 Mar 1937; 17(8): 543-568.
14 Jul 1939 (TL-2/781).

<em>Co-author</em>: Mary Agnes Chase, née Merrill (1869-1963).
<em>Publ</em>.: 18 Aug 1917 (p. ii; J. Bot. Dec 1917), p. [i]-v, 261-471, vii-xviii. <em>Copies</em>: U, US. – Contr.
	U.S. natl. Herb. 18(7). 1917.
<em>Ref</em>.: Rendle, A. B., J. Bot. 55: 355-357. 1917.

2808. <em>Flora of the District of Columbia and vicinity</em> ... Washington [D.C.] (Government
Printing Office) 1919. Oct. (<em>Fl. D.C.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Paul Sarpenter Standley (1884-1963).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1919, p. [1]-329, <em>pl. 1-42. Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, US, USDA. – Contr. U.S. natl.
	Herb. vol. 21.
	"It goes without saying that the nomenclature of the District Flora follows the American
Code, rather than the so-called International Code forced down the throats of the Vienna
Botanical Congress by a German majority and further manipulated by the same majority at
the Brussels Congress; we can well understand why the French have never recognized it as
valid, and why anybody but Germans or Austrians should so regard it has always been a
puzzle, especially as the American Code is much more logical and cuts out autocracy.
Internationalism is proving a dangerous principle to play with, and in many aspects has
much to condemn it.
	The Washington botanists have followed the American Code consistently in almost every
item except the use of duplicate binomials; they do not say why these have not been used;
zoölogists have used them for many years without losing sleep, and <em>Sassafras</em> runs well with
<em>Corvus Corvus</em>. We must, I suppose, conclude that our colleagues of the fifteen-mile circle

PAGE: 215
HEADING: HITCHCOCK, A. S.

around the national Capitol, or most of them, simply do not like to say <em>Catalpa Catalpa</em>,
although by refusing such diction they lose the valuable suggestion that Linnaeus named the
tree <em>Bignonia Catalpa</em>. Or may it be that they are influenced by the line of thought advanced
by Engler at the Vienna Congress when we asked him why he objected and he told us
principally that such names had made some of his students laugh! And so the risibility of
juvenile Huns prevented their adoption at that highly amusing convocation". (N. L. Britton
(1920), stepping in the shoes of Monroe.) It took another ten years to reach a less"dan-
gerous" international agreement through people like Hitchcock himself, H. M. Hall, Rendle
and Briquet.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britton, N. L., Torreya 19: 244-246. 1920.
	Britten, J., J. Bot. 58: 119. 1920.
	Krause, Bot. Jahrb. 57(Lit.): 69. 1922.

<em>Orig</em>.: 20 Mar 1920, p. [1]-307, <em>pl. 1-20. Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY, US, USDA; IDC 7557.
	– U.S. Dept. Agr. Bull. 772. – Nelson (1920):"At the present low ebb of systematic
	botany, due largely to the deplorable schism over the question of nomenclatorial rules, the
	appearance ... is of capital importance ..."
<em>Revised ed</em>.: Mai 1936, Washington, D.C. (id.). Oct., p. 1-302, <em>pl. 1-20. Copies</em>: G, MICH,
	MO, U, US(2).

2819. <em>Location of type specimens</em>. [Washington, D.C. (Smithsonian Institution)] s.d., 2 pars

<em>List 1</em>: Fall 1934, p. 1-19. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
<em>List 2</em>: 9 Aug 1935, p. 1, 1 bis, 2-28. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.

Lists issued by Hitchcock on behalf of the Committee on nomenclature of the Botanical
Society of America, constituting a forerunner of the modern type-registers. The publication
of these lists was not continued, because of Hitchcock's death on 16 Dec 1935 after returning
from Amsterdam where he had distributed his lists among some of the participants.

2820. <em>Manual of the grasses of the United States</em>. [headline:] United States Department of
Agriculture Miscellaneous Publication no. 200. Washington D.C. (United States Govern-
ment Printing Office) 1935. 16mo. (<em>Man. Grasses U.S.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1-11 Mai 1935 (Hitchcock's copy marked in unknown hand: 1 Mai 1935; US copy
	stamped 11 Mai 1935; MO copy dated 5 Mai), p. [i], 1-1040. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, G, MICH,
	MO, U, US(3), USDA. – The date Feb 1935 on the original was corrected to Mai 1935 on
	the t.p. of the "1950" reprint.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: revised by Mary Agnes Chase (1869-1963), Washington [D.C] (id.) 16-mo. 1950,
	<em>publ</em>.: 12 Feb 1951 (t.p.; stamped copy US), p. [i], 1-1051. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO(2), U, US,
	USDA.
<em>Ed 2, reprint</em>: New York (Dover Publications Inc.) s.d. [1971], ISBN 0-486-22717-0, 2 vols., 1:
	[i], 1-569, 2: [i, iii], [569]-1051. <em>Copy</em>: US.

"The synonymy alone (207 pages of it!) will be worth the price of the whole book to the
pestered systematist" (Science News Letter 25 Mai 1935). Actually, the price of the book was
only US $ I.75.
<em>Ref</em>.: Rendle, A. B., J. Bot. 74: 28-29. Jan 1936 ("May Dr. Hitchcock long continue working
	at Grasses!" H. died 16 Dec 1935).

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov 1936 (p. 1), p. [i], 1-439. <em>Copies</em>: NY, U, US. – Misc. Publ. no. 243, U.S. Dept.
	Agr.

Hitchcock, Charles Leo (1902-x), American botanist in the Pacific Northwest. (<em>C.
Hitchc.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mainly at WTU; duplicates in many herbaria.

Hobkirk, Charles Codrington Pressick (1837-1902), British (Yorkshire) banker, local
historian, and bryologist at Huddersfield and Dewsbury; after retirement in 1897 at

Hobson, Edward (1782-1830), British self-taught bryologist, entomologist and geologist at
Manchester, correspondent of R. K. Greville and W. J. Hooker. (<em>Hobs</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Manchester Botanical Society; further material at BM, K and
OXF, partly as "<em>Musci britannici</em>, a collection of specimens of British mosses and hepaticae,
collected in the vicinity of Manchester," 2 vols. Manchester 1818-1822, for details see Sayre
1975.

Hochreutiner, Bénedict Pierre Georges (1873-1959), Swiss botanist and theologist;
assistant to Briquet (1896); in Indonesia 1903-1905; at the Conservatoire botanique de
Genève 1906-1943; specialist on Malvaceae and on the flora of S. Algeria. (<em>Hochr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G. – Exsiccatae: <em>Plantae bogorienses exsiccatae novae vel minus cognitae</em>,
Java 1904, 162 nos., sets at B, BO, BR, G, K, L, MO, NSW, NY, P, W, Z. (for schedae see no.
2829). – Most of H's types are at G; others at P.

Hochstetter, Christian Ferdinand (1787-1860), German botanist, clergyman (Stadt-
pfarrer), and professor at the teacher's college at Esslingen; founded and led the Esslinger
Reiseverein (Unio itineraria) with E. G. Steudel. (<em>Hochst</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TUB. – Plants collected by Hochstetter on his voyage to Portugal,
Madeira and the Açores (1838) and in Central Europe are in many herbaria (see IH). M.
Seubert's <em>Flora azorica</em> of 1844 is based on the collections by Hochstetter and his eldest son
Karl Christian Friedrich (1818-1880).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Ascherson et Graebner, Syn. (2): 465 (1904) point out that H's name was Christian
Ferdinand, not Friedrich (as in PR). – Hochstetter's sons were Karl Christian Friedrich
(1818-1880), Wilhelm Christian (1825-1881), and Christian Gottlob Ferdinand [later Ritter
von] Hochstetter (1829-1884); the latter was geologist on the Novara expedition, and
collected ferns in Indonesia.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 465, 5(1): 687; Backer p. 269; Barnhart 2: 184; BM
2: 851; Bossert p. 177; Clokie p. 184; CSP 3: 370-371, 6: 689; DTS 1: 119, 6(4): 153; Frank
3(Anh.): 44; GR p. 20, cat. p. 65; Hawksworth p. 183; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Hochst."); IH 2:
278; Jackson p. 559 [index]; Kew 3: 3; Klášterský p. 92-93; KR p. 298; Langman p. 372; PR
3966, 4100-4104, 8633 (ed. 1: 4531-4533); Rehder 5: 395; RS p. 87; SBC p. 122
("Hochst."); TL-2/1620; Tucker 1: 344; Urban-Berl. p. 287, 302, 357; WU 9: 74; Zander
ed. 10, p. 670.
Anon., Flora 43: 143-144. 1860; Bot. Zeit. 19: 109-111. 1861.

2832. <em>Populäre Botanik</em>, oder fassliche Anleitung zur Kenntnis der Gewächse, besonders der
in Deutschland und in der Schweiz am häufigsten wildwachsenden Arten, wie auch der
deutschen Culturpflanzen und der merkwürdigsten Gewächse der wärmern Länder. Zum
Gebrauch und Selbstunterricht der Erwachsenen und der Jugend, überhaupt aller derer, die
mit der Pflanzenwelt näher bekannt zu werden wünschen, besonders der Schullehrer und
Schulgehülfen, der Gymnasial- und Realschüler, junger Pharmaceuten und aller Jüng-
linge und Töchter aus den gebildeten Ständen ... Reutlingen (Im Verlage der lithographi-
schen Anstalt von Joh. G. Mäcken, jun.) 1831. Oct. (<em>Pop. Bot.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 2 parts, 1831. <em>Copies</em>: NY, Regensburg, USDA.

	iii*], [i]-xiv, [1], [1]-808.
	<em>Zweiter Theil</em>: 1831, p. [i], [809]-910, [1-60, ind.], <em>pl. 1-28</em>, all but <em>1-3</em> handcol. liths.

	und verbesserte Ausgabe." Reutlingen (Druck und Verlag von Johann Conrad Mäcken

	<em>Plates</em>: <em>1-22</em>, all but <em>1-3</em> hand-col. liths., issued unde: (fix)arate cover:"XXII Kupfertafel
	zur zweiten, mit besonderer Rücksicht ..." Reutlingen (id.) 1837.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: "Dritte vielseitig vermehrte und verbesserte Auflage" Reutlingen (Druck und Verlag

HEADING: HOCHSTETTER, C. G. F. VON

Hochstetter, Christian Gottlob Ferdinand (Ritter) von (1829-1884), German geo-
logist and naturalist; Dr. phil. Tübingen 1852; in Vienna at the Geol. Reichsanstalt (1852-
1857); on the Novara expedition (1857-1859); son of C. F. Hochstetter; in New Zealand
1859; professor of geology at the Vienna polytechnic 1860-1876, from 1876-1884 "Inten-
dant" (director) of the k.k. Naturhistorische Hofmuseum; later working mainly on pre-
history and ethnology. (<em>C. G. F. Hochst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 339-340. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 465; Barnhart 2: 185; CSP 10: 242, 243, 15: 876;
IH 2: 279; Quenstedt p. 203-204; Rehder 5: 395, SK 1: 234; Tucker 1: 344.
Anon., Bonplandia 8(5): 83. 1860.
Cockayne, L., Veget. New Zealand 6. 1921.
Embacher, F., Lexik. Reisen 148. 1882.
Haast, J. v., New Zealand J. Sci. 5(2): 202-220. 1884.
Hauer, Jahrb. k.k. geol. Reichsanst. 34(4): 601-608. 1884; Leopoldina 20: 167. 1884, 21: 98-
	102. 1885.
Heger, Mitt, geogr. Ges. Wien 27(6): 249, 345-392. 1894 (bibl.).
Hochstetter, G. G. F. v., Gesammelte Reiseberichte von der Erdumsegelung der Fregatte
	Novara 1857-1859. Wien 1885 (portr., biogr. data).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep-Dec 1852 (p. vi: 8 Aug 1852), p. [i]-[vii], [1]-64, <em>1 pl. Copy</em>: G. – A partial
	plagarism, see Ed. Löscher, Bot. Zeit. 12: 136. 24 Feb 1854 and Seemann, Bonplandia
	1(24): 250-251. 1853. Löscher's <em>Die Königliche Wasserlilie Victoria regia</em>, Publ. Mar-Jul.
	1853, has priority. Hochstetter used this text in an overly liberal way.

Hodgson, William (1824-1901), English botanist and schoolmaster at Watermillock, and
Aspatria, Cumberland. (<em>Hodgs</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CGE, British material. It is not certain whether this is the original

material at OXF (via herb. Haileybury).

HEADING: HOEFER

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hodgsonia</em> F. von Mueller (1860) and <em>Hodgsoniola</em> F. von Mueller (1861) are
dedicated to John Hodgson, Australian politician and promotor of Australia's exploration.
<em>Hodgsonia</em> J. D. Hooker &amp; T. Thomson (1854) is dedicated to Brian Houghton Hodgson
(1800-1894), English public servant in India, orientalist, linguist and collector of plants and
animals. The etymology of <em>Hodgsonia</em> H. Persson 1953 and <em>Neohodgsonia</em> H. Persson 1954
could not be established.

2843. <em>Flora of Cumberland</em> containing a full list of the flowering plants and ferns to be found in

	of plants, consulted those authorities who are always willing to impart to others the
knowledge they have themselves obtained at the expenditure of time, trouble, patience
and perseverance, he would have produced a more satisfactory book" (Britten 1899).

	Hodgson, W., Trans. Cumberland Ass. 11: 114-126. 1886, 14: 49-72. 1889 (Bot. Solway).

Höeg, Ove Arbo (1898-x), Norwegian palaeo- and ethno-botanist, at Trondhjems Mu-
seum (1926-1947); professor of botany at Oslo (1947-1968); specialist on the fossil floras of
the Arctic and in general on palaeozoic floras. (<em>Höeg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TRH; further material at C, K, LD, O. – All fossil material is at the
Palaeontological Museum of Oslo University (inf. O. A. Höeg in litt. 27 Jul 1977).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 278; Barnhart 2: 186; BL 2: 442, 446, 459, 668;
Bossert p. 178; GR p. 713, cat. p. 65; Hirsch p. 125; IH 2: 279; Kew 3: 5; Kleppa p. 325
[index]; LS suppl. 11743-11744; Roon p. 53; SBC p. 122 ("Høeg").

Hoehne, Frederico Carlos (1882-1959), Brazilian botanist; at Rio de Janeiro 1907-1917;
from 1917-1952 at the botanical institute of São Paulo. (<em>Hoehne</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SP; duplicates in many herbaria.
<em>Ref</em>.: Hoehne, F. C, Indice bibliográfico e numérico das plantas colhidas pela Commissão
	Rondon, ou Commissão de Linhas telegráphicas ... de 1908 até 1923. São Paulo,
	1951, 400 p. (lists colls. by F. C. Hoehne, J. G. Kuhlmann e.a. as well as the bot. publ.
	by the Commissão Rondon).
	Prance, G., Acta amaz. 1(1): 40. 1971.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 340. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 186; BL 1: 238, 241, 301; BM 6: 471; Bossert p.
178; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Hoehne"); IH 2: 279; Kew 3: 5-6; Langmanp. 373; LS suppl. 11745;
Urban-Berl. p. 357.
Anon., Hoehnea 1: [1]. 1971 (portr.).
C.S., Tribuna farmácéutica 27: 46-47. 1959.
Hoehne, F. C, M. Kuhlmann and Oswaldo Handro, O jardim botânico de São Paulo 1941,
	650 p., <em>48 pl</em>. (contains a history of botany in Brazil).
Kränzlin, F. W. L., Bot. Jahrb. 58(Lit.): 10. 1922 (general review of H's publications 1910-
	1920).
Pabst, Die Orchidee 10(3): 90-92. 1959 (H's bibliography counts 650 papers and books, in all
	circa 12.000 printed pages).
Sampaio, Arch. Mus. nac. Rio de Janeiro 22: 43-44. 1919.
Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 8: 209. 1959.
Teixeira, Arq. bot. Est. S. Paulo ser. 2. 3(5): 221-223. 1962 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Hoehne's major work, "<em>Flora brasilica</em> planejada e iniciada por F. C.
Hoehne", started in Sep 1940, falls outside the scope of TL/2. Twelve fascicles were issued up
to 1968, with treatments by various authors. Fasc. 12(1968), Xyridaceae by L. B. Smith and
R.J. Downs) appeared under the editorship of Alcides Ribeiro Teixeira.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm> (genera): <em>Hoehnea</em> Epling (1939); <em>Hoehneella</em> A. Ruschi (1945); <em>Hoehnephytum</em> A. L.
Cabrera (1950); (journal): <em>Hoehnea</em>. São Paulo. Vol. l-x. 1971-x. <em>Note: Hoehnemonas</em> B.
Skvortzov (1969) is dedicated to Wilson Hoehne, Brazilian botanist.

HEADING: HÖHNEL

Höhnel, Franz Xaver Rudolf, Ritter von (1852-1920), Austrian bryologist and myco-
logist; Dr. phil Strassburg 1877; ultimately (1884, 1888) professor of botany at the Tech-
nische Hochschule, Wien. (<em>Höhn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH; other material at B, H, K, L, PAV, PC, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 283; Barnhart 2: 186; Bossert p. 179; CSP 10:
256-257, 12: 338, 15: 883-884; DTS 3: xliii, Nachtr.: 2, 6(4): 153; Frank 3(Anh.): 44; GR p.
433-434, cat. p. 65; IH 2: 281; Jackson p. 210; Kew 3: 6-7; Kleppa p. 208; Langman p. 373;
LS 12367-12390, 34637-34658, suppl. 11746-12050; Moebius p. 174, 257, 451; Rehder 5:
396; Saccardo 1: 89; SBC p. 122 ("Höhn."); SK p. 236; Stevenson p. 1245; Tucker 1: 345;
Urban-Berl. p. 302, 357.
Anon., Alman. Akad. Wiss. 71: 171-173. 1921; Bot. Not. 1921: 14; Deut. Biogr. Jahrb.,
	Überleitungsband 2: 749. 1928.
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. IIIyr. länder 13, 24, 35. 1901. (Veg. Erde 4).
Falck, Mykologische Untersuchungen und Berichte 1: i-vi. 1923 (1924?) (bibl.).
Husnot, T. H., Rev. bryol. 21: 62. 1894, 22: 92. 1895, 25: 53. 1898 (bryol. publ.).
Merrill, E. D., Contr. natl. Herb. U.S. 30(1): 153. 1947.
Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 17: 81-82. 1968.
Weese, Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 38: (103)-(126). 1920 (bibl.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed to Schneider, C. K., <em>Illustriertes Handwörterbuch der Botanik</em>,
Leipzig 1905.

<sm>NOTE</sm> For publications with Viktor Litschauer see no. 2862.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hoehneliella</em> Bresadola &amp; P. A. Saccardo ex P. Strasser (1902); <em>Hoehnelomyces</em> Neese
(1920); <em>Neohoehnelia</em> Theissen &amp; H. Sydow (1918).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mar 1895 (date Heft S.B., also on p. 1 of reprint; Bot. Zeit. 1 Sep 1895), p. [1]-40. <em>Copy</em>:
	G. – Reprinted from S.B. Akad. Wiss. Wien 104 (1): 297-336. 1895.

2859. <em>Fragmente zur Mykologie i-xxiv</em> (1902-1920). <em>Facsimile</em> reprint Lehre (J. Cramer) 1967, 2
vols. Oct. (ISBN 3-7682-0467-7). (<em>Fragm. Mykol.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: The <em>Fragmente zur Mykologie</em> were originally published as a series of 24 papers in the
	Sitzungsberichte der kaiserl. Akademie der Wissenschaften in Wien, Mathem. Naturw.
	Classe, Abth. 1, volumes III (1902)-129 (1920). Each <em>Fragment</em> (entry) carries a separate
	number (1-1214). The 1967 <em>reprint</em> includes the <em>General-Index der Fragmente 1 bis 1000</em> which
	must be used to find the entries in the reprint. For parts xix-xxiv it is necessary to use the
	indexes contained in the individual parts. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, NY.
<em>Vol. 1</em> of reprint:

The dates for the Hefte of the Sitzungsberichte cannot always be the dates of publication
since the dates on which the manuscripts were presented to sessions of the Academy are
sometimes later than the dates appearing on the covers.

Hofer, Johannes [Jean] (1697-1781), Swiss botanist. (<em>Hofer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 187; Dryander 2: 335, 3: 79, 214, 245, 4: 346.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Rothmaler (Repert. Sp. nov. 53(1): 29. 1944) dates the two publications by Hofer in
Acta helv. (phys.-math.-anat.-bot.-med.) 2: 14-20, and 131-159 at Feb 1755, thus antedat-
ing most other 1755 publications in systematic botany. The publication in the same journal
5: 267-268. 1762 cannot so far be dated with further precision.

Jahn, Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 56, 198-203. 1914 (bibl, portr.).

2877. <em>Beiträge zur Kenntnis der Flora von Central-Ost-Afrika</em>. Inaugural-Dissertation zur Er-
langung der philosophischen Doctorwürde einer hohen philosophischen Fakultät der Uni-
versität Jena eingereicht von Ferdinand Hoffmann aus Charlottenburg. Berlin (Druck von
W. &amp; S. Loewenthal, Grünstr. 4.) 1889. Oct. (<em>Beitr. Fl. Centr.-Ost-Afr.</em>).

<em>Thesis ed</em>.: 1889 (Bot. Zeit. 28 Nov 1889), [1]-39. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, HH, MO, NY, US. – It is not
	clear whether there was a separate trade edition (but see Bot. Zeit. 31 Jan 1890).

Hoffmann, Georg Franz (1760-1826), German botanist, professor of botany at Erlangen
(1789), Göttingen (1792) and Moscow (1804). (<em>Hoffm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MW; further material at GOET and LE. – Letters at LINN (Smith
corr.). – On 16 Sep 1815 G. F. Hoffmann wrote to J. E. Smith reporting the loss of his
collections by fire.
<em>Ref</em>.: Lindemann, Bull. Soc. Natural. Moscou 59(1): 304. 1884.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 75; Barnhart 2: 188; Backer p. 270; BM 2: 857; Bossert
p. 178; CSP 3: 386; DTS 1: 120, 4: xlv; Dawson p. 111, 112, 359, 417; Dryander 5: 285-286;
GR p. 20-21, cat. p. 65; Hawksworth p. 183; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Hoffm."); HU 678; IF p. 703;
Jackson p. 559 [index]; Kew 3: 8; Krempelh. 2: 56-58; Lasègue p. 337, 339, 353; Lipschitz 3:
18-19; LS 12396-12405; MW p. 184; NI 888-897; Plesch p. 265; PR 4125-4140 (ed. 1: 4581-
4590); Rehder 5: 397; RS p. 87-88; SBC p. 122 ("Hoffm."); SO 735a; ST p. 63; Stevenson p.
1245; TR 581-584; Zander ed. 10, p. 670-671.
Anon., Bot. Zeit., Regensburg 3: 255-256. 1804; Flora 9: 336. 1826.
Bourdeille, Bull. Soc. imp. Natur. Moscou ser. 2. 6: 364-365, 489-490. 1900.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 90. 1969.
Hausmann, F., Fl. Tirol 3: 1180. 1854.
H.E., Rev. Encycl. sér. 3. 43: 258. 1829.

	Bayer, bot. Ges. Regensburg 19: 1-96. 1933.

<sm>DATE OF BIRTH</sm>: Hoffmann was born at Marktbreit (Unterfranken) on 13 Jan 1760. The date
31.1.1761, cited by various older sources is erroneous. Grummann (GR p. 20) checked the
birthdate in the Marktbreit church archives.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 30: 395-396. 1975.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Smith, J. E., <em>Compendium florae Brittaniae in usum florae Germanicae</em> editum a
Georgio Francisco Hoffmann, Erlangae (apud Joannem Jacobem Palm) 1801. – 16mo (in
eights), p. [i-x], [1]-274, [1-6, index]. <em>Copy</em>: HH. – See under J. E. Smith.
<em>Note</em>: for Phytographische Blätter see no. 2889.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hoffmannia</em> O. Swartz (1788); <em>Hoffmannia</em> Willdenow (1789).

2878. <em>Enumeratio lichenum</em> iconibus et descriptionibus illustrata a Georg Franc. Hoffmann.
Fascic. I Lepra Verrucaria Tubercularia Scutellaria. Erlangae (Sumtibus Wolfgangi Wal-
theri) 1784 [-1786]. Qu. †. (<em>Enum. lich.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1784 [-1786], p. [i], [1]-102, <em>pl. 1-22</em>, uncol. copper engr. <em>Copies</em>: FH, G, MICH, NY;
	IDC 579. – PR states that the book was published in three parts, part 2 1784, part 3 1786.
	We have seen no t.p.'s of these parts and do not know the contents. Fasc. 1 possibly
	comprised p. [1]-54 and <em>pl. 1-8.</em> The text ends abruptly with p. 102.

2879. <em>Historia salicum iconibus illustrata</em> ... Lipsiae [Leipzig] (Impensis Siegfried Lebrecht
Crusii) 1785-1791. 2 vols. Fol. †. (<em>Hist, salic. ill.</em>).

vol.	fasc.	pages	plates	dates
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1	1	[1]-32	1-5	1785, Feb-Jun
	2	[33]-48	6-10	1785, Feb-Jun
	3	[49]-66	11-16	1786, prob. Sep-Oct
	4	[i*], [i], 67-78	17-24	1787, prob. Sep-Oct
2	1	[1]-12	25-29, 31	1791, Jan-Jun

The t.p. for vol. 1 [i*], dated 1787, was issued with part 4. The book was issued with coloured
(copies NY, U) as well as with plain plates (other copies seen), (copper engravings of
drawings by the author). <em>Copies</em>: B, G, HU (as AD 70); L, M, MO (a few pl. col.), NY (plates
col.) U (plates col), USDA; IDC 5954.

2880. Georg. Franc. Hoffmann med. doct. <em>De vario lichenum usu commentatio</em> sect. I. Erlangae
[Erlangen] (Impensis Joh. Jac. Palm.) 1786. Qu. (<em>Var. lich. usu</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1786, p. [1]-35, [36, theses]. <em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, NY.
<em>Ed</em>.[<em>2</em>]: 1787, see below under Mémoires,... sur l'utilité des lichens (no. 2881).

2881. Mémoires, couronnés en l'année 1786, par l'Académie des Sciences, Belles-Lettres et
Arts de Lyon, <em>sur l'utilité des lichens</em>, dans la médecine et dans les arts; par MM. G. F.
Hoffmann,... Amorcux, fils, ... et Willemet ... Lyon (Chez Piestre et Delamollière)
1787. Oct. (<em>Util. lich.</em>).

<em>Co-authors</em>: Pierre Joseph Amoreux (1741-1824) [?, author is "Amoreux fils"]; Pierre Rémi
	François de Paule Willemet (1762-1790).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1787 (priv. p. [3]: 17 Sep 1787), p. [i, iii*], [i]-xxxvi, followed by three articles: [a] by

PAGE: 239
HEADING: HOFFMANN. G. F.

	Willemet, p. [i], [1]-48, [b] by Amoreux, p. [i], [1]-103, and [c] by Hoffmann, p. [i], [1]-
	60, <em>pl. 1-8</em>, [i], 61-68, [1-3, privilège]. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, Stevenson; IDC 922.

[a] : Willemet, "<em>Lichénographie économique</em>, ou histoire des lichens utiles dans la médecine et les
	arts."
[b] : Amoreux, fils, "<em>Recherches</em> et expériences <em>sur les</em> divers <em>lichens</em>, dont on peut faire usage en
	médecine et dans les arts."
[c] : Hoffman, "<em>Commentatio de vario lichenum usu</em>." This is a reprint of the 1786 Publ. "De vario
	lichenum usu commentatio" (see no. 2880).
The text on p. [i]-xxxvi is by Jean Emmanuel Gilibert (1741-1814), who also served as editor.

2882. <em>Observationes botanicae</em>. Erlangen (apud Joannen[sic] Jacobum Palm) 1787. Qu. (<em>Ob-
sew. bot.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1787, p. [1]-19. <em>Copies</em>: G, USDA.

2883. <em>Vegetabilia cryptogama</em> [Erlangae (Sumtu Joh. Jac. Palm)] 1787-1790, 2 parts. Qu. (in
twos). (<em>Veg. crypt.</em>).

[<em>1</em>:] 1787 (p. viii, Mar 1787), cover, p. [i*, iii*], [i]-viii, [1]-42, <em>pl. 1-8.</em> Index on p. [3] cover.
[<em>2</em>:] 1790, cover, p. [i-vi], [1]-34, <em>pl. 1-8.</em>
<em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY, Stevenson, US, USDA. – The <em>plates</em> are uncoloured copper
engr. by the author. The title has "cryptogama" on the regular t.p.'s but "cryptogamica" on
the covers. These covers also carry the imprint.

2884. <em>Nomenclator fungorum</em>. Pars I. Agarici. Accedunt tabulae vi aeri incisae et ab auctore
delineatae. Verzeichniss der Schwämme. Erster Theil. Blätterschwämme. Mit 6 nach der
Natur vom Verfasser gezeichneten Kupfertafeln. Berlin (bey Joachim Pauli, Buchhändler)
1789. Oct. † (<em>Nomencl. fung.</em>).

<em>Part 1</em>: 1789 (p. vi: 18 Mar 1789; GGA 14 Sep 1789), p. [i]-viii, [1]-256, <em>pl. 1-6</em> (uncol. copp.
	engr.). <em>Copies</em>: NY, Stevenson, US. – Anonymous; see also no. 2885.
<em>Continuatio prima</em>, indice locupleta ... Erste Fortsetzung, nebst dreifachen register. Berlin
	(id.) 1790. Oct., <em>publ</em>.: 1790, p. [1]-85. <em>Copy</em>: Stevenson.
<em>Ref</em>.: BM 2: 857.

2885. <em>Abbildungen der Schwämme</em>. Erstes [-Drittes] Heft. Taf. i-x. [xxx]. 1790-1793. Qu. †. (<em>Abbild. Schwämme</em>).

<em>Heft 1</em>: 1790, p. [i-iii], <em>pl</em>. [<em>1-10</em>] (hand-col. copper engr.).
<em>Heft 2</em>: 1791, p. [i, cover], <em>pl</em>. [<em>11-20</em>] (id.), index on p. [iii], cover.
<em>Heft 3</em>: 1793, p. [i, ii, cover], <em>pl</em>. [<em>21-30</em>] (id.), index on p. [iii], cover.

<em>Copies</em>: FH, Stevenson. – 30 anonymously published plates and some text on the covers of the
	fascicles. According to P. Usteri, Ann. Bot. 12: 77-80 (1794) Hoffmann was the "Heraus-
	geber". There should have been 40 plates, intended to illustrate Hoffmann's also ano-
	nymous, <em>Nomenclator fungorum</em>, 1789-1790 † (no. 2884). The first two fascicles contain
	plates which are all (except for one) copied from James Bolton's <em>A history of fungusses</em>,
	growing about Halifax (Huddersfield 1788-1791). The third fascicle has 10 new species.
	The "Nachricht" contains the following statement: "... gröstentheils neue von Herrn
	Persoon zu Göttingen gesammelte und zu diesem Entzweck mitgetheilte [communicated]
	Arten, der Natur auf das getreueste von der Hand eines geschickten Mahlers nachgebildet
	..." A review of fascicles 1-3 (<em>tt. 1-30</em>) appeared in GGA of 30 Oct 1793.
<em>Ref</em>.: Killermann, S., Z. Pilz. 4: 92-96. 1925, 5: 50-57. 1925; Denkschr. bot. Ges. Regensburg
	19: 1-96. 1933.
	Schmid, Z. Pilzk. 12 (alte Folge 17): 54-60. 1933.

pl. cl. crypt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: three volumes, published in parts. <em>Copies</em>: G, USDA; IDC 813.

	celsissimi ac potentissimi Lusitaniae principis regentis domini nostri, et jussu, et auspiciis

2887. <em>Deutschland Flora</em> oder botanisches Taschenbuch für das Jahr 1791 ... Erlangen (Bey
Johann Jacob Palm) [1791]. Oct. (<em>Deutschl. Fl.</em>).

[<em>Erster Jahrgang</em>]: Jan-Mar 1791, frontisp., p. [i-xxvm], <em>pl. 1-12</em>, [i*-x*], [1]-360, [1, add.].
	<em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, U, USDA. – <em>Plates</em>: hand-col. copper engr., in other copies
	uncol. Issues (for all 4 vols): "theils on Velin-, theils on Schreibpapier."
<em>Zweiter Theil</em> "... für das Jahr 1795. Cryptogamie." Erlangen (id.) s.d., <em>publ</em>.: 1796,
	frontisp., p. [i-lxviii], [1]-200, [1-39, cont. and err.], <em>pl. 1-14. Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, US
	(2) USDA. – <em>Plates</em>: execution as in vol. for 1791; according to the publishers statement
	(Palm 1803) there should be <em>14 plates</em>, as in the US copies. <em>Date</em>: the Latin t.p. [iii] dated
	1795, p. xii: 1796.
<em>Dritter Jahrgang</em>: "... für das Jahr 1800 ... Dritter Jahrgang. I. Abtheilung. Erste bis
	Dreizehnte Klasse oder des ersten Jahrgang neue und vermehrte Auflage". Erlangen
	(id.), s.d. Oct. – <em>Publ</em>.: Mai-Dec 1800, frontisp., p. [i-xlviii], <em>pl. 1-12</em>, [1]-273, [274, impr.].
	<em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, U, US, USDA. – <em>Plates</em>: execution as in previous vols.
<em>Vierter Jahrgang</em>: "... für das Jahr 1804 ... Vierter Jahrgang oder des III. Jahrgangs II.
	Abtheilung. Vierzehnte bis drei und zwanzigste Klasse." Erlangen (id.), s.d. Oct. – <em>Publ</em>.:
	Feb-Mar 1804, frontisp. (by Chodowieky) p. [ii, alt. t.p. identifying this also as a new
	edition of the Erster Jahrgang. II. Abtheilung], [iii-xlviii], <em>pl. 1-12</em>, [i, h.t.], [1]-308.
	<em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, U, US, USDA.
<em>Note</em>: The number and arrangement of the unnumbered pages varies. Plates and accom-
	panying text may be combined or separate. None of the copies seen was exactly identical
	with any of the other.
<em>French ed.: La flore de l' Allemagne</em> ou étrennes botaniques pour l'an 1791 [... 1795]. Erlang
	(chez Jean Jacques Palm) 2 vols. 1791-1796.

<em>1791</em>: frontisp., p. [i-vi], <em>pl. 1-12</em> (as in orig.), [i-x], [1]-360, [361, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY.
<em>1795</em>: "Cryptogamie" Erlang (id.), publ. 1796 (p. 42: Mai 1796), frontisp., [i], [1-60], [1]-
	200, [39, ind., err.], <em>pl. 1-14</em> (id.). <em>Copy</em>: US.

PAGE: 241
HEADING: HOFFMANN, G.F.

	This is a reissue, with a french t.p. and latin preface, on velin, with col. plates, of the
	original sheets. Another reissue, with English title and latin preface is mentioned by the
	publisher Palm (1803), but was not seen by us.

2888. <em>Hortus gottingensis</em> quem proponit simulque orationem inchoandae professioni sacram

2895. Georg. Franc. Hoffmann ... <em>Genera plantarum umbelliferarum</em> eorumque characteres
naturales secundum numerum, figuram, situm et proportionem omnium fructificationis
partium. Accedunt icones et analyses aeri incisae. Mosquae (Sumtibus auctoris, typis N.S.
Vsevolozskianis) 1814. Oct. (<em>Gen. pl. umbell.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1814 (p. xxii: id. Nov 1813; possibly in parts and p.p. in 1815), p. [i]-xxix, [xxx], [1]-
	182. <em>Copies</em>: L, NY, USDA (bound with <em>Syllabus</em>, 1814 (2893), followed by <em>pl. 1a, 1b, 2-4</em>).
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1816 (p. xxii: id. Mai 1816). Copies vary slightly. The U copy is as follows: frontisp.
	engr. t.p. 1816, p. [i]-xxxiv, [1-2, consp., motto], [1]-94, [1, h.t. vol. 1, pars 2], [1-2, note],
	engr. t.p. 1816, 95-122, syllabus [1]-20, plates, <em>1a, 1b, 2-4</em>, prospectus [1]-4, Erörterungen
	[1]-34, [1-2, err.], [1-2, h.t. vol. 1, pars 1 and motto, wrongly bound]. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO,
	U, US, USDA. – The <em>Syllabus</em> was also issued separately (see above, 1814) (no. 2893).

2896. <em>Herbarium vivum</em>, sive collectio plantarum siccarum, Caesareae universitatis mos-
quensis. Publicae utilitatis causa in ordinem secundum Systema Linnaearum digessit et
edidit G. Fr. Hoffmann. Mosquae [Moskva] (Typis Universitatis) 1824-1825, 2 parts. Oct. (<em>Herb. viv.</em>).

PAGE: 242
HEADING: HOFFMANN, G. F.

<em>Pars 1</em>: 1824, p. [1]-179; <em>pars 2</em>: 1825, p. [1]-467. <em>Copy</em>: Helsinki University Library;
	photocopy at H. – Information by H. Luther and D. L. Hawksworth. The latter saw
	another copy at Leningrad and mentions the probable existence of a further copy at
	Moscow. In view of the existence of more than one copy the book must be considered as
	effectively published.

Hoffinann, [Heinrich Karl] Hermann (1819-1891), German mycologist, plant-geog-
rapher, and experimental systematist; Dr. med. Giessen 1841; practicing physician 1842;
Privatdozent 1842; extraordinary professor 1848; from 1853 full professor of botany; from
1851 director of the botanic garden at Giessen. (<em>H. Hoffm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: University of Giessen; some further material at MANCH and PC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 343 [index]; Barnhart 2: 189; BFM 321, 294;
BM 2: 857-858; Bossert p. 178; CSP 3: 387-388, 10: 250-251, 12: 339-340, 15: 892-893; De
Toni 1: lxiv; DTS 1: 120-122, (6)4: 154; Frank 3(Anh.): 45; IH 2: 280; Jackson p. 15, 97,
101, 163; LS 12406; Moebius p. 262, 318, 366; NI 897n, 898; PR 4141-4149 (ed. 1: 4591);
Ratzeburg 247-248; Rehder 5: 398; Stevenson p. 1245; Tucker 1: 345.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1892: 47; Bot. Gaz. 16: 350. 1891; Leopoldina 28: 49. 1892; Naturwiss.
	Wochenschr. 6: 471. 1891; Bot. Zeit. 49: 754. 1891.
Anon., Brockhaus' Conversations-Lexikon ed. 13. 9: 300. 1884.
Hoffmann, Ber. Oberhess. Ges. Nat. Heilk. 11: 183-184. 1864 (floristic appeal).

Hoffmann, Johan Frederik (1823-1841), Dutch botanist. (<em>J. F. Hoffm.</em>).

Hoffmann, [Karl August] Otto (1853-1909), German synantherologist of the Engler
School, studied at Berlin and Göttingen, from 1877 high school teacher at the Friedrichs-
Werdersche Gymnasium at Berlin. (<em>O. Hoffm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B; some further material at GOET.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 189; BFM 3167; BJI 1: 28; BM 2: 858, 6: 473;
CSP 10: 251, 15: 894; Hortus 3: 1195 ("O. Hoffm."); IH 2: 280; Kew 3: 9; KR p. 299;
Langman p. 373; NAF ser. 2. 2: 160; Rehder 5: 398; RS p. 88; Urban-Berl. p. 357; Zander
ed. 10, p. 671.
Anon., Nat. Nov. 1909: iii; Bot. Zeit. 67(2): 320. 1909.
Ascherson, P. F. A., Ver. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 51: (153)-158. 1910. (bibl. by Muschler).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) EP, <em>Die natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien</em>, ed. 1 (TL-2/1710). <em>Compositae</em> 4(5):
87-128. Feb 1890, 129-176. Mai 1890, 177-224. Aug 1890, 225-272. Jan 1891, 273-320. Jul
1892, 321-368. Sep 1893, 369-387. 22 Mai 1894 (<em>Hieracium</em> by A. Peter); Nachtr. 2-4(1): 320-
330. Nov 1897, (2): 75-78. 8 Oct 1900.
(2) <em>Compositae, in</em> Deutsch Ost Afrika 5(C) 1895.
(3) <em>Compositae, in</em> Engler, <em>Plantae Marlothianae</em>. 1888.
(4) <em>Compositae, in</em> Engler, <em>Pflanzenwelt Ostafrikas</em> C, p. 402-422. Aug 1895 (TL-2/1708).
For a complete list of Otto Hoffmann's numerous contributions on <em>Compositae</em> in publications
by others see the bibliography by R. Muschler, in Ascherson (1910).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Hoffmanniella</em> R. Schlechter ex A. Lawalrée (1943).

Hoffmannsegg, Johann Centurius, Graf von (1766-1849), German botanist, entomo-
logist and ornithologist; travelled in Hungary (1793-1794) and Portugal (1797-1801).
(<em>Hoffmanns</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Hoffmannsegg's mosses are at G; phanerogams at B (in part in the
Willdenow herbarium, extant), G, G-DC, H and HAL. The original mss. of the unpublished
<em>Flora lusitanica</em> (not to be confused with the <em>Flore portugaise</em>) was at B and is now destroyed. The
preface was saved (Staatsbibl. preuss. Kulturbesitz, Berlin), see Helm and Hirsch (1974).

<sm>NAME</sm>: The author spelled his name consistently Hoffmannsegg except on the t.p. of the <em>Flore
portugaise</em> ("Hoffmansegg").

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 189; BM 2: 858, 6: 473; Bossert p. 178; CSP 3:
389; Dawson p. 354, 417; Frank 3(Anh.): 45; GF p. 59; Hortus 3: 1195 ("Hoffmanns."); IH
2: 280; Kew 3: 9; Jackson p. 341, 425; Lasègue p. 105, 475, 570; Maiwald p. 89; MW p. 184;
NI 901; PR 4161-4163 (ed. 1: 4606-4610); Ratzeburg p. 248-251 ; Rehder 5: 398; RS p. 88;
SK p. 236; TL-2/812; Tucker 1: 346; Zander ed. 10, p. 671.
Anon., Allg. Garten Zeit. 18: 128. 1850; Bot. Zeit. 14: 48. 1856, 8: 56. 1850.
Dolezal, H., Friedrich Welwitsch 122-123, 125-126. 1974.
Frison, Ed., Henri Ferdinand Van Heurck 39. 1959.
Hall, N., Botanists of the Eucalypts 69. 1978.
Helm &amp; Hirsch, Bot. Jahrb. 94(4): 562-570. 1974 (preface to a destroyed mss. <em>Flora
	lusitaniae</em>).

HEADING: HOFFMANNSEGG

	Helm).
