<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Taxon 19: 556. 1970.

<sm>ARTISTS</sm>: Jacquin himself provided information on the artists employed by him in his
numerous sumptuously illustrated works in the preface (1, p. vii) to the <em>Plantarum rariorum
horti caesarei schoenbrunnensis descriptiones et icones</em>. The most important were Franz Scheidl,
Joseph Hofbauer, Ferdinand Bauer, Franz Bauer, Johannes Scharf, Martin Sedelmayer. See
Nissen 2: 91 for a reprint of Jacquin's text.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Jacquinia</em> N. J. Jacquin (1760, <em>orth. var.</em>); <em>Jacquiniella</em> Schlechter (1920); <em>Jaquinia</em>
Linnaeus (1760).

<sm>POSTAGE STAMPS</sm>: Austria 1977, 4 sch., yv 1369, issued 16-2-1977.

3241. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Enumeratio systematica plantarum</em>, quas in insulis Caribaeis
vicinaque Americes continente detexit novas, aut jam cognitas emendavit. Lugduni Bata-
vorum [Leiden] (apud Theodorum Haak) 1760. Oct. (<em>Enum. syst. pl.</em>).

<em>Orig. ed.</em>: Aug-Sep 1760, p. [i, iii-iv], 1-41. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, U; IDC 775. – "If you want any
	further copies of your booklet, please write to me." Gronovius to J. on 11 Nov 1760 (in
	Dutch; letter at W).
<em>Nürnberg reprint</em>: "... emendavit. Ad exemplar Lugduni Batavorum, apud Theodorum
	Haak, mdcclxi excusum Norimbergae stanno Christiani de Launoy recusum anno mdc-
	clxii." Oct.– <em>Publ</em>.: 1762 (the reference to the Haak edition as of 1761 is erroneous), p. [i,
	iii-iv], 1-41. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, UC, US, USDA.
<em>Zug facsimile: "Enumeratio systematica plantarum</em> 1760" with introduction by Frans A. Stafleu
	reprint 1967 Zug (Interdocumentation Company AG), Sertum botanicum V, p. [i*],
	[iii*-iv*], i-ix, facsimile: [i], [iii-iv], 1-41. <em>Copies</em>: G, FAS, MICH, NY, U, US. – See
	Taxon 16: 209. 1967.

The diagnoses are sometimes extremely short, consisting in some cases even only of one word.
Even so all binary names are validly published. Linnaeus frequently refers to the <em>Enumeratio</em> in
ed. 2 of his <em>Species plantarum</em>, Jacquin himself, in his <em>Selectarum stirpium</em> (1763) only oc-
casionally. The 1763 publication is an important complement to the 1760 Enumeratio and
should always be consulted with it.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon, [review], GGA 1763: 600. 20 Jun 1763.
	Rothmaler, W., Repert. Sp. nov. 53: 33. 1944 (gives 15 Mai as date of <em>publ</em>.).
	Stafleu, F. A., Introduction to Jacquin's Caribbean Enumeratio, in <em>facsimile</em> edition. Zug
	1967; Jacquin and his American plants 1971 (see above); Gorteria 5: 208-213. 1971.
	Howard, R. S., J. Arnold Arb. 54: 435-470. 1973.

PAGE: 409
HEADING: JACQUIN, N. J.

3242. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Enumeratio stirpium plerarumque, quae sponte crescunt in agro
vindobonensi</em>, montibusque confinibus. Accedunt observationum centuria et appendix de
paucis exoticis. Cum tabulis aeneis... Vindobonae [Wien] (impensis Joannis Pauli Kraus)
1762. Oct. (<em>Enum. stirp. Vindob.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1762, p. [i-iv], [1]-315, [index 316-322], <em>pl. 1-9. Copies</em>: BR, G, MICH, MO, NY,
	Stevenson, US, USDA; IDC 5343. – See Jacquin, <em>Collectanea</em> 1: 366-367 for relation (in
	date of <em>publ</em>.) with Crantz, <em>Stirp. austr. stirp.</em>, fasc. 1, which is stated to have been published
	after the <em>Enumeratio</em>.
<em>Addenda</em>: see Jacquin, Observ. bot. icon. 41-48. 1764 (no. 3244).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon, [review], GGA 1763: 895-896. 15 Sep 1763.
	Rothmaler, W., Repert. Sp. nov. 53: 35. 1944.
	Steam, W. T., Taxon 9: 209-210. 1960.

3243. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Selectarum stirpium americanarum historia</em> in qua ad linnaeanum
systema determinatae descriptaeque sistuntur plantae illae, quas in insula Martinica,
Jamaica, Domingo, aliisque, et in vicinae continentes parte, observavit rariores: adjectis
iconibus in solo natali delineatis. Vindobonae [Wien] (ex officina Krausiana) 1763. Qu. (<em>Select, stirp. amer. hist.</em>).

<em>Orig. ed.</em>: 5 Jan 1763, p. [i-x], [i]-vii, [viii-xii], [1]-284, [1-14, indices, expl. pl.], front., <em>pl. 1-
	183, 37*</em>, copper engravings of drawings by Jacquin. Incidental coloured engravings
	occur, but there were also at least three copies (fide Ebert) on "dutch paper" with fully
	coloured engravings. One of these is in the National Library, another, formerly owned by
	the Erzherzog Anton Victor von Österreich, is now at the Hunt Botanical Library (HU
	576). A special edition with 264 coloured drawings is mentioned below under no. 3249. –
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, G, HU(col.), MICH, MO, U(partly col.), US(2), USDA; IDC 934.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: New York (Hafner Publishing Company, Inc., New York) 1971, with an
	introduction by Frans A. Stafleu, p. [F1]-F32, facsimile: same as orig., 2 vols, (plates in
	vol. 2). <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U.
<em>Further editions</em>: See below under nos. 3249-3250; see also under J. Zorn.
<em>Reissue of plates only</em>: "Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Icones selectarum stirpium americanarum</em>." Viennae
	(apud A. Blumauer) 1797, front., [i, t.p.], [1-3, consp.], <em>pl. 1-37, 37*-183.</em> (uncol.). <em>Copy</em>:
	USDA.
The <em>Enumeratio</em> of 1760 was a prodromus to the 1763 folio and should always be consulted
with it. This is the more pressing since Jacquin, for unknown reasons, did not refer to the 1760
publication of his new taxa in his <em>Historia</em>. For further details on these two works see Dandy
(DA 1967), Stafleu (1967, 1971, 1971a) and Howard (1973).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon, [review], GGA 1764: 743-744. 2 Aug 1764.
	Cobres, J. P. von, Deliciae cobresianae 590. 1782.
	Ebert, Allg. bibl. Lexikon Leipzig 1821 (no, 10686).
	Junk, Rara 15. 1900; Catalogue 206: no. 151. 1977 (<em>col. pl.</em>).
	Stafleu, F. A., Introduction to Jacquin's Caribbean Enumeratio, in <em>facsimile</em> edition, Zug
	1967; Gorteria 5: 208-213. 1971; Jacquin and his American plants. 1971a (<em>in</em> facsimile
	edition; see above).
	Howard, R. A., J. Arnold. Arb. 54: 435-470. 1973 (lists correct names).

3244. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Observationum botanicarum</em> iconibus ab auctore delineatis
illustratarum ... Vindobonae [Wien] (ex officina Krausiana) 1764-1771, 4 parts. Fol. (in
doubles). (<em>Observ. bot.</em>).

<em>2</em>: Apr 1767, p. [i-vii], [1]-32, [1, err.], <em>pl. 26-50.</em>

<em>Copies</em> MICH, MO, NY, U, US(2), USDA; IDC 5254.
<em>Plates</em>: col. or uncol. copper engr. or etchings of drawings by author.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: announced, but not yet published, by Koeltz 1974.

	Kuntze, O., Rev. gen. 1: cxxxi. 1891.

3246. <em>Hortus botanicus vindobonensis</em>, seu plantarum rariorum quae in horto botanico vindo-
bonensi, augustissimae Mariae Theresiae munificentia regia in universitatis patriae excel-
lens ornamentum publicamque utilitatem exstructo, coluntur, icones coloratae et succinctae
descriptiones. Cura et sumptibus Nicolai Josephi Jacquin... Vindobonae [Wien] (typis
Leopoldi Joannis Kaliwoda,...) 1770-1776. Fol. (<em>Hort. bot. vindob.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1770-1771, p. [i-x], 1-44, <em>pl. 1-30</em> [1770], <em>31-100</em> [1771], (<em>pl. 31</em> fold-out); frontisp. (plan
	garden, NY copy).
<em>2</em>: 1772-1773, p. [i, iii], 45-95, [1-2, ind.], <em>pl. 101-200.</em>
<em>3</em>: 1776-1777, p. [i, iii], 1-52, <em>pl. 1-100</em>, (nos. <em>1, 4, 8, 54</em> fold-outs) (probably: 1-28, <em>pl. 1-50.</em>
	1776; <em>29-52, 51-100</em>. 1777), 2 p. index sometimes added.

<em>Copies</em> (first fasc. numbered): MO (71), NY (74), Teyler (81); IDC 409. – The plates are
hand-coloured copper engravings by F. Scheidl. It is possible to follow the printing of the
plates in Jacquin's letters to Linnaeus. It is not always clear, however, when the fascicles were
actually available to the public. Only 162 copies printed of first fascicle.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sotheby 389 (sold £ 5000).
	Schrader, H. A., J. Bot. 1808(1): 495.

3247. <em>Florae austriaceae</em>, sive plantarum selectarum in Austriae archiducatu sponte crescen-
tium, icones, ad vivum coloratae, et descriptionibus, ac synononymis illustratae. Vol. 1[-5]
Opera et sumptibus Nicolai Josephi Jacquin. Viennae Austriae (Typis Leopoldi Joannis
Kaliwoda,...) 1773-1778. 5 vols. Fol. (<em>Fl. austriae.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1 773. p [i, iii-iv], 1-61, <em>pl. 1-100.</em>

<em>4</em>: 1776, p. [i, iii], 1-53, [54, expl. front.], <em>pl. 301-400, 392</em> *[uncol.], no. 336 fold-out.
<em>5</em>: 1778, p. [i, iii-iv], 1-56, [1-4, ind.], <em>pl 401-450, app. 1-50.</em>

<em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, Teyler. – <em>Plates</em>: hand-coloured, unsigned, engravings, mostly by
	F. Scheidl. Plates of high quality.
<em>Ref</em>.: Bartlett, H. H., 55 rare books 1949, no. 48.

3248. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Miscellanea austriaca</em> ad botanicam, chemiam, et historiam
naturalem spectantia, cum figuris partim coloratis... Vindobonae [Wien] (ex officina
Krausiana) 1778-1778, 2 vols. Qu. (<em>Misc. austriac.</em>).

<em>1</em>: "1778" possibly issued only in 1779, p. [i-iv], [1]-212, <em>pl. 1-21</em>, handcoloured copper
	engravings of drawings by Jacquin, engraved (but only a few so signed) by Adam.

<em>Copies</em>: BR, G, M, MICH, MO, NY, Stevenson, U, USDA; IDC 5976. – See Sotheby 390
(Collins) on issues on different paper.

3249. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Selectarum stirpium americanarum historia</em> in qua ad Linnaeanum
systema determinatae descriptaeque sistuntur plantae illae, quas in insulis Martinica,
Jamaica, Domingo, aliisque, et in vicinae continentis parte, observavit rariores; adjectis
iconibus ad auctoris archetypa pictis. [Wien, 1780-1781]. Fol. (<em>Select. stirp. amer. hist.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In two fascicles, the first in 1780, the second probably in 1781 (see the extensive reviews
	in GGA 29 Sep and 13 Oct 1781), engr. t.p., p. [1]-236, [1-4, expl. pl.], <em>pl. 1-264</em>, handcol.
	original drawings. <em>Copy</em>: NY. - The book has in general the same text as no. 3243 (1763)
	but with additional remarks (137 pp.). A number of species is treated much more
	extensively. References to Murray's <em>Systema</em> of 1774 are added. The book contains 264

PAGE: 411
HEADING: JACQUIN, N. J.

	handcoloured plates which are copies of Jacquin's originals. Only 12-18 copies were issued
	and delivered to the buyers with different title-pages. These title-pages are (as far as
	reported in the literature) by Franz Bauer. The text was reprinted in 1788 (Mannheim,
	Oct.) with references to the plates of the 1780 edition (see below no. 3250). Other copies
	e.g. at the British Museum, Teyler's Foundation Haarlem, Library of Congress, National-
	bibliothek Wien. Zorn's <em>Auswahl schöner und seltener Gewachse</em> and his <em>Dreihundert auserlesene
	Amerikanische Gewächse</em> (q.v.) are based on this work. – A true colour facsimile edition was
	offered by the trade (ca. 1967) but never published.
<em>Ref</em>.: DU 152; IDC 934 (n.v.).
	Cobres, J. P. von, Deliciae cobresianae 590-592. 1782.
	Ebert, Allg. bibl. Lexikon, Leipzig 1821, no. 10687.
	Wiltshear, F. G., J. Bot. 51: 140-141. 1913 (q.v. for several bibliographical differences
	between the copies).

	NY, USDA. – Text only, references to the plates of the 1780 edition (no. 3249).

3251. <em>Icones plantarum rariorum</em>. Editae a Nicolao Josepho Jacquin ... Vindobonae [Wien]
(prostant apud Christianum Fridericum Wappler; Londini apud B. White et filium;

For the contents of the fascicles see Schubert. Each contained 25 plates (issued without
regard to the sequence later assigned to them except the last, 16th, published 1795, which
contained seventy-four plates).
The text of vols. 2 and 3 was issued with the 16th fascicle. Nissen (2: 91) reprints the
information on the artists provided by Jacquin in the preface to the <em>Hortus Schoenbrunnensis</em>.
648 Coloured copper engravings mainly by Joseph Hofbauer, Ferdinand and Franz Bauer
and Joseph Scharf. Twelve copies were printed on elephant folio.

3253. Nicolai Josephi Jacquin <em>Collectanea</em> ad botanicam, chemiam, et historiam naturalem

3255. <em>Plantarum rariorum horti caesarei schoenbrunnensis</em> descriptiones et icones. Opera et sump-
tibus Nicolai Josephi Jacquin ... Prostant Viennae apud C. F. Wappler; Londini apud B. et
J. White; Lugduni Batavorum apud S. et J. Luchtmans. 1797-1804, 4 vols. Fol. (<em>Pl. hort.
schoenbr.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1797, p. [i*, iii*], [i]-xxi, [1]-70, <em>pl. 1-129.</em>
<em>2</em>: 1797; p. [i], [1]-68, <em>pl. 130-250.</em>
<em>3</em>: 1798, p. [i], [1]-80, <em>pl. 251-400.</em>
<em>4</em>: 1804, p. [i], [1]-56, <em>pl. 401-500.</em>

<em>Copies</em>: BR (no. 31), MO (no. 134), NY (no. 32), US (no. 121) (numbers in front page base
line of vol. 1); IDC 129. – The four volumes bear the dates 1797, 1797, 1798 and 1804 on the
title-pages, but there are reasons to assume that publication was more involved. Volume 1
was completed by 3 Mai 1798 (Mag. Encycl. 1798(4): 389). Volumes 1 and 2 were reviewed
(as of "1798") only in 1800 by the Med.-Chir. Zeitung (Salzburg) [1800(1): 257-261]. Banks
received a letter from Jacquin dated 18 Jan 1803 in which the sending of vol. 3 part 2 was
announced. Vol. 4 was announced and sent by Jacquin on 5 Mar 1805. The history of the

PAGE: 413
HEADING: JACZEWSKI

book merits further investigation. – The 500 coloured copper engravings are mostly of
drawings by Johannes Scharf and Martin Sedelmayer.
<em>Ref</em>.: Garside, J. S., Afr. Bot. 8: 201-224. 1942 (on Schoenbrunn gardens).

3256. <em>Fragmenta botanica</em>, figuris coloratis illustrata, ab anno 1800 ad annum 1809 per sex
fasciculos edita. Opera et sumptibus Nicolai Josephi Jacquin. Viennae Austriae (typis
Mathiae Andreae Schmidt, typogr. universit.) [1800-] 1809. Fol. (<em>Fragm. bot.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In six parts, 1800-1809 (p. vi: Cal. Mart. 1800), p. [i-vi], [1]-86, [1-2, index], <em>pl. 1-138.</em>
	<em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY, U; IDC 5977. – The plates are hand-coloured, unsigned, copper
	engravings. – Fasc. 6 was ready by 16 Mar 1809 (letter to de Candolle at Genève).
	Number 1 came out in the summer of 1800, 2 appeared in 1801 (Ann. Bot. 1: 64. 1805)
	(Dawson, Banks letters p. 446, 448); 4 came out before 20 Aug 1806, 5 after Mar 1807, 6
	Feb-early Mar 1809. The history of the book should be further investigated.
<em>Ref</em>.: DU 158; Sotheby 394 (sold at £ 6000,-).
	Steenis-Kruseman, M. J. van, Fl. males. Bull. 26: 2018. 1972.

3257. <em>Stapeliarum in hortis vindobonensibus cultarum</em> descriptiones figuris coloratis illustratae.
Vindobonae [Wien] (prostant apud Wappler et Beck), Londini (apud White) 1806-[1819].
Fol. (<em>Stapel. hort. vindob. cult.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In five fascicles between 1806 and 1819; the contents and precise dates of which are
	unknown; p. [i-viii], <em>pl</em>. [<em>1-64</em>], unnumbered hand-coloured engraved plates with letter-
	press. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, Teyler, USDA.
<em>1</em>: possibly 1806 (fide Pritzel).
<em>2</em>: ready by 16 Mar 1809.
<em>3</em>: 7 Mar 1813 (letter J. F. Jacquin to A. P. de Candolle).
<em>4</em>: 2 Jan 1817 ("a paru de ces jours," letter idem).
<em>5</em>: 20 Nov 1819 (date fide NI: copy sent to A. P. de Candolle on 24 Jan 1820); published by J.
	F. Jacquin.

3258. <em>Genitalia Asclepiadearum controversa</em>. Auctore Nicolao Josepho L. B. a Jacquin ... Vien-
nae (apud Carol. Ferdinand. Beck) 1811. Oct. (<em>Genit. Asclep.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1811 (p. 8: Dec 1810), p. [1]-137, [138-140], <em>1 pl</em>. (col. copp., unsigned). <em>Copies</em>: G,
	MO, USDA.

Jaczewski, Arthur Louis Arthurovic de (1863-1932), Russian mycologist and phyto-
pathologist at St. Petersburg, Petrograd and Leningrad. (<em>Jacz</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE; other material at B, BR, E and K. Exsiccatae: <em>Fungi Rossiae
exsiccati</em>, (fasc. 1-7, nos. 1-350, 1895-1900), (with Vladimir Leontjevic Komarov and Wol-
demar Tranzschel); set at FH.

548, cat. p. 65; IH 2: 308; Kew 3: 139; LS 12959-13015, 34895-34964, suppl. 12847-12892;

<em>1</em>: 1870-1875, p. [i*], [i]-xl, [1]-155, [157]-338, [399]-740.
<em>2</em>: 1876.187g, p. [i]-iv, [1]-104, [105]-275, [277]-520, [521]-778.
<em>Index</em>: p. [i]-xl.

<em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – This reprint has independent pagination (printed page nos.) with an index
	which refers to these reprint page numbers. The reprint of vol. 1 came out in three parts as
	indicated above, the first with a t.p. dated 1870, the second (157-338) in 1873 and the
	third (399-740) in 1875. The second volume came out in four parts without indication of
	dates. <em>Original publication</em> took place in nine parts of the "Verhandlungen" [Berichte über
	die Thätigkeit] der St. Gallischen Naturwissenschaftlichen Gesellschaft, as follows.

PAGE: 415
HEADING: JAEGER, G. F.

Part	Berichte	pages	dates	pages reprint	date
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1	1869/70	[245]-299	1870 or 1871	[1]-	1870
2	1870/71	[359]-451	1872	-155	1872
3	1871/72	[309]-490	1873	[157]-338	1873
4	1872/73	[61]-236	1874	[339]-512	1874
5	1873/74	[53]-278	1875	[514]-740	Apr 1875
6	1874/75	[85]-188	1876	2: [1]-104	Jan-Apr 1876
7	1875/76	[201]-371	1877	2: [105]-275	Jan-Jun 1877
8	1876/77	[211]-454	1878	2: [277]-520	Jan-Sep 1878
9	1877/78	257-361,	1879	2: [521]-778	Jan-Sep 1879
		362-514
index	[213]-252	1880	[i]-xl	Jan-Sep 1880

<em>Copies</em> of reprints of original journal issue with journal page numbers: BR, NY.
<em>Reissue</em>: 1897.-The nine parts were reissued with new covers and title pages in 1897 (see Bot.
	Zeit. 55(2): 272. 1897). This reissue can be recognised because <em>all</em> covers and t.p.'s give
	Jaeger and Sauerbeck as joint authors. Actually Jaeger died on 23 Aug 1877. Sauerbeck
	collaborated from part 7 onward and published parts 8-9 and the index solely, basing
	himself on the Jaeger manuscripts. Part 9 was actually issued under joint authorship. <em>Title-
	pages</em>: undated, "<em>Genera</em> ... autoribus Dr. Augusto Jaeger et Fr. Sauerbeck. Pars I [-IX]
	(J. B. 69-70) [-(77-78)]. Sancti Galli Werner Hausknecht."
	<em>Copies</em>: FH (2), M, Steere. – Each part has the originaljournal sheets plus a newt. p. [i] and
	a cover.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1978, Vaduz (J. Cramer), based on the Steere copy (now at MO) of the re-issue;
	with introduction by William Campbell Steere (1907-x).

James, Edwin (1797-1861), American physician and botanist and explorer on Long's
exploring expedition to the sources of the St. Peters River; Colorado's first botanist; from
1836 nr. Burlington, Iowa. (<em>E. James</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY. – Plants collected byjames were described byjohn Torrey (1824,
1828). Early authors cited them as "iter Long" (see Ewan 1950).

<sm>NOTE ON NAME</sm> (by Barnhart): His papers in Trans. Am. philos. Soc. ser. 2. 2, 1825 are signed
E. P.James.

p. 465, 466; Lenley p. 240; ME 3: 604 [index]; Merrill p. 245-247, 702; NAF ser. 2. 5: 244;
Pennell p. 610; PR 4389; Rehder 1: 321; Zander ed. 10, p. 675.

Earle Smith, Bartonia 28: 16. 1957.

James, Joseph Francis (1857-1897), American naturalist; from 1881-1886 professor of
medical botany at Cincinnati College of Pharmacy and custodian of the Society of Natural
History (Cincinnati); from 1886-1888 professor of botany and geology at Miami University,
Oxford, Ohio; from 1889-1891 assistant palaeontologist with the USGS; from 1891-1897
vegetable pathologist at USDA. (<em>J. James</em>).

James, Thomas Potts (1803-1882), American bryologist; collaborator of Leo Les-
quereux; lived at Philadelphia 1803-1869; at Cambridge, Mass. 1869-1882. (<em>T. James</em>).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) See Lesquereux and James, <em>Manual of the mosses of North America</em>.
Boston (Cassino &amp; Co.), 1884 (TL-2/4421).
(2) Assisted Darlington in the preparation of <em>Flora cestrica</em>, 1853 ed. (TL-2/1310).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: In a printed announcement of his death (copy at MO) his widow, Isabella James,
writes "Until within a few hours of his death, Mr. James was working on a Manual of North
American Mosses, which he, in connection with M. Leo Lesquereux, was preparing for the
press, giving the result of the study of the past forty years."
See A. D. Rogers (1944) for many notes on James and on the rôle played by him in the
publication of Lesquereux and James, <em>Manual</em> (see above, composite works).

<sm>PORTRAITS</sm>: See Bossert p. 194, and Gozzaldi (1903).

Jaubert, Hippolyte-François, Comte de (1798-1874), French politician and botanist,
one of the founders of the Société botanique de France, pupil of Desfontaines, Mirbel, and of
Laugier, member of the Chambre des députés and minister of public works 1831-1842.
(<em>Jaub</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Jaubert's original herbarium is in part at P (many duplicates at G).
The types of the <em>Ill. pl. orient.</em> are presumably also at P; they are in part drawings in the
"collection des vélins" of the <em>Muséum</em>.

<em>Ref</em>.: Germain de Saint-Pierre, Bull. Soc. bot. France 22: x-xxvii. 1875.
	Steinberg, Webbia 32(1): 28. 1977 (FI material via herb. Desf).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 431, 12(2): 270; Barnhart 2: 247; BM 2: 928;
Bossert p. 196; CSP 3: 539, 8: 18 ("Jaubert, A."), 12: 365; Hortus 3: 1196 ("Jaub."); IF 707;
IH 2: 314; Jackson p. 191, 378, 422; Kew 3: 156; Laségue p. 111, 572 [index]; MW p. 217;
Nl 985; Plesch p. 280; PR 4397-4399 (ed. 1: 4865); Rehder 5: 432; Saccardo 2: 59-60; SK 4:
cxci; Sotheby 396; TL-2/208; Tucker 1: 370; Zander ed. 10, p. 675.
Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 15 (bibl.): 236. 1869 (Jaubert moved his collections from Paris
	to Berry); Rev. bryol. 2: 16. 1875.
Bureau, L. E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 21: 188, 351-352. 1874.
Germain de Saint-Pierre, E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 22: x-xxvii. 1875.
Jaubert, H. F., Note sur les travaux scientifiques de M. le Comte Jaubert. Paris 1857, 4 p.
	(bibl.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 18 (C.R.); 36. 1871; Unedémission à l'institut [Paris 1872],
	12 p., (on administrative quarrel at the Institut de France).
McPhail, I. et al., Catal. Redout. 69 (no. 52). 1963.
Trimen, H., J. Bot. 13: 32. 1875.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Jaubertia</em> Guillemin (1841): <em>Jaubertia</em> Spach ex Jaubert &amp; Spach (1850).

3303. <em>Illustrationes plantarum orientalium</em> auctoribus Comite Jaubert et Eduardo Spach ...
Parisiis (apud Roret bibliopolam,...) 1842-1857, 5 vols. Qu. (<em>Ill. pl. orient.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1842-1843 (t.p.), p. [i*, iii*], [i-vi], [1, expl. map] [1]-176, <em>pl. 1-100</em>, 4 maps.

<em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY, Teyler; IDC 814.

Jaume Saint-Hilaire, Jean Henri (1772-1845), French botanist. (<em>Jaume St.-Hil.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – The original drawings for no. 3305 are at Paris
(Muséum d'Histoire naturelle, mss. 1861).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 247; BL 2: 104, 672; BM 2: 928-929; CSP 3:
540; Hortus3: 1196 ("Jaume St.-Hil."); Jackson p. 113, 274; Kew3: 156; Langman p. 394;
MW p. 217; NI 986-991; Plesch p. 280-282; PR 4400-4405 (ed. 1: 4867-4875); Sotheby 397-
400, 848; TL-2/1293, 1409-1410, 1547; Tucker 1: 370.
Blunt, W., Art bot. ill. 180, 182. 1950.
MacPhail, I. et al., Catal. Redout. 52. 1963.
Nissen, Philobiblon 6(9): 337. 1933.
Persoon, C. H., Syn. pl. 1: 397. 1907.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Collaborator, <em>Dictionnaire des sciences naturelles</em>, ed. Cuvier, see Tl 2/1293.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Jaumea</em> Persoon (1807). <em>Note: Hilairanthus</em> Van Tieghem (1898) and <em>Hilairella</em> Van
Tieghem (1904) are dedicated to Auguste Francois César Prouvençal de Saint-Hilaire
(1779-1853), q.v.

3305. <em>Exposition des families naturelles</em> et de la germination des plantes, par Jaume Saint-
Hilaire; contenant la description de deux mille trois cent trente-sept genres, et d'environ
quatre mille especes, les plus utiles et les plus intéressantes. Cent dix-sept planches, dont les
figures ont été dessinées par l'auteur, représentent [sic] les caractéres des families et les
différens modes de germination des plantes monocotylédones et dicotylédones. Paris (chez
Treuttel et Würtz,...), Strasbourg (même Maison de Commerce) an XIII. – 1805, 2 vols.
Oct. and Qu. (<em>Expos. fam. nat</em>).

<em>1</em>: Feb-Apr 1805, p. [i-iii], [1]-7, [i]-lxiii, [lxiv, avis], [1]-512, <em>pl. 1-70, A-E.</em>
<em>2</em>: Feb-Apr 1805, p. [i]-[iii], [1]-198, <em>pl. 71-103</em>, [part 2:] 119-473, [474, expl. pl.], <em>pl. 104-112.</em>
<em>Copies</em>: BR(qu., col. pl.), G(oct., uncol.), MO(oct., uncol.), NY(oct., uncol.), US(qu., col.);
	IDC 5979.

-The plates are coloured or uncoloured copper engr. of drawings by the author. The JGLE
announcement of Feb 1805 announces the availability of coloured copies. These coloured
copies (BR, US) are on large paper (qu.).
See Collins (Sotheby 848) for a bibliographic collation.
<em>Ref</em>.: RS p.90; Sotheby 848; SY p. 24.
	Croizat, Amer. Midl. Nat. 30: 808-809. 1943.

3306. <em>Plantes de la France</em>, décrites et peintes d'aprés nature par M. Jaume Saint-Hilaire...
Paris (Chez l'Auteur,... de l'imprimerie de P. Didot l'aîné) [1805-] 1808-1822[-1824], 10
vols. Qu. and Oct. (<em>Pl. France</em>).

<em>1</em>: [1805-]1808, p. [i*], [i]-xxviii, <em>pl. 1-94</em> with text.
<em>2</em>: 1808 (t.p.), [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 95-207</em> with text.
<em>3</em>: 1809 (t.p.) [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 208-301</em>, with text.
<em>4</em>: 1809 (t.p.), [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 302-400</em>, p. [i]-vi index, [i-ii, subscr.], [1, err.].
<em>5</em>: 1819 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 401-500</em>, [<em>472 a</em>], <em>494</em> as <em>"504"</em>, with text. Frontispiece portrait
	of H.L. Duhamel du Monceau.
<em>6</em>: 1819 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 501-600</em>, with text. Frontispiece portrait of R. L. Desfontai-
	nes.
<em>7</em>: 1820 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 601-700</em>, with text. Frontispiece portrait of André Thouin.
	"... de l'imprimerie de Firmin Didot, pére et fils."
<em>8</em>: 1821 (t.p.), front, [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 701-800</em>, with text. Frontispiece portrait of J. B. P. A. Monet
	de Lamarck. "... de l'imprimerie de Firmin Didot."
<em>9</em>: 1822 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 801-900</em>, with text. Frontispiece portrait J. J. H. de
	Labillardiere. "... de l'imprimerie de Didot le jeune."
<em>10</em>: 1822 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 901-1000</em>, with text; [3, subscr.], [1]-15 index of plates.–
	Frontispiece of J. H. Jaume Saint-Hilaire. "... Didot le jeune."

PAGE: 430
HEADING: JAUME ST.-HIL.

<em>Reissue vol. 1</em>: 1822 (t.p.), p. [i*], [iii*], [v*]-x*, [i]-xxviii, <em>pl. 1-100 (or 1-94</em>), with text. –
	Frontispiece portrait of J. P. de Tournefort. "De lmerie de Didot le jeune."
<em>Reissue vol. 2</em>: 1822 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 101-207</em> (or <em>95-207</em>), with text. – Frontispiece
	portrait of S. Vaillant. "... Didot le jeune."
<em>Reissue vol. 3</em>: 1822 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 208-301</em>, with text. – Frontispiece portrait of J.
	Barrelier. "De rimprimerie le Normant, ..."
<em>Reissue vol. 4</em>: 1822 (t.p.), front., [i, t.p.], <em>pl. 302-400</em>, with text. – Frontispiece portrait of M.
	Adanson. "... le Normant,..."
<em>Copies</em>: MICH (qu.), MO(qu.), USDA (qu.); IDC 815.

Publication took place in parts, the contents of which are only incompletely known to us. the
dates of the parts can be established, however, from the contemporary reviewing journals
(JT, JGLF, BF, Mag. Enc.) and from the dates of receipt by the Académic The announce-
ment in the JT of 16 Jan 1807 states that publication was on a monthly schedule, that up to
1807 the parts contained 6, but from Jan 1807 onwards 8 plates, and that there was an octavo
and a quarto issue; the earlier parts contained 12 pages of text each. The octavo issue was on
"papier jésus" the quarto issue on laid paper "papier vélin". The 1000 plates are colour-
printed stipple engravings (some "terminees au pinceau") of drawings by Jaume himself.
Number of copies printed: 400. – Semipopular.
<em>Ref</em>.: DU 159; GF p. 61; Sotheby 397, 398.

3307. <em>Mémoire sur les indigoferes du Bengale et de la Chine</em>, ou histoire et description de quelques
vegetaux peu connus et dont les feuilles donnent un tres bel indigo. Par M. Jaume Saint-
Hilaire. s.l.n.d. [Paris 1826]. Fol. (<em>Mém. indigof. Bengale</em>)

<em>Publ</em>.: 26Jan 1826 (BF); limited to an edition of 100 copies; p. [5]-12. <em>pl. 1-5</em> (col). <em>Copy</em>: G.

3308. <em>Mémoire sur la culture du poivrier noir</em>, precede de quelques observations critiques sur
l'administration du royaume, et orné de figures en noir et en couleur. Par M. Jaume Saint-
Hilaire. s.l.n.d. [Paris (Firmin Didot) 1827]. Fol. (<em>Mémpoivr. noir</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan 1827 (BF), p. [1]-7. [8, expl. pl], <em>pl. 1-2</em> (col.). <em>Copy</em>: G.

3309. <em>Traité des arbrisseaux et des arbustes cultivés en France</em> et en pleine terre, par M. Jaume
Saint-Hilaire; ouvrage precede d'une instruction sur la culture des arbres et des arbrisseaux,
par M. Thouin, ... Paris (chez l'auteur, ... de rimprimerie de Firmin Didot, ...) 1825, 2
vols. Qu. (in twos). (<em>Traité arbr. cult. France</em>).

<em>Instruction</em> by: Andre Thouin (1747-1824).
<em>1</em>: 1825, p. [i], [1]-27 [dated 18 Aug 1824], <em>pl. 1-88</em>, with text.
<em>2</em>: 1825, p. [i], <em>pl. 89-176</em> with text.
<em>Copies</em>: MO, NY. – <em>Plates</em>: colour printed stipple engravings, retouched by hand, taken from
<em>Plantes de la France</em> (see no. 3306). Issued in 22 livraisons of 8 plates with text from Sep 1825
onward, extending at least into 1826 (prospectus dated 24 Sep 1825).

3310. <em>Traité des arbres forestiers</em>, ou histoire et description des arbres indigènes ou naturalisés,
dont la tige a de trente a cent vingt pieds d'élévation, et sert aux constructions civiles et
navales; par M. Jaume Saint-Hilaire. Ouvrage précédé d'une instruction sur la culture des
arbres, par M. Thouin, ... et orne de figures imprimées en couleur, et retouchees au pinceau.
A Paris (Chez l'auteur, ... de rimprimerie de Firmin Didot, ...) 1824. Qu. (<em>Traité arbr.
forest.</em>).

<em>Introduction</em>: André Thouin (1747-1824).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1824 (p. 27: 18 Aug 1824), in 15 fascicles of 6 plates with text (precise dates not
	known), torn tisp. portr. Duhamel du Monceau, p. [i*], [i]-iv, [1]-27, [copy of USDA has
	the following plates:] <em>pl. 4, 5, 7, 8, 11-21, 26-29, 32-33, 37, 42, 50, 52, 53, 56-63, 54-55, 72-81, 89,
	1-3, 6,9-10, 22-25, 30-31, 34-36, 38-41, 43, 46, 44, 45, 47-49' 64-69 81-88, 90</em> (<em>pl. 1-90</em>, of which
	<em>51</em> and <em>70-71</em> missing). <em>Copy</em>: USDA. – Plates stipple engravings, colour-printed, retouched
	by hand.

3311. <em>Laflore et la pomonefrangaises</em>, ou histoire et figures en couleur, des fleurs et des fruits de
France ou naturalisés sur le sol français ... Paris (chez l'Auteur, ...) 1828-1830. Qu., Fol. (<em>Fl. pom. franç.</em>).

PAGE: 431
HEADING: JAVORKA

<em>Publ</em>.: 1828-1835, 6 vols (in parts), as follows:
<em>1</em>: 1828, p. [i*-vi*], [i]-viii, <em>pl. 1-100.</em>
<em>2</em>: 1829, p. [i-iii], <em>pl. 101-200.</em>
<em>3</em>: 1830, p. [i], <em>pl. 201-300.</em>
<em>4</em>: 1831, p. [i], <em>pl. 301-400.</em>
<em>5</em>: 1832, p. [i], <em>pl. 401-500.</em>
<em>6</em>: 1833[-1835], p. [i] <em>pl. 501-544</em> (Plesch copy: <em>501-552</em>).

Originally issued in 136 (138?) livraisons (of <em>4 pl</em>. with text) of which the contents are
incompletely known. It was planned to publish 800 plates but in so far as we know the regular
publication was terminated with plate <em>544</em>: however, plates<em>545-552</em> are present in the former
Plesch copy; this number is also mentioned by Brunet. We have seen too few copies to
establish the nature of these last two instalments. Livraison 1 appeared on 30 Aug 1828.
There were three issues.
a.	"jesus grand", on ordinary wove paper. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY.
b.	"vélin" in qu. <em>Copies</em>: incomplete at G and USDA.
c.	"vélin" in fol, 12 copies issued. No copies seen.

3312. <em>Flore parisienne</em>, ou description des plantes qui croissent aux environs de Paris et dans
les départements voisins, avec l'indication de leurs usages en agriculture, en médecine et dans
les arts. Accompagnee de la figure d'une ou de plusieurs espèces de chaque genre, avec
l'analyse des parties de la fleur, du fruit et de la graine, dessinées de grandeur naturelle et
grossies; par M. J. H. Jaume Saint-Hilaire, ... Paris (chez l'auteur, ... chez Mme Hu-
zard, ... chez Hautecoeur-Martinet, ... et Adde, ...) 1835. Qu. (<em>Fl. paris.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1835, p. [1]-112, map, ill. <em>Copy</em>: NY (p. 105-112, and map lacking; see PR).

3313. <em>Les Dahlia</em>, ou histoire, description et culture des plus belles espèces ou variétés de
Dahlia. Ouvrage orné de figures peintes d'après nature par Mile Nanine Guillon. Première
livraison. Paris (Didot) s.d.† (<em>Dahlia</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: no copy seen; information taken from PR ((ed. 1) 4875) who saw the first livraison at
	Goettingen (<em>4 col. pl.</em>). Apparently it was planned to issue 10 parts of 4 plates each.

Jàvorka, Sandor A. (1883-1961), Hungarian botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. Budapest 1906; in
various functions at the Botany Department of the Hungarian National Museum from 1905-
1940; from 1945 active in the Hungarian Academy of Sciences. (<em>Jáv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP (13.000); duplicates in A, B, BPU, C, E, F, GH, H, LE, MICH,

Jeanbernat, Ernest-Marie-Jules (1835-1888), French physician, geologist and botanist;
studied at Paris; dr. med. 1862; practicing physician at Toulouse 1862-1866; from 1866 on
combining a business and a scientific career. (<em>Jeanb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TLM (50.000 bryoph.).

315; Jackson p. 279, 280, 291; Kew 3: 158; Rehder 5: 432; Tucker 1: 370.

	540. 1888, ser. 9. 1: 1-28. 1889.

	Sci Toulouse ser. 9.1: 562-587. 1889.

Jeanpert, Henri Édouard (1861-1921), French botanist; originally in private business;
from 1907 connected with the Muséum d'histoire naturelle, Paris, in charge of the Cosson
herbarium. (<em>Jeanp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, PC; further material: E,F, G.

also 161, 166, 201; CSP 16: 91-92; IF suppl. 1: 82, 3: 212; IH 2: 315; Kew 3: 158: Rehder 5:
432; Tucker 1: 370.

Jeffrey, Edward Charles (1866-1952), Canadian botanist; Ph. D. Harvard 1898; at
Toronto (1898-1902); from 1902 plant morphologist at Harvard; professor of plant mor-
phology 1907-1933. (<em>E. Jeffr.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Jeffr.</em>).

Jeffs, Royal Edgar (1879-1933), American botanist; M.S.A. Iowa State College 1910; Ph.
D. State University Iowa 1923; professor of biology at Iowa Wesleyan College 1910-1912; at
Friends University 1913-1914; instructor (1916-1921) and professor of botany (1923-1932)
at the University of Oklahoma. (<em>Jeffs</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at IA, ISC, MICH, OKL and OKLA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 249; BL 1: 208, 303; Hortus 3: 1196 ("Jeffs");
IH 2: 315; NAF ser. 2. 5: 244.

Botany, Univ. of Calif. (Berkeley) 1887-1947, founder of the California botanical Society
(1913), founder and editor of Madroño (1916-1934). (<em>Jeps</em>.).

	24b, [25]-1238. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, MO, NY, U, US.
<em>Second printing</em>: 1938.
<em>Third printing</em>: 2 Apr 1951, Berkeley and Los Angeles (University of California Press), p. [1]-
	24, 24a-24h, 25-1238. <em>Copies</em>: NY, US, – Reprinted in facsimile 1957.
<em>Fourth printing</em>: 1960, Berkeley.
The dates for ed. 1 are those given on the verso of the title page. Wheeler has questioned the
reliability of these dates but in the absence of proof to the contrary they should be accepted.
C.V. Morton received a letter from Jepson (3 Apr 1939) stating that the Manager of the
Associated Students Store had verified that the parts were received and on sale on the dates
specified. The parts were indeed not advertised. See also Heckard et al. (1967). Com-
plimentary Copies of the parts as issued were sent to K, LE and the Library of Congress.
<em>Ref</em>.: Wheeler, Amer. J. Bot. 29 (Suppl.): 19-20. 1942.
	Heckard et al., Madroño 19(4): 98-99. 1967.

Jessen, Karl Friedrich Wilhelm (1821-1889), German botanist, bibliographer, his-
torian of science and friend of Pritzel; Dr. phil. Kiel 1848; 1850 "Privatdozent" in Berlin;
1852-1877 professor of botany at the agricultural College of Eldena and the university of
Greifswald; from 1877 in Berlin. (<em>Jess</em>.).

3362. <em>Alpenpflanzen 1</em> [Wien ca. 1807]. (<em>Alpenpfl</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sets of coloured copper engravings by Johann Knapp, ordered by Johann Baptist are
	found at BM, GZU and W. For an extensive analysis and description of two of the sets (85
	in GZU, and 36 at the Institut für Anatomie, Graz) and for the collection of 185 original
	watercolours (Alpenpflanzen I) see Widder (1960). The portfolio of original drawings at
	GZU contains part of the reputedly 300 drawings made for this purpose. Further sets of the
	engravings are at W (33 plates, not 92, with handwritten title <em>Icones plantarum alpinarum cum
	Archiducis Johannis peractae</em>, mentioned under this name by PR) and 51 plates at BM (BM
	2: 934: "Johann Baptist ... <em>Icones plantarum alpestrium Austriae</em>" title handwritten). An
	"<em>Alvawetischer Catalog von Alpenpflanzen</em>" by Johann Knapp (mss) is also at GZU.
	<em>Ref</em>.: Schrader, J. Bot. 1808(2): 373.
	Rupprecht, Arch. Geogr. hist. Staats-Kriegskunst 12: 138-140. 1821 (n.v., fide Widder,
	provides details on Knapp's work and Johann Baptist's assignment to him).
	Widder, F., Jahrb. Ver. Schutze Alpenpflanzen 25: 104-117. 1960 (extensive details).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Johsonia</em> P. Miller (1754, <em>nom. rej.</em>) and <em>Johnsonia</em> R. Brown (1810, <em>nom. cons.</em>) are

amended edition of J. Gerard's <em>Herball</em> (TL-2/1993). The same, probably, holds for <em>Johnsonia</em>
Adanson (1763). <em>Johnsonia</em> K. B. Kordoe (1965) is dedicated to Jesse Harlan Johnson (1892-
x), American geologist and paleobotanist, who is also commemorated in <em>Harlanjohnsonella</em> G.
F. E. Elliott (1968).

Johnston, Ivan Murray (1898-1960), American botanist at the Arnold Arboretum; Ph.
D. Harvard 1925; in Chile 1925-1926; from 1922-1931 assistant at Gray herbarium with
Robinson and Fernald; 1931-1938 research associate Arnold Arboretum; ass. professor of
botany Harvard 1938-1960; ass. dir. Arnold Arboretum 1948-1953; specialist on Boragi-
naceae. (<em>I. M. Johnst.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Correll (1961): "I have never met anyone who displayed more zest for life and living
than did Ivan Murray Johnston ... His was a brilliant, complicated and, to some, con-
troversial personality."

Johnstone, William Grosart (died c. 1860), British algologist. (<em>Johnstone</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Trail (1886), in his obituary of Croall: "The "British Sea Weeds" was nominally the
joint production of W. G. Johnstone and Alexander Croall, but I have reason to know that
nearly the whole of the work devolved on Croall, while the remuneration went to Johnstone,
who died, or in some other way conveniently vanished before accounts were squared
between them."

3385. <em>Elémens de botanique</em>, ou méthode pour connoitre les plantes, par Pitton de Tournefort.
Edition augmentée de tous les supplémens donnés par Antoine de Jussieu; enrichie d'une
concordance avec les classes, les ordres du systême sexuel de Linné, et les familles naturelles
créees par Laurent-Antoine de Jussieu; mise à la portée de tous les hommes par
l'interprétation française du texte grec ou latin des espèces admises dans les auteurs, par des
additions très-considérables au dictionnaire des termes du botaniste, etc. etc. etc. Par N.

Jordan, [Claude Thomas] Alexis (1814-1897), French botanist, whose extremely nar-
row species concept led to "jordanism" and Jordan-species (jordanons) vs. Linnaean species.
(<em>Jord</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Jordan had a private herbarium which he kept at Lyon, and left to
Hilarion Joseph Borel. Later it came to the Université libre de Lyon (LY). Kew (K) received
a European herbarium made by A. Jordan in 1911 (1225 specimens). Other important sets of
Jordan plants are at BM (1800) and P (1000). The manuscripts and original drawings of the
<em>Icones</em> are the property of the Société botanique de France.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 259,6(1): 109, 12(3): 32; BM 2: 942; CSP 3: 577-

PAGE: 461
HEADING: JORDAN

578, 8: 37, 16: 140; DSB 7: 165-167; Hortus 3: 1197 ("Jord."); IH 2: 331; Jackson p. 97, 117,
226, 274, 285, 429; Kew 3: 192-193; Moebius p. 56; NI 1008; PFC 1: xliv-xlv; Plesch p. 285;
PR 4476-4482 (ed. 1: 4945); Render 5: 437; SO 906a; TL-2/see Fourreau, J. P., Gilibert, J.
E.; Tucker 1: 375-376; Zander ed. 10, p. 676.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1898: 45; Bull. Soc. bot. Deux-Sèvres 1908-1909: <em>pl. I. 1909</em> (portr.); Bull.
	Soc. bot. France 23: clxxxvi-clxxxvii. 1876 (on herb.).

	Piquemal).

Stearn (in SK 4: cxcii) gives some additional information based on contemporary reviews.
Vol. 2, pp. 17-24 are listed by him for 1871, pp. 25-52 for Jun 1903 and vol. 3 as a whole also
for Jun 1903. – The interruption in the publication was due to the death of Fourreau on 13
Dec 1870 (battle of Nuits). Camille A. Jordan continued the publication in 1903 from p. 25
and <em>t. 281</em> of vol. 2 onward. The 501 coloured plates are by the artists: C. Delorme, J.
Fourreau, P. Gallaud, A. Mignot.
<em>Ref</em>.: Pellegrin, Bull. Soc. bot. Fr. 84: 296-297. 1937 (on orig. water-colours).

Oct.

	journal.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Issued: <em>Algae aquaticae quas in littora Maris Dynastium
Jeveranum et Frisiam Orientalem alluentis rejectas</em>, fasc. 1-20, 1816-1824. Sets at B, BM, C, FH,
FH, G, H, HBG, KIEL, L, LD, LE, PAV, PC, ROST, STR. The title refers to the seacoasts
of Eastern Frisia and of the "Erbherrschaft Jever", part of old Friesia, later of Oldenburg.
<em>Schedae</em>: see no. 3433.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 2: 949; Frank 3(Anh.): 48; IH 2: 335; PR (alph.);
Urban-Berl. p. 265.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Juergensia</em> K. P. J. Sprengel (1818); <em>Juergensia</em> H. G. L. Reichenbach (1841).

3433. <em>Algae aquaticae</em> quas, et in littora maris Dynastium Jeveranum et Frisiam orientalem
alluentis rejectas, et in harum terrarum aquis habitantes, collegit et exsiccavit Georg
Heinrich Bernhard Jürgens, Jeveranus ... Wasser Algen aus der Nordwest-Küste Deutsch-
lands, besonders Jever- und Ostfrieslands, und in deren Gewässern gesammelt. Heraus-
gegeben von Georg Heinrich Bernhard Jürgens, Advocat ... Gedruckt bey C. L. Mettcker in
Jever, und in Commission bei den Gebrüdern Hahn in Hannover, 1816-1824, 20 Hefte
(decades). Fol. (<em>Alg. aquat.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: The text accompanying the above-mentioned exsiccatae consists of four pages per
	Heft, p. [i] t.p., p. [iii-iv] the descriptions. For further details see Sayre who saw copies at
	FH, L, PC and STR. We saw, in addition, a set of the text of fasc. 1-16 at Regensburg and
	G.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 82-83. 1969.

3446. Philippi Caspari Junghans, ... <em>Icones Plantarum ad vitam impressae</em> Centuria I. Halae
Salicae [Halle] (Typis Frider. Guil. Michaelis, prostant venales apud auctorum et in

<em>Publ</em>.: In parts from Easter 1787 onward. Contents and dates of these parts are as yet
	unknown. In all 68 Plates were issued; we have seen only an incomplete copy (NY): p. [i-
	iv], <em>Pl. 1-12</em>, watercolours on faint copper outlines.
<em>Reissue</em>: 1792 as <em>Icones plantarum rariorum</em>. (n.v.) The remaining plates were later sold by
	auction.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1787, in parts, contents unknown, <em>pl. 1-37.</em> (n.v.).

Junghuhn, Franz Wilhelm (1809-1864), German botanist and traveller. (<em>Jungh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L. Duplicates in many herbaria. The type-specimens of the <em>Plantae
Junghuhnianae</em> of Miquel (see under that name) are all at L (received from the Botanical
Society of the Netherlands). The types of J's <em>Observationes mycologicae</em>, Linnaea 5: 388-410. Jul
1830, are in HAL (through Schlechtendal) (see Schmid 1929).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 49: 493. 1866 (herb, to L).
	Schmid, Z. Pilzkunde 13(1): 3-10. 1929.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 349. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 296; Barnhart 2: 263; BL 1: 107, 112, 303; BM 2:
951; Bossert p. 201; CSP 3: 592, 8: 47; Frank 3(Anh.): 48; GR p. 93; Hortus 3: 1197
("Jungh."); IF p. 708; IH 2: 334; Jackson p. 117, 396, 397; JW 1: 444, 2: 193, 3: 355, 4: 392,
5: 243; Kew 3: 203; Langman p. 402; Lasègue p. 495, 506; LS 13451-13458, 35125; MW p.
220; NI suppl. (alph.); PR 4535-4537 (ed. 1: 5003-5006); Quensted t p. 226; Rehder 5: 441;
SBC p. 124 ("Jungh."); SK 1: 267-269; TL-2/2077; Tucker 1: 378-379; Urban-Berl. p. 288,
303.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1888: 206; Bull. Soc. bot. France 11 (bibl.): 190. 1864; Flora 47: 348, 474-
	480. 1864, Bot. Zeit. 22: 184. 1864.
De Wit, H. C. D., <em>in</em> C. G. G. J. van Steenis, Fl. males, ser. I. 4(2): ciii. 1949 (portr.).
Embacher, F., Lexik. Reisen 159-160. 1882.
Junghuhn, F. W., Licht- en schaduwbeelden uit de binnenlanden van Java. ed. 5, 1867, iv
	444 p. (portr.); De onuitputtelijke natuur. Amsterdam 1966.
Mägdefrau, K., Gesch. Bot. 104, 268. 1973.
Rochussen, Nat. Tijdschr. Ned. Indië 28: 342-356. 1865.
Schmidt, M. C. P., ed., Franz Junghuhn. Biographische Beiträge zur 100. Wiederkehr seines
	Geburtstages. Leipzig 1909, xiv, 374 p. (portr., important and original biography).
Schmidt, M. et al., Gedenkboek Franz Junghuhn 1809-1909. 's Gravenhage 1910 (with
	main bibl. by Muller).

Wichmann, Petermanns geogr. Mitt. 55: 297-300. 1909 (portr.).
Zuchold, E. A., Jahresb. nat. ver. Halle 5: 27. 1853.

HEADING: JUNGHUHN

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Junghuhnia</em> Corda (1842); <em>Junghuhnia</em> Miquel (1859); <em>Junghuhnites</em> Goeppert
(1854); <em>Neojunghuhnia</em> Koorders (1909).

3448. <em>Praemissa in floram cryptogamicam Javae insulae</em>. Fasc. i. Continet enumerationem fungo-
rum, quos in excursionibus per diversas Javae regiones hucusque observavit Franciscus
Junghuhnius s.l.n.d. [Batavia 1838]. Oct.†. (<em>Praem. fl. crypt. Java</em>).

<em>Fasc. 1</em>: 1838 (all Published), Published separately, in advance, from <em>Verh. Batav. Genootsch.</em>
	17(2): 1-86, <em>pl. 1-15.</em> Part 17(2) of the Verhandelingen has no title-page, but several of the
	articles contained in it have individual title-pages dated 1838 (pp. 137, 159). It is therefore
	reasonable to assume that Junghuhn's article which is undated and which precedes these
	other articles was also published in 1838. Montagne gives the date 1838. <em>Preprint</em>: [1]-86,
	<em>pl. 1-15</em> (col. liths.). <em>Copies</em>: G, NY; IDC 5981. – <em>Copy</em> of journal Publ.: Stevenson.
<em>Ref</em>.: Montagne, C, Ann. Sci. nat. Bot. ser. 2. 16: 306-320. 1841.

3449. <em>Novagenera et species Plantarum florae Javanicae</em>, Tydschr. nat. Gesch. Physiol. 7: 285-317,
<em>pl. 8.</em> 1840. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov 1840; reprint with orig. p. [285]-317. <em>Copy</em>: U. – To be cited from journal.

3450. <em>Über Javan'sche Balanophoreen</em>, Nova Acta Leop. 18, suppl. 1: [201]-228. 18141. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1841. <em>Copy</em>: KNAW. – To be cited from journal.

3451. <em>Topographische und naturwissenschaftliche Reisen durch Java</em>, von Dr. Friedrich [sic]
Junghuhn, ... zum Druck befordert und bevorwortet durch Dr. C. G. Nees von Esenbeck.
mit einem aus 38 Tafeln und 2 Höhenkarten bestehenden Atlasse. Magdeburg (Emil
Baensch), Rotterdam (A. Baedeker), Amsterdam (J. Müller) 1845. Oct. (<em>Reis. Java</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan 1845, p. [i]-x, [1]-518, [2, err.]. <em>Copies</em> KNAW, U.
<em>Atlas</em>: "<em>Topographischer und naturwissenschaftlicher Atlas</em> zur Reise durch Java ... enthaltend 38
	lithographirte Tafeln und 2 Höhen-Karten," Magdeburg (Emil Baensch) 1845, oblong
	Qu., p. [i, t.p.], [4, expl. pl.], <em>pl. 1-11, 11b, 12-37</em>, 2 maps. <em>Copies</em>: KNAW.
<em>Ref</em>.: K.M., Bot Zeit. 3: 588 passim. 1845 (extensive reviews), English translation Ann. Mag.
	nat. Hist. 16: 329-332, 462-466. 1845, 17: 46-48, 469-476. 1846.

3452. <em>Java</em>, deszelfs gedaante, bekleeding en inwendige structuur. Amsterdam (P. N. van
Kampen) 1850-1854, 4 vols. Oct. (<em>Java</em>).

<em>Orig. ed.</em>: For the very involved and sometimes even confused bibliography see Muller in
	Schmidt (1910). The KNAW copy in original covers has the original Flrst livraison (P. N.
	van Kampen), p. 1-123, which was to be substituted by a new "aflevering" (livraison) 1 of
	the second edition with the pagination 1-176. Part 11 * of this copy has an imprint Mieling
	and is dated '1854' with pagination [125]-188, rather than 177-240, followed by 241-368.
	The new livraison 1 was issued in 1852, p. 1-176, with the imprint P. N. van Kampen. It
	served at the same time as livraison 1 for ed. 2, with the imprint Mieling. This part,
although dated 1852, came out in 1853.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

<em>Atlas van Platen bevattende elf pittoreske gezigten</em>, s.l.n.d. [1854], eleven coloured Plates by
	Junghuhn, lithographed by Mieling. The lists of Plates in vol. 1, p. 667 mention twelve
	Plates but one of them, the G. Lamongan, is the frontispiece to vol. 1 itself. Various
	printings exist because two different spellings appear of Gunung (mountain) (Goenoeng).

<em>Second edition</em>: 1853-1854, 's Gravenhage (C. W. Mieling), "tweede verbeterde uitgave."
	<em>1</em>: 1853 (t.p.), front., lith. t.p., [i]-viii, [1]-671.

	<em>4</em>: 1854 (t.p.), lith. t.p., [i]-xii, [1]-538.
<em>Copy</em>: U. – The first "aflevering" of this second edition also exists with the imprint P.N. van
	Kampen 1852, p. 1-176.

	Junghuhn. Nach der zweiten, verbesserten Auflage des holländischen Originals in's
	Deutsche übertragen von J. K. Hasskarl." Leipzig (Arnoldische Buchhandlung) 1852-
	1854. Oct.

	("soeben").

	bibl. by Muller).

Jungk, Christian Ludwig (fl. 1807), German physician, pupil of K. P. J. Sprengel (<em>Jungk</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 263; PR 4527 (ed. 1: 4994); Rehder 5: 441.
Kraus, G., der Botanische Garten der Universität Halle 2: 35. 1894.

3454. <em>Observationes botanicae in floram Halensem</em>. Halle (formis F. A. Grunerti patt.) 1807. Oct. (<em>Observ. bot. fl. Hal</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 11 Apr 1807 (date of "promotion"), 26 p. "Liber omnino quadrat cum Sprengelii
	mantissa prima Florae Halensis [TL-1 no. 1260] praeter non additam novarum spe-
	cierum centuriam (PR); "... besteht aus nichts anderem, als aus den in Sprengel's
	Mantissa prima in demselben Jahre unter gleicher Kopf-Ueberschrift veröffentlichten 26
	ersten Seiten, denen Sprengel dann für die Mantissa noch eine Centurie neuer Pflanzen
	seines Herbariums anhing" (Schlechtendal). The Publication by Junk has priority over
	that by Schlechtendal himself in the Mantissa (4 Jul 1807). We have seen no copy of the
	original dissertation.
<em>Ref</em>.: PR 4527; IDC 5749 (sub Sprengel).
	Schrader, Neues J. Bot. 3: 194-198. 1809.
	Schlechtendal, D. F. L. v., Bot. Zeit. 15: 519. 1857.

Juratzka, Jakob (1821-1878), Austro-Hungarian, Moravia-born, bryologist and "Ober-
ingenieur der Dicasterialgebäude-Direction" [direction of the law-courts] in Vienna. (<em>Jur</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W. – For further collections and duplicates see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 73, 542; Barnhart 2: 264; BM 2: 951; Bossert p.
202; CSP 3: 593, 8: 48, 10: 367; DTS 1: 134-136, 6(4): 46; IH 2: 335; Kanitz 265; Kew 3: 203;
Klašterský p. 102; LS 13462a-13462b; Maiwald p. 235; SBC p. 124 ("Jur."); Zander
ed. 10, p. 676.
Anon., Botanik und Zoologie in Oesterreich 1850-1900. Wien 1901 (portr.); Bot. Not. 1879:
	31; Hedwigia 17: 176. 1878; Flora 61: 544. 1878; Bot. Zeit. 37: 96. 1879; Oesterr. bot. Z.
	23: 1-4. 1873 (Portr) 28: 413. 1878; Rev. bryol. 6: 16. 1879.
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. Länder 36. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4).

Dolezal, H., Friedrich Welwitsch 117. 1974.
Juratzka, J., Zur Moosflora Oesterreichs, Verh. zool. bot. Ver. Wien 9 (Abh.): 97-102, 313-
	316. 1859, 10: 121-122, 367-368, 673-674. 1860, 11: 121-124, 235-237, 431-433. 1861, 13:
	499-504. 1863. [for a further list of J's contributions to the bryology of Austria see CSP].

Trimen, H., J. Bot. 17: 32. 1879.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 82. 1903, 3(3): 68. 1905.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Juratzkaea</em> P. G. Lorentz (1866); <em>Juratzkaeella</em> W. R. Buck (1977).

3456. <em>Die Laubmoosflora von Oesterreich-Ungarn</em>. Handschriftlicher Nachlass Jakob Juratzka's
enthaltend die Beschreibung der in Oesterreich-Ungarn wachsenden Laubmoose mit Aus-
nahme der Leskeaceae, Hypnaceae, der Andreaeaceae und der Sphagnaceae.
Zusammengestellt von J. Breidler und J. B. Förster. Herausgegeben von der k.k. zoologisch-
botanischen Gesellschaft in Wien. Mit dem Bildnisse Juratzka's. Wien (W. Braumüller),
Leipzig (F. A. Brockhaus) 1882. Oct. (<em>Laubm.-Fl. Oesterr.-Ung.</em>).

<em>Editors</em>: Johann Breidler (1828-1913), Johann B. Förster (1843/4-1907).
<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1881 (p. viii: Oct 1881; Nat. Nov. Jul 1882; Bot. Zeit. 25 Aug 1882, Flora Aug
	1882), frontisp. portr. Juratzka, p. [i]-viii, [1-2, abbr.], [1]-385. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, U.
<em>Ref</em>.: Limpricht, Hedwigia 21: 154-156. Oct 1882.

HEADING: JUSSIEU, ADR.

Jussieu, Adrien Henri Laurent de (1797-1853), French botanist; son of A. L. de Jussieu;
professor of botany at the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle 1826. (<em>Adr. Juss.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P–JU. Some types also in general herbarium of P and PC. The
herbarium is available on IDC microfiches (IDC 6206).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2: 283; Ainsworth p. 31-32, 310; Barnhart 2: 264; BM 2:
952; Bossert p. 202; Bret. p. 124; CSP 3: 595-596, 12: 375; DSB 7: 196-197; Frank 3(Anh.):
49; Hortus 3: 1197 ("A. Juss."); IH 2: 335; Jackson p. 565 [index]; Kew 3: 204; Langman p.
402; Lasègue p. 133, 572 [index]; Lenley p. 461; MW p. 220; NI 1014-1017; Plesch p. 285;
PR 4539-4545 (ed. 1: 5007-5023); Rehder 5: 441; RS p. 90; SO 2477; TL–2/669, 863, 2025;
Tucker 1: 379; Zander ed. 10, p. 676.
Anon., Bonplandia 2: 266-267. 1854; Bot. Not. 1855: 159; Bot. Zeit. 11: 527. 1853; Bull. Soc.
	bot. France 1: 386-399. 1855 (bibl.); Flora 36: 600. 1853, 37: 237. 1854; Proc. Linn. Soc.
	London 2: 321-322. 1855.
Costantin, Ann. Sci. nat. ser. 10. 16: 416 seq. 1934.

	membres Soc. Agric. France 1848 à 1853: 435-466. 1865 (bibl.); also in Mém. Soc. centr.
	Agric. France 1854: 216-236 and Soc. centr. Agric. France, séance 8 Nov 1854, Paris 1854,

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Jussieu published the volume <em>Botanique</em> in the <em>Cours élémentaire d'histoire
naturelle</em> ... by A. de Jussieu, Mime-Edwards, et F. S. Beudant, Paris (Langlois et Leclercq;
Fortin, Masson et Cie,...) s.d. [1843], p. [ii-iii], [1]-2, [1], [1]-728, duod. (in sixes). (<em>Copy</em>:
NY), which went through twelve editions (ed. 12, 1884) and which was translated into
English, German and Italian. (2) J. published also <em>Epistolae Caroli a Linné ad Bernardum de
Jussieu ineditae</em>,... Cambridge, Mass., 1854.
(3) Contributed botanical articles to d'Orbigny, <em>Dict. univ. hist. nat.</em> signing himself "Ad.J",
13 vols. Paris 1840-1849; also to Bory de Saint-Vincent, <em>Dict, class hist, nat.</em>, 16 vols. Paris
1822-1831 (TL-2/669).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Clokie, H., Acc. herb. Oxf. 279. 1964; Burdet, Candollea 31: 131-132. 1976.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Adriana</em> Gaudichaud-Beaupré (1825).

3457. <em>De Euphorbiacearum generibus</em> medicisque earundem viribus tentamen, tabulis aeneis 18
illustratum ... Parisiis (Ex typis Didot junioris,...) 1824. Qu. (<em>Euphorb. gen.</em>).

	uncoloured copper engravings of drawings by Jussieu. <em>Copies</em>: G, L, M, MICH, MO, NY,

PAGE: 476
HEADING: JUSSIEU, ADR.

3458. <em>Mémoires sur les Rutacées</em>, ou considérations sur ce groupe de plantes, suivies de
l'exposition des genres qui les composent, et accompagnées de 16 planches ... Paris (Impri-
merie de A. Berlin, ...) 1825. Qu. (<em>Mém. Rutac.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Dec 1825 (reprint presented to Académie on 2 Jan 1826), p. [i, iii], [1]-160, <em>pl. 1-15</em>,
	[<em>16</em>] (<em>14-29</em>). <em>Copies</em>: M, MICH; IDC 1596, 5135. – Reprinted, with independent
	pagination, from Mém. Mus. Hist. nat. [Paris] 12: 384-542, <em>pl. 14-29</em> (<em>1-16</em>). 1825. The 16
	uncoloured copper engravings are of drawings by Jussieu. – The publication in the journal
	bears the title: <em>Mémoire sur le groupe des Rutacées, copies</em>: G, MO, USDA. – NY has a copy of
	the reprint with journal pagination preceded by the special t.p. as cited above.

3459. <em>Monographie du genre Phebalium</em> [Paris, 1825]. Qu. (<em>Monogr. Phebalium</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1825, p. [1]-13, <em>pl. 1-3</em> (<em>10-12</em>; uncol. engr.). <em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY, USDA. –
	Reprinted from Mem. Soc. Hist. nat. Paris 2: [125]-137, <em>pl. 10-12.</em> 1825. – The drawings of
	<em>pl. 11</em> and <em>12</em> were by Mlle Félicie de Jussieu.

3460. <em>Mémoire sur le. groupe des Méliacées.</em> [Paris] s.d. [1832]. Qu. (<em>Mém. Meliac.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov 1832 (BF 3 Nov), p. [1]-152, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (= <em>12-23</em>), table. <em>Copies</em>: M, NY. – Reprinted
	from Mém. Mus. Hist. Nat., Paris, 19: [153]-212, [213]-304, <em>pl. 12-23.</em> 1830. These <em>mémoires</em>
	were published in parts of various size. The sheets 20-38, occupied by de Jussieu's article,
	were published in 1831 and/or in 1832. Jussieu cites various works from 1831 on p. 304. In
	view of the delay in publication de Férussac published an abbreviated version containing
	the valid publication of all new names in his Bull. Sci. nat. géol. 23: 234-241 of Nov 1830
	with the note: "Le retard qu' éprouve cette publication [in Mém. vol. 19], nous engage à
	ne pas attendre pour en rendre compte, que l'impression en soit entièrement terminée."
	The new names from Jussieu's memoir date therefore from the publication in Férussac's
	<em>Bulletin</em> of Nov 1830. It is possible that this <em>Bulletin</em> itself suffered a delay of some months in
	publication; the text mentions a space of time of over a year since the paper was read on 25
	Jan 1830. We are grateful to Dr. B. T. Styles (Oxford) for drawing our attention to this
	problem. – The 12 uncoloured copper engravings are of drawings by Jussieu.
<em>Ref</em>.: Jussieu, Adr. de, Bull. Sci. nat. géol. 23: 234-241. Nov 1830 (preliminary report by "G".).

3461. <em>Observations sur quelques plantes du Chili</em>; ... [Paris 1832]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1832, p. [1]-26, <em>pl. 3-4. Copy</em>: U. – Reprinted from Ann. Ann. Sci. nat. 25: 5-30. 1832.
	To be cited from journal.

3462. <em>Malpighiacearum synopsis</em>, monographiae mox edendae Prodromus. [Paris] 1840. Oct. (<em>Malpigh. syn.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1840, p. [1]-63. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted with independent pagination, dated Apr
	1840, from Ann. Sci. nat. Bot. ser. 2. 13: 247-294. Apr 1840, 321-338. Mai 1840.

HEADING: JUSSIEU, A. L.

Jussieu, Antoine de (1686-1758), French botanist, brother of Bernard and Joseph, uncle of
Antoine Laurent de Jussieu. (<em>Ant. Juss.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P–JU; further material at OXF, P, PC. – The Jussieu herbarium is
available on microfiches (IDC 6206).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 4: 93-94. 1857 (gift of herb.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 283; Backer p. 296; Barnhart 2: 264; BM 2: 952;
Bossert p. 202; Bret. p. 124; Clokie p. 191; Dryander 5: 299; DSB 7: 197-198; GR p. 330; IH
2: 335; Jackson p. 30, 225; Langman p. 402; Lasègue p. 53, 572 [index]; LS 13468-13471; NI
suppl. (alph.); PR 4546-4547 (ed. 1: 5024-5027); Quenstedt p. 226-227; Render 5: 442;
Saccardo 1: 92; TL-2/see Fagon, G. C.; Tucker 1: 379.
Darlington, W., Memorials 200, 316, 317. 1849.
Fries, Th. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(4): 12, 31, 181. 1910, 1(5): 51, 245, 259. 1911, 1(6): 437.
	1912.
Hulth, J. M. &amp; A. H. Uggla, Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(1): 3, 4, 6, 81, 124. 1916; 2(2): 48, 49, 123.
	1943.
Lacroix, A., Mem. Acad. Sci. Inst. France ser. 2. 63: 8-21. 1911.
Lütjeharms, W. J., Gesch. Mykol. 131-133, 243. 1936.
Magnin, A., Bull. Soc. bot. Lyon 31: 28. 1906. (q.v. for further biogr. refs.), 32: 109. 1907.
Martins, Le Jardin des Plantes de Montpellier 32, 33, 38. 1854.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Jussiaea</em> Linnaeus (1753); <em>Jussiaeapollenites</em> [sic] E. Nagy (1969); <em>Jussieua</em> Linnaeus
(1774, <em>orth. var.</em>). <em>Note</em>: Linnaeus, Hortus Upsal. 104. 1748, dedicated the name to the
brothers Antoine and Bernard. The etymology of <em>Jussieua</em> Houstoun (1781) could not be
established.

3467. <em>Traité des vertus des plantes</em>, ouvrage posthume de M. Antoine de Jussieu, ... Edité &amp;
augmenté d'un grand nombre de notes de M. Gandoger de Foigny, ... A Nancy (Chez
Hiacinthe Leclerc) 1771. Duod. (<em>Traité vert. pl.</em>).

	1772. Duod.

Jussieu, Antoine Laurent de (1748-1836), French botanist at the Muséum d'Histoire
naturelle; most forceful early promoter of the "natural system." (<em>Juss</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P–JU. – For a description of the herbarium (microfiche IDC 6202)
and a general commentary on Jussieu's earlier work see Stafleu (1964), for a general
commentary on "les cinq Jussieu" see Lacroix (1941). See Sotheby for a mss. catalogue of
1781. Much manuscript material is at P.

Bonn 1829, TL/2, 1917.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: A. L. de Jussieu published a long series of fundamental papers on natural relationship
and the taxonomy of many taxa in the Annales and Mémoires du Museum d'Histoire
naturelle, Paris, between 1802-1820. Reprints of the earlier papers are usually simple
reprints with original pagination or tearsheets from the regular journal issues. For lists of
these reprints see e.g. CSP and PR.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: See two facsimiles of letters from 1789 and 1833 in Ann. Sci. nat. Bot. ser. 2. 7:
1-20. 1837; also: Candollea 31: 133-134. 1976.

3480. <em>Encyclopädisches Pflanzen-Wörterbuch</em> aller einheimischen und fremden Vegetabilien,
welche sich durch Nutzen, Schönheit, Seltenheit oder sonstige Eigenthumlichkeiten be-
sonders auszeichnen; ihrer botanischen, deutschen, französischen und englischen Benen-
nungen; ihrer Dauer, Heimath, Formen, Eigenschaften, Verwendung, Gultur, Vermeh-
rung, Synonymen etc. etc. Mit beständiger Hinweisung auf das natürliche und das Sexual-
System. Nebst einem angehängten Polyglotten-Lexicon. Ein gemeinnütziges Hand- und
Hülfsbuch für Botaniker, Gartenfreunde, Blumisten, Pomologen, Handelsgärtner, Land-
und Hauswirthe, Forstmänner, Technologen, und überhaupt für Liebhaber der Gewächs-
kunde. Nach den neuesten und bewährtesten Quellen kritisch bearbeitet ... Wien (Druck
und Verlag von J. P. Sollinger) 1829, 2 vols. Oct (<em>Encycl. Pfl.-Wörterb.</em>).

3481. <em>Grundriss der Pflanzenkunde</em>, in Gestalt eines Wörterbuches der botanischen Sprache.
Beigefügt: Tabellarische Übersicht des Linné'schen Systems nach Thunberg's Abänder-
ungen. – Deutsches Wörterbuch für die botanischen Ausdrücke. – Anhang, enthaltend das
neueste System: Übersicht des Gewächsreiches in seinen natürlichen Entwickelungsstufen.
Gedrängte Darstellung dieses Systems in Tabellenform. Für Freunde der Gewächskunde
eine umfassende Anleitung zum gründlichen Selbststudium. Für Botaniker ein bequemes
Nachschlagebuch ... Wien (Druck und Verlag von J. P. Sollinger) 1830. Oct. (<em>Grundr.
Pflanzenk.</em>).

Kämpfer, Engelbert [Kaempfer] (1651-1716), German physician and traveller; se-
cretary of the Swedish embassy to Russia and Persia; with the Dutch East Indian Company
1685-1693; subsequently physician to the Count of Lippe. (<em>Kaempf</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Sloane herbarium at BM contains (H.S. 211) the only known
Kämpfer herbarium. The drawings in the <em>Amoenitates</em> seem to have been taken from some of
the specimens. Some further specimens are at OXF (Sherard herb.). The British Museum
possesses an extensive collection of Kämpfer manuscripts. Among them are several volumes of
drawings. Most of the botanical drawings (59) were published by Joseph Banks as <em>Icones
selectae plantarum</em>.
<em>Ref</em>.: Clokie p. 192; IH 2: 340.
	Steam, W. T., Roy. Hort. Soc. Lily Year Book 12: 65-70. 1948
	Dandy, J. E., The Sloane herbarium 144-145. 1958.
	Scott, E. J. L., Index to the Sloane manuscripts in the British Museum 286. 1904.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 15: 62-64; AG 1: 180, 3: 500; Ainsworth p. 303; Backer

PAGE: 487
HEADING: KALM, P.

Kalm, Pehr (1716-1779), Finnish-born botanist and traveller; pupil of Linnaeus; in North-
America (1748-1751); from 1747 lecturer, later professor of economy and natural history at
Abo (Turku). (<em>Kalm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Kalm's own set of plants from North America was burnt in the great
fire of Åbo. The most important extant set is the one Kalm gave to Linnaeus on whose
instigation his North-American trip had been made (now at LINN). Juel states that
Linnaeus received a specimen of each of Kalm's species. Another set of 320 or 380 specimens
came to Queen Lovisa Ulrika and was given to Uppsala (UPS) by Gustav IV in 1803. Other
material in the Thunberg herbarium (UPS), in the Banks herbarium (BM), and at H.
<em>Ref</em>.: Juel, H. O., Sv. Linné-Sällsk. Arsskr. 3: 61-79. 1920, 4: 16-23. 1921, 13: 40-60. 1930
	(revision of Kalm's herbarium at UPS).
	Juel, H. O. and Harshberger, J. W., Proc. Acad. nat. Sci. Philadelphia 81: 297-303. 1929.
	Kukkonen, I. &amp; Viljamaa, K., Ann. Bot. fenn. 10: 312. 1973.
	Löwegren, Naturaliekabinett i Sverige under 1700-talet 209, 314, 353. 1952.
	Baum, B., Canad. J. Bot. 45(10): 1845-1852. 1967 (Kalm's specimens of North American
	grasses; evaluation for typification).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 297; Barnhart 2: 268; BM 2: 955-956; Bossert p.
203; Dryander 5: 300-302; DSB 7: 210-211; Frank 3(Anh.): 49; Henrey 2: 217, 273; Hortus
3: 1197 ("Kalm"); HU 599, 616; IH 2: 339; Kew 3: 208; KR p. 337-339; Lasègue p. 344,
572 [index]; ME 3: 344-346, 348, 349; Pennell p. 611; PR 4571-4584 (ed. 1: 5090-5127);
Rehder 5: 444-445; Saelan p. 209-219; SO 144a, 903, 659a, 2586b, 2586-j, 3529; TR 630-
634; Tucker 1: 381; Zander ed. 10, p. 676.
Archer, Huntia 1: 204-209. 1964 (Thomas Pennant's copy of Kalm's Travels).
Berkeley, E. and D. S., John Clayton 233 [index]. 1963; Dr. Alexander Garden 41-42, 54, 87.
	1969; Dr. John Mitchell 280 [index]. 1974.
Boone, W., Hist. bot. W. Virginia 4. 1965.

	in the light of his <em>Plantae fennicae</em> mss. of 1754 and of his correspondence with e.g.
	Linnaeus); Mem. Soc. Fauna Fl. fenn. 23: 145-150. 1947.

3487. I.N.J. <em>Adumbratio florae</em>, dissertatione academica leviter delineata, quam consensu
ampl. facult. phil. in reg. acad. Aboëns. praeside, Dr. Petro Kalm, oeconom. profess. ...,
publice examinandam sistit Gustavus Orraeus, m.f. Wiburgensis. In audit. superiori, ad. d.
iv. decembr. mdccliv. Horis, ante meridiem consuetis. Aboae, Impressit direct. &amp; typog. reg.
m. duc. Finland. Jacob Merckell [1754]. Qu. (<em>Adumbr. fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 4 Dec 1754, p. [i-viii], [1]-28. <em>Copies</em>: GB, H. – The respondens Gustaf Orraeus (<em>fl</em>.
	1754) is not to be considered author of this treatise on how to write a flora. – Information B.
	Peterson.
<em>Ref</em>.: Saelan p. 383 (under Orraeus).

3488. D.A.G. Dissertatio botanica-oeconomica, <em>de Erica vulgari</em> et Pteride aquilina, quam,
consensu ampl. facult. phil. in Lyceo, quod Aboae floret, sub moderamine Dr Petri Kalm,
... publico examini subjicit Johannes Lagus, J. F. Carelia-Fenno, die vii. Decembr.
mdccliv. Loco horisque ante meridiem solitis. Aboae, impressit direct. &amp; typog. reg. m. duc.
Finland. Jacob Merckell [1754]. Qu. (<em>Erica vulg</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 7 Dec 1754, p. [i-vi], [1]-20. <em>Copy</em>: GB (inf. B. Peterson). – Text to be attributed to
	Kalm. The respondens Johann Lagus (<em>fl</em>. 1755) published another botanical treatise in
	1756 (economic botany); see Saelan. <em>Calluna</em> ("Erica") is dealt with on p. 2-15, <em>Pteris
	aquilina</em> on p. 15-20.

HEADING: KALM, P.

ställe, med wederbörandes minne, under ... Pehr Kalms inseende, uti et academiskt försök

Kaltenbach, Johann Heinrich (1807-1876), German botanist and entomologist; high
school teacher at Hastenrieth (1815-1817), at Aachen (Aix-la-Chapelle) (1817-1876).
(<em>Kaltenb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Some material at W.

3: 208; PR 4585; Rehder 5: 445; Tucker 1: 381.
Hilgers, Entom. Nachr. 2: 112-114. 1876.

combinirten höhern Bürger- und Provinzial-Gewerbschule zu Aachen ... Aachen (Bern-
hard Boisserée) 1845. Duod. (in sixes). (<em>Fl. Aachen. Beckens</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1845 (p. [vi*]: 15 Sep 1844), p. [i*-vi*], [iii]-viii, [1]-314. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Zuchold, Jahresb. nat. ver. Halle 5: 27. 1853.

3495b. <em>Die Pflanzenfeinde</em> aus der Klasse der Insekten. Ein nach Pflanzenfamilien geordnetes
Handbuch sämtlicher auf den einheimischen Pflanzen bisher beobachteten Insekten zum
Gebrauch für Entomologen, Insektensammler, Botaniker, Land- und Forstwirthe und
Gartenfreunde ... Mit 402 charakteristischen Holzschnitt-Illustrationen der wichtigsten
Pflanzenfamilien. Stuttgart (Julius Hoffmann (K. Thienemann's Verlag)) 1874. Oct. (<em>Pflan-
zenfeinde</em>).

	Verhandlungen des naturhistorischen Vereins der preussischen Rheinlande und West-

Moravia born Jesuit (lay brother) missionary and pharmacist in the Phillippines. (<em>Kamel</em>).

HEADING: KAMEL

3496. <em>Herbarium</em> aliarumque stirpium in insula Luzone <em>Philippinarum primaria nascenticum

	accompanying unpublished plates ("Camellis" in Jussieu, Gen. pl.) were in the hands of
	A. L. Jussieu. Linnaeus (Bibl. bot. ed. 2. 156. 1751) referred to the 1704 publication as
	"Descriptiones imperfectae, florum nulla notitia," an inexplicable statement; see further
	Dandy (1958).

3498. <em>Flora und Fauna von Harzburg</em>. Aufzählung der bei Harzburg und Umgegend ein-
schliesslich des Radau-, Oker-, Ilse- und Eckerthals wildwachsenden Pflanzen, sowie der
dort vorkommenden Schmetterlinge und Käfer ... mit einem Anhange: Brockenflora von
Dr. E. Kampe. Harzburg (C. R. Stolle's Hofbuchhandlung) s.d. Oct. (<em>Fl. Harzburg</em>).

<em>Co-authors</em>: Friedrich Schwarze and E. Prediger.
<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1888 (Nat. Nov. Jul (1) 1888), p. [i-iii], 1-49. <em>Copy</em>: B.

Kampmann, Frédéric-Edouard fils ("Fritz") (1830-1914), Alsatian pharmacist at Col-
mar, after 1872 at Genève, from 1907-1914 at Vallorbe, enthusiastic amateur botanist (son
of Frédéric-Edouard K. 1797-1873). (<em>Kampm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G.

Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève ser. 2. 6: 158. 1914.

Kanehira, Ryôzô, (1882-1948), Japanese botanist, director of the Department of Forestry,
Formosa, later at Fukuoka. (<em>Kaneh</em>.).

HEADING: KANITZ

Kanitz, August (Agoston, Agost) (1843-1896), Hungarian botanist, who studied with
Neilreich in Wien, at Hungarian Altenburg (1869-1872), after 1872 professor of botany and
director of the botanic garden at Klausenburg (Cluj, Kolozsvár). (<em>Kanitz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP; other material at B, FI, K, LE, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 254; Backer p. 298; Barnhart 2: 270; BM 2: 957;
Bossert p. 204; CSP 3: 606, 8: 52, 10: 372, 12: 377, 16: 182; DTS 1: 137 (d.: 12 Jul 1897);
Frank 3(Anh.): 49; GR p. 659; Hortus 3: 1197 ("Kanitz"); IH 2: 341; Jackson p. 4, 18, 100,
118, 146, 267, 314, 372, 383, 474; Kew 3: 210-211 Langman p. 403; LS 13552-13553, 35228;
MW p. 223-224; Plesch p. 286; Rehder 5: 445; TL-2/1: 197, 2: 2719; Tucker 1: 381.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1897: 47; Bot. Zeit. 54(2): 240. 1896. Österr. bot. Z. 24: 1-16. 1974 (portr.).
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. Länder 4, 16, 36. 1901 (Veget. Erde vol. 4).
Bettelheim, A., ed., Biogr. Jahrb. deut. Nekrol. 3: 92*. 1900.
Diels, L. &amp; J. Mildbraed, Generalregister Bot. Jahrb. 1(1-30): 30. 1904.
Dolezal, H., Friedrich Welwitsch 111. 1974.
Huszty, Studia bot. Hung. 8: 111-124. 1973 (on K. and the Magy. növén. Lapok).
Knapp ("-a-"), Oest. bot. Z. 24: 1-16. 1874.
Nordstedt, C. F. O., Index Desmid. bibl. 19. 1896.
Pax, F., Grundz. Pflanzenverbr. Karpathen 29, 59. 1898 (Veg. Erde vol. 2(1)).
Urban, I., Fl. bras. 1(1): 180. 1906.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 157, <em>pl. 22.</em> 1903 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) With P. Ascherson: <em>Catalogus Cormophytorum et Anthophytorum Serbiae</em>.
Claudiopoli (Cluj) 1877 (TL-2/197).
(2) Editor and founder of <em>Magyar Növénytani Lapok</em> (1-6), (1877-1892).
(3) With S. Schulzer von Müggenburg (q.v.) and J. A. Knapp, <em>Die bisher bekannten Pflanzen
	Slavoniens</em>. Wien 1866, p. [1]-172 (see Bot. Zeit. 24: 233. 27 Jul 1866).
(4) Martius, <em>Flora brasiliensis</em>:
(a) <em>Lobeliaceae</em>, 6(4): 129-158, <em>pl. 39-45.</em> 1 Dec 1878.
(b) <em>Haloragaceae</em>, 13(2): 373-382, <em>pl. 68-69.</em> 1 Mai 1882.
(c) <em>Campanulaceae</em>, 6(4): 177-188, <em>pl. 48-49.</em> 1 Jun 1885.
(5) Warming, E., <em>Symbolae, Haloragidaceae</em>, part 35, p. 165, publ. 21 Apr 1891; <em>Lobeliaceae</em>, part
	38, p. 46, publ. 3 Mai 1892.

3502. <em>Rèliquiae kitaibelianae</em> e manuscriptis musei nationalis hungarici publicatae Augusto
Kanitz, ... Vindobonae [Wien] (apud Guil. Braumüller bibliopolam C. R. Aulicum) 1862-
1863. Ou. (<em>Reliq. kit.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1863, p. [i], [1]-199. <em>Copies</em>: M, MO, NY. – Number of copies printed: 70 (of which 10
	Wien 12: [559-576 one copy], 589-606. 1862 (publ. Jan-Apr 1863) and 13: 57-118, 505-
	554. 1863 (publ. before Oct) (resp. p. [1]-18, [19]-80 and 81-139). See also Kanitz,
	Linnaea 32(3): 305-385. Sep 1863, 385-640. Jan 1864, 641-642. Feb 1864 (Further
	additions to the Flora hungarica from Kitaibels mss. at BP) (see TL-2/3504).
<em>Ref</em>.: Fournier, P. N. E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 10: 449. Jan 1864.

3503. <em>Geschichte der Botanik in Ungarn</em>. Skizzen von August Kanitz. Gedruckt in 70 Exem-
plaren. Hannover (Druck und Verlag von Wilh. Riemschneider) Pestl (In Commission bei
Mor. Rath.) 1863. Oct. (<em>Gesch. Bot. Ungarn</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1863, p. [i], [1]-199. <em>Copies</em>: M, MO, NY. – Number of copies printed: 70 (of which 10
	for the trade). A fuller account was published as "<em>Versuch einer Geschichte der ungarischen
	Botanik</em>," Linnaea 33: 401-664, referred to as "Kanitz" in TL/2, citation by numbers of
	entries. This later version has no index. See no. 3505. – The first three chapters were
	published originally in Bonplandia; after the discontinuation of <em>Bonplandia</em> Kanitz had the
	later chapters printed at his own cost at the same printing shop. Schlechtendal, regretting
	the relative unavailability of this text, invited Kanitz to publish this emended version in
	Linnaea. The 22 year old Kanitz was assisted in the compilation of this work by Neilreich.
	Preliminary notice in Verh. zool.-bot. Ver. Wien 12: 97-100. 1862.

de plantis Hungariae mus. nat. Hung. edidit Augustus Kanitz. Ex Linnaeae xxxii. tomo

Kanouse, Bessie Bernice (1889-1969), American mycologist; Ph. D. Univ. Mich. 1926;
specialist on watermolds and discomycetes; at the Ann Arbor University Herbarium of the

Kappler, August (1815-1887), German soldier and naturalist; from 1836-1879 in Suri-
name and the West Indies; travelled around the world in 1883; the most important author on
Suriname of the mid-nineteenth century. (<em>Kappl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: His "<em>Plantae surinamenses</em> edit. R. F. Hohenacker" in many herbaria
e.g. F, FI, G, GENT (205 nos.), GOET, H, K, L, MO, P, U, UPS, W. – Kappler was not
associated with the Esslingen "Reiseverein".

HEADING: KARELIN

392-393; NNBW 8: 945; Rehder 1: 339.

HEADING: KARLING

Karling, John Sidney (1898-x), American algologist and mycologist at Columbia and
Purdue Universities, Ph. D. Columbia Univ. 1926. (<em>Karling</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PUR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 271; GR p. 226; Hirsch p. 146; Kew 3: 214;
Langman p. 404; Lasègue p. 466; LS suppl. 13467-13470; Roon p. 59; Stevenson p. 1247.
Rickett, H. W., Index Bull. Torrey bot. Club 53-54. 1955.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: K'S main work, <em>The Plasmidiophorales</em> (i, 144 p.) was first Published New York 1942. A
revised second edition appeared in 1968 (New York, Hafner Publishing Co.) xiii, 256 p. (see
Taxon 18: 575. 1969); it contains a bibliography of his writings. K's <em>Chytridiomycetarum
iconographia</em> was Published in Vaduz, 1977.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Karlingia</em> A. E. Johanson (1944); <em>Karlingiomyces</em> F. K. Sparrow (1960).

Karsch, Anton (1822-1892), German botanist, zoologist and physician; Dr. phil. et med.
Greifswald 1846; practicing physician at Münster i.W. 1848, professor of medicine at the
University 1852 (extraord.), 1856 (ord.), Geheimer Medizinalrath 1874. (<em>Karsch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MSTR. – Nat. Nov. 16 (Mar. 1), 1894 cites a set of <em>Lichenes Europaei
exsiccati</em>, 5 fasc, on which we have no details.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 272; BM 2: 595; Bossert p. 205; CSP 3: 610, 16:
