Karsten, Georg Henry Herman (1863-1937), German botanist; Dr. phil. Rostock 1885;
habit. Leipzig 1892; at Bonn 1899-1909; at Halle 1909-1928; travelled in Indonesia (1888-
1890) and Mexico (1894). (<em>G. Karst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Algae types at L; other material at HAL and L; hepatics from
Amboina at FH.
<em>Ref</em>.: Koster, J., Blumea 2(3): 231. 1936; Taxon 18: 554. 1969.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 351. 1975.

<em>Ref</em>.: Gran-, Bot. Zeit. 64(2): 7-9. 1 Jan 1906 (rev. part 1), 65(2): 42. 1 Feb 1907 (part 2).

Karsten, Hermann [Gustav Karl Wilhelm Hermann] (1817-1908), German botanist;
studied botany in the Stralsund pharmacy; travelled in South America 1844-1847, 1848-
1856; from 1856-1868 professor of botany in Berlin; 1868-1872 in Wien; from 1872 onward in
Berlin. (<em>H. Karst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Hitchcock (List 2: 14) cites LE as the location of Karsten types. The
location of K's own herbarium is unknown. Alphonse de Candolle (Phytogr.) cites Lenin-
grad as the herbarium with a large set (2000) of Columbian plants collected by Karsten.
Another important set is at W (3594). It is not known whether this was the first set, and
whether it really contains Karsten's types. Duplicates are in many herbaria (e.g. BM, G,
GH, GOET, JE, K, KIEL, L, NY, P, US, W).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 4: 101-104. 1846 (lists of Colombian collections for sale).
	Tryon, R., Taxon 12: 103-105. 1963.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 120, 317; Barnhart 2: 272; BJI 11: 30; BM 2:
959-960; CSP 3: 614-615; 8: 53-54, 10: 376; DTS 1: 137-138; GR p. 23; Hortus 3: 1197: IH
2: 343; Jackson p. 376, 565 [index]; Kew 3: 216; LS 13564-13587; Moebius p. 76, 104, 178,
215; NAF 28B(2): 340; NI 1028-1029; PR 4593-4606, 10584 (ed. 1: 5144); Ratzeburg p.
275-279(!); Rehder 5: 446; RS p. 90; Tucker 1: 382; Urban-Berl. p. 265, 288, 303, 361;
Zander ed. 10, p. 677. – <em>Note</em>: not all CSP refs. are referable to this author.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1908: 212; Bot. Zeit. 66(2): 288. 1908.
Embacher, F., Lexikon Reisen 161. 1882.
Karsten, H., Ges. Beitr. Anat. Physiol. Pfl., 2 vols. Berlin 1865, 1890.
Mägdefrau, K., Neue deut. Biogr. II: 305-306. 1977 (many refs.).
Müller, Natur 1871 (nos. 16-29) (fide Ratzeburg).
Röhl, Bol. Acad. Ci. fis. mat. nat. 8(25): 991-1025. 1944 (extensive study on his S. Amer.
	studies; portr.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Karstenia</em> Goeppert (1836) is dedicated to Carl Johann Bernard Karsten (1782-
1853), German mining engineer.

Karsten, Petter [Peter] Adolf (1834-1917), Finnish mycologist; Ph. D. Helsinki 1859;
teacher at the Wasa Gymnasium 1862-1864; lecturer in botany at Mustiala agricultural
college 1864-1908; later in Forssa. (<em>P. Karst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H (rd. 1905); large set at UPS. – Exsiccatae: (information T. Ahti)
(1) <em>Fungi fenniae exsiccati</em>, Samling af finska svampar, nos. 1-1000, Åbo 1861-1870. (Karsten
collected and distributed some specimens in this series long after the original dates of issue.)
Sets at FH, H.

Kauffman, Calvin Henry (1869-1931), America mycologist of Pennsylvania-Dutch
origin at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan; Ph. D. Ann Arbor 1907;
instructor of botany 1904; assist. professor 1912; associate professor 1920; full professor 1923;
founder of the Ann Arbor mycological school. (<em>Kauffm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MICH; further material e.g. at NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kauffman, C. H., Mich. Acad. Sci. 1: 101-150. 1921 (Mycological flora of the higher
	Rockies of Colorado).
	Shope, Mycologia 21: 295. 1929.

PAGE: 508
HEADING: KAULFUSS

Kaulfuss, Georg Friedrich (1786-1830), German botanist; Dr. jur. et phil. Halle 1816;
extra-ord. prof. forestry at Halle 1823; ord. prof. of botany ib. 1818. (<em>Kaulf</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Kaulfuss herbarium was sold after his death. A circular
announcing the sale and describing the rich herbarium is at G. Kaulfuss acquired the
herbarium of Johann Karl Friedrich Meyer (Stettin, 1739-1811). This herbarium contained
material from Isert, Pallas, Thunberg, Swartz, Vahl and Willdenow. According to Flora
(1832), "Römer", at Dresden acquired the Kaulfuss Pteridophytes. The identity of this
Römer is not known to us. Bryophytes are at B (Bridel, still extant), L (id.) and LZ
(destroyed). Some ferns are at PH. Some material of Kaulfuss (e.g. at M) in other herbaria
may be of Johann Simon Kaulfuss. – Information on B courtesy W. Schultze-Motel. For
biographical information we are indebted to S. Rauschert.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Anzeige über den Verkauf einer bedeutenden Pflanzensammlung [Halle, circa
	1831].

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 150; Barnhart 2: 274 (<em>b</em>. 1786); BM 2: 962; CSP 3:
619; Hortus 3: 1197 ("Kaulf."); IF 708-709, suppl. 1: 82; Jackson p. 150; Kew 3: 222;
Lasègue p. 320, 335, 545; Moebius p. 128, 132, 134, 135; MW p. 225; PR 4608-4610 (ed. 1:
5147-5149); Zander ed. 10, p. 677.
Anon., Flora 14: 48. Int. Bl. 2: 6-8, 3: 7. 1831, 15: 119, 384. 1832 (Pteridophytes with
	Römer).
Kraus, G., Bot. Gart. Halle 2: 78-82. 1894.
Schrader, Kraus u. Runde, Chronik der Stadt Halle 154. 1933 (inf. S. Rauschert).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kaulfussia</em> C. G. D. Nees (1820); <em>Kaulfussia</em> Blume (1828).

3549. <em>Enumeratio filicum</em> quas in itinere circa terram legit Cl. Adalbertus de Chamisso adiectis
in omnia harum plantarum genera permultasque species non satis cognitas vel novas
animadversionibus ... Cum tabulis aeneis duabus. Lipsiae [Leipzig] (sumtibus Caroli
Cnobloch) 1824. Oct. (<em>Enum. filic.</em>).

<em>Collector</em>: Ludolf Adalbert von Chamisso (1781-1838), see TL-2/vol. 1, p. 482.
<em>Publ</em>.: 8 Apr-28 Mai 1824 (preface 8 Apr 1824; see Kunze 1824; Florard. 14 Oct 1824), p. [i]-
	vi, [1]-300, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (uncol. copper engr. by author). <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY, U, US, USDA, IDC
	7206. – Chamisso brought home 165 pteridophyta, 77 of which were new. Kaulfuss
	dedicated the tree-fern <em>Cibotum Chamissoi</em> to the collector. – Information on dates provided
	by John W. Landon.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schmid, G., Chamisso als Naturforscher 1942, nos. 136 (p. 89) and 346, see also p. 169.
	Kunze, G., Flora 7: 305-317. 28 Mai 1824, 324-334. 7 Jun 1824; 337-349. 14 Jun 1824.

3550. <em>Erfahnmgen über das Keimen der Charen</em> nebst andern Beyträgen zur Kenntniss dieser
Pflanzengattung ... Leipzig (bey Carl Cnobloch) 1825. Oct. (<em>Erfahr. Keimen Charen</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Sep 1825 (p. [viii]: 18 Mar 1825; Flora 28 Sep 1825), p. [i-viii], [1]-92, [1-2, expl.
	pl.], <em>1 pl</em>. (partly col.). <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, NY, Regensburg.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 12: 369-380. 1829.

3551. <em>Das Wesen der Farrenkräuter</em> besonders ihrer Fruchttheile zugleich mit Rücksicht auf
systematische Anordnung betrachtet und mit einer Darstellung der Entwicklung der Pteris
serrulata aus dem Samen begleitet ... Erste Hälfte. Mit einer Kupfertafel. Leipzig (bey
Carl Cnobloch) 1827. Qu. † (<em>Wesen Farrenkr</em>.)

<em>Publ</em>.: 1827, p. [i-iv], [1]-117, [1, chart], Anhang [i]-xxiv, <em>1 plate</em> (uncol. copper engr.).
	<em>Copies</em>: MO, NY, US, USDA, IDC 7207.

Kaurin, Christian (1831-1898), Norwegian bryologist and clergyman at Opdal and Ager
o. Sand vid Drammen. (<em>Kaur</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at O, H, TRH and TROM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 274; BM 2: 963; CSP 10: 378, 16: 208; IH 2:
345; Kleppa p. 325; KR p. 340; Lenley p. 247; SBC p. 124 ("Kaur."); TL-2/2: 2249.
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 27(1): 79. 1899; Bot. Not. 1898: 240; Generalregister Bot. Not. 1839-1938:

HEADING: KAVINA

	39, 102. 1939; Medd. Soc. Fauna Fl. fenn. 25: 91. 1900; Rev. bryol. 16: 78. 1889, 18: 46,

3552. <em>Additamenta et corrigenda ad Enumerationem bryinearum dovrensium</em> auctore N. C. Kindberg
(Chr. Vidensk.-Selsk. Forh. 1888 no. 6) auctore Chr. Kaurin ... Christiania [Oslo] (I
commission hos Jacob Dybwab. A. W. Broggers Bogtrykkeri) 1889. Oct. (<em>Addit. Enum. bryin.
dovrens.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Oct-Nov 1889; Bot. Not. 15 Dec 1889; Nat. Nov. Dec(1) 1889), p. [1]-25. <em>Copy</em>: NY. –

	Kaurin in Bot. Not. 1882; 17-18. See also Scheutz, Overs. k. Sv. Vet. Akad. Förh. 1869(5):

Kausel, Eberhard Max Leopold (1910-1972), Chilean dentist and botanist at Santiago;
specialist on Myrtaceae. (<em>Kausel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H; other material F, GB, HBR, LIL, SGO.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kukkonen, I., Taxon 24: 132. 1975 (herb, at H.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 274; Hortus 3: 1197 ("Kausel"); IH 2: 346;
Kew 3: 222; Langman p. 404; Roon p. 60.
Looser, G., Taxon 21: 733. 1972; Bol. Soc. Arg. Bot. 15(1): 137-139. 1973 (portr.); An. Mus.
	Hist. nat. Valparaiso 6: 281-284. 1973 (portr.).
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 209. 1963.

Kavina, Karel (1890-1948), Czechoslovakian botanist and mycologist at Praha; pupil of J.
Velenovsky. (<em>Kavina</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Partly destroyed (World War II) but some material at PR, PRC,
PRM (information J. Vána). – Issued exsiccatae with Alfred Hilitzer (1899-1940): <em>Crypto-
gamae cechoslovenicae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-6, nos. 1-300, Praha 1933-1937, sets at FH, NY, UPS.
Some further bryophytes also at H.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 30. 1969.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 275; Hortus 3: 1197; IH 2: 346; Kew 3: 222-
223; Klášterský p. 105 (q.v. for further biogr. refs.); LS suppl. 13563-13605; Stevenson p.
1247.
Anon., Rev. bryol. lichén. 18: 184. 1947 (1948).
Hesler, L. R., Biogr. Sketches North American [and of some European] mycol. 1975, mss.
Klika, Preslia 18/19: 12-21. 1940 (bibl.).
Pilát, A., Studia bot. Čechosl. 9: 3-5. 1949.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With A. Pilat, <em>Atlas des champignons de l'Europe</em>, Praha 6 vols, (in 7), 1934-
1948.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kavinia</em> Pilát (1938).

3553. <em>České rašelinníky</em> [Sphagnum] monografická studie ... Zvláštní otisk z vestníka král.
Ceské spolecnosti náuk v praze 1912. předloženo v Sezení dne 22. Bnezna 1912 vydáno dne
10. srpna 1912. v Praze (Nákladem královské Česke spolecnosti náuk...) 1912. Oct. (<em>České
rašelinn</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 10 Aug 1912 (t.p.: submitted 22 Mar 1912, publ. 10 Aug 1912), p. [1]-219, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (col.
	liths. auct.). <em>Copies</em>: B, Steere. – Reprinted from Vestn. Král. Ceské Spolecn. Nauk, Frida
	2, 1912 (no. 11). (S.B. k. boehm. Ges. Wiss.).

3554. <em>Monografie českých jatrovek</em>. Dil. I. Jatrovky lupenité. (Hepaticae frondosae Bohemiae)
... Praha (V. Komisi fr. rivnace.-Tiskom dr. Eduarda Grégra a syna v Praze). 1915. Oct. (<em>Monogr. česk. jatrovek</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1915, p. [1]-284. <em>Copy</em>: Steere. – Archiv pro přírodovedecký výzkum čech. (Dil. xvi.

HEADING: KAVINA

	Číslo 2.) – J. Vana informed us (30 Aug 1977) that part 2 (foliose hep.) was never finished;
	if there was any mss. it must have been incomplete. Kavina's manuscripts were destroyed
	along with his private herbarium during World War II.

Kawakami, Takiya (1871-1915), Japanese botanist; botanist of the Government of
Formosa from 1901. (<em>Kawak</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TAIM and TI; further material at A and BO.

Kearney, Thomas Henry (1874-1956), American botanist at the Bureau for Plant
Industry; in various functions at USDA 1894-1914; cotton breeder; explorer; from 1944 at
CAS. (<em>Kearn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OS and US; duplicates in ARIZ, GU, E, F, GH, K, MINN, MO,
MSG, POM, SI, TENN. The original Kearney-Peebles herbarium of Arizona plants is at
ARIZ.
<em>Ref</em>.: Hultén, E., Bot. Not. 1940: 292, 315-316 (itin., Alaska).
	Stuckey and Wentz, Ohio J. Sci. 74(1): 20-35. 1974 (lists types).
	Wentz, W. A., Taxon 23: 357-363. 1974 (lists types).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 351. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 275; BFM 1591; BJI 2: 88; BL 1: 164, 183, 205,
218; BM 2: 964; Bossert p. 207; CSP 16: 213-214; GR p. 226; Hirsch p. 148; Hortus 3: 1197
("Kearn."); IH 2: 346; Kew 3: 226; Langman p. 405; Lenley p. 248; LS 13700; NW p. 50;
Pennell p. 611; Rehder 5: 448; Tucker 1: 383.
Anon., Academy News Letter, San Francisco, 203: 2-3. 1956; Science n.s. 51: 611. 1920 (Dr.
	h.c. Univ. Ariz.).
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 101. 1969.

Kearney et al., Leafl. western Bot. 8(12): 273-288. 1958 (autobiographical notes; bibl. by E.
	McClintock.).
Miller, R. C., Taxon 6: 31. 1957.
Murrill, W. A., Hist. found. bot. Florida 40. 1945.
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 484 [ind.]. 1963.
Reveal, J., <em>in</em> A. Gronquist et al., Intermountain flora 1: 67. 1972.
Rickett, H. W., Index Bull. Torrey bot. Club 54. 1955 (bibl.).
Rodgers, A. D., Bernard Eduard Fernow 281. 1951; Liberty Hyde Bailey 268, 283-284.
	1949.
Thomas, J. H., Bot. Expl. Washington, Oregon, Calif, preprint Huntia 3: 28-29. 1969
	(portr.).
Wiggins, I. Cosmos Club Bull. 5(9): 2-4. 1952, Pacific Discovery 1952 March-April (portr.).

HEADING: KEATING

3559. <em>Flowering plants and ferns of Arizona</em> ...Washington (United States Government
Printing Office) 1942. Oct. (<em>Fl. pl. ferns Ariz.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Robert Hibbs Peebles (1900-1955) (see Kearney on Peebles, Madroñno 14: 11-13.
	1957).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: May 1942, frontisp., p. [i], 1-1096. <em>Copy</em>: U.

	fl</em>.).

Keating, William Hippolitus [Hypolitus] (1799-1840), American mineralogist and
geologist on the Long expedition to St. Peter's River (1823); professor of chemistry Univ.
Pennsylvania 1822-1828. (<em>Keating</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The plants on Stephen Long's expedition were collected by the
entomologist Thomas Say (1787-1834); they were described by Lewis D. de Schweinitz
whose collections are at PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 276; BM 2: 964; CSP 3: 624; DAB 10: 276-277
(by J.H.F.); Kew 3: 226; ME 274, 276, 702; Tucker 1: 383.
Graustein, J. E., Thomas Nuttall 164, 165, 195. 1967 (Long's Exp.).
Lamb's Biogr. Dict. U.S. 4: 481-482. 1901 (fide ME).
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 484 [ind.]. 1963.

3560. <em>Narrative of an expedition to the source of St. Peter's River</em>, Lake Winnepeek, Lake of the
Woods, &amp;c. &amp;c. performed in the year 1823, by order of the hon. J. C. Calhoun, secretary of
war, under the command of Stephen H. Long, major U.S.F.E. Compiled from the notes of
major Long, messrs. Say, Keating and Calhoun, by William H. Keating, ... Philadelphia
(H. C. Carey &amp; I. Lea ...) 1824, 2 vols. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Narrat. exp. St. Peter's River</em>).

<em>Botanical descriptions by</em>: Lewis David von Schweinitz (1780-1834).
<em>Commander of expedition</em>: Stephen Harriman Long (1784-1864).

<em>Publ</em>.: Dec 1824 or early 1825 (p. iv: 29 Nov 1824. North Amer. Rev. Jul 1825).
	<em>1</em>: p. [i]-xii, [1-2, cont.], map, [9]-439, <em>pl. 1-5.</em>
	<em>2</em>: p. [i]-vi, [5]-459, <em>pl. 6-15</em> (uncol. liths.).
	<em>Copies</em>: HH, MO, NY, US.
<em>London ed</em>.: 1825, London (printed for Geo. B. Whittaker) 1825, 2 vols. (<em>1</em>: 13, [3], 458 p., <em>5 pl</em>.;
	<em>2</em>: 6, 248, 154 p., <em>3 pl</em>.) – No copy seen. – The appendix (p. 253-459 in the Philadelphia
	edition), is separately paged 1-154. For a concordance of the pagination of the two editions
	see ME.
<em>Botany</em>: in Appendix to vol. 2, by de Schweinitz, "A catalogue of the plants collected in the
	North Western territory by Mr. Thomas Say, in the year, 1823," Philadelphia ed. vol. 2:
	379-400, London ed. app. to vol. 2, p. 105-123. – Nuttall was to have described the plants
	but his absence in Europe made the change to de Schweinitz necessary (see p. 379).
<em>Ref</em>.: ME 2: 421-423, q.v. for further details on Long's Expedition.
	Earle Smith, Bartonia 28: 30. 1957.

PAGE: 512
HEADING: KECK, D. D.

Keck, David Daniels (1903-x); American botanist; Ph. D. Berkeley 1930; collaborated
with Clausen and Hiesey in their pioneer experimental systematics at Stanford (1926-1950);
specialist on <em>Penstemon</em>; head curator at the New York Bot. Gard. 1950-1959; at the National
Science Foundation 1959-1970; subsequently living in New Zealand (1971-1976) and
California (1976-x). (<em>D. Keck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DS; later types at NY. – For duplicates see IH. Collected ca. 6000
nos. in the western United States; first set at DS; dupl. in 40 herbaria.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 276; Bossert p. 207; IH 2: 347; Kew 3: 227-228;
Langman p. 405-406; Lenley p. 248; NW p. 50; Roon p. 60; Zander ed. 10, p. 677.
Anon., National Science Foundation, News release 10 Nov. 1958, 1 p.; Taxon 7: 251. 1958.
Ewan, J., Short hist. bot. U.S. 112, 114. 1969.
Hansell, D. E., News release New York Bot. Gard. 6 Oct 1958, 1 p.
Keck, D. D., Curriculum vitae and list of publications up to 1949, typescript in Archives NY;
	Personal communications to senior author 1957 and following.
Krause, Bot. Jahrb. 66(Lit.): 38, 67. 1934.
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 173. 1947.
Munz, P., Aliso 5: 2. 1961 (portr. Mai 1922).
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 203, 209. 1963.
Reveal, J., <em>in</em> A. Cronquist et al., Intermountain flora 1: 67, 71. 1972.
Rickett, H. W., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 54. 1955.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See Clausen, Jens, Keck, D.D. and Hiesey, William McKinley (1903-x,
originally W. M. Heusi) in TL-2/suppl. A-G.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Keckia</em> Straw (1966); <em>Keckiella</em> Straw (1967).

3561. <em>A revision of the genus Orthocarpus</em> ... San Franciso (published by the Academy) 1927. (<em>Revis. Orthocarp.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 11 Jun 1927, Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci. ser. 4 16(17): 517-571. 1927. <em>Copy</em>: U.

3562. <em>The Hawaiian silver swords</em> systematics, affinities, and phytogeographic problems of the
genus Argyroxiphium ... Honolulu, Hawai (published by the [Bernice P. Bishop] Mu-
seum) 1936. (<em>Haw. silverwords</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Mar 1936, p. [1]-38, pl. 1-9. <em>Copies</em>: U, USDA. – Occasional Papers Bernice P.
	Bishop Museum 11(19), 1936.

Keck, Karl (1825-1894), Austrian owner of a printing office, botanist and physician at
Aistersheim. (<em>K. Keck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WU (80.000). Keck distributed numerous sets named "<em>Herbarium</em>
..." which showed great diversity in numbers and which were commercially distributed sets
of plants of diverse origin rather than formal exsiccatae. His "<em>Herbarium normale</em>" was a
continuation of the series issued under this name by F. Schultz, new series, cent. 1-28, 1878-
1892, nos. 1-2800, accompanied by printed lists, p. [1]-99, [1]-4, [1]-3. Ovilabis [Wels] (typis
Joan. Haas). <em>Copy</em>: G.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 56: 464. 1873. Bull. Torr. bot. Club 4: 42. 1873 (sale herbarium); Rev.
	bryol. 3(2): 32. 1876; Nat. Nov. Nov(2). 1889.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 299; Barnhart 2: 276; Clokie p. 192; DTS 1: 138,
6(4): 158; IH 2: 347; NW p. 50.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1895: 38.
Harshberger, J. W., Bot. Philadelphia 281. 1899.
Lindemann, E., Bull. Soc. Natural. Moscou 59(1): 310. 1884.
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 567. 1963.
Poetsch, J. S. und K. B. Schiedermayr, Syst. Aufz. Krypt. Oesterr. xvii. 1872.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Keckia</em> E. F. Glocker (1841) is dedicated to Michael Keck von Keck (1785?-1840),
Austrian soldier, geologist and paleontologist.

PAGE: 513
HEADING: KEISSLER

Kegel, Hermann Aribert Heinrich (1819-1856), German gardener at Halle, collected in
Surinam 1844-1846. (<em>Kegel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GOET; other material B, BR, CN, FH, L, P, PC, W.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 14: 479-480. 1856, 15: 487-488. 1857 (herbarium of Suriname plants
	still for sale).
	Pulle, A. A., Enum. vasc, plants Suriname 6-7. 1906.
	Florschütz, P. A., Mosses Suriname 2. 1964.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York bot. Gard. 19(3): 351. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 299; Barnhart 2: 277; CSP 3: 627; IH 2: 348; PR
(alph.); Urban-Berl p. 304, 320, 362.
Anon., Bonplandia 4: 195. 1856; Bot. Zeit. 14: 508; Flora 39: 414. 1856; Gartenflora 5: 287,
	319.
C.S., Gartenfiora 7: 360. 1858.
Sirks, M. J., Indisch natuuronderzoek 291. 1915.
Stafleu, F. A., Regn. veg. 70: 317, 338. 1970; Wentia 16: 25. 1966.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kegelia</em> C. H. Schultz Bip. (1848); <em>Kegelia</em> H. G. Reichenbach (1852); <em>Kegeliella</em>

Keissler, Karl von (1872-1965), Austrian lichenologist at Vienna; Dr. phil. Vienna 1895;
at the Botanical Garden 1895-1899; in various functions at the Botanische Abteilung des
Naturhistorischen Hofmuseums 1899-1938; pupil of A. Zahlbrückner; from 1924 with the
title Hofrat. (<em>Keissl</em>.)

HEADING: KELLERMAN

Kellerman, William Ashbrook (1850-1908), American botanist and mycologist, studied
at Cornell and Zürich, high school teacher at the Oshkosh State Normal School, Wisconsin
(1874-1879), worked for his degree at Zürich (1879-1881), professor of botany at the
University of Kentucky, Lexington (1881-1883), id. at Kansas State College of Agriculture,
Manhattan (1883-1891), id. at Ohio State University, Columbus (1891-1908); died while
botanizing in Guatemala. (<em>Kellerm</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OS; further original material at US, PUR and F; material in many
herbaria. <em>Exsiccatae</em>:
(1) <em>Fungi selecti guatemalenses</em>, dec. 1-2, nos. 1-20, 1906-1907, sets at BPI, CUP, F, FH, OS,
PUR, SOLH, UC.
(2) <em>Ohio fungi</em>, fasc. 1-10, nos. 1-200, 1901-1905, sets see IH; texts in Ohio Naturalist.
(3) <em>Kansas fungi</em>, fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-50, publ. 1 May and 1 Aug 1889, with Walter Tennyson F.
Swingle (1871-1952), sets: BPI, DAOM. FH, ISC, MASS, MICH, MSC, NEB, NY, OC,
OS, PUR, RUTPP, UT, WIS.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Torreya 9: 239. 1909.
	Stevenson, J., Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 225-226. 1971.
	Stuckey and Wentz, Ohio J. Sci. 74(1): 20-35. 1974 (lists types).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 277; Barnhart 2: 279; BL 1: 304 [index]; BM 2:
967; Bossert p. 208; CSP 16: 229; GR p. 226; Hortus 3: 1197; IH 2: 349-350; Kew 3: 230;
Lenley p. 248-249; LS 13722-13798, 35306-35328; NAF 7: 1072; NW p. 50; Nordstedt p. 19;
Pennell p. 611; Rehder 5: 449; Stevenson p. 1247; TL-2/1: see Ellis, J. B.; Tucker 1: 384;
Urban-Berl. p. 277.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 48: 304. 1891; Bryologist 11(3): 59. 1 Mai 1908; J. Mycol. 14: 49-63.
	1908 (portr., bibl.); Torreya 8: 64. 1908; New York Times 11 Mar 1908.
Armstrong, Ohio naturalist 1(3): 38. 1901.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 12, 16. 1969.
Griggs et al., Ohio Naturalist 8(7): 361-362. 1908.
Hard, M. E., The mushroom, Columbus Ohio, 1908, p. viii.
Harshberger, J. W., Bot. Philadelphia 266. 1899.
O[sborn], H[erbert], Ohio Naturalist 8(5): 286. 1908.
Hesler, L. R., Biogr. Sketches North Amer. mycol. 1975, mss.
Humphrey, Makers N. Amer. Bot. 137-138. 1961.
Kellerman, W. A., <em>in</em> Geol. Ohio Pl. 68, 75, 76, 77, 78. 1895 (bibl.).
Lloyd, C. G., Mycol. notes 36: 477-478. Aug 1910 (portr.).
Lowden, R. M., Taxon 19: 19-35. 1970 (itin., sources, portr.).
Murrill, W. A., Hist. found. bot. Florida 30. 1945.
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 26, 164, 906. 1963.
Reiche, K., Grundzüge Pflanzenverbr. Chile 34. 1907 (Veg. Erde 8).
Rickett, H. W., Index Bull. Torrey bot. Club 54. 1955.
Rodgers, A. D., Liberty Hyde Bailey 136, 147. 1949.
Rogers, D. P., Brief hist. mycol. N. Amer. 14, 19. 1977.
Walters, The Industrialist 1908: 362-363.
Willard, Trans. Kansas Acad. Sci. 22: 46-47. 1909 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Established in 1885 <em>The Journal of mycology</em>, (with J. B. Ellis and B. M.
Everhart); editor 1885-1889, 1902-1908. <em>The Journal of mycology</em> was terminated with
Kellerman's death and succeeded by <em>Mycologia</em> (first issue Feb 1909).
(2) Contributed <em>Botany</em> (Catalogue of Ohio Plants) to <em>Geology of Ohio</em> (in Rep. Geol. Surv.
Ohio) vol. 7, part 2: [i], [56]-406, by Kellerman and W. C. Werner (<em>copy</em>: USDA). [William
C. Werner (1851-1935); the letter C stands for W's father's name Conrad, not spelled out].
The bibliography of this Catalogue (p. 58-79) was published again, updated to 1895, in Ann.
Rep. Ohio Acad. Sci. 4: 5-18. 1896.
(3) Editor of <em>Mycological Bulletin</em> 1903-1908; (4) Co-founder of the <em>Ohio Naturalist</em>, 1900.
(5) With O. E. Jennings: <em>Flora of Cedar Point</em>, Ohio Naturalist 4: 186-190. 1904 (add.: ib. 6:
540, 544-545. 1906, 10: 61-63. 1910, 12: 473. 1912, 13: 78. 1913).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kellermannia</em> J. B. Ellis &amp; Everhart (1885); <em>Kellermanniopsis</em> J. C. Edward et al.
(1974).

HEADING: KELLERMAN

3572. <em>Spring flora of Ohio</em> consisting of descriptions of the early native flowering plants, with
keys for their identification; also a key for the identification of the trees and shrubs of the state
by their leaves and fruits ... published the author. Columbus, Ohio (J. L. Trauger, printer

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1895 (p. 5: Jan 1895; TBC 31 Aug 1895), p. [1]-128. <em>Copy</em>: NY.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: "<em>Spring flora for beginners and amateurs</em>," Columbus, Ohio, 1906 (TBC 5 Oct 1906), p. [i]-
	xiii, [1]-188. <em>Copy</em>: SMU. – Subtitle "Consisting of the early flowering herbaceous and
	woody plants, with simple keys for their identification: also a key for the identification of
	trees and shrubs based on leaf and twig characters. Being a new edition of W. A.
	Kellerman's Spring flora of Ohio, revised and extended so as to cover the area of Ohio,
	Indiana and adjacent States by W. A. Kellerman, H. A. Gleason and John H. Schaffner
	... Columbus, Ohio (Geo. W. Tooill, publisher) 1906." [co-authors: Henry Allan
	Gleason (1882-1975); John Henry Schaffner (1866-1939)]. (Inf. Wm. F Mahler).
<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1914, [i]-xii, [1]-205. <em>Copy</em>: SMU. – "<em>Springflora</em> ... third edition. Columbus, Ohio
	(id.) 1914" (Inf. id.).

Kellogg, Albert (1813-1887), American physician and botanist in California; one of the
seven founders of the California Academy of Sciences (4 Apr 1853); first resident botanist in
California (1849). (<em>Kellogg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CAS (mostly destroyed in 1906), DS, other material at B, BM, F, GH,
GRA, LE, PH, US, WELC.
<em>Ref</em>.: Hultén, E., Bot. Not. 1940: 302 (on Alaskan coll. 1867).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 351. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 452, 6(2): 128; Backer p. 299; Barnhart 2: 279; BM 2:
968; Bossert p. 208; CSP 3: 632, 8: 61-64, 10: 383, 16: 232; DAB (by W. L. Jepson); DSB 7:
285; Hortus 3: 1197 ("Kellogg"); IF 709; IH 2: 350; Kew 3: 231; Langman p. 406; ME 1:
200, 3: 734; NAF 28B(2): 340, ser. 2. 2: 162, 5: 244-245; NCAB 25: 205-206; Pennell p. 611;
PR (alph.); Rehder 5: 449-450; TL-2/1: 2139; Tucker 1: 384, 776; Zander ed. 10, p. 677.
Anon., Ann. Bot., London 1: 404. 1888. (bibl., incompl.); Bot. Gaz. 12: 118. 1887; Bot. Not.
	1888: 45. Leopoldina 23: 109-110. 1887.
Barnhart, J. H., <em>in</em> H. A. Kelly and W. L. Burrage, Amer. med. biogr. 649-650. 1920.
Behr et al., Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci. ser. 2. 1(2): 276-277. 1889 ("memorial").
Brandegee et al. (eds.), Zoe 4(1): 1-2. 1893 (portr.).

Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 180. 1903.
Woodcock, H. B. D. ad Stearn, W. T., The lilies of the world 245. 1950.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: "Voyaged to Calif. 'around the Horn,' arriving in Sacramento, 8 Aug. 1849; ... his
personal botanizing began in earnest in Alaska, 1867. None was more intimately associated
with Calif. botany in the twenty-year period ending in his death." (Cantelow 1957).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With E. L. Greene (q.v.), <em>Illustrations of West-American oaks</em> (see no. 2139)
(additional ref.: Taubert, Bot. Jahrb. 13(Lit,): 270. 1891, rev.)

Kelsey, Francis Duncan (1849-1905), American congregational clergyman and botanist;
D. Sc. College of Montana 1890; minister at Helena, Mont. until 1893; professor of botany at
Oberlin College 1893-1897; pastor Central Congregational Church, Toledo Ohio 1897-
1905. (<em>Kelsey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OC (727 specimens), but Montana plants at MU, for duplicates see
IH. World fair 1893 exhibit plants at MONT.

Kemmler, Carl [Karl] Albert (1813-1888), German clergyman and botanist at Un-
tersontheim 1847-1863; from 1863 at Donnstetten, Württemberg. (<em>Kemmler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Personal herbarium at Botanisches Institut der Universität Hohen-
heim, Stuttgart; much further material at STU; some material at B. A large collection of
lichens, from the estate of M. Fünfstück, went to STU but was destroyed in World War II.
Material contributed by Kemmler is present in the regular series of exsiccatae issued by F. C.
G. Arnold, C. Baenitz, R. F. Hohenacker and G. L. Rabenhorst. [Information S. Seybold].
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 47: 484. 19 Jul 1889 (herb. for sale).
	Mayer, Jahresh. Ver. vaterl. naturk. Württ. 69: 360. 1913.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 690; Barnhart 2: 280; BM 2: 968; IH 2: 351;
Jackson p. 312; Kew 3: 231; Rehder 5: 450; Tucker 1: 385; Urban p. 277.
Kemmler, K., Jahresh. Ver. vaterl. Naturk. Württ. 45: 36-39. 1913.
Künkele, S., Jahresh. Ges. Naturk. Württ. 125: 147, 152. 1970.
Lehmann, E., Schwäbische Apotheker 48, 59, 97, 200. 1951.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Published the second edition (1872) of G. Schuebler &amp; G. M. v. Martens,
<em>Fl. Württ.</em> with Martens; ed. 3 (1882) was published by Kemmler alone. See Schuebler.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kemmleria</em> Körber (1861).

Kennedy, John (1759-1842), British nurseryman; partner of James Lee at the Vineyard
Nursery, Hammersmith; advised Josephine on the Malmaison gardens. (<em>J. Kennedy</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Britten, J., J. Bot. 42: 296-297. 1904.

Johnson, G. W., Hist. English gardening 301. 1829 (fide Desmond).
Willson, E. J., James Lee and the Vineyard Nursery Hammersmith, London 1961, p. 52-55.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) see James Lee for <em>Catalogue of plants and seeds sold by</em> Kennedy and Lee,
... London 1774.
(2) Contributed to H. C. Andrews, <em>Botanical Repository</em> (vols. 1-5). [Andrews was Kennedy's
son-in-law].
(3) Author of <em>Page's Prodromus</em>; as a general nomenclature of all the plants, indigenous and
exotic, cultivated by him in the Southampton Botanic Gardens, London 1817 (see J. Bot. 42:
297. 1904 and Desmond p. 355).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kentia</em> J. Schiller (1953). <em>Note</em>: <em>Kentiopsis</em> A. T. Brongniart (1873), <em>Kentites</em> E.
Bureau (1896), and <em>Siphokentia</em> Burret (1927) are related to <em>Kentia</em> Blume (1838), which is
dedicated to William Kent (1779-1827), Dutch gardener (of English origin?) in Harderwijk
and Buitenzorg, who accompanied Reinwardt and Blume in the Indian Archipelago.

Ker, Charles Henry Bellenden (1785?-1871), British botanist and legal reformer; bar-
rister at Lincoln's Inn; son of John Bellenden Ker. (<em>Ker</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Letters at Kew.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 283; BB p. 172; BM 2: 970; Bret. 1: 186-189;
Desmond p. 356; DNB 31: 47; DU 163; GF p. 62; Jackson p. 380; MW p. 229; NI 1030;

Anon., Flora 55: 128. 1872.
Junk, Rara 41. 1900-1913.
Trimen, H., J. Bot. 10: 32. 1872.

3583. <em>Icones pictae indo-asiaticae plantarum excerptae e codicibus Dom. Cattley.</em> London 1818. Fol.
(n.v.). (<em>Icon. indo-asiat. pl. Cattley</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: The original edition of this set of plates seems to be extremely rare. We have seen no
	copy of this edition; a copy is at the Massachusetts Horticultural Society (see Sotheby 417;
	corrigenda on p. 94). The plates are copies of Chinese drawings brought from China by A.
	E. van Braam-Houckgeest then obviously in the hands of the horticulturist and busin-
	essman William Cattley (x-1832). Junk offered a copy of this 1818 edition with 30 plates.
	A second edition was published in 1821 under the title <em>Icones plantarum sponte China
	nascentium</em>; <em>è bibliothecâ Braamianâ excerptae</em>. London (J. H. Bohte) 1821, 30 plates of which
	23 (or 24) lithographed and 7 (or 6) etched on copper by Ker; p. [i, iii], <em>pl. 1-30. Copy</em>: BR.

Ker, John Bellenden (1764-1842), British botanist at Ramridge; editor of <em>Botanical Register</em>
1815-1824; until 5 Nov 1804, John Gawler. (<em>Ker-Gawl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Ker's manuscripts and drawings are at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 51; Backer p. 300-301; BB p. 172; BM 2: 970; Bret. p.

PAGE: 523
HEADING: KERCHOVE

189, 201, 280; CSP 3: 638, 4: 279 ("Masson"); Desmond p. 356; DNB 31: 52; Hortus 3: 1197
("Ker-Gawl."); Jackson p. 565 [index]; Kew 3: 237; Langman p. 408; Lasègue p. 529; MW
p. 229-230, suppl. p. 157; NI 2379; PR 4626 (not 4625) (ed. 1: 5167-5169, 5171); Rehder 5:
450; RS p. 90; TL-2/1: 136, 1625, see Edwards, S. T.; Zander ed. 10, p. 677.
Britten, J., J. Bot. 40: 419-422. 1902.
Ewan, J., Southw. Louisiana J. 7(1-4): 14. 1967.
Candolle, A. P. de, Mém. Souvenirs 269. 1862.
Herbert, W., Amaryllidaceae 269. 1837 ("I place great reliance on the general accuracy of
	his botanical labours").
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U. S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 173-174. 1947.
Pritzel, G., Linnaea 19: 455-456. 1847.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Born Jon Gawler; name changed by Royal permission to Ker Bellenden, 5 Nov 1804,
but used as Bellenden Ker. Also often referred to as Ker-Gawler.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Ker is the author of all descriptions in the volumes of the <em>Botanical Register</em>
(see no. 1625), vols 1-14, for 1815-1829 "quae signum in calce non gerunt". (PR note sub
4626).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Belendenia</em> [sic] Rafinesque 1832; <em>Bellendena</em> R. Brown (1810). <em>Note</em>: <em>Keria</em> K. P. J.
Sprengel (1818, <em>orth. var.</em>) and <em>Kerria</em> A. P. de Candolle (1818) are dedicated to William Kerr
(x-1814), English gardener and botanical collector, travelling in China, the Philippines,
Java and Ceylon. <em>Kerrdora</em> Gagnepain (1950) and <em>Kerriochloa</em> C. E. Hubbard (1950) are
dedicated to Arthur Francis George Kerr (1877-1942), North Irish physicia and botanist,
working in Siam.

3584. <em>Recensio plantarum</em> huc usque in Repositorio botanicarum depictarum. A review of the
plants hitherto figured in the Botanist's Repository, with a translation of the essential and
special characters. Index duplex. London (printed for J. White) 1801. Ou. (<em>Recens. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1801, p. [i-iii], [1]-74, [4, ind.]. <em>Copy</em>: G. – An index to Andrews, Bot. Repos. (see nos.
	135 and 136). For authorship see Catal. Libr. Kew. 319. 1899.

3585. <em>On the genus Crinum</em>. By John Bellenden Ker, Esq. From the Journal of Science and the
Arts. London (Printed by W. Bulmer and Co.) 1817. Oct. (<em>Crinum</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1817, p. [1]-1W, <em>pl. 8.</em> reprinted from J. Sci. Arts 3: 102-115. 1817. <em>Copy</em> (repr.): G. –
	First valid publication of several names occurring as nomina nuda in Roxburgh's <em>Hortus
	bengalensis</em> (1814).

Kerchove de Denterghem, Oswald Charles Eugène Marie Ghislain de (1844-
1906), Belgian horticulturist, botanist, politician and administrator. (<em>Kerch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 435; 2: 283; BM 2: 970; CSP 16: 246; Hortus 3:

<em>Ref</em>.: Balis, J., Hortus Belgicus 75. 1962.

Kerckhove, Lorenz Wenceslas (1785-1839) [fictitious] Dutch botanist.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Created by an anonymous contributor to Appleton's Cyclopedia of American Biog-
raphy (ca. 1890). See Barnhart, J. New York Bot. Gard. 20: 173-174. 1919. Reported to have
travelled in Central America and the United States, to have been professor of natural history
at Leiden, and to have published e.g. <em>Surinam in Bildern und Skizzen</em> (1835) and <em>Historia
plantarum circa Havana sponte crescentium</em>, (3 vols. Amsterdam 1839). Wholly fictitious. A
mixture of rich imagination with details reminiscent of Kappler, Kerchove and Humboldt.

Kern, Frank Dunn (1883-1973), American mycologist and phytopathologist; Ph. D.
Columbia 1911; specialist on Uredinales; associate botanist at Purdue University (1905-
1910); instructor at Purdue 1910-1913; from 1913-1950 at Pennsylvania State University.
(<em>F. Kern</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAC and PUR; duplicates CUP, IAC, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kern, Bull. Torrey bot. Club 34: 459-463. 1907 (mycol. coll. Colorado).
	Shope, Mycologia 21: 293. 1929.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 283; Bossert p. 209; Hirsch p. 149; IH 2: 353;
Kew 3: 238; LS 13820, 35336-35350, suppl. 13740-13759; MW p. 230; NAF 7(15): 1072-
1073; Roon p. 60; Stevenson p. 1247; TL-2/1: 781.
Anon., J. New York Bot. Gard. 9: 69. 1908, 12: 134. 1911; Mycologia 38: front. portr. 1946.
Boyle et al., Phytopathology 64: 766. 1974 (portr.).
Ewan, J., Rocky Mountain naturalists 243. 1950.
Fergus et al., Mycologia 66(5): 739-742. 1974 (portr., bibl.).
Hesler, L. R., Biogr. sketches North Amer. mycol. 1975 (mss.).

Rogers, D. P., Brief hist. mycol. N. Amer. 29. 1977.
Rogerson, C. D., Mycologia index vols. 1-58, p. 935-936. 1968.

PAGE: 525
HEADING: KERNER, A.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>:(1) NAF, <em>Aecidiaceae, Gymnosporangium</em>, 7(3): 188-211. 15 Apr 1912 (TL-
2/781).
(2) Associate editor <em>Mycologia</em> 1926-1932.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Kern's thesis <em>A biologic and taxonomic study of the genus Gymnosporangiu</em> was published in
the Bull. New York Bot. Gard. 7: 391-483. 1911 (Nat. Nov. Dec (2) 1911; rev. Mycologia 4:
40. 6 Jan 1912). It was revised and issued in book-form 26 Jul 1973 as "<em>A revised taxonomic
account of Gymnosporangium.</em>" (Taxon 22: 684. 1973, 23: 202-203. 1974), probably the only
taxonomic treatment ever to have been revised and republished by the original author after
62 years. – Kern conributed towards J.C. Arthur, <em>The plant rusts</em>, New York 1929.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kernella</em> Thirumalachar (1949); <em>Kernia</em> Thirumalachar (1947); <em>Kerniomyces</em> Toro
(1939). <em>Note: Kernia</em> Nieuwland (1916) may also commemorate him. – Kern Graduate
Building, graduate center at Penn State, 1971.

Kern, Johannes Hendrikus (1903-1974), Dutch botanist, high school teacher at
Nijmegen; later at the Rijksherbarium, Leiden, specialist on Cyperaceae. (<em>J. Kern</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (Dutch coll.), BO (Java).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 425, 674; Bossert p. 209; IH 2: 353-354; Kew 3: 238-

Kerner von Marilaun, Anton Joseph, Ritter (1831-1898); Austrian botanist, Dr. med.
Wien 1854; high school teacher at Budapest 1855-1858, at the Polytechnic 1858-1860;
director of the Innsbruck (1860-1878), and of the Vienna botanical garden (1878-1898);
outstanding floristic botanist, plant geographer and popular writer. (<em>A. Kern</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WU (80.000). – For further details on collections see IH. (1) Kerner's

austro-hungarica a museo botanico universitatis edita was</em> published as follows:

<em>Dutch translation</em>: "<em>Het leven der planten</em> ... naar den tweeden druk voor Nederland bewerkt
	door Dr. Vitus Bruinsma ..." Zutphen, Schillemans &amp; van Belkum, s.d. [1902], 4 vols.
	<em>Copy</em>: Kon. Inst. Tropen, Amsterdam (<em>Leven pl</em>.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Krause, K., Bot. Jahrb. 51 (Lit.): 2. 1913.
	Engler, A., Bot. Jahrb. 54(Lit.): 50. 1917.

3600. <em>The natural history of plants</em> their forms, growth, reproduction, and distribution from the
German of Anton Kerner von Marilaun ... by F.W. Oliver ... with the assistance of Marian
Busk, B. Sc. and Mary F. Ewart, B. Sc. With about 2000 original woodcut illustrations and
sixteen plates in colours ... London (Blackie &amp; Son, ...) Glasgow and Dublin, 1894-1895, 2
vols. Oct. (<em>Nat. hist. pl.</em>)

<em>Original title</em>: "Pflanzenleben", see 3599. Translation by Francis Wall Oliver (1864-1951).
<em>Collaborators</em>: Marian (Lady) Busk (née Balfour, 1861-1941) and Mary Frances Ewart (later
	Macdonald).
<em>Issue in 2 vols</em>.: <em>Vol. 1</em> (part 1-7): [i]-xiv, [xv], [1]-777, <em>pl. 1-8</em>; <em>Vol. 2</em> (parts 8-16): [i]-xiv, [xv],
	[1, err.], [1]-983, <em>pl. 9-16.</em> <em>Copies</em>: MO, USDA.
<em>Issue in 4 half-volumes</em>: <em>1</em>: [i]-iii, [1]-400, <em>pl. 1-3</em>;<em>2</em>: [i-iii], 401-477, <em>pl. 5-8</em>; : [i-iii], [1]-496, <em>pl. 9</em>-
	<em>14</em>; <em>4</em>: [i-v], 497-983. <em>pl. 15-16. Copy</em>: MO.
<em>Imprint</em>: New York (Henry Holt and Company) 1895; also with London imprint. <em>Copies</em>: MO
	(New York), US (London). The US copy of the four half volumes issue (London imprint)
	has in addition the preface material following the volume t.p.'s: 1: [i]-xiv, [1, h.t.; 1, err.].
<em>2</em>: [i]-xiv.

Keyserling, Alexander Friedrich Michael Leberecht Arthur von, [Andreëvich]
 (1815-1891), Latvian/Russian botanist, geologist and palaeontologist of Baltic German
origin; educated at Berlin University; from 1840-1850 handling special missions in the
Russian mining department and travelling in Northern and Eastern Russia; from 1850 on his
Esthonian estate Raiküll. (<em>Keyserl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE.

and high school teacher at Copenhagen; from 1861-1883 assistant at the Botanisk Museum
parttime); from 1883-1900 inspector id. (<em>Kiaersk</em>.).

Kickx, Jean, Sr. (1775-1831), Belgian botanist and mineralogist, professor of botany,
pharmacy and mineralogy at the Brussels medical school. (<em>J. Kickx</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some duplicates at BR; location of main herbarium unknown
(information kindly supplied by A. Lawalrée).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 302; Barnhart 2: 287; BM 2: 976; Bossert p. 210;
CSP 3: 648; IH 2: 357 (incorrect); Jackson p. 272; Kew 3: 253; PR 4653 (ed. 1: 5192-5194);
Rehder 1: 392; Tucker 1: 387.
Crépin, F., Guide bot. Belgique 236, 237, 435, 453. 1878.
Evens, F. M. J. C., Gesch. algol. Belgie 175. 1944.
Jourdan, Dict. Sci. med. 5: 422. 1822.

	Braeckman) 1857, 14 p. (portr., bibl.).
Vanderheyden, J. Pharmacie, Anvers, 1851: 315 (fide Morren 1857).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kickxia</em> Dumortier (1827); <em>Kixia</em> Blume (1828). <em>Kickxia</em> Blume (1849, <em>orth. var.</em> of
<em>Kicxsia</em> Blume (1828)) is explicitly dedicated to his son Jean Kickx jr., q.v., as well.

3615. <em>Flora bruxellensis</em>, exhibens characteres generum et specierum plantarum circum
Bruxellas crescentium, secundum Linneum disposita, cum synonymis auctorum, cui additur
lexicon botanicon, in quo termini artis breviter exponuntur; cura J. Kickx, pharma-
copeorum Bruxellensium collegae ... Bruxellis (Typis M.-E. Rampelberg, ...) 1812. Oct.
(in fours). (<em>Fl. bruxell.</em>).

	5984). Number of copies printed: 600.

Kickx, Jean, Jr. (1803-1864), Belgian botanist and malacologist, son of Jean Kickx (1775-
1831); Ph. D. Leuven 1830; professor of botany at Brussels 1831-1835, at Gent 1835-1864;
one of the founders of the Société de Botanique de Belgique. (<em>J. Kickx fil.</em>)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GENT. – A set of 200 specimens was sent to Lenormand in 1854,
came to CN and is now at P (information P. van der Veken). Kickx' library is also at Gent.

3616. Joannis Kickx ... in Academia Lovaniensi studiosi commentatio ad quaestionem
botanicam ab ordine mathem. et physic, ejusdem Academiae propositam: "Detur <em>accurata
descriptio plantarum</em> officinalium et venenatarum tum phanerogamarum turn cryptoga-
marum, <em>in agro lovaniensi sponte crescentium</em>, addita earum historia. Indicentur characteres
praecipui lam familiarum naturalium quam classium Linnei quo referuntur; deinde osten-
dantur earum proprietates, loci natales, efflorescentiae tempus, usus medici et oeconomici,
ac denique doceatur quibus illae notis differant a plantis quibuscum facile possunt con-
fundi." Quae praemio est ornata postridie iduum octobris mdcccxxvi. Lovanii [Louvain.

Killermann, Sebastian (1870-1956), German clergyman and botanist; Dr. rer. nat.
Regensburg 1893; ordin. ib. 1895; curate at Arendsberg 1895-1901; teacher (1901) and
professor (1910) at the theological-philosophical college at Regensburg; from 1916-1956
president of the Regensburgische botanische Gesellschaft; specialist on Hymenomycetes.
(<em>Killerm</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M. Three hundred unpublished drawings of fungi and the second set
of Bresadola's herbarium, acquired by Killerman, are also at M.
<em>Ref</em>.: Quenstedt, Z. Pilzk. ser. 2. 23: 23. 1957.

HEADING: KING

King, [Sir] George (1840-1909), British botanist; MB Aberdeen 1865; superintendent of
the Calcutta Botanic Gardens and of the Cinchona cultivation in Bengal 1871-1898; director
Botanical Survey of India 1891-1898. (<em>King</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main sets at CAL and K; much other material collected by him and
by "King's collector" (H. H. Kunstler et al.) in various herbaria; see IH.
<em>Ref</em>.: IH 2: 360; SK 1: 281-282 (itin., coll. D.E.I., portr.).
	Hedge, I. C, J. Proc. Asiat. Soc. Bengal n.s. 27: 327-334. 1933 (collectors).
	Hedge, I. C. and J. M. Lamond, Index coll. Edinburgh 98. 1970.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 302; Barnhart 2: 291; BB p. 173; BM 2: 980-981;
Bossert p. 211; Bret. p. 682; CSP 8: 75, 10: 398, 16: 277; Desmond p. 359; GF p. 83; Hortus 3:
1197 ("King"); Jackson p. 386, 387; Kew 3: 259-260; Lasègue p. 275, 282, 573 [index]; MW
p. 232-233; NI 1046-1052, 1840-1909; Rehder 5: 454; Tucker 1: 388, 776; Zander ed. 10, p.
678.
Anon., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 27: (144). 1910; Bot. Not. 1909: 146; Bull. Acad. int. Géogr. bot.
	10(135): frontisp. portr. 1901 (Director Academy for 1901); Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1898:
	54-55, 1909: 68-72, 193-197 (bibl.); Gard. Chron. 1901: 293 (portr.). 1909: 138 (portr.).
	Trans. Proc. bot. Soc. Edinburgh 24(2): 46-48, 24(3): 101-103. 1911 (obituary notice by
	Robert Pantling; name consistently spelled "Panthing").
Britten, J., J. Bot. 47: 120-122. 1909 (portr.).
Burkill, I. H., Chapt. hist. bot. India 241 [index]. 1965.
Huxley, L., Life letters J. D. Hooker 2: 552 [index]. 1918.
Nelmes &amp; Cuthbertson, Curtis's Bot. Mag. Dedic. 1827-1927: 206. 1932 (portr.).
O.S., Proc. Linn. Soc. London 121: 42-45. 1909.
Prain ["D.P."], Proc. R. Soc. London B 81: xi-xxviii. 1909.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 158. 1903.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Founder and first editor of the <em>Annals of the royal botanic Gardens</em>, Calcutta,
1-8. 1887-1898.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Indokingia</em> W. B. Hemsley (1906); <em>Kingella</em> Van Tieghem (1895); <em>Kingiella</em> Rolfe
(1917); <em>Kinginda</em> O. Kuntze (1891); <em>Kingiodendron</em> Harms (1897). <em>Note</em>: <em>Kingiacolpites</em> R. S.
Tiwari &amp; A. A. Moíz (1971) is dedicated to W. King (1809-1886), Irish geologist and
paleontologist; <em>Kingiobryum</em> H. E. Robinson (1967), and <em>Kingiolejeunea</em> H. E. Robinson (1967)
commemorate Robert Merrill King (1930-x), American botanist.

Kingdon-Ward, Francis (Frank) (1885-1958), British plant collector in China, Burma,
Tibet and Thailand (1909-1956), introduced e.g. <em>Meconopsis betonicifolia</em> into cultivation;
prolific author on "plant hunting." (<em>Kingdon-Ward</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 212; Desmond p. 360 (provides numerous
biogr. references); DNB 1951-1960: 620-621; Kew: 3: 261-363; Lenley p. 251; MW suppl. p.
391-392; Plesch p. 288; SK 1: 561.
Anderson, Garden J. 25(2): 40. 1975.
Coats, A. M., Quest for plants 128-131. 1969.
Chatterjee and Mukerjee, Sci. and Cult. 24: 131. 1958.
Cox, E. H. M., Plant hunting in China 180-191. 1945.
Fletcher, H. R., R. Bot. Gard. Edinburgh 245. 1970.
Schweinfurth and Schweinfurth-Marby, Exploration in the Eastern Himalayas ... Francis
	(Frank) Kingdon-Ward (1885-1958): an annotated bibliography ... Wiesbaden. F.
	Steiner, 1975, x, 114 p. (maps, portr., bibl.).
Stearn, W. T., Biographical introduction. A list of publications, <em>in</em> F. Kingdon-Ward,
	Pilgrimage for Plants 11-18, 181-186. 1960.

<sm>TRAVELOGUES</sm>: K. published a series of travel books, listed e.g. by Desmond, from 1913 (<em>Land
of Blue Poppy</em> 1913) until 1960 (<em>Pilgrimage for plants</em>, posthumous, with a biographical and
bibliographical introduction by W. T. Stearn); see also Schweinfurth and Schweinfurth-
Marby (1975).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kingdon-wardia</em> Marquand (1929). <em>Note: Kingdonia</em> I. B. Balfour &amp; W. W. Smith
(1914) commemorates his mother, Mrs. Marshall Ward, about whom we have no further
details.

3661. <em>Field notes of Rhododendrons collected by Kingdon-Ward in 1926</em>. s.l.n.d. Oct. (<em>Field notes
Rhododendr.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Kingdon-Ward published a number of <em>Field notes</em> booklets, with no imprints, giving
	details on his collections.
	<em>1926</em>: Field notes of Rhododendrons ... p. [7]-81.
	<em>1926</em>: Field notes of trees, shrubs and plants other than rhododendrons ... in 1926, p. [7]-
	46.
	<em>1927/28-1937</em>: Field notes of Rhododendrons and other plants ... in 1927/28 (p. [1]-33, 1-
	34), in 1931 ([1]-49, 1-49), in 1933 (p. [1]-23, 1-43), in 1935 ([i], 1-35), in 1937 ([1]-35).
	Set at NY (probably incomplete).

Kinney, Abbot (1850-1920), American popular writer on botany (<em>Kinney</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Kirby, Mary (1860: Mrs. H. Gregg) (1817-1893), British botanist at Leicester. (<em>Kirby</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The herbarium of Mary's sister Elizabeth Kirby (1823-1873) is at
LEI. The two sisters collaborated narrowly.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kent, D. H., Brit. herbaria 63, 1957.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 293; BB p. 174-175; BM 2: 983; CSP 3: 658;

	on Elizabeth Kirby).
Kirby, M., Leaflets from my life, 1887 (fide BB).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kirbyella</em> C. Zeliff (1930) and <em>Kirbynia</em> Grassé &amp; A. C. Hollande (1950) are
dedicated to Harold Kirby, American protistologist.

Kirchner, [Emil Otto] Oskar (1851-1925), German botanist and flower-biologist; Dr.
phil. Breslau 1874; from 1873-1877 at Breslau; from 1877-1917 assistant, from 1881 professor
of botany at the Landwirtschaftliche Akademie, Hohenheim; from 1917-1925 living at
München. (<em>Kirchn</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 563; BM 2: 985; CSP 10: 402, 12: 386, 16: 288; De

p. 1247; Tucker 1: 389.

HEADING: KIRILLOW

(3) Started the <em>Lebensgeschichte der Blütenpflanzen Mitteleuropas</em>, with E. Loew and C. Schröter,
later continued by W. Wangerin and C. Schröter, ultimately by Th. Schmucker, 1904-1942
(64 Lieferungen). Remained unfinished. See under Schröter. Lieferung 1 (p. 1-96, 97 figs.,
Stuttgart) came out Jan-Apr 1904 (rev. by Engler, Bot. Jahrb. 34(Lit.): 21. 1904). Kirchner
co-authored parts 1-25, 1904-1925.

Kirillow, Peter (<em>fl</em>. 1849), Russian botanist and physician at Charkow. (<em>Kirillow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M\V.

Bourdeille, Bull. Soc. Imp. Natural. Moscou ser. 2. 6: 369. 1893.

3669. <em>Die Loniceren des russischen Reiches</em> geschichtnch und kritisch behandelt. Eine Abhand-
lung zur Erlangung der Würde eines Magisters der Philosophie vcrfasst und mit Geneh-

Kirilow, Iwan Petrovic ("Johann"), (1821-1842,, Russian botanist. (<em>Kir</em>.).

Kirk, [Sir] John (1832-1922), Scottish colonial administrator, explorer and botanist;
mainly active in eastern Africa; M. D. Edinburgh 1854; physician and naturalist on
Livingstone's second Zambesi expedition (1858-1863); in Zanzibar 1866-1881, 1883-1887;
thence onward in England. (<em>J. Kirk</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; for duplicates see IH. The plants collected by him on the
Livingstone Expedition, are also at K. First set of plants from Turkey at E.
<em>Ref</em>.: Exell, A. W, Fl. zambesiaca 1: 35-37. 1960 (itin. Afr.).
	Hedge, I. C. and J. M. Lamond, Ind. coll. Edinburgh 98. 1970.
	Hepper, F. N. and F. Neate, Plant coll. West Africa 45. 1971.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 456-457; Backer p. 303; Barnhart 2: 294; BB p. 175;
Bossert p. 212; CSP 3: 662, 8: 78-79, 10: 403, 16: 289; Desmond p. 361-362; Hortus 3: 1197
("Kirk, J."); IH 2: 363; Kew 3: 266; Rehder 5: 455; SO 3404; Tucker 1: 389; Zandered. 10,
p. 678.
Anon., J. Bot. 60: 69. 1922; J. Bot. 71: 206. 1933; Nature 109: 114-115. 1922.
Coupland, R., Kirk on the Zambesi, Oxford, Clarendon Press, 1928.
D.P., Proc. R. Soc. B. 94: xi-xxx. 1923.

	Edinburgh 1964, 187p. (portr.).

	John Murray, 1865.

Wild, Kirkia 1: 5-11. 1960 (portr.).

	USDA. — Incomplete: Ranunc.-Compos.
	"It is matter for regret that Mr. Kirk has quoted throughout the MS. names employed in
	the Flora [i.e. a transcript of Solander's manuscript <em>Florae Novae Zelandiae</em> at BM], thus
	adding to synonymy a number of entirely useless names of which future monographers will
	have to take note." (Britten 1900). The book remained incomplete because of Kirk's death
	in 1898.
<em>Ref</em>: Britten, J., J. Bot. 38: 141-143. Apr 1900.
	Cockayne, L., Veget. New Zealand 6. 1921.

Kirkwood, Joseph Edward (1872-1928), American botanist; Ph. D. Columbia 1903,
from 1901-1907 at Syracuse University; from 1907-1909 involved in guayule-rubber re-

Kirschleger, Frédéric (1804-1869), Alsatian botanist; M.D. Paris 1829; 1829-1834
physician at Munster; from 1834-1845 at the Strasbourg École de Pharmacie; from 1845 at

Rehder 5: 455; Tl 2/1: 2164, see Buchoz, P.J.; Tucker 1: 389; Zander ed. 10, p. 678.

Vosges et dans la Vallée du Rhin, ... Paris (J. B. Baillière et Fils, ...), Strasbourg (Treuttel

	1870; Flora rd. 30 Jun 1870; p. vi dated Feb 1870), p. [i], portr. author, [iii]-vi, [1]-502,
	[1, avis].

<em>Copies</em>: B, G, MIGH, USDA. – On 18 Sep 1869, shortly before his death (on 15 Nov 1869),
	Kirschleger sent "23 premières demifeuilles" to Burnat, p. [1]-384. It is likely that the
	copy mentioned by Flora (see above) was a similar set. The treatment of the vascular
	cryptogams, and in general the publication of the second volume, is by Ph. Becker. The
	second volume was promised for the autumn of 1870, but the outbreak of the Franco-
	Prussian war at that time makes it difficult to ascertain its date of publication. Jessen, <em>in</em>
	Pritzel (1872) mentions only tome I.
<em>Ref</em>.: P.A., Bot. Zeit. 28: 611-613. 23 Sep 1870 (rev. of torn. 1).
	Winter, Flora 53: 292-304. 1870 (rd. 1).

Kirschstein, Wilhelm (1863-1946), German mycologist; high school teacher at Ra-
thenow (Havel), later at Berlin-Pankov. (<em>Kirschst</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (10.000, extant; rd. 1945). K's library came also to B. – "Kirschstein
krönte seine Uneigennützigkeit durch Schenkung seines Pilzherbars ... an das Botanische
Museum [Berlin-Dahlem] ..." (Rosenthal, 1956).
<em>Ref</em>.: Kohlmeyer, Willdenowia 2: 783. 1961.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 226; Barnhart 2: 295; Bossert p. 212; CSP 16: 294;
IH 2: 363; Kew 3: 268; LS 13925-13926, suppl. 13966-13969; Stevenson p. 1247; Urban-
Berl. p. 277.
Rosenthal, M., Willdenowia 1(4): 606-611. 1956 (portr., bibl.); Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a:
	254. 1956.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>Kryptogamenflora von Brandenburg</em>:
(a) <em>Sphaeriales</em>, 7(2): [164]-304. 20 Nov 1911.
(b) <em>Sphaerellaceae</em>, 7(3): 305-448. 5 Mai 1938.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Willdenowia 1 (4): 607. 1956.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kirschsteinia</em> H. Sydow (1906); <em>Kirschsteiniella</em> F. Petrak (1923).

PAGE: 555
HEADING: KITAIBEL

Kirtikar, Kanhoba Ranchoddâs (1849/1850-1917), Indian botanist; surgeon-major in
the British-Indian army; stationed at various locations; 1886 assistant, 1887 full professor of
materia medica at Bombay; one of the founders of the Bombay Natural History Society.
(<em>Kirt</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 295; BB p. 175; CSP 16: 294; Desmond p. 362;
Kew 3: 268; LS 13927, 35416; MW suppl. p. 161.
Jackson, B. D., Proc. Linn. Soc. London 129: 48. 1917.

3682. <em>Indian medicinal plants</em> ... published by Sudhindra Nath Basu, M.B., ... Bahadur-
ganj, Allahabad (printed by Apurva Krishna Rose, at the Indian Press) 1918. Qu. (<em>Ind. med.
pl.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Major Basu Baman Das.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1918 (p. x: 1 Jan 1918), in two parts text and four parts plates (uncol.); the plates

HEADING: KJELLMAN

Kjellman, Frans Reinhold (1846-1907), Swedish phycologist at Uppsala; collected in
Spitzbergen 1872-1873; Novaya Zemlya 1875; botanist with Nordenskjöld on the <em>Vega</em>
expedition of 1878-1880; Ph. D. Uppsala 1872; extra ord. professor of botany 1883; ord.
professor 1900. (<em>Kjellm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS; duplicates at B, FI, GB, H, K, KIEL, L, LY, P, PC, S, S-PA,
WRSL.

BM 2: 988-989; Bossert p. 213; CSP 10: 407, 16: 301; Frank 3(Anh.): 50; IH 2: 365; Jackson
p. 336, 566 [index]; Kew 3: 271; Kleppa p. 326; KR p. 349-354; Moebius p. 86, 87, 88, 90;
MW p. 235; Rehder 5: 546; SO 426, 2841; SK 8: lv; TR 681-682; Urban-Berl. p. 363.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1871: 196, 1872: 127, 188, 1875: 93, 1976: 93, 1878: 132, 1883: 239, 1849:
	iv, 1907: 150; Bot. Zeit. 65(2): 200. 1907; Generalregister Bot. Not. 1839-1938: 40-41,
	103, 178. 1939; Törreya 7: 110. 1907.

	Notatisia 22: 121-125. 1907 (bibl.).
Embacher, F., Lexikon Reisen 165-166. 1882.
Hultén, E., Bot. Not. 1940: 303 (Alaskan coll.).

	(portr.); K. Sv. Vet. Akad. Årsbok 1908: 279-300 (portr., bibl.).
Wille, Naturen 31: 161-165. 1907.

expedition (1878-1879) are at UPS, dupl. at S.

HEADING: KLATT

Kjoeping, Oläus (1741-1809), [fictitious] Swedish botanical explorer. (<em>Kjoeping</em>).

<sm>NAME</sm>: Created by an unknown contributor to Appleton's Dictionary of American Biography
(ca. 1890); said to have been a military surgeon in the Danish service. See Barnhart (1919)
for further details. Fictitious titles: "<em>Prodromus florae</em>, sistens enumerationem plantarum
cellularium quas in insulas, Santa Domingo, Cuba, Sancti Thomae et Sancti Bartholomei a
Kjoeping collectas ... Copenhagen 1799, and "<em>Anmärkingar om Planter of Cuba</em>" (3 vols.
1807). Reminiscent of Olov Swartz.
<em>Ref</em>.: Barnhart, J. H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 20: 174. 1919.

Klášterský, Ivan (1901-197.), Czechoslovak botanist, especially rhodologist, curator of
PR 1925-1955, later working at the Geobotanical laboratory of the Ceskosl. Akad. ved.,
Pruhonice. (<em>Klášt</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Klášterský p. 107; Roon p. 62.
Deyl, Preslia 33: 419-424. 1961 (bibl.).
Futák, J. &amp; K. Domin, Bibl CSR 313-314. 1960.
Jerábkova, O. &amp; Soják, J., Cas. Slezsk. Muz. C. Dendrol. 2: 97-103. 1972 (portr.).
Klika, Ochrana přírody 6: 104-105. 1951.
Mesícek, Preslia 43: 276-278. 1971 (70th birthday).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Klasterskya Petrak (1940).

Klatt, Friedrich Wilhelm (1825-1897), German botanist; from 1842-1897 high school
teacher at Hamburg; Dr. phil. Rostock 1864. (<em>Klatt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GH (11.5000): Further material at B, CGE, HBG, K, SAM. – The
Klatt herbarium contained the Primulaceae from Lehmann's herbarium.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Gaz. 27: 151. 1899 (GH buys herb.).
	Day, Rhodora 3: 244. 1901.
	Solbrig, O., Taxon 14: 188-191. 1965 (Compositae herbarium at GH).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 297; BJI 1: 32; BM 2: 990; Bossert p. 213; CSP
3: 673, 10: 408, 16: 303-304; DTS 1: 154; Hortus 3: 1197 ("Klatt"); IH 2: 366; Jackson p.
346, 372; Kew 3: 273; Langman p. 410; MW p. 235; NAF ser. 2.2: 162; NI 1056, 1056n; PR
4710-4713; Rehder 5: 456; TL 2/1: 198, 1592; Tucker 1: 389-390; Urban-Berl. p. 363;
Zander ed. 10, p. 678.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1898: 45.
Fischer-Benzon, R. J. D. von, <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schleswig-Holstein 2: 28-29. 1890.
Goverts, Leopoldina 35: 142-145. 1899 (bibl.).
Schinz, Bull. Herb. Boissier 5(10): 836-839. Oct 1877 (bibl.).
Urban, I., Fl. bras. 1(1): 180-181. 1906.
Voigt, Jahrb. Hamb. Wiss. Anst. 16, Beiheft 3: 97-106. 1898 (portr., bibl.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See Voigt (1898, cited above) for Klatt's various contributions, often on
Compositae, to other works. The important are:
(1) Martius, <em>Flora brasiliensis, Irideae</em>, 3(1): 509-548, <em>pl. 64-71.</em> 1 Jul 1871.
(2) C. C. von der Decken, <em>Reisen in Ost Afrika in 1859-61</em>, vol. 3(3), <em>Irideen und Compositen</em>, p. 73-
79. 1879 (Nat. Nov. Sep 1879).
(3) E. Warming, <em>Symbolae</em>, 13, <em>Irideae</em>, p. 127-130, <em>Publ</em>. 26 Apr 1873.
(4) Durand et Schinz, <em>Conspectus florae africae, Iridaceae africanae</em> 5: 143-250. Dec 1894 (see TL-
2/1593).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Klatt was requested by J. G. C. Lehmann (in his will) to sell the latter's herbarium. He
sold parts of the herbarium to some 120 botanists, netting a receipt of DM 20.000. = which
went to Lehmann's widow.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Klattia</em> J. G. Baker (1877).

HEADING: KLATT

Klebahn, Heinrich (1859-1942), German mycologist and phytopathologist; Dr. phil. Jena
1884; high school teacher (linguistics) at Bremen 1885-1894, at Hamburg 1894-1899; from
1899-1905 at the Hamburg botanical Garden; from 1905-1930 at the agricultural institute of
Bromberg; teaching at Hamburg University 1921-1934. (<em>Kleb</em>.)

410; Tucker 1: 390.

Wood, R. D., Monogr. Charac. 1: 820. 1965.

Klein, Jakob Theodor (1685-1759), German botanist, born at Königsberg, municipal
secretary at Danzig. (<em>Klein</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ER.

PAGE: 565
HEADING: KLETT

<em>Kleinia</em> A. L. Jussieu (1803) probably are also dedicated to him. <em>Kleiniella</em> R. Francé (1894) is
dedicated to Julius Klein, mycologist. <em>Kleinodendron</em> L. B. Smith &amp; R. J. Downs (1964) is
dedicated to Roberto Miquel Klein, Brazilian botanist and ecologist.

Kleinhans, Rodolphe (1828-?), French bryologist. (<em>Kleinh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Klement, Oscar (1897-x), Bohemian lichenologist; pupil of Anders; in Czechoslovakia
until 1945; later in Hannover and Kempten. (<em>Klem</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR and PRM (20.000, confiscated with his library in 1945 fide GR);
IH also lists material at a regional museum at Chomutov (Komotau) where Klement was
born and worked until he was forced to leave the country. Other material: GOET, GZU,
LD. – Klement built up a new herbarium after 1945. This is now at the Institut für
pharmazeutische Biologie, Bonn. Several types, designated after 1945, are at M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 299; GR p. 434-435 (very detailed) [<em>pl. 22</em>], cat.
p. 66; IH 2: 367; Roon p. 62; SBC p. 124 ("Klem."); TL-2/1: see Cretzoiu, P.
Anon., Hessische floristische Briefe 8(96. Brief). Dec 1959 (Dr. h.c. Bonn).
Dörr, Mitt. naturw. Arbeitskr. Kempten (Allgäu) 16(1): 1-7. 1972 (bibl., n.v.) (note on the
	occasion of K's 75th birthday); ib. 21: x-xx. Apr 1977 (80th birthday).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: C. F. E. Erichsen, <em>Flechtenflora von Nordwestdeutschland</em>, Stuttgart 1957,
edited by W. Christiansen, O. Klement and W. Saxen.

Klett, Gustav Theodor (x-1827), German botanist at Leipzig. (<em>Klett</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM and TYPES</sm>: LZ (destroyed).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 299; BM 2: 993; IH 2: 367; PR 4718 (ed. 1:
5261); Rehder 5: 457.

Klinge, Johannes Christoph (1851-1902), Estonian botanist; Dr. phil. Dorpat (Tartu)
1893; at the Dorpat botanical garden 1879-1895; from 1895 librarian and botanist at the St.
Petersburg botanical garden. (<em>Klinge</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE.

natural history of South Africa.

Klinggräff, Carl Julius Meyer von (1809-1879), German physician and botanist; Dr.
med. Königsberg 1832; at first physician at Marienwerder; from 1836 landowner at
Paleschken bei Stuhm in Prussia. (<em>C. Klinggr.</em>)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: At the former "Westpreussisches Provinzial-Museum zu Danzig."
According to our information this museum was destroyed during World War II, but recent
confirmation from Poland is lacking. Other material: B, L, PC.

Volkens, Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 51: (84). 1910.

Klinggräff, Hugo Erich Meyer von (1820-1902), German bryologist; brother of C. J. M.
von Klinggräff; educated in Croatia (Zmrock, 1826-1842); on the family estate of Palesch-
ken 1842-1846; Dr. phil. Königsberg 1846; in Croatia 1846-1848; from 1848 active in
various parts of Prussia, mainly at Marienwerder. (<em>H. Klinggr.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: An important part of K's herbarium is at BP. Another part may have
been at Königsberg, now Kaliningrad, but recent information received by us on the former
Königsberg herbarium collections indicates that all was lost during World War II. Other
Klinggräff material is at B, GOET, GFW, H, IBF, KIEL, L, MW, NY, PC, S, UPS. Most of
this material was distributed in the series <em>Unio itin. crypt.</em>

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 300; BM 2: 994: CSP 3: 676, 8: 87, 10: 415, 12:
389, 16: 322; GR p. 95-96; IH 2: 367; Jackson p. 309; Kanitz 299; Kew 3: 276; LS 14033,
35451; NAF ser 2. 3: 38; Rehder 5: 458; SBC p. 124 ("Klinggr."); Tucker 1: 391.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1903: 34; J. Bot. 17: 383. 1879; Rev. bryol. 16: 78. 1889, 20: 77. 1893; 29:
	131. 1902.
Beck, G., Vegetationsverh. Illyr. länder 37. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4).
Caspary, R., Lebensbeschr. Ost-Westpreuss. Botaniker 228-229. 1912 (portr., bibl.).
Conwentz, H. W., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 29: (12)-(13). 1911.
Kalmuss, Ber. westpreuss. bot.-zool. Ver. 26/27: 1-9. 1905 (portr.).
Szweykowski, J., Prodr. fl. hepat. polon. 1958.

Klinsmann, Ernst Ferdinand (1794-1865), Danzig botanist and physician; studied at
Berlin under F. G. Hayne; Dr. med. Berlin 1823; practiced medicine in Danzig 1824-1865;
curator of the botanical collections of the Naturforschende Gesellschaft in Danzig. (<em>Klinsm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: At the Provinzialmuseum, Danzig; now destroyed. – L has some
Charophyta attributed to "Klinsmann."

Kloos, Abraham Willem, Jr. (1880-1952), Dutch botanist; Dr. phil. h.c. Leiden 1946;
civil engineer; high school teacher at Schiermonnikoog (1904-1905), Goes (1905-1911) and
Dordrecht (1911-1945); student of the adventitious flora of the Netherlands. (<em>Kloos</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L; further material at C, K and U.

Klotzsch, Johann Friedrich (1805-1860), German botanist at Berlin; curator of the
herbarium (1833-1860); outstanding mycologist. (<em>Klotzsch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mostly destroyed). Exsiccatae: <em>Herbarium vivum mycologicum</em> sistens
fungorum per totam germaniam crescentium collectionem perfectam, Berlin 1832, cent. 1-2,
nos. 1 -200, sets at B (complete set, extant), BM, BR, BPI, FH, HAL, K, L, M, MSTR, OXF,
PAV, PC, UPS. – For the continuation of this series see under L. Rabenhorst. A detailed
review of title development and editors is given by IH and by Stevenson (1971). For an
alphabetical index see Kohlmeyer (1962).
<em>Ref</em>.: Klotzsch, J. F., Linnaea (Lit.) 8: 17-19. 1833.
	Kohlmeyer, J., Willdenowia 2: 785. 1961; Index alphabeticus Klotzschii et Rabenhorstii

	Stevenson, J., Taxon 16: 112-119. 1967; Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 274-296. 1971.

3735. <em>Species novae et minus cognitae</em> horti regii botanici berolinensis auctoribus A. Braun,
Klotszch [sic] et Bouché, s.l.n.d. [Berolini (Typis C. Feisteri) 1851, 1852]. Qu. (<em>Sp. nov. min.
cogn.</em>)

<em>Co-authors</em>: Alexander Carl Heinrich Braun (1805-1877); Carl David Bouché (1908-1881).

<em>1851</em>: late 1851 or early 1852, p. [1]-3. <em>Copy</em>: HH. – Issued as an appendix to <em>Index seminum
	horto botanico berolinensi</em> anno 1851 collectorum (by A. Braun and C. D. Bouché), p. [1]-14.
	The 1851 issue starts with I. <em>Acrostichum</em> (<em>Elaphoglossum</em>) <em>erythrotrichum</em> Kl.; spelling
	"Klotszch".
<em>1852</em>: late 1852 or early 1853, p. [1]-3. <em>Copy</em>: HH. – Reprinted with independent pagination
	from idem 1852 ([1]-14); pagination in original issue p. [12]-14. The 1852 issue starts with
	1. <em>Pleurothallis</em> (<em>elongatae</em>) <em>subpellucida</em> Kl.; spelling "Klotzsch." Copy with original pagi-
	nation at U.

3736. <em>Über Pistia</em> ... Berlin (Gedruckt in der Druckerei der königl. Akademie der Wissen-
schaften) 1853. Qu. (<em>Pista</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep 1853 (submitted 2 Dec 1852; "soeben" Bonplandia 1 Oct 1853, Bot. Zeit. 7 Oct
	1853), p. [i], [1]-31, <em>pl. 1-3</em> (uncol. liths. by C. F. Schmidt). <em>Copies</em>: G, WU. – Abh.

3737. <em>Appendix specierum novarum</em> et minus cognitarum, quae in horto regio botanico be-
rolinensi coluntur. Auctoribus A. Braun, Klotzsch, C. Koch et Bouché. [Berlin] 1853. Qu. (<em>App. sp. nov.</em>)

<em>Co-authors</em>: A. Braun (see above), C. D. Bouché (see above), Karl Heinrich Emil Koch (1809-
	1879).
<em>Publ</em>.: Dec 1853 or early 1854, p. [1]-14. <em>Copies</em>: HH(2), MO. – Issued with <em>Index seminum in

3738. <em>Appendix generum et specierum novarum</em> et minus cognitarum quae in Horto regio botanico
berolinensi coluntur. [Berlin] 1854. Qu. (<em>App. gen. sp. nov.</em>)

<em>General editor</em> (as director): A. Braun (see above).

<em>1854</em>: Dec 1854 or, more likely, early 1855, p. [1]-19. <em>Copies</em>: B, HH. – Issued with <em>Index
	seminum in horto botanico berolinensi</em> anno 1854 collectorum. [Berlin 1854], p. [1]-10. Several
	co-authors.
<em>1855</em>: Dec 1855 or early 1856, p. [1]-29. <em>Copies</em>: HH, MO, – Issued with id. 1855, p. [1]-10.
The appendices to the Berlin seed lists appeared in this form from 1844 onward; they contain
contributions by various authors. We treat here only those seen by us. The <em>appendices</em> for 1854
and 1855 (and probably several others) contained several contributions by K. H. E. Koch
who was then "Adjunkt" at the Garden (director 1851-1877: Alexander Braun); other
contributors in 1854 were Bouché, Koernicke, Caspary and A. Braun.

3739. <em>Begoniaceen-Gattungen und Arten</em> ... Berlin (in der Nicolaischen Buchhandlung. Ge-
druckt in der Druckerei der königl. Akademie der Wissenschaften) 1855. Qu. (<em>Begoniac</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1855, before 1 Oct (t.p. 1855; Bonplandia 15 Oct 1855; Bot. Zeit. 5 Oct 1855; Flora rd.
	14 Sep-7 Oct 1855), p. [i], [1]-135, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (uncol. liths. by C. F. Schmidt). <em>Copies</em>: B, G,
	M, MO, NY, U, US. – Reprinted from Abh. k. Akad. Wiss. Berlin 1854: 121-255. 1855.
	See also Monatsber. 1854: 119-228. Mar 1854 (diagnoses!). – Splits <em>Begonia</em> in 42 genera.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 13: 707-709. 5 Oct 1855.
	Seemann, B. C., Bonplandia 3: 286-288. 15 Oct 1855 (extensive review).
	Hooker, W. J., J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 7: 352. Nov 1855.

	Erde 2(1)).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with the Austrian artist and botanical painter Johann Knapp
(1778-1833), who painted the famous "Jacquin Denkmal" (at Vienna) and who made the
flower paintings for Archduke Johann Baptist von Österreich (1782-1859), treated above
under 3362 ("<em>Icones plantarum</em>"). For biogr. details on Johann Knapp see e.g. WU 12: 137-
139; Widder, Jahrb. Ver. Schutze Alpenfl. 25: 104-117. 1960; Nissen, Philobiblon 6(9): 338.
1933; and G. Frodl, <em>in</em> Johann Knapp, Jacquins Denkmal. Österr. Galerie, Schloss Belvé-
dère, Wien 1966, p. 30-46.

bekannten Pflanzen Slavoniens</em>. Wien 1866 (Apr-Mai), see Schulzer.
(2) For a description of the plants collected by Knapp in Persian "Adserbidschan"
(Azerbaijan) in 1884 see the series of papers edited by R. v. Wettstein as "<em>Beitrag zur Flora von
Persien</em>."

Knaut, Christian (1654-1716), German botanist at Halle, brother of Christoph Knauth.
(<em>Knaut</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Knaut's brother Christoph Knauth [sic] (1638-1694), physician and botanist at Halle
published an <em>Enumeratio plantarum circa Halam Saxonum</em> (1687, ed. 2 1689), see PR 4740, see
below. We agree with Schmid that it is more likely that Knauth and Knaut were brothers,
rather than father and son. They spelled their family name differently on the t.p.'s of their
books.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 278; Barnhart 2: 301; BM 2: 996; Bossert p. 214;

PAGE: 574
HEADING: KNAUT, C.

Dryander 3: 162; Jackson p. 15; Kew 3: 280; PR 4741-4742 (ed. 1: 5277-5278); Rehder 5:
459.

O., Dict. Sci. méd. 5: 440-441. 1822.
Stafleu, F. A., Linnaeus and the Linnaeans 42, 61. 1971.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Knautia</em> Linnaeus (1753).

3753. <em>Enumeratio plantarum circa Halam saxonum</em> et in ejus vicinia, ad trium fere milliarum
spatium, sponte provenientium, cum earum synonymiis, locis natalibus ubi proveniunt, &amp;
tempore quo florent, additis characteribus generum summorum atque subalternorum, &amp;
indice copioso, in botanophilorum gratiam methodice consignata, studio Christophori
Knauths ... Lipsiae [Leipzig] (Sumpt. haered. Fried. Langkisii) 1687. Oct. (<em>Enum. pl. Hal.
sax.</em>)

<em>Publ</em>.: 1687, p. [i-viii], 1-187, [188-212, index], [2, add.], [1, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: U, USDA. –
	Zuchold (1853) mentions this title with a 1688 imprint (Leipzig, id.), stating that it does
	not differ from the 1687 edition. Leimbach (1886) provides more details on the minor
	differences as well as on the merits of the book. We have seen no copy of the 1688 issue.
<em>Ref</em>.: Zuchold, E. A., Jahresber. Naturf. Ges. Halle 5: 29. 1853.
	Leimbach, Irmischia 6(3/4): 14. 1886.

Knebel, Gottfried (1908-x), German algologist, Dr. phil. Berlin 1935. (<em>Knebel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at KIEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAHPY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH 2: 370.

augural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der Doktorwurde genehmigt von der Philosophischen

Oct. (<em>Monogr. Prasiolales</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 15 Apr 1935 (in Hedwigia), p. [i-iii], [1]-120, [1, vita], 3 maps. <em>Copy</em>: FH. – Reprinted
	from Hedwigia 75(1/2): [1]-120. 15 Apr 1935.

Kneucker, Johann Andreas ("Andrees") (1862-1946), German high school teacher and
botanist at Karlsruhe; from 1905 also curator of KR; botanical explorer of the Near East,
especially of the Sinai Peninsula. (<em>Kneuck</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KR; bryophytes also at H. – The pre-1942 collections at KR were
destroyed by fire in 1942 (Bürgelin 1949).
<em>1. Editio Caricum Badensium</em>, Stuttgart 1890-1902, see below under 3.
<em>2. Editio Graminum badensium</em>, Stuttgart 1894.
<em>3. Carices exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-13, 1896-1911, nos. 1-390. Sets at B, BERN, H, IBF, K, L, LAU,
LE, MANCH, TO, STU, WRSL. (orig. issued 3 fasc., 90 nos. 1890-1892, reissued 1894, then
ctd.).
<em>4. Cyperaceae</em> (exclus. Carices) <em>et Juncaceae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-9, 1900-1911, nos. 1-270. Sets at B,
BM, C, IBF, K, L, LAU, LE, MANCH, SI.
<em>5. Gramineae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-32, 1900-1920, sets at B, BAF, BM, C, GH, H, IBF, K, L, LAU,
LE, MANCH, NSW, PR, SI, STU, W.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kneucker, J. A., Bemerkungen zu den "Carices [Cyperaceae, Gramineae, Glumaceae]
	exsiccatae" in Allg. bot. Z. 1896-1920 (see 3756).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 71; Backer p. 304; Barnhart 2: 302; BM 2: 997;
Bossert p. 214; CSP 16: 335; DTS 1: 154-155, 6(4): 161-162; GR p. 97; Hirsch p. 153; IH
1(ed. 6): 128, 2: 370; SBC p. 124 ("Kneuck."); TL-2/1: see Bauer, E., Buchenau, F.G.P.
Bürgelin, Andreas Kneucker. Ein Lebensbild zu seinem 75. Geburtstag, Karlsruhe i. B.
	1937, 15 p. (Beitr. naturk. Forschung Südwestdeutschland 2(1): 1-15. 1937) (portr.,
	bibl.); Ber. Baye. bot. Ges. 28: 299. 1950.
Kneucker, J. A., Bot. Jahrb. 34: 19-21. 1905 (on his travels to Sinai).
Oberdorfer, E., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a: 216. 1956.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Allgemeine botanische Zeitschrift</em>, editor, 1895-1927, vols. 1-33. –
Published very regularly every month from 1895-1913. The journal is a rich source of
information for European floristics with extensive biographical and bibliographical notices,
data on series of exsiccatae, etc. The journal appeared "pünktlich am 15. jeden Monats" and
for some time played the role played previously by <em>Flora</em>.
(2) <em>Carex</em>, in Seubert &amp; Klein, <em>Excursions flora für das Grossherzogthum Baden</em>, Stuttgart, ed. 5,
1891, and ed. 6, 1905.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kneuckeria</em> Schmidle (1905).

von J. J. Reiff) 1886. Oct. (<em>Führer Fl. Karlsruhe</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1886 (p. v: Apr 1886; Nat. Nov. Jun(1) 1886; J. Bot. Aug 1886; Bot. Zeit. 25 Jun
	1886), p. [i]-v, [1, abbr.], [1]-167. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, HBG.

Knieskern, Peter D. (1798-1871), American botanist and physician; resided in eastern
New Jersey 1841-1871. (<em>Kniesk</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CHRB; further material at B, BR, C, DWC, L, NY, US. –
Knieskern's herbarium changed hands several times after his death but was finally acquired
by H. H. Rusby who presented it to CHRB in 1928; it was in bad condition and much of it
had to be discarded. Part of the material came to NY via Princeton University (inf. D. E.
Fairbrothers).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Torreya 28(3): 66-67. 28 Jun 1928.

591; Tucker 1: 391.

Gray, A., Amer. J. Sci. ser. 3. 2: 388-389. 1871.
