4030. <em>Nomenklatorische Revision höherer Pflanzengruppen</em> und über einige Tausend Korrekturen
zu Englers Phaenogamen-Register [Karlsruhe i. B. (Verlag von J. J. Reiff) 1900]. (<em>Nomenkl.
Revis. höher. Pfl.-Gr.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Tom Erik von Post (1858-1912).
<em>Publ</em>.: Jun-Sep 1900 (for dates in journal see below), p. [1]-39. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted from
	Allg. bot. Z. (ed. A. Kneucker): 1900(6): 110-120. Jun 1910; (7/8): 150-164. Jul/Aug
	1900. (9): 179-191. Sep 1900.

4031. <em>Exposé sur les Congrès pour la Nomenclature botanique</em> et six propositions pour le Congrès de
Paris en 1900. s.l.n.d. [1900]. Oct. (<em>Exposé Congr. Nomencl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 15-31 Aug 1900, p. [1]-15. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, NY – Pamphlet proposing to take up
	nomenclature at a future congress (1905, Vienna) (because the Oct 1900 Paris congrès
	was held to be not representative) and to appoint R. v. Wettstein and J. Wiesner as
	"directors." These proposals were supported by J. Briquet, C. de Candolle, K. Fritsch, L.
	B. Robinson, H. Schinz and T. v. Post. In Sep 1900 Cogniaux, Fünfstück, Leimbach and
	Carl Müller (Berlin) joined the proposers. [fide a separate 1 p. pamphlet by Kuntze, dated
	Aix-la Chapelle, 22 Sep 1900, <em>copy</em>: FAS]. NY has also a preliminary version of this
	pamphlet (in proof), from which it is clear it was originally intended for publication in the
	<em>Mémoires de l'Herbier Boissier</em>.

4032. <em>An dem Landtag des Königsreichs Preussen</em> ... San Remo [Druck von Gessner &amp;
Schramm, Leipzig] 1901. Fol. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1901 (p. [1]: 10 Jan 1901),p. [1-4]. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – A protest against Engler's <em>Pflanzenreich</em>
	and the financing of it by the Prussian government. The Landtag (House of repre-
	sentatives) is requested to strike all subventions because the <em>Pflanzenreich</em> is said to become a
	danger to science.

Kunze, Gustav (1793-1851), German botanist; Dr. med. Leipzig 1819; from 1837-1851
director of the Leipzig botanical garden; professor of botany at Leipzig University (1835);
induced his pupil Willkomm to go to Spain. (<em>Kunze</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LZ; now destroyed; material at H (musci), L, PH, and UPS. – See IH
2: 396.

IH 2: 396; Jackson p. 568 [index]; Kew 3: 336; KR p. 360; Langman p. 422; Lasègue p.
293, 320, 545; LS 14626-14634; ME 2: 346; MW p. 256; NI 1113-1114; PR 4942-4949, (ed.

1248; TL-2/1: 831, 2064; Zander ed. 10, p. 681.
Anon., Bonplandia 1: 33, 240. 1853 2: 267. 1854 (cogn. Battarra); Bot. Not. 1851: 94, 96;

Kurr, Johann Gottlob von (1798-1870), German botanist and pharmacist; Dr. mod.
Tübingen 1832; from 1812-1825 at various pharmacies, from 1832-1870 teacher at the
"Gewerbeschule" at Stuttgart which became the polytechnical school in 1841; collected for
the Esslingen Reiseverein. (<em>Kurr</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Probably at TUB (see Künkele, 1970). Some other material at L and
OXF.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 309; Barnhart 2: 329; BM 2: 1037; Clokie p. 196;

Quenstedt p. 246; Rehder 5: 478.

Künkele, S., Jh. Ges. Naturk. Württemberg 125: 155. 1970.
Lehmann, E., Schwäbische Apotheker 142-143. 1951.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kurria</em> Hochstetter &amp; Steudel (1842). <em>Note: Kurrimia</em> Wallich ex C. F. Meisner
(1837) is dedicated to Kurrim Khan, Indian gardener who worked for forty years in the
Calcutta botanic garden (fide Wallich).

Kurtz, Fritz (Frederico) (1854-1920), German botanist; Dr. phil. Berlin 1879; from 1878-
80 at Berlin-Dahlem under Eichler; to Argentina 1884, professor of botany at Cordoba 1884-
1915. (<em>F. Kurtz</em>).

PAGE: 706
HEADING: KURTZ, F.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CORD (contains much material also from Germany as well as
the herbarium of G. H. Bauer. K's library was also acquired by Cordoba).
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York bot. Gard. 29(3): 353. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 292; Barnhart 2: 329; BL 1: 132, 232, 235, 254,
305; BM 2: 1037; Bossert p. 223; CSP 10: 480, 12: 419, 16: 519; DTS 1: 164, xxi, 6(4): 50;
Frank 3(Anh.): 54; GRp. 102-103; IH2: 397; Jackson p. 393, 424, 510; Kew 3: 339-340; LS
35701; MW p. 257; Quenstedt p. 485; Rehder 5: 478-479; TL-2/1: see Ascherson, P. F. A.;
TR 735; Tucker 1: 404; Zander ed. 10, p. 681.
A. C, Physis 5: 82-84. 1921.

4047. <em>Aufzählung der von K. Graf von Walburg-Zeil im Jahre 1876 in Westsiberien gesammelten
Pflanzen</em>. Botanische Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der philosophischen Doctor-
würde. Mit Genehmigung der philosophischen Facultät der Friedrich-Wilhelms-Univer-
sität zu Berlin zu vertheidigen am 27 März 1879, vormittags 12 Uhr von Fritz Kurtz aus
Berlin ... Berlin 1879. Oct. (<em>Aufzähl. Westsib. Pfl</em>.).

<em>Collector</em>: Karl Graf von Waldburg-Zeil-Trauchburg (1841-1890).
<em>Publ</em>.: 27 Mar 1879 (Nat. Nov. Sep(2) 1879), p. [i], [1]-69, [70, vita], [1, theses]. <em>Copies</em>:
	MO(2).– Reprinted from Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 21: 11-77. 1879. – Harms (1920)
	relates that some copies of this dissertation, sent to friends, had an annotation on p. [70]
	following the "vita": "Während seiner Studienzeit trank der Verfasser ca. 6 (genau 5.930)
	cbm Bier." This amounts to nearly 6.000 liter Bier. We have alas not seen a copy with this
	annotation.
<em>Bericht</em> über die Pflanzen, welche Karl Graf von Waldburg-Zeil im August 1881 am unteren
	Jenissei gesammelt hat, Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 36: 141-149. 9 Mai 1894 (reprint
	later; Nat. Nov. Feb(1) 1895) reprint with original pagination at MO. Collection made
	23-28 Aug 1881 near Karaul (Karauly). [Reprint combined with a paper by Kurtz on
	plants collected by K. Keilhack on Iceland and the Faer-Oern in 1883, ib. 36: 150-158. 9
	Mai 1894].
<em>Ref</em>.: Henglin, Th., Reisen nach dem Nordpolarmeer in den Jahren 1870-71, 3 vols.,
	Braunschweig 1872-1874 (n.v.).
	Finsch, O., Reise nach Westsiberien im Jahre 1876, Berlin 1879 (n.v.).

Labillardière, Jacques Julien Houttou de (1775-1834), French explorer and botanist;
studied medicine at Montpellier; travelled in near East 1786; on expedition to find La
Pérouse 1791-1795; from 1828 at Rouen. (<em>Labill</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Labillardière's herbarium was acquired by Webb (1834) and is now
at FI A nearly complete set of duplicates is also at FI, acquired with the Desfontaines
herbarium. It contains the first set of the plants collected by him on the voyage in search of La
Pérouse. The most important set of duplicates of these collections was acquired by Dclessert
(now G). Labillardière's Syrian collections were originally in the Lemonnier herbarium,
now at G, and the types of the <em>Icones plantarum Syriae rariorum</em> are therefore also at G. The types
of his lichens and algae collected on the Pérouse expedition are in part at PC, but in general
the types from this expedition are at FL
<em>Ref</em>.: Wetmore, Rev. bryol. lichénol. 32: 228. 1963 (Tasman. lich.).
	Koster, J.T., Taxon 18: 554. 1969.
	Miller, H.S., Taxon 19: 528-529. 1970.
	Kukkonen, I., Herb. Chr. Steven 64. 1971 (Syrian coll. dupl. at H).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 354. 1975.
	Apfelbaum, J., Taxon 26(5/6): 541-548. 1977 (Australian material at PH).
	Steinberg, C., Webbia 32(1): 7-8, 11,29. 1977-

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 81; Backer p. 309; Barnhart 2: 331; BM3: 1040; CSP
3: 784-785, 16: 528; Dawson p. 514, 906, 941; Dryander 3: 175, 311, 514, 5: 313; Frank
3(Anh.): 54; GF p. 63; GR p. 282-283; Hortus 3: "97 ("Labill."); HR, IF p. 713; IH 2:
401; Jackson p. 223, 394, 398; Kew 3: 343; Lasègue p. 573; NAF 28B(2): 441; NI 1115-1117;
Plesch p. 294; PR 4962-4965; Rehder 5: 480-481; RS p. 111; Saccardo 1: 93; SBC p. 125
("LaBill."); SK 1: 57-59, 599, 4: clxxi, 8: xiv; ST p. 67-68; TL-2/1: 109; Tucker 1: 405;

4079. <em>Flore élémentaire</em> comprenant toutes les plantes phanérogames croissant spontanément
ou cultivées en grand dans l'arrondissement de Semur avec des clefs analytiques simples et
faciles, permettant de déterminer avec la plus grande précision les espèces les plus communes
des départements de la Côte-d'Or, de l'Yonne, de Seine-et-Marne, de Seine-et-Oise, de la
Seine et de l'Oise. Édition spéciale aux écoles précédée d'un vocabulaire des principaux
termes employés dans l'ouvrage par Henry Lachot ... Chez l'Auteur, à Magny-la-Ville, par
Semur (Côte-d'Or). 1884. Oct. (<em>Fl. élém.</em>).

sûr et facile pour parvenir promptement et sans maître à la détermination de ces plantes

Navarra. (<em>Lacoizq</em>.).

Lacouture, Charles (1832-1908), French botanist; teacher of natural sciences at the
Collège Saint-Clément de Metz until 1872; later at Dijon. (<em>Lacout</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Lacouture had a private herbarium. Duplicates are in the
herbarium of the American Bryological Society (ABSL).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 333; BM 7: 596; Kew 3: 346; SBC p. 125
("Lac.").
Anon., Rev. bryol. 32: 100. 1905, 35: 100, 38: 22. 1911.
Friren, Rev. bryol. 35: 145. 1908.
Haynes, C. C., Bryologist 13: 10. 1910.
Lamy, D., Rev. bryol. lichénol. 42(1): 562-564. 1976.
Schuster, R. M., Hep. Anthoc. N. Amer. 1: 68. 1966.

4085. <em>Hépatiques de la France</em>. Tableaux synoptiques des caractères saillants des tribus, des
genres et des espèces avec plus de 200 figures représentant toutes les espèces de la flore
française. Paris (Paul Klincksieck ...) 1905. Qu. ((i)Hépat. France(/i)).

<em>Publ</em>.: prob. Sep 1905 (Rev. Bryol. Oct 1905), p. [i]-iv, [5]-78, [1, err. slip]. <em>Copies</em>: G,
	Gradstein, PC. – Half-title: <em>Atlas des hépatiques de la France</em>.
<em>Ref</em>.: Haynes, C. C., Bryologist 9(2): 28-29. 3 Mar 1906.

4086. <em>Hépatiques foliées de la France</em> tableaux synoptiques pour faciliter la détermination des
tribus, des genres et des espèces dont 150 figures donnent le croquis. [Dijon 1905, not
Published]. 

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not effectively Published; autograph manuscript of which only a very small number
were written out ("autographié à un très petit nombre d'exemplaires"), distributed with the
statement that the manuscript remained unpublished, preface dated Dijon Apr 1905. Title-
page and note on non-publication printed; other pages "manuscript." <em>Copy</em>: PC. – In view of
the author's statement that the text remained private and not published, it remains not

PAGE: 718
HEADING: LACOUTURE

effectively published (ICBN 29. 1) because the "domaine privé" mentioned in the printed
note does not constitute "distribution to the general public ..." even if the autograph should
prove to be "indelible". We are grateful to Dr. D. Lamy for making copies of the relevant
pages available to us.

4087. <em>Genera hepaticarum</em>. Clé synoptique avec figures de tous les genres connus d'hépatiques
à l'exception des dérivés de l'ancien Lejeunea (Publiés précédemment) et des cinq nouveaux
genres monotypes, Bucegia, Ascidiota, Mesoptychia, Gollaniella et Massalongoa ... Dijon
(Librairie Venot ...) 1910. Qu. (<em>Gen. hepat.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1910 (Nat. Nov. Jan(2) 1911; Rev. Bryol. Jan 1911), p. [1]-46, <em>142 figs. Copies</em>: FH, NY,
	PC (inf. D. Lamy). – For L's treatment of the "ancien Lejeunea" see his <em>Clé analytique</em> ...,
	Rev. bryol. 35(4): 101-114. 1908 (also as reprint, see Rev. Bryol. 35: 100. 1900).
<em>Ref</em>.: Haynes, C. C., Bryologist 14(6): 106-107. 17 Nov 1911.

Lacroix, Louis-Sosthène Veyron de (1818-1864), French clergyman and botanist at
Montmorillon, Saint-Romain-sur-Vienne, ultimately "Aumônier des Petites Soeurs des
Pauvres" at Poitiers. (<em>Lacr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lacroix left a herbarium of the Poitou region upon his death; the
present location is unknown but Sayre (mss) mentions that his bryophytes are at BM
(Schimper herb.). Some further material is at MW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 3: 1043; GR p. – 332; IH 2: 402; NAF 7(15): 1074; PR
4974; Rehder 5: 482; SBC p. 125 ("Lacr."); Stevenson p. 1248.
Anon., Actes Soc. Linn. Bordeaux 25: 652. 1864; Bull. Soc. bot. Deux-Sèvres 18: <em>pl. 3.</em> 1907;
	Bull. Soc. bot. France 12: vii. 1865; Österr. bot. Z. 15: 90. 1865; Bot. Zeit. 23: 12. 6 Jan
	1865; Flora 48: 60. 17 Feb 1865.
Chaboisseau, Bull. Soc. bot. France 12: 5-6. 1865.

4088. <em>Nouveaux faits constatés relativement à l'histoire de la botanique</em> et à la distribution géo-
graphique des plantes de la Vienne ... Caen (Typ. de A. Hardel, ...) 1857. Qu. (<em>Nouv.
faits</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1857, p. [i], [1]-32. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – Reprinted from Mém. Inst. des Provinces (journal
	publ. n.v.). Intended to supplement Delastre, <em>Flore de la Vienne</em>.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bul. Soc. bot. France 5: 184. Jul-Dec 1858.

Laestadius, Lars Levi (1800-1861), Swedish clergyman and botanist; born in Arjepluog
(Lapland); clergyman at Karesuando (1825-1848) and Pajala (Norrbotten) (1848-1861);
pupil of Wahlenberg. (<em>Laest</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: JYV, H and S; duplicates, B, BM, C, E, FI, G, L, P, SBT, UPS.

Lagasca y Segura [La Gasca], Mariano (1776-1839), Spanish botanist at the Madrid
botanical garden; in exile to England 1822; in Jersey 1831-1834; back to Spain 1834-1839.
(<em>Lag</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: original herbarium destroyed during his flight from Madrid to
Gibraltar (1822). Some material at MA, but also in BR, BM, C, FI, G, LD, MEXU. Types
probably mainly at MA and FI. Exsiccatae: <em>Hortus siccus londinensis</em>; or a collection of dried
specimens of plants, growing wild within twenty miles round London, named on the
authority of the Banksian herbarium, and other original collections, – four fascicles with
accompanying text: 1, Dec 1827, 25 specimens; 2, early 1827, 25 specimens; 3, early April
1827, 30 specimens; 4, Jul-Dec 1827, 40 specimens (81-110, and Suppl. 111-120). No new
species are described. Sets at MICH (1-4), and OXF (1-3). McVaugh (1968) reports the
existence of a further two complete copies in Mexico City.
<em>Ref</em>.: Druce G. C., and Britten J., J. Bot. [London] 46: 163-170. 1908.
	McVaugh, R., Mich. Botanist 7: 11-13. 1968 (<em>Hort. sicc. Lond.</em>).
	Bellot and Casaseca, Lagascalia 5(1): 15-26. 1975 (type species at MA).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 164, 5(2): 2; Backer p. 311; Barnhart 2: 334; BB p.
179; BM 3: 1044; Clokie p. 196; Colmeiro 1: clxxxii-clxxxiii; CSP 3: 801-802; Desmond p.
367; Frank 3 (Anh.): 54; GR p. 761; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lag"); IF p. 713; Jackson p. 446; Kew
3: 347; Langman p. 424; Lasègue p. 348; LS 14730; MW p. 260; NAF 28B(2): 441, ser. 2. 2:
163, 5: 245; PR 4982-4988; Rehder 5: 482; SBC p. 125 ("Lag."); TL-2/1: 1066; Tucker 1:
407; Zander ed. 10, p. 682.
Alvarez Lopez, Anal. Inst. bot. Cavanilles 18: 9-13, 37. 1960 (portr.).
Anon., Flora 2: 63. 1819, 24: 176. 1841; Proc. Linn. Soc. 1: 71-72. 1840 (1849).
Bellot Rodriguez, F., Lagascalia 6(2): 203-208. 1976 ("Lagasca como politico").
Bellot Rodriguez, F. et al., Simposio conmerativo del centenario de Lagasca, Sevilla 1976:
	47. (abstract only; fide Kew Rec.).
Britten, J., J. Bot. 46: 169-170. 1908.
Britten, J., and Jackson, B. D., J. Bot. 62: 355-358. 1924 ("347"-"350") (Lagasca in
	England).
Bulguerias, Anal. Inst. Bot. Cavanilles 10(1): 119-127. 1951 (letter to Bardají, 1808).
Candolle, A. P. de, Mém. souvenirs 216, 218-219. 1867.
Carrasco, Lagascalia 6(2): 219-221. 1976 (two species).
Carreno, Ann. Sci. nat. ser. 2. 14: 146-161. 1840.
Casaseca, Lagascalia 6(2): 191-201. 1976 (life).
Colmeiro, M., La botánica y los botanicos de la peninsula hispano-lusitana 191-195. 1858.
Constance et al., Rev. Biol. trop. 23: 137-153. 1975 (letter by L. to de Candolle).
Dawson, W. R., Smith papers 62. 1934 (letter to J. E. Smith).
Fernandez-Galiano y Valdes, Lagascalia 6: 179-189. 1976.
Hooker, W. J., Bot. Misc. 1: 64. 1829.

HEADING: LAGASCA

Espana, <em>Anal. Ci. nat. Madrid</em>, 5(14): 135-215. Aug 1802 (see e.g. SY p. 12).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (genera): <em>Lagasca</em> Cavanilles (1803, <em>orth. rej.</em>); <em>Lagascea</em> Cavanilles; corr. Will-
denow (1809, <em>orth. et nom. cons.</em>); (journal): <em>Lagascalia</em>. Sevilla. Vol. 1-x. 1971-x.

4096. <em>Amenidades naturales de las Españas</em>: o bien disertaciones varias sobre las producciones
naturales espontaneas, ó conaturalizades en los dominios españoles ... Orihuela. (En la
Imprenta de la Muy Ilustre Junta) Año de 1811 [numero segundo 1821]. Qu. (<em>Amen. nat.
Españ.</em>)

<em>1</em> (<em>1</em>): 1811 (pref. 19 Apr 1811), p. [i]-xi, [1]-44.
<em>1</em> (<em>2</em>): 1821 (p. 60: 15 Jul 1821), p. [45]-111. – <em>Imprint</em>: Madrid (por Ibarra, Impresor de
	cámara de S.M.) 1821.
<em>Copies</em>: G, MO (part 1), NY, P, USDA; IDC 5999.

4097. <em>Elenchus plantarum</em>, quae in horto regio botanico matritensi colebantur anno mdcccxv.
Cum novarum, aut minus cognitarum stirpium diagnosi, nonnullarumque descriptionibus
contractis. Matriti [Madrid] (ex typographia Regia) 1816. Qu. (<em>Elench. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun-Dec 1816 (prob. Jun-Jul; in a letter from Lagasca to A. P. de Candolle (G), dated
	pridie kal. Junii [31 Mai] 1816; the former states that the work is being printed
	[information R. McVaugh]; p. [v] dated kalendis Aprilis 1816). – The <em>Elenchus</em> consists of
	unnumbered pages [i-viii] containing title-page and preface, and p. [1]-20 containing the
	<em>Elenchus</em> itself followed by 35 pages (printed as [[1]]-[35]) containing the <em>Generum specierum-
	que plantarum novarum aut minus cognitarum diagnoses</em>. This text was also issued separately (PR
	4985) under the title: <em>Genera et species plantarum, quae aut novae sunt, aut nondum recte
	cognoscuntur</em>. Madrid 1816. Qu. with two plates [lacking from the <em>Elenchus</em>], a separate title-
	page and introduction "Lectori" and "Notarum explicatio". This separate edition (also
	with preface dated kal. Apr. 1816) can be assumed to have been published almost
	simultaneously with the Elenchus. (see 4098). <em>Copies</em>: G, McYaugh, NY, IDC 6000.

4098. <em>Genera et species plantarum</em>, quae aut novae sunt aut nondum recte cognoscuntur ...
Matriti [Madrid] (ex typographia regia) 1816. Qu. (<em>Gen. sp. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun-Dec 1816 (see no. 4097), p. [i-vii], [1]-35, <em>2 pl</em>. (uncol. copper engr. by A. D.
	Meneses). <em>Copies</em>: L, M, MO, NY, U, USDA; IDC 6000.

4099. <em>Memoria sobre las plantas Barrilleras</em> de España: por D. Mariano La Gasca ... Madrid
(en la Imprenta Real) 1817. Qu. (<em>Mem. pl. Barrill.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1817, p. [i-x], [1]-84, [1, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, L.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 2: 14. 7 Jan 1819.

4100. <em>Observaciones sobre la familia natural de las plantas aparasoladas</em>, (Umbelliferae.) ...
Londres [London] Año de 1826. Qu. (<em>Observ. pl. aparasol.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1826, p. [i], [1]-43. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY (photocopy). – Reprinted from the London

Laing, Robert Malcolm (1865-1941), New Zealand botanist; M. A. Canterbury, N.Z.
1889; master at Otago Boy's High School 1886-1924; specialist on New Zealand marine
algae. (<em>Laing</em>).

Lakowitz, Conrad Waldemar (1859-1945), German algologist, palaeobotanist, and high
school teacher at the royal gymnasium at Danzig (now Gdansk); educated at Breslau
university (Dr. phil. 1881). (<em>Lakow</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material (algae) at KIEL and L. The original collections most
likely destroyed with the other collections at Danzig during World War II.

Wood, R. D., Monogr. Charac. 1: 821. 1965.

La Llave, Pablo de (1773-1833), Mexican clergyman; for some time director of the Madrid
botanical garden; member of the Cortes 1812; back to Mexico 1823; minister of justice 1823-
1825; president of the Senate 1830. (<em>La Llave</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mexican material at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 393; BM 3: 1159; Colmeiro 1: clxxxiii; Enc.
univ. 29: 354; GR p. 758; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Llave"); IH 2: 405; Jackson p. 138; Kew 3: 351;
Langman p. 425; PR 5000; RS p. 111 Tucker 1: 407; Zander ed. 10, p. 686.
Colmeiro, M., Bot. bot. peninsula hisp.-lus. 201. 1858.
Miller, Taxon 19: 529. 1970.
Sosa, La Naturaleza 7: 79-81. 1887.
Standley, P. C., Trees and shrubs of Mexico 788. 1923.

<sm>NOTES</sm>: La Llave signed himself "Pablo dela Llave" on the copy of the <em>Nov. veg. descr.</em> sent by
him to von Martius (NY); it is probably more correct to list the author as "Llave, P. de la." –
La Llave dedicated several new genera of plants to the heroes of the Mexican war of
independence.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Llavea</em> Lagasca (1816); <em>Llavea</em> Liebmann (1854).

Joannis Lexarza Reip. Mexic. civ ... Méxici (Apud Martínum Riveram) 1824-1825, 2
parts. Fol. (<em>Nov. veg. descr.</em>).

<em>Fasc. 1</em>: 1824, p. [i-viii], [1]-32.

<em>Copies</em>: MICH, NY, Regensburg, US; IDC 6001.

Lam, Herman Johannes (1892-1977), Dutch botanist; Ph. D. Utrecht 1917; at Buiten-
zorg (Bogor), Indonesia (1919-1933), professor of botany and director of the Rijksherbarium
Leiden (1933-1962) (<em>H. J. Lam</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BO and L; for further collections and references see IH and SK.

PAGE: 730
HEADING: LAMARCK

Lamarck, Jean Baptiste Antoine Pierre Monnet de (1744-1829), French biologist;
founder of the theory of evolution; 1761-1768 in French army; 1768-1778 bank employee in
Paris; 1778-1793 botanist at the Jardin des Plantes; 1793-1829 professor of zoology at the
Museum d'histoire naturelle (<em>Lam</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: at P, kept as an <em>herbier historique</em> (P-LA, on microfiche IDC no. 6207).
Lamarck sold his herbarium to J. A. C. Roeper in 1824 who took it to Basel and Rostock. It
was acquired by the University of Rostock in 1875 and offered to P at Fr. 12.000 by Goebel
who needed the money to buy laboratory equipment. (Goebel had first offered the collection
to Kew but received too low a bid. He then approached Paris; the herbarium was received at
Paris 17 Jan 1887). The collection consists of ca. 19.000 specimens. Lamarck's types are
partly in his own herbarium, but, since he worked also with other collections, partly also in
other herbaria, most of which are now at P and PC (e.g. in P-JU). Insofar as Lamarck based
his descriptions of new species on material owned by L'Héritier or Lemonnier, his types are
at G, Desfontaines in FI, etc. The types of Lamarck and de Candolle's <em>Flore française</em> ed. 3 are
in part at G. Lamarck material is furthermore present at B-W, C, FI and G.
<em>Ref</em>.: Bureau, C. R., Acad. Sci. Paris 104: 187-190. 1887.
	Bonnet, J. Bot. [Morot] 16: 129-138. 1902.
	Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel 37, 57. 1941 (original letters concerning sale).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 572; Andrews p. 293; Backer p. 312; Barnhart 2:
337; BM 3: 1048-1049; Bossert p. 225; Bret. p. 125; Colmeiro 1: clxxxiii; CSP 3: 809-810, 12:
423; Dawson p. 518-519, 942; Dryander 5: 314-315; DSB 7: 584-594; Frank 3(Anh.): 54-55;
GR p. 284-285, <em>pl</em>. [<em>30</em>]; Henry 2: 177; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lam."); HU clxxv, 653; IF p. 714;
IH 2: 406; Jackson p. 12, 114, 115, 273; Kew 3: 353; Langman p. 425-426; Lasègue p. 575;
LS 14811-14813, 35759-35762; Moebius p. 452; MW p. 260; NAF 9(6): 440, 28B(2): 441-
442; NI 2224; PFC 1: xxxviii; Plesch p. 295; PR 5002-5507; Quenstedt p. 248-249; Rehder
5: 484; RS p. 111-112; SBC p. 125 ("Lam."); SK p. 309; SO 125, 165, 166, 747, 1230; TL-
2/1: 987, 988, see index; Tucker 1: 407-408; Urban-Berl. p. 367; Zander ed. 10, p. 682.
Allan, M., The Hookers of Kew 67-68, 193-194. 1967.
Anon., Flora 13: 64. 1830, 16: 369-378. 1833.

Bornet, A., Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France, Paris
	1914,. 125-127, 266.

	année 1896).

Daudin, H., Cuvier et Lamarck, Les classes zoologiques et l'idée de série animale. Paris 1926.
Dawson, W. R., Smith papers 62. 1934 (letter to J. E. Smith).

Giard, Bull. sci. France Belgique 40: 443-595. 1906 (discours d'ouverture).

	Dict. nat. 10: 441-468. 1817 (article "espèce", basic definition of biological species):

	(portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) see TL 2/1: 987 and 988.
(2) Lamarck was one of the editors of the <em>Journal d'histoire naturelle</em>, Paris (les Directeurs de
l'Imprimerie du Circle Social), 2 vols. 1792. (see e.g. MacPhail, I., Cat. Redout. 38. 1963).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Arch. de Bot., Guillemin, 2: opp. p. 94. 1833; Candollea 31: 151-152. 1976.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lamarckia</em> G. Olivi (1792, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Lamarckia</em> Moench (1794); corr. Koeler (1802,
<em>nom. et orth. cons.</em>); <em>Lamarkia</em> [sic] Medicus (1788, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Lamarkia</em> Moench (1794, <em>orth. rej.</em>);
<em>Markea</em> L. C. Richard (1792; with the following <em>orth. vars.</em> and substitute names: <em>Marckea</em> A.
Richard (1826); <em>Marckia</em> Post &amp; O. Kuntze (1903); <em>Lamarkia</em> G. Don (1838); <em>Lamarckea</em>
Steudel (1840); <em>Lamarckia</em> Vahl (1810); <em>Lamarkea</em> Persoon (1805)); <em>Monetia</em> [sic] L'Héritier
de Brutelle (1785).

4135. <em>Flore françoise</em> ou description succincte de toutes les plantes qui croissent naturellement
en France, disposée selon une nouvelle méthode d'analyse, &amp; à laquelle on a joint la citation
de leurs vertus les moins équivoques en médecine, &amp; de leur utilité dans les arts ... À Paris
(de l'Imprimerie Royale) 1778, 3 vols. Oct. (<em>Fl. franç.</em>)

<em>Ed. 1</em>: all three volumes <em>after</em> 21 Mar 1779 (privilège 10 Mar 1779, see vol. 1 p. (4)). <em>Copies</em>:
	G(2), MICH, MO, NY, U, US(2), USDA.
	<em>1</em>: [i-ii], (1)-(4), i-cxix, [1]-223, [(1)]-(132), i-xxix, <em>pl. i-viii</em>, uncoloured copper engr.
	<em>2</em>: [i*-ii*], i-iv, chart, [(1)]-(684).
	<em>3</em>: [i-ii], [(1)]-654, i-xx, [1, err.].
	Internal evidence (e.g. p. 648, citation of <em>Laserpitium hirsutum</em>) suggests that Villars'
	<em>Prospectus</em> antedates the <em>Fl. franç.</em> (inf. W. Gutermann).

HEADING: LAMARCK

<em>Ed. 2</em>: Paris (Chez H. Agasse), all three volumes publ. 1795 (l'an 3e. de la République), an
	almost word by word reprint. <em>Copies</em>: G, US(2), USDA.
	<em>1</em>: p. [i*], [(1)]-(4), [i]-cxix, [1]-(223), [(1)]-[159], <em>pl. 1-8</em>, uncol copper engr.
	<em>2</em>: p. [i*-ii*], [i]-iv, tabl., [(1)]-(684).
	<em>3</em>: p. [i-ii], [(1)]-(674), [1, err.]
<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1805-1815, see under A. P. de Candolle, no. 987.

	Breistoffer, M., Proc.-Verb. Soc. Dauph. Ethnol. Archéol. 23/24, n. 179-181 (1947-1948).
	Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 20: 404-408. 1971.

4136. <em>Encyclopédie méthodique. Botanique</em> ... A Paris (Chez Panckoucke, ...), Liège (Chez
Plomteux, ...) 1783-1817, 13 vols. Qu. (<em>Encycl</em>.)

<em>Co-author</em>: Jean Louis Marie Poiret (1755-1834).
<em>Collaborators</em>: Augustin Pyramus de Candolle (1778-1841), Louis Auguste Joseph Desrous-
	seaux (1753-1838), Marie Jules César Lelorgne de Savigny (1777-1851).
<em>Publ</em>.: Volumes 1 and 2 are by Lamarck; vol. 3 up till P is also by Lamarck, the rest of the
	volume is by Lamarck and Desrousseaux; vol. 4 is by Desrousseaux, Poiret and Savigny;
	vol. 5 by Poiret and (a few texts) A. P. de Candolle; vols. 6, 7, 8 and suppl 1-5 are all by
	Poiret. New taxa in this work should be attributed always to only one of the authors.

4137. <em>Tableau encyclopédique et méthodique</em> des trois règnes de la nature. <em>Botanique</em> ... Paris
(Chez Pancoucke, ...) 1791-1823, 3 Tomes (6 volumes). Qu. (<em>Tabl. encycl.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Jean Louis Marie Poiret (1755-1834).
<em>Publ</em>.: Vols. 1-5(1) are by Lamarck, vol. 5(2) and tome 3 are by Poiret. The book is often cited
	as "<em>Illustration des genres</em>" a sub-title occuring on the introductory page of vol. 1, and the
	title-page of tome 3.

tome	vol.	part	pages	plates	dates
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1	1	1	1-200	1-100	3 Mar 1791
		2	201-352	101-200	13 Feb 1792

		2	441-496	301-400	11 Feb 1793

<em>Tome 3</em>: [i], [1]-523, suppl [527]-728, Paris (Chez Mme Ve Agasse, ...) 1823.
<em>Reissue of plates</em>: The plates were reissued 1823 (or later) with 4 special title-pages: "Recueil
	de planches de botanique de l'Encyclopédie. Première partie. Planche 1 à 250 [deuxième
	... 251 à 500, troisième ... 501 à 750; quatrième 751 à 1000] À Paris (Chez Mme veuve
	Agasse, ...)" 1823. The plates are copper engravings of drawings by Audebert, Fossier,
	de Sève, Poiret fils and H.-J. Redouté. The originals were acquired by the Paris Muséum
	d'Histoire naturelle in 1909.

	Gleason, H. A., Phytologia 2: 292. 1947 (fasc. 60).
	Breistroffer, M., Proc. Verb. mens. Soc. Dauph. Ethn. Arch. 23 (nos. 182-184) Mar-Mai
	1948.

4139. <em>Hydrogeologie</em> ou recherches sur l'influence qu'ont les eaux sur la surface du globe
terrestre; sur les causes de l'existence du bassin des mers, de son déplacement et de son
transport successif sur les différens points de la surface de ce globe; enfin sur les changemens
que les corps vivans exercent sur la nature et l'état de cette surface. Paris (chez l'auteur ...
Agasse ... Maillard ...) An x [1802]. Oct. (<em>Hydrogéologie</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1802, p. (1)-268. <em>Copies</em>: Kon. Bibl., Brussel.
<em>English translation</em>: Hydrogeology, by J. B. Lamarck, translated by Albert V. Carozzi,
	Urbana (University of Illinois Press) 1964, [i]-[viii], (1)-152, with editor's introduction on
	p. 1-11. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
<em>Ref</em>: Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 20: 402-403. 1971.

4140. <em>Histoire naturelle des végétaux, classés par familles</em>, avec la citation de la classe et de l'ordre
de Linné, et l'indication de l'usage que l'on peut faire des plantes dans les arts, le commerce,
l'agriculture, le jardinage, la médecine, etc. des figures dessinées d'après nature, et un genera
complet, selon le systême de Linné, avec des renvois aux families naturelles de A. L. de
Jussieu. Paris (de l'Imprimerie de Crapelet ... chez Deterville) An XI-1803, 15 vols. 18-mo. (<em>Hist. nat. vég.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Charles François Brisseau de Mirbel (1776-1854).
<em>Publ</em>.: Entire work recorded as published on 21 Nov 1802 (JT) although the title-pages of all
	volumes have "An XI-1803". It is unlikely that at the time of the announcement of the
	work in the Journal typographique all 15 volumes were indeed available. Volumes 10, 11
	and 12, for instance, are reviewed (as just published) in the Journ. phys. chim. hist. nat.
	61: 77-78 (Jun-Jul 1805); 13 and 14 ibid. pp. 315-316 (Sep-Oct 1805). On the other hand
	the Botanische Zeitung (Regensburg) of 28 Mar 1803 reviews all 15 volumes even though
	only very briefly. Issues (fide JT): I. Papier carré fin d'Angoulême, plates uncoloured, 2.
	papier idem, plates coloured, 3. papier vélin, plates uncoloured, 4. papier vélin, plates
	coloured. – Belongs to the <em>Suites à Buffon</em> accompanying the 18mo edition of Buffon, <em>Histoire
	naturelle classée</em> d'après le systême de Linné ... par R. R. Castel, 80 vols., Paris 1801-1803.
	A "nouvelle édition" of the <em>Histoire naturelle des végétaux</em> of this edition was published in
	Paris, 1825. – The text of volumes 1 and 2 is by Lamarck, that of vols. 3-15 by Mirbel.
<em>Copies</em>: B (uncol.), BR (numbers of plates as in list below; col.).

<em>1</em>: [i]-xvi, [1]-324 <em>9</em>: [i-iii], [1]-338, <em>8 pl</em>.
<em>2</em>: [i-iii], [1]-335 <em>10</em>: [i-iii], [1]-740, <em>7 pl</em>.
<em>3</em>: [i-iii], [1]-588 <em>11</em>: [i-iii], [1]-326, <em>6 pl</em>.
<em>4</em>: [i-iii], [1]-317, <em>15 pl</em>. <em>12</em>: [i-iii], [1]-326, <em>20 pl</em>.
<em>5</em>: [i-iii], [1]-332, <em>10 pl</em>. <em>13</em>: [i-iii], [1]-323, <em>13 pl</em>.
<em>6</em>: [i-iii], [1]-317, <em>12 pl</em>. <em>14</em>: [i-iii], [1]-285, <em>6 pl</em>.
<em>7</em>: [i-iii], [1]-328, <em>10 pl</em>. <em>15</em>: [i-iii], [1]-325, <em>2 pl</em>.
<em>8</em>: [i-iii], [1]-328, <em>10 pl</em>.

The numbers of plates in the B copy are <em>10</em> (in vol. 4), <em>9</em>(5), <em>10</em>(6), <em>9</em>(7), <em>10</em>(8), <em>7</em>(9), <em>6</em>(10),
<em>6</em>(11),<em>21</em>(12), <em>7</em>(13), <em>7</em>(14), <em>1</em>(15).

4141. <em>Philosophie zoologique</em>, ou exposition des considérations relatives à l'histoire naturelle
des animaux; à la diversité de leur organisation et des facultés qu'ils en obtiennent; aux
causes physiques qui maintiennent en eux la vie et donnent lieu aux mouvements qu'ils
exécutent; enfin, à celles qui produisent, les unes le sentiment, et les autres l'intelligence de
ceux qui en sont doués. Paris 1809. Oct. (<em>Philos. zool.</em>)

<em>Publ</em>.: 14 Aug 1809 (presented to Académie), [1:] p. [i*, iii*], [i]-xxv, [1]-42, [2:] [1], [1]-
	475. For translations and later editions see the Lamarck bibliographies, cited above.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Weinheim (J. Cramer) 1960. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
<em>Ref</em>.: Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 20: 420-434. 1971.

4142. <em>Système analitique des connaissances positives de l'homme</em>, restreintes à celles qui proviennent
directement ou indirectement de l'observation. Paris (Germer Baillière) 1830. Oct. (<em>Syst.
anal.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1830, p. [i, iii], [1]-362. <em>Copy</em>: Kon. Bibl. 's Gravenhage. – Lamarck's main theoretical
	work of his later years.
<em>Ref</em>.: Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 20: 434-435. 1971.

PAGE: 735
HEADING: LAMBERT, A. B.

Lamb, Ivan Mackenzie, later Elke Mackenzie (1911-x), British botanist; at the British
Museum 1935-1943; in 1947 in Argentina; 1950 in Canada; 1953-1974 director of the
Farlow Herbarium at Cambridge, Mass. (<em>Lamb</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, FH, CAN, LIL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 225; GR p. 375, <em>pl</em>. [<em>33</em>] (portr.), cat. p. 66; IH
1(ed. 6): 361, 2: 406; Kew 3: 354; Roon p. 66; SBC p. 125 ("Lamb").
Anon., Taxon 3: 92-93. 1954 (becomes curator of FH).
Hawksworth, D. L. &amp; M. R. D. Seaward, Lichenology Brit. Isles 1568-1975. 31, 106-107.
	198. 1977.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lambia</em> R. Delépine (1967). <em>Note</em>: <em>Lamblia</em> R. Blanchard (1886) is dedicated to
Vilém Dušan Fedorovic Lambl (1824-1895), Czech physician.

4143. <em>Index nominum lichenum</em> inter annos 1932 et 1960 divulgatorum. New York (The
Ronald Press Company) [1963]. Oct. (<em>Ind. nom. lich.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>: 1963, p. [i]-xi, [1, h.t.], 1-809. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U. – Continuation of Zahlbruckner,
	<em>Catalogus lichenum universalis</em> (1860-1938).

Lambert, Aylmer Bourke (1761-1842), British botanist; studied at St. Mary Hall,
Oxford; visited Ireland 1798; gentleman of leisure; assembled an important herbarium and
library. (<em>Lamb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lambert's herbarium was sold after his death. The annotated sales
catalogues at K and BM provide sometimes a key to the places where the various parts are
now preserved. A detailed study of the herbarium and its dispersal was made by H. P. Miller.
Considerable parts were acquired by BM such as important portions of the herbaria or
collections of Pallas, Ruiz and Pavon, George Forster, Buchanan Hamilton, Martin (French
Guiana). Delessert (now at G) also acquired a substantial part of the herbarium. Lambert's
correspondence with Hooker and others is at K.
<em>Ref</em>.: Lambert, A. B., Catalogue of the valuable botanical library (689 numbers) of the late
	... sold by auction ... by Mr. Leigh Sotheby ... April 18th 1842; 42 p.; Catalogue of
	the highly valuable botanical museum (321 numbers) of the late ... sold by auction
	... by Mr. Leigh Sotheby ... June 27th 1842, 16 p.
	Miller, H. S., Taxon 19: 489-553. 1970 (main study).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 312; Barnhart 2: 338; BB p. 179; BM 3: 1050;
Bossert p. 225; Bret. p. 205; Clokie p. 196; CSP 3: 812-1813; Dawson p. 519-520, 942;
Desmond p. 368; DNB 32: 6; Dryander 3: 651, 5: 20, 83, 315; Frank 3(Anh.) : 55; GF p. 64;
Henrey 2: 725, 3: 68-69; Hist. Coll. 40, 161; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lamb."); HK; IH 2: 406-407;
Jackson p. 569 [index]; Kew 3: 355; Langman p. 426; Lasègue p. 573; Lenley p. 255; LS
14815a; MW p. 260-261; NI 1122-1128; PR 5009-5012 (ed. 1: 5507-5512); Rehder 2: 12, 5:
484; RS p. 112; SK p. 310; TL-2/1: 141, 2087; Tucker 1: 408-409; Zander ed. 10, p. 682.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1842: 209; Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1891: 326-327; Proc. Linn. Soc. London 1:
	137-139. 1842 (1849) (obit.), 1888-1890: 37. 1891 (on portr. by Russell at LINN).
Bohn, H. G., in Gordon, G., Pinetum ed. 3. 1880 (reference list to Lambert's plates of <em>Pinus</em>).
Britten, J., J. Bot. 43: 219. 1905 (on Lambert in Ireland).
Burkill, I. H., Chapters hist. bot. India 15, 24, 25, 26, 27, 78. 1965.
Candolle, A. P. de, Mém. Souvenirs 269. 1862.
Darlington, W., Reliq. Baldw. 196, 197, 235, 236, 239, 242, 244, 246, 316. 1843.
Dawson, W. R., Smith papers 62-64. 1934 (list of letters to J. E. Smith with details).
Ewan, J., Proc. Amer. philos. Soc. 96(5): 616-617. 1952; Short hist. bot. U.S. 8, 38. 1969.
Graustein, J. E., Thomas Nuttall 469-470. 1967.

	Smith, <em>English botany</em>, and Turner and Dillwyn, <em>Botanist's Guide</em>).

HEADING: LAMBERT, A. B.

Little, E. L., Madroño 10: 46-47. 1949.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Edited: F. T. Pursh, <em>Flora americae septentrionalis</em>, London 1814, 2 vols.,

associates.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Taxon 19: 492. 1970.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Aylmeria</em> C. F. P. Martius (1826); <em>Lambertia</em> J. E. Smith (1798). <em>Note</em>: <em>Lambertella</em> F.
von Höhnel (1918) is dedicated to Rev. P. Lambert Gelbenegger (<em>fl</em>. 1917), Austrian
botanist. <em>Lambertia</em> O. Korshikov (1953) is dedicated to Fred Dayton Lambert (1871-1931),
American botanist.

4144. <em>A description of the genus Cinchona</em>, comprehending the various species of vegetables from
which the Peruvian and other barks of a similar quality are taken. Illustrated by figures of all
the species hitherto discovered. To which is prefixed professor Vahl's dissertation on this
genus, ... also a description, accompanied by figures of a new genus named Hyaenanche: or
Hyaena poison. London (printed for B. and J. White, ...) 1797. Qu. (<em>Descr. Cinchona</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Martin Vahl (1749-1804).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1797 (Monthly Rev., London Dec 1798), p. [i*], [i]-[x], [1]-54, [1, list.], <em>pl. 1-13</em> of
	which nos. <em>4, 5, 7-12</em> by Ferd. Bauer. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY, USDA.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten, J., J. Bot. 47: 426-429. 1909 (plates by Hawkins).

4145. <em>A description of the genus Pinus</em>, illustrated with figures, directions relative to the
cultivation, and remarks on the uses of the several species ... London (printed for J. White,
...) 1803-1824, 2 vols. Fol. (<em>Descr. Pinus</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1803 (t.p.; 1803-1807, see below), p. [i*-iv*], [i]-ii, [iii-v], [1]-98, <em>pl. 1-21, 21</em> [<em>bis</em>], <em>22-34,
	34bis, 35-37, 37bis, 38, 38bis, 39, 40</em> (as "lx"), <em>41-43. Author</em>: Lambert.
<em>2</em>: 1824, p. [i]-vi, [1]-26, 27*-34*, [27]-40, 40*, 41-42 [43-45], <em>pl. 1-6, 8-12. Author of volume</em>:
	David Don (1799-1841).
<em>Copies</em>: G, NY (col. pl.). – Volume 1 was issued in Sep 1803 (plain copies available in
	September; coloured copies later; the Monthly Review mentions them only in Nov 1804).
	The appendix was issued in two parts: the first in 1806 and the last (one sheet) in 1807. The
	appendix was presented to the Paris Academy on 27 Oct 1806, and the last sheet "feuille
	servant de continuation à l'appendice" on 21 Dec 1807. Volume 2 was issued in 1824.

vol.	pages	plates	dates
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1	[i*-iv*], [i]-ii, [1]-86	1-38, 21 bis, 34bis	Sep 1803
		37 bis, 38bis
app.	87-94	39-43	1806 (before 27 Oct)
	95-98		1807
2	vi, 1-42, [43-45]	1-6, 8-12	1824
	27*-34*, 40*	[+ Pinus deodora?]

The contents of the copies vary; Renkema (1928 pp. 20-21) gives a summary of the complete
contents. – A few copies were coloured by W. Hooker.

PAGE: 737
HEADING: LAMBERT, A. B.

[<em>Ed. 2</em>:] <em>Edition 1828-1837</em>: 3 volumes, "<em>A description ... several species</em>: also descriptions of
	many other trees of the family of Coniferae, by Aylmer Bourke Lambert, ... to which is
	added an appendix containing descriptions and figures of some other remarkable plants
	and an account of the Lambertian herbarium, by Mr. David Don, ... Second edition. In
	two volumes." London (Messrs Weddell, ...) 1828. Broadsheet or Fol., 3 vols. London
	(H. Weddell, ...) 1837. Fol.

	<em>1</em>: 1828, portr. Lambert, [i]-vi, [1]-58, <em>pl</em>. [<em>Pinus Lamb</em>.], [<em>1</em>], [<em>1 bis</em>], <em>2-4</em>, [<em>5-6</em>], <em>7-14</em>, [<em>14bis</em>],
	<em>15-23</em>, [<em>24</em>]-<em>25</em>, [<em>26</em>],<em>27-33</em>, [<em>34</em>], <em>35</em>, [<em>35bis</em>]-<em>36</em> (in copy US; other copies may have: [1]-
	62, <em>pl. 1-38</em>; see Renkema for minor variations).
	<em>2</em>: 1828, p. [i], 59-124, <em>pl. 37-41</em>, [<em>42, 42bis</em>], <em>43-44</em>, [<em>44bis, 44ter</em>.],<em>45</em>, [<em>45bis, 46, 46bis, 46ter</em>.],
	<em>47</em>, [<em>47bis, 48</em>], <em>49</em>, [<em>49bis</em>], <em>50</em> [<em>5obis</em>], <em>51</em>, appendix [1]-8, 7*-8*, 7**-8**, 9-30, [32-35],
	<em>pl. 1</em>, [<em>2, 3, 4, 5</em>] <em>6</em>, [<em>7, 8</em>].
	<em>3</em>: 1837, p. [1-65], <em>pl</em>. [<em>52-80 or 1-17, 17a, 18-28</em>].

<em>Copies</em>: BR, MO, NY, US (composition as above).
<em>Plates</em>: Hand-coloured copper engravings. Due to differences in binding the unnumbered
	plates show up at different places.
<em>Variation</em>: All copies show differences. NY has e.g. the t.p. for vol. 3, the iii changed to ii,
	prefacing vol. 2. Vol. 2 was printed by J. Haddon, vol. 3 by George White.

[<em>Ed. 4</em>] <em>1837-1842 edition</em>, folio, a reprint of the 1828-1837 edition. See Henrey 924, Renkema
	and NI for further details (no copy seen).

<em>Octavo editions</em>: [3, 5]: see 4146.
<em>Note</em>: In view of the extensive studies by Renkema, Ardagh and Little we refrain from citing
	all variations, both of the folio and the octavo editions. See below under no. 4146 for these
	and other references.

4146. <em>A description of the genus Pinus</em>, with directions relative to the cultivation, and remarks
on the uses of the several species; also descriptions of many other new species of the family of
Coniferae. Illustrated with figures. London (Messrs. Weddell) 1832, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Descr.
Pinus</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1832, p. [1]-viii, [1]-76, <em>pl. 1-43</em>, numbered in text, <em>2</em> unnumbered, (extra plates: frontisp.,
	<em>1a</em> and <em>12</em>*).
<em>2</em>: 1832, p. [i], [77]-183, [1-12, misc.], <em>pl. 44-69, 79-80</em>, extra plates <em>52a, 56a, b, 65a, 66a</em>.

<em>Copy</em>: G. – This is the "third edition", "editio minor" of 4145. For a description see Renkema
	(1928) p. 12, 13, 24-26, but especially also Little (1949) who provides many details.
<em>Reissue</em> [ed. 5]: London (James Bonn, ...) 2 vols. 1842, <em>vol. 1</em>: text, <em>vol. 2</em>: plates. <em>Copies</em>:
	MICH, NY. – ("Ed. 5"). Actually a re-issue of "ed. 3" with 30 extra pages between
	144/145. <em>Text</em>: [i]-xiv, [1]-144, [1-30], 145-183. <em>Plates</em>: see Renkema and Ardagh and
	Henrey no. 925.
<em>Ref</em>.: GF p. 64; Henrey 920-925 q.v. for further details; NI 1123-1127; SK 1: cxcvi.
	Gordon, An alphabetical reference-list of all the coloured plates of the genus <em>Pinus</em>, The
	Pinetum 1880.
	Renkema, Med. Landbouwhoogeschool Wageningen 32: 1-28. 1928.
	Renkema and Ardagh, J. Linn. Soc. Bot. 48: 439-466. 1930.
	Little, Madroño 10: 33-47. 1949.

Lamouroux, Jean Vincent Félix (1779-1825), French algologist and professor of natural
history at Caen; from 1808 at the Lycée de Caen; from 1809 at the Faculté des Sciences (1812
succeeding Roussel as professor). (<em>J. V. Lamour.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lamouroux's herbarium was dispersed after his death. An important
part is at CN. Other parts are B, G (through Delessert), G-DC and PC.
<em>Ref</em>.: Womersley, H. B. S., Austr. J. mar. freshwater Res. 7: 347. 1956.
	Koster, J. T., Taxon 18: 555. 1969.

66, 84; NI 1129; Plesch p. 296; PR 5024-5026 (ed. 1: 5517-5520); TL-1: 648; TL-2/1: 669,
670, 1663; Urban-Berl. p. 266.

	Mém. Soc. Linn. Paris 4: 705-710. 1826.

father of Jean Vincent Félix. Agardh dedicated his new name explicitly to father and son);

Lamouroux, Jean [Jeanin,] Pierre Péthion (1797-1866), French physician; Dr. med.

Lamson-Scribner, Frank (originally Franklin Pierce Lamson) (1851-1938); American
agrostologist; at Girard College, Philadelphia (1877-1885); from 1885 at the U.S. Dept.
Agriculture; L.L.D. h.c. Univ. Maine 1920. (<em>Lams.-Scribn.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: main herbarium at US (through A. S. Hitchcock); other material at
A, B, BPI, C, GH, K, NY.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Also frequently alphabetized under Scribner, F. Lamson (e.g. CSP, IH).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 339; BL 1: 123, 184; BM 3: 1052; CSP 12: 669,
16: 575, 18: 650-651; IH 2: 408; Kew 3: 357; Langman p. 426-427; Lenley p. 363-364; LS
35774-35775; NW p. 57.
Anon., The Graphic 19 Nov 1892 (portr.); Orchard and Garden 1890 (Aug): 149 (portr.);
	Science 87: 206. 1938; Seattle Post Intellinger 11 Aug 1898 (portr.; copy at MO).

Ewan, J., Rocky Mountain naturalists 301. 1950; Short hist. bot. U.S. 20, 83. 1969.

Woods, Science 88: 101-102. 1938.

Lamy de la Chapelle, Pierre Marie Édouard (1804 [not 1803]-1886), French crypto-
gamist and banker at Limoges. (<em>Lamy</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC (Lamy left his cryptogamic herbarium to Malinvaud). L's
phanerogamic herbarium is at ANG (through Boreau). An early cryptogamic collection
went to Duby. Other bryophytes at BR. – Exsiccatae:
(1) <em>Flore Galliae et Germaniae exsiccata</em> (1841), set at L.
(2) <em>Hepaticae Galliae</em> (1840-1929, with Husnot and Puget).

4173. <em>Flore de Paris</em> (Phanérogames et cryptogames) contenant la description de toutes les
espèces utiles ou nuisibles, avec l'indication de leurs propriétés médicales, industrielles et
économiques et des tableaux dichotomiques très détaillés permettant d'arriver facilement à
la détermination des familles, des tribus, des genres et des espèces de toutes les phanérogames

PAGE: 745
HEADING: LANGE, J. E.

et cryptogames de la région parisienne augmentée d'un tableau donnant les synonymes
latins, les noms vulgaires, l'époque de floraison, l'habitat et les localités de toutes les espèces,
d'un vocabulaire des termes techniques, et d'un mémento des principales herborisations,
avec 702 figures dans le texte. Paris (Octave Doin) 1884. 18-mo. (<em>Fl. Paris</em>).

Lange, Johan Martin Christian (1818-1898), Danish botanist at Copenhagen; 1842-
1848 teacher; 1851-1858 librarian at the botanical garden (1856-1876 part-time director);
1858-1893 lecturer in botany at the agricultural and veterinary college; from 1860 professor
of botany at the polytechnical university; Dr. phil. h.c. 1877 Uppsala. (<em>Lange</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C; duplicates see IH.

PAGE: 747
HEADING: LANGE, J. M. C.

Langenbach, Gustav (1831-1873), German botanist; Dr. phil. Breslau 1863; later at
Naples where he died of cholera. (<em>Langenb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Langenbach states on p. viii of his <em>Meeresalgen</em> (see below)
that C. I. L. Kny and he himself planned to deposit an algal herbarium, with sets of their
collections, at PAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 342; BM 3: 1055; CSP 8: 160; Jackson p. 322;
Saccardo 1: 94; Anon., Bot. Zeit. 31: 797. 1873.
Cesati, V. de, Saggio bibl. algol. ital. 212. 1882.

Langethal, Christian Eduard (1806-1878), German botanist; high school teacher at
Eldena 1835-1839; from 1839 professor of agriculture at Jena. (<em>Langeth</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Anon., Bot. Not. 1879: 31; Nature 18(460): 435. 1878.
Trimen, H., J. Bot. 16: 320. 1878.

D. F. L. von Schlechtendal. Langethal edited vol. 7(Lief. 5)-vol. 22, 1847-1869, and also the

Langlois, Auguste Barthélemy (1832-1900), French-born clergyman and botanist who
settled in the United States in 1855, at Point-à-la-Hache and St. Martinsville, Louisiana.
(<em>Langl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LCU (12.000) phanerogams, US (cryptogams), important sets of
duplicates at BPI, FH, NY and PC. – The LCU herbarium is officially called "the Langlois
herbarium".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 343; BL 1: 184, 305; Bossert p. 227; CSP 16: 597;
IH 2: 410-411; Lenley p. 256; LS 14884; Rehder 5: 489; SBC p. 125 ("Langl."); Stevenson
p. 1248; Tucker 1: 411.
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 30: 359. 1900; Bot. Not. 1901: 114.
Cardot, J., Rev. bryol. 27: 83-84. 1900.
Ewan, J., Southw. Louisiana J. 7: 32, 35. 1967.
Harshberger, J. W., Bot. Philadelphia 266. 1899.
Lamson-Scribner, F., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 20: 326. 1893.
Rogers, D. P., Brief hist, mycol. N. Amer. 20. 1977.
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 355. 1975.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Langloisia</em> E. L. Greene (1896); <em>Langloisula</em> J. B. Ellis &amp; B. M. Everhart (1889);
<em>Mycolangloisia</em> Arnaud (1918).

Lapeyrouse, Philippe Picot Baron de (1744-1818), French mineralogist and botanist at
Toulouse, teacher at the École centrale, later (1800) maire of Toulouse, subsequently
professor of natural history at Toulouse University; deputy during the "cent jours". (<em>La-
peyr</em>.).

HERBARIUM and TYPES: TLJ; a small herbarium is also at MPU. Much material also in the
Thunberg herbarium (UPS).
<em>Ref</em>.: Clos, Mém. Acad. Sci. Toulouse ser. 5. 1: 221-303. 1857, also published separately
	under the title"Révision comparative de l'herbier et de l'Histoire abrégée des Pyrenées
	de Lapeyrouse", Toulouse 1857, p. [i], [1]-86. <em>Copy</em>: BR. -See also extract in Bull. Soc.
	bot. France 4: 418-422. 1857, 1017-1020. 1858.
	Serres, Bull. Soc. bot. France 4: 418-422 1857.
Roumeguère, Mém. Acad. Sci. Toulouse ser. 5. 3: 452. 1859.
Duchartre, Bull. Soc. bot. France 7: 17-22, 66-72. 1860.
Timbal-Lagrave et Loret, Bull. Soc. bot. France 7: 17-22, 66-72. 1860 (on herb. Mar-
	chand in herb. Lapeyrouse at TLJ).
Granel de Solignac et Bertrand, Naturalia monspeliensia, Bot. 18: 281. 1967 ("petit
	herbier de Lapeyrouse").

<sm>NAME</sm>: In earlier publications the name is spelled La Peirouse or Lapeirouse; Lapeyrouse
signed himself Picot de Lapeyrouse.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 31: 155-156. 1976.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lapeirousia</em> [sic] Pourret (1788); <em>Lapeirousia</em> Thunberg (1801); <em>Lapeyrousia</em> Thun-
berg (1823, <em>orth. var.</em>); <em>Peyrousia</em> Poiret (1826, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Picotia</em> J. J. Roemer &amp; J. A. Schultes
(1819). <em>Note</em>: <em>Peyrousea</em> A. P. de Candolle (1838, <em>nom. cons.</em>) is a substitute name for <em>Lapeirousia</em>
Thunberg (1801), non Pourret (1788), but is explicitly dedicated to the french maritime
explorer Jean François Galaup de la Pérouse (1741-1788), since de Candolle assumed that
the same was true for the Thunberg name.

HEADING: LAPHAM

4207. <em>Description de quelques plantes des Pyrénées</em>. Par M. de la Peirouse. [Toulouse 1778]. Ou. (<em>Descr. pl. Pyrén.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1782 (read 30 Jul 1778, but Mém. vol. 1 publ. 1782, see Gras), p. [1]-16, <em>pl. 15-20</em>
	(uncol. copper engr.). <em>Copy</em>: G. –Reprinted from Mém. Acad. Sci. Toulouse 1: 208-223.
	1782 (1778). It is possible that the independently paged issue is in fact a preprint, but we
	have no definitive indication of this.
<em>Ref</em>.: Gras, Bull. Soc. bot. France 11: xl. 1864 (dates this publication as of 1782).

4208. <em>Figures de la flore des Pyrénées</em>, avec des descriptions, des notes critiques et des obser-
vations. Par Philippe Picot Lapeyrouse, Inspecteur des mines de la République. Tome
premier. Paris (De l'imprimerie de Du Pont), L'an iii de la République mdccxcv. Fol. † (<em>Fig.
pl Pyrénées.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1795-1801, p. [i*], [iii*], [i]-viii, [1]-68, <em>pl. 1-4.3. Copy</em>: G.–Only vol. 1 was published,
	in two or four parts (1795-1801). The first "decade", published "1795", containing 11
	plates and 20 p. of text, was announced by JGLF only in Nov 1798. Roumeguère states
	that the work was published in two parts, part 1 in 1795, part 2 in 1801. It is unlikely,
	however, that this is the complete story. The 43 plates are coloured stipple-engravings and
	colour prints of drawings by Laferrerie and P. J. Redouté (11); <em>plates 44-46</em> were also
	printed (Roumeguère); 55 further plates were ready by 1812 and another set of published
	plates is discussed by Timbal-Lagrave (1864, 1885). – <em>Reissue</em>: An xi [1801], n.v.
<em>Ref</em>.: DU 245; GF p. 64; IDC 5561".
	Roumeguère, C, Mém. Acad. Sci. Toulouse sér. 5. 1: 411-413. 1857.
	Timbal-Lagrave, Bull. Soc. bot. France 11: xxxiii-xxxvii. 1864; Mém. Acad. Sci. Inscr.
	Belles-Lettres Toulouse 1885 (2. sem.), reprint p. [1]-31.
	MacPhail, I., Cat. Redout. 18, 65. 1963.

4209. <em>Tableau analytique de la monographie des saxifrages des Pyrénées</em> [Paris (chez J. J. Fuchs,
...) 1799] Qu (<em>Tabl. saxifr. Pyrénées</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Apr 1799-19 Mai 1799 ("Germinal an 7"), p. [1]-8. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted from J.
	Phys.: 4.8: 261-268. 1799.

4210. <em>Histoire abrégée des plantes des Pyrénées</em>, et itinéraire des botanistes dans ces montagnes;

<em>Publ</em>.: early Mai 1813 (BF 21 Mai 1813; author sent a copy to Gouan on 10 Mai 1813), p.
	[1*], map, [iii*], [v*-vii*], [1]-lxxxiii, [1]-700. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, NY; IDC 6006.

For a comparison of the descriptions in this flora with L's <sm>types</sm> see Clos (1857, cited above).
Further critical notes on the many errors are given by Bentham, Cat. pl. Pyrénées (1821, no.
420) and Timbal-Lagrave, Bull. Soc. bot. France 7: 16. 1860.

Lapham, Increase Allen (1811-1875), American pioneer naturalist and botanist; from
1836 businessman at Milwaukee; state geologist of Wisconsin 1873-1875. (<em>Laph</em>.)

Larbalestier, Charles Du Bois (1838-1911), Jersey lichenologist, studied at St. John's
College, Cambridge (BA 1863), resided as tutor in Connemara, later again at Cambridge
and St. Aubin's, Jersey, ultimately at St. Helier. (<em>Larbal</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BIRM; important sets also at BM and CRK. – Exsiccatae:
(1) <em>Lichenes caesarienses et sargienses exsiccati</em> fasc. 1-6, no. 1-280, 1867-1872, sets at BM, K,
MANCH, NY (but see Sayre). (Caesaria is Jersey; Sargia stands for Sark, not for Sarnia =
Guernsey).
(2) <em>Lichenes exsiccati circa Cantabrigiam</em> nos. 1-35, Cambridge 1896, sets at BM, K.
(3)	<em>Lichen-Herbarium, fasc</em>. 1-9, nos. 1-360, 1879-1881, sets at BM, C, H, K, LIVU, PC, W.
(4)	"Lichens of Connemare", "Lichenes rarissima," "Lichenes aegyptiaci" and "Lichens of
Ireland" are mentioned in the literature.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 139-140. 1969.
	Hawksworth, D. L., Mycol. handb. 184. 1974 (fungi also at CRK, FI).
	Anon., Rev. bryol. lichén. 38(2): 307. 1972 (colls, at CRK).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 345;BB p. 180; Desmond p. 371;GR p. 375, cat.
p. 66; Hist. coll. BMNH 161; IH 2: 412; LS 14921.
Anon., Science ser. 2. 33(852): 654. 1911; Times 11 Apr 1911 (fide BB).

Britten, J., Bot. 49: 200. 1911.

	1977.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B; other material: L, MSTR, MW, PAV, WRSL. Exsiccatae:
<em>Herbarium norddeutscher Pflanzen</em> für angehende Lehrer, Pharmaceuten und alle Freunde der
Botanikfasc. i-viii, 346 nos., Driesen und Gorlitz 1860; ed. 2, 1863. (with C. G. Baenitz). Set
at FH. Lasch contributed also to Klotzsch-Rabenhorst, <em>Herbarium mycologicum</em>.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 46: 47, 432. 1863; Bot. Zeit. 21: 348. 1863, 22: 92, 200. 1864. (herb.).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 32. 1969.

Lasègue, Antoine (1793-1873), French librarian to Benjamin Delessert. (<em>Lasègue</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lasègue is not known to have made a herbarium.

4225. <em>Musée botanique de M. Benjamin Delessert</em>. Notices sur les collections de plantes et la
bibliothèque qui le composent; contenant en outre des documents sur les principaux herbiers
d'Europe et l'exposé des voyages entrepris dans l'intérêt de la botanique ... Paris (Librairie
de Fortin, Masson et Cie., ...), Leipzig (même maison chez L. Michelsen). Janvier 1845.
Oct. (<em>Mus. bot. Delessert</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan 1845 (title-page; BF 11 Jan 1845),. [i-xi],-1]-588. <em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY
	(dedic. copy Torrey), U, USDA, IDC 434. – One of the most important sources for
	establishing the location of older herbaria, <sm>types</sm> and collections; the first true <em>Index
	Herbariorum</em>. – An "Uebersicht der Länder oder Gegenden und der bekanntesten Rei-
	senden ..." (Flora ser. 2. 4: 49-64. 1846), published under Lasègue's name, differs in
	various respects and is less accurate.

4227. <em>Hortus burdigalensis</em>, seu catalogus omnigenarum plantarum, praesertim officinalium,

Laterrade, Jean-François (1784-1858), French botanist; at first high school teacher;
founded the Société Linnéenne de Bordeaux on 25 Jun 1818; director of the Bordeaux
botanical garden 1842. (<em>Laterr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BORD.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Act. Soc. Linn. Bordeaux 48: xxx. 1895, 55: exxvi, cxlix, clii. 1900.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Des Moulins (1860) relates that Latterrade, after founding the <em>Société linnéenne de
Bordeaux</em>, tried to make this a nation-wide organisation with twelve different sections. The
French government disbanded this organisation of Linnaean societies in 1828. "en lui
interdisant de s'attacher désormais des collègues par des liens si directs." An interesting
example of early suppression of botanical societies through governmental action. From the
point of view of the history of ideas in botany this incident merits further investigation.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 348; BL 2: 152, 679; BM 3: 1063; CSP 3: 868-
869; GR p. 332; Jackson p. 280; Kew 3: 373; PR 5083; Quenstedt p. 253; Rehder 5: 491;
Tucker 1: 413; Zander ed. 10, p. 683.
Des Moulins, C. R. A., Actes Soc. Linn. Bordeaux 20: 87-93. 1860 (extract: Bull. Soc. bot.
	France 7: 206-207. 1860), 22: 445-460, 585 1860 (portr.; also as repr. 18 p.), 23: 478. 1861.

PAGE: 764
HEADING: LATERRADE

Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 114. 1903,3(3): 106. 1905.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>L'ami des champs</em>, journal d'agriculture du Département de la Gironde,
Bordeaux; Laterrade editor 1825 (vol.3)-1867. The first number came out on 25 Mar 1823
according to a prospectus of 8 p. by Saget at the Bibliothèque municipal, Bordeaux;
Laterrade took over the editorship from 1825 (inf. W. D. Margadant).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Laterradea</em> Raspail (1824).

4228. <em>Flore bordelaise</em>, ou tableau des plantes qui croissent naturellement aux environs de
Bordeaux, dans un circle d'un myriamètre et demi de rayon, classées d'apres le système de
Linné, avec l'étymologie des noms génériques, le site, l'époque de la floraison, etc., leurs
usages dans les arts, l'économie rurale et la médecine; précédée de notions élémentaires sur la
Botanique. Dédiée à Monsieur Lynch, Maire de la Ville de Bordeaux, comte de l'Empire ...
Bordeaux (De l' Impr. de Moreau, ...) An 1811. Duod. (<em>FI. bordel.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1811, p. [1]-299, [300, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, USDA.
<em>Supplément</em>: Jan 1817, p. [301]-338, 339-364. <em>Copy</em>: USDA. – This supplement contains the
	species described by Laterrade in Bull, philom. Jun 1814. The supplement proper is
	followed by indexes and further notes on p. 339-364.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: Aug-Dec 1821 (see p. 477, reference to <em>A. verm</em>), p. [1]-516, [1-3], err. slip. <em>Copies</em>: G,
	NY. "Flore bordelaise, ou description charactéristique des plantes qui croissent naturelle-
	ment aux environs de Bordeaux, avec l'étymologie, le site, l'époque de la floraison, etc.;
	leurs propriétés et leurs principaux usages; précédée de notions élémentaires sur la
	botanique. Dédiée ... seconde édition, entièrement refondue et augmentée d'un Essai de
	la flore de la Gironde. A Bordeaux (de l'imprimerie d'André Brossier.) Année 1821."
	Duod. – A copy at BORD has 15 coloured plates.
<em>Ed</em>. 3: 1829, p. [1]-591, [592]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – "<em>Flore bordelaise</em> et du département de la
	Gironde, description characteristique des plantes qui croissent naturellement aux en-
	virons de Bordeaux, et dans les autres parties du Département, avec l'étymologie, le site,
	l'époque de la floraison, etc.; leurs propriétés et leurs principaux usages, précédée de
	notions élémentaires de botanique. Troisième edition, revue ... Bordeaux (Imprimerie
	de R. Laguillotière et comp.) Année 1829." Duod. – For supplementary notes see Act.
	Soc. Linn. Bordeaux 10: 159-179, 242-250. 1838, 11: 153-160. 1839.
<em>Ed. 4</em>: 1-15 Apr 1846 (copy at BORD), p. [1]-624– <em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, NY.– "<em>Flore bordelaise</em> et
	de la Gironde, description ... quatrième edition, disposée d'après la méthode naturelle et
	avec l'indication de beaucoup d'espèces cultivées ..." Bordeaux (Imprimerie de Th.
	Lafargue, ...) 1846. 18-mo. (gatherings of 6 and 12 p. alternate).
<em>Supplément</em>: Apr 1857, p. [625]-690. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, NY.
<em>Note</em>: Copies of all editions at BORD were seen by W. D. Margadant (personal comm. 29
	Nov 1977).

Latourrette, Marc Antione Louis Claret de [Fleurieude] (1729-1793), French natural-
ist; judge at the Lyon fiscal court until 1771; permanent secretary of the Lyon Academy
1767-1793; founder of various botanic gardens in the Lyon area; active floristic botanist and
popularizer of science. (<em>Latourr</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material in LINN and P-JU. Magnin (1906) states that his "rich
herbarium," which contained the Villars herbarium, is at the "Conservat. du Jardin bot. de
Lyon." Bryophytes also in B (herb. Bridel, extant).

<sm>NOTE ON NAME</sm>: Latourrette signed himself "M. Ant. Lud. à Latourrette" at the end of his
<em>Chloris lugdunensis</em> (1785).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 349; BM 3: 1064; Dryander 5: 318; HU 632; IH
2: 415; Jackson p. 34; Kew 3: 373; Lenley p. 462; LS 14963; NI 1144; Plesch p. 392; PR
5084.-5086; Rehder 5: 491; Saccardo 1: 95; SO 282, add. 655ab, 716, 717, 2631; Tucker 1:
413.
Gilibert, <em>in</em> Latourette, M. A. L. C. de, Démonst. bot. ed. 4. 1: xlvii-xlviii. 1796.
Magnin, A., Bull. Soc. bot. Lyon 31: 3, 37-39, 46. 1906 (many references to original sources.

PAGE: 765
HEADING: LATOURRETTE

bibl., attributions of anonymous publications), 32: 112-113. 1907 (add. bibl.) 35: 21-22,
66, 67, 68, 73, 76. 1910 (add.); Claret de la Tourette. Paris, Lyon 1885, iii, 236 p. (major
biography).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Magnin, A., Claret de la Tourette, Paris, Lyon 1885; Candollea 31: 157-158.
1976.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tourretia</em> Fougeroux 1787 (<em>orth. rej.</em>); <em>Tourrettia</em> Fourgeroux (1787); corr. Schreber
(1791, <em>orth. et nom. cons.</em>)

4229. <em>Démonstrations élémentaires de botanique</em> ... À Lyon, (Chez Jean-Marie Bruyset, im-
primeur-libraire.) 1766, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Démonstr. élém. bot.</em>).

<em>Collaborator</em>: Abbé François Rozier (1734-1793).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: In two volumes, 1766 (privilège 21 Feb 1766). <em>Copies</em>: G, USDA.
	<em>1</em>: [i*-iii*], i-xvi, 1-272, i-xxv, [xxvi, err.], <em>pl. 1-8</em> (uncol. copp.).
	<em>2</em>: [i*-iii*], i-viii, [1]-652, i-xl, [1-3, priv.].
<em>Ed. 2</em>: In two volumes, 1773. <em>Copy</em>: NY.
	<em>1</em>: [i*-iv*], i-xl, 1-316, <em>pl. 1-8</em> (uncol. copp.).
	<em>2</em>: [i]-viii, [1]-652, i-xl, [1-3, priv. 1766]. "<em>Démonstrations ... botanique</em>, à l'usage de l'école
	royale vétérinaire ... nouvelle édition, corrigée et augmentée." A Lyon (id.) 1773.
	Oct.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: Nov-Dec 1787 (p. xv: Nov 1787; registr. vol. 3, 15 Sep 1787), in three volumes, edited
	and annotated <em>by</em>: Jean Emmanuel Gilibert (1741-1814) (see 1: xv). <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY,
	USDA.
	<em>1</em>: [i]-lii, [1]-176,<em>pl. 1-8</em> (uncol. copp.), [i]-xxiv, <em>1 pl</em>. [<em>9</em>] (id.), [1]-482, <em>pl. 1-2</em> [<em>10-11</em>] (id.).
	<em>2</em>: [i]-lxxxviii, [1]-580.
	<em>3</em>: [i-iv], [1]-720.
	"<em>Démonstrations</em> ... <em>botanique</em>, contenant les principes généraux de cette science,
	l'explication des termes, les fondemens des méthodes, &amp; les éléments de la physique des
	végétaux. La description des plantes les plus communes, les plus curieuses, les plus utiles,
	rangées suivant la méthode de M. de Tournefort &amp; celle du Chevalier Linné. Leurs usages
	&amp; leurs propriétés dans les arts, l'économie rurale, dans la médecine humaine &amp; vété-
	rinaire; ainsi qu'une instruction sur la formation d'un herbier, sur la dessication. la
	macération, l'infusion des plantes, &amp;c. Troisième édition, corrigée &amp; considérablement
	augmentée ..." À Lyon (chez Bruyset frères.) 1787, 3 vols. Oct.
<em>Ed. 4</em>: 1796 (1: xxxii Nov 1795), 4 vols. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY, USDA. – <em>Editor</em>: Gilibert (see ed. 3).
	<em>1</em>: [i]-xxxii, [i]-cxv, [cxvi], [1]-515, [516], <em>pl. 1-8</em> (uncol. copp.).
	<em>2</em>: [i]-iv, [1]-752.
	<em>3</em>: [i-iv], [1]-776.
	<em>4</em>: [i-iv], [1)-735, <em>4 pl</em>. (uncol. copp.).
	"<em>Démonstrations</em> ... [as ed. 3] méthode de Tournefort &amp; celle de Linné; leurs usages &amp;
	leurs propriétés dans les arts, l'économie rurale, dans la médecine humaine &amp; vétérinaire;
	ainsi qu'une instruction sur la récolte &amp; la dessication des plantes. Quatrième édition,
	revue avec soin, augmentée de notices raisonnées sur les principaux auteurs, de la
	description de près de douze cents espèces non comprises dans l'edition précédente, &amp;
	rédigée pour former un corps complet de doctrine, embrassant l'histoire de presque toutes
	les plantes de l'Europe &amp; de celles qui y ont été naturalisées par la culture. On y a joint les
	figures de près de 400 plantes alpines, méridionales ou septentrionales dessinées sous la
	direction de Richier de Belleval &amp; sous celle de Linné, celles des graminées les plus
	communes en Europe, des mousses &amp; analogues, accompagnées d'un commentaire &amp;
	d'une discussion critique ... À Lyon" (Chez Bruyset ainé &amp; C.e) 1796, 4 vols. Oct.
<em>Quarto atlas</em> (accompanying the octavo ed.): 1796, 2 vols. <em>Editor</em>: Gilibert (see ed. 3). <em>Copies</em>: B,
	G, NY, USDA. – (The copies show differences in the binding of the various parts).
	<em>1</em>: [i-iv], [1]-15, <em>pl. 1-14</em> (uncoil. copp.), [i]-xvi (on P. R. de Belleval), [1]-140,<em>pl. 1-150, 250
	a-c, 151-166</em> (id.).
	<em>2</em>: [i-iv],<em>pl. 167-276, 278-282</em> (id.), [1]-24 [with biogr. notice of J. C. Leers],<em>pl. 1-16</em> (id.),
	[1]-31 [with biogr. notice of S. Vaillant],<em>pl. 1-16</em> (id.), [1]-48, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (id.), [1]-15
	[French transl. of latin poem by Trante].
	"Démonstrations ... botanique. Partie des figures ..." À Lyon (id.) 1792, 2 vols. Qu.

Lauche, [Friedrich] Wilhelm [Georg] (1827-1883), German dendrologist and gardener
at the horticultural school at Wildpark near Potsdam; obtained fern-hybirds. (<em>Lauche</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 162-163, 5(2): 444; Barnhart 2: 349; BM 3: 1065;
Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lauche"); Jackson p. 506; Kew 3: 374; MW 1145; NI 1145; Rehder 5:
492; Tucker 1: 414; Zander ed. 10, p. 683.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1884: 39; Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 15: xxix. 1884 (on Society's
	affairs.), 51: 86. 1910 (death notice).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lauchea</em> Klotzsch (1854). <em>Note</em>: <em>Neolauchea</em> Kränzlin (1897) is dedicated to another
Lauche (<em>fl</em>. 1897), German horticulturist.

4232. <em>Deutsche Dendrologie</em>. Systematische Uebersicht, Beschreibung, Kulturanweisung und
Verwendung der in Deutschland ohne oder mit Decke aushaltenden Gehölze ... Berlin
(Verlag von Wiegandt, Hempel &amp; Parey. (Paul Parey)) 1880. Oct. (<em>Deut. Dendrol.</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: Oct 1880 (p. vi: 1 Oct 1880; Nat. Nov. Oct(2) 1880; Bot. Zeit. 19 N0V 1880; Flora 11

	<em>Copies</em>: B, USDA. "Zweite Ausgabe." Berlin (Verlag von Paul Parey ... 1883. Oct.
	[actually simply a reissue].

Launay, de (<em>fl</em>. 1993), French botanist (<em>Laun</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> AND <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at P-JU (?).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The M. de Launay, mentioned in the "approbation" of "Les genres sexuels ..."is not
necessarily identical with Louis de Launay (1740-1805); the author may be J. Cl. M.
Mordant de Launay (1750?-1816), see below under eponymy.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Plesch p. 299; Sotheby 438.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Launaea</em> Cassini (1822) is dedicated to J. Cl. M. Mordant de Launay (1750?-
1816), French lawyer, later librarian of the Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris, author
and editor of horticultural works. (see Backer, p. 317).

4233. <em>Les genres sexuels des plantes</em>, établis par Linné, et mis à la portée de tout le monde. Ou
manuel de botanique, destiné à servir de guide pour étudier dans un ordre systématique, les
descriptions des végétaux, données par Miller dans son Dictionnaire des jardiniers et des
cultivateurs. Avec deux tables aphabétiques, l'une des noms françois, et l'autre des noms
latins. À Bruxelles, (de l'Imprimerie d'Emm. Flon, ...) 1793. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Gen. Sex. pl.</em>).

Lauterbach, Carl (Karl) Adolf Georg (1864-1937), German botanist and explorer;
director of the Neu-Guinea Compagnie; characteristic "Privatgelehrter" of independent
means, who built up a rich botanical collection and library on his estate Stabelwitz near
Breslau. (<em>Lauterb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WRSL (50.000); material from his voyage around the world and
other expeditions at: B, BM, BO, H (musci), K, L, LE, S, US, WRSL. – Lauterbach, who
had acquired Otto Kuntze's <em>Thesaurus iconum</em>, (142 folio volumes) left this collection also to
WRSL. – The type specimens of <em>Die Flora der deutschen Schutzgebiete in der Südsee</em> were at B.
<em>Ref</em>.: Lauterbach, Verh. Ges. Erdk., Berlin, 23: 360-364, 507-509, 24: 51-69. 1897 (on Kaiser
	Wilhelms-Land Expedition).
	Rostánski &amp; Weretelnik, Prace Bot., Wroclaw 16: 77-90. 1973 (catal. Lauterbach herb.,
	part 1).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 317; Barnhart 2: 351; BJI 1: 36, 2: 102-103; BL 1 :
115, 120, 121, 127,305; BM 3: 1067; Bossert p. 229; CSP 16: 630; GR p. 104; Hortus 3: 1198
("Lauterb."); IF suppl. 1: 83; IH 1(ed.6): 361, 2: 416; Kew 3: 378; Plesch p. 300; Rehder 5:
493; SK 1: 313-314, cxxv, 4(2): cix, 5: ccxcv; Tucker 1: 415; Urban-Berl. p. 176, 177, 189,
305, 367; Zander ed. 10, p. 683.
Hatusima, Bot. Mag. Tokyo 65: 109-111. 1952 (revision of some of L's genera).
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 186. 1947.
Verdoorn, F., Chron. bot. 4(1): 76-78. 1938 (portr.).
Winkler, Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 55: (231)-(247). 1938 (portr., bibl.).

name Lauterbach); <em>Lauterbachia</em> J. Perkins (1900); <em>Lauterbachiella</em> P. C. Hennings (1898).

<em>Publ</em>: 1880-1885, in six parts, p. [i]-iv, [1]-121, [1, ind., 2 bibl.], <em>pl. 1-36</em> (some details col.;

	have month dates, cited below. These dates are in general confirmed by the contemporary
	references (Nat. Nov., Bot. Zeit., Flora, BSbF) and must hence be accepted. The only
	discrepancy is between the indication Mai 1881 for part 3 and the receipt by Nat. Nov. of
	this part in Mai 1882.

-----------------------------------------------------
1	[1]-19	1-6	Jul 1880

4	[65]-87	19-24	Feb 1882

6	[i]-iv, [109]-121, [123-124]	31-36	Sep 1885

The AA copy has 28 unpublished plates (fide Tucker).

Lawrence, George Hill Mathewson (1910-1978), American botanist; Ph. D. Ithaca
1939; at the Bailey Hortorium and Cornell University 1937-1943, 1945-1960; director of the
Hunt Botanical library from 1960; ultimately at East Greenwich, Rhode Island. (<em>G. Lawr.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 297; Bossert p. 230; Hortus 3: 1198; IH 2: 417;

Steam, W. T., The Times, Monday June 26, 1978.

Lawson, Charles (1794-1873), Scottish botanist; son of the Edinburgh nurseryman Peter
Lawson; succeeded his father 1821. (<em>C. Laws.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 238; Barnhart 2: 353; BB p. 182; BM 3: 1070; Bossert
p. 230; Desmond p. 375; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Laws., C."); Jackson p. 133; Moebius p. 129; NI
(alph.) 1588; PR 5103 (sub Peter L.); Rehder 5: 494; Tucker 1: 415.
Anon., The Garden, London, 11(suppl.): xv-xvi. 1877 (portr.).
James, The trees of Bicton 110. 1969.
Sargent, C. S., Silva North America 10: 120-121. 1896.
Woodward, A. S., Gard. Chron. 1904(2): 36-37. (list of parts of <em>Pinetum Britannicarum</em> with
	contents).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: For "<em>Lawson's Pinetum</em>" see under E. J. Ravenscroft. The book was
originally issued by Peter and Charles Lawson and printed at their private press. The plates
issued with the first 23 fascicles bear the original designation. The text, however, was
compiled by Ravenscroft, the botanical descriptions were contributed by John Lindley (pars
1-3), Andrew Murray (4-37) and Maxwell T. Masters (38-52) (see Gard. Chron. 1904(2):
36-37).

Lawson, George (1827-1895), Scottish botanist; originally at Edinburgh; moved to
Canada 1858; professor of nat. hist. Queen's Univ., Kingston 1858-1863; professor of
chemistry at Dalhousie College, Halifax, Nova Scotia, 1863-1895. (<em>G. Laws.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Original herbarium at Mount Allison University, Sackville, New
Brunswick, Canada, containing several, if not all of his types. Some further material at E and
CAN.
<em>Ref</em>.: Weatherby, C. A., Fern J. 31(2): 59-62. 1941 (fern types).
	Hedge, I. C. and J. M. Lamond, Ind. coll. Edinburgh 101-102. 1970.

177-178, 10: 532, 12: 433-434, 16: 641; Desmond p. 375; De Toni 1: lxxvii; Hortus 3: 1198
("Laws., G."); IF suppl. 4: 329; Jackson p. 570; Kew 3: 385; Lenley p. 462; LS 15030;
Nordstedt p. 21; PR 5101; Rehder 5: 494; Tucker 1: 415-416.
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 21(1): 42. 1896; Bot. Not. 1896: 44; Garden and Forest 406: 490. 1895;

	Lawson medal in botany).
Britten, J., J. Bot. 34: 48. 1896.

Lawson, Marmaduke Alexander (1840-1896), British botanist, professor of botany at
Oxford 1868-1882; director Botany Dept. Ootacamund (India) 1882; government botanist

Our information on the many editions and issues of the Nouvelle flore is incomplete.
Complications not mentioned here are the existence of extra pages (10 bis, 9 ter, 11 bis, 11 ter),
of copies with covers printed later than the text; of other issues with the inverted title "Flore
de la Belgique et du Nord de la France" and of further unchanged reprints after 1909.

Lea, Thomas Gibson (1785-1844), American botanist at Cincinnati, Ohio (<em>Lea</em>).

	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 356. 1975.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Berkleasmium</em> Zobel (1854, also dedicated to Miles Joseph Berkeley (1803-1889)
(q.v.); <em>Leaia</em> Banker 1906. <em>Note</em>: <em>Leachia</em> Cassini (1822) is dedicated to William Elford Leach
(1790-1836), English zoologist, author of articles about Crustaceae in Cuvier's <em>Dictionnaire
des Sciences naturelles</em> (TL-2/1293). <em>Leaoa</em> Schlechter &amp; C. Porto (1922) is dedicated to A.
Pacheco Leão, Brazilian botanist, successor (1909) of J. Barbosa Rodrigues (q.v.) as director
of the Jardim Botanico do Rio de Janeiro. Leão is also commemorated in <em>Leocereus</em> [sic] N. L.
Britton &amp; J. N. Rose (1920).

Leavenworth, Melines Conklin (1796-1862), United States explorer; studied medicine
at Yale (grad. 1817); practiced at Cahawba (Alabama) and Augusta (Georgia); sub-
sequently army surgeon and explorer until 1842; physician at Waterbury (Conn.) 1842-
1861; ultimately again army surgeon; sent plants to Torrey. (<em>Leavenw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at BKL, GH, NY, PH, Y.

HEADING: LEAVENWORTH

Tucker 1: 416.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For the three editions of L.'S <em>Outlines of the geology of Northumberland</em> (1878, 1886, 1889),
see BM 3: 1073. The book is sometimes quoted as <em>Handbook to the geology</em> and natural history of
Northumberland and Durham, a title which can only apply to ed. 3 which carries the title
<em>Visit of the British Association to Newcastle-upon- Tyne</em>, 1889, <em>Official and local guide, geology and
natural history.</em>
