Lechler, Wilibald (1814-1856), German pharmacist, botanist and explorer; studied
pharmacy at Reutlingen; pharmaceutical assistant at Augsburg, Genève, Vevey, Basel
(1831-1836); pharmacist at Stuttgart (1839-1849); to Chile 1850-1855; Dr. sc. nat. Tu-
bingen 1856; died at sea near Ecuador on his return to Peru where he had accepted a position
as physician at Arequiba. (<em>Lechl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MB. – Further material at E, G, GFW, H, LE, LZ (destroyed), P,
TCD, TUB, W, Z. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Plantae chilenses</em> (col. 1850-1853), sets see IH.
(2) <em>Plantae insularum maclovianarum</em> 1853, ed. R. F. Hohenacker, plants from the Falkland
Islands (Iles Malouines, after the French town St. Malo, classical name Maclovium), sets see
IH.
('3) <em>Plantae magellanicae</em> (col. 1850-1853), sets see IH.
(4) <em>Plantae peruvianae</em>, ed. R. F. Hohenacker (col. 1850-1853), sets see IH.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. v., Bot. Zeit. 16: 19. 1858, Bull. Soc. bot. France 4: 848. 1858.
	Candolle, A. de, Phytographie 426. 1880.
	Sayre, Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 32-33. 1969, 19(3): 356-357. 1975.
	Ludwig, Hess. florist. Briefe 16: 13-16. 1967 (herb. at MB via Wigand).
	Künkele, S. und Seybold, S., Jahresh. Ges. Naturk. Württemberg 125: 153. 1970.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 633; Barnhart 2: 357; BM 3: 1074; CSP 3: 913;
GR p. 104; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lechl."); IH 2: 421; Kew 3: 392; PR 5117-5118 led. 1: 5620);
Rehder 5: 496; TL-2/1: 2178; Tucker 1: 417; Urban-Berl. p. 288, 305, 320, 368.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1858: 14; Bot. Zeit. 14: 743-744. 1856, 15: 856. 1857, 16: 19, 62-64. 1858;
	Flora 39: 624. 1856, 40: 736 ("732"). 1857.

Lecomte, (Paul) Henri (1856-1934), French botanist; Lic. sc. nat. Nancy 1881, id. phys.
1883, Dr. sci. nat. Paris 1889; from 1884-1906 teacher at the Lycées Saint-Louis and Henri

PAGE: 782
HEADING: LECOMTE

IV; from 1906 director of the Laboratoire de Phanérogamie of the Museum d'Histoire
naturelle; played an active rôle in the founding of the new Paris herbarium by means of
Rockefeller money. (<em>Lecomte</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 319; Barnhart 2: 358; BJI 2: 103; BL 1: 98, 305;

Langman p. 433; LS 15079, suppl. 15674; MW p. 263, suppl. p. 195; N\V p. 51; Plesch p.
303; Rehder 5: 496; SK 1: 317, 8: lx; TL-2/1: see Finet, E. A.; Tucker 1: 417, 777; Zander
ed. 10. p. 683.

HEADING: LECONTE, J. – CTD. FROM p. 782

<em>Ref</em>.: Baird, Amer. midl. Natural. 20(1): 245-247. 1938 (correlation of water-colors of violets
	and the names used by Leconte with the names used by Ezra Brainerd).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 358; Bossert p. 231; CSP 3: 915-916, 8: 184, 12:
435, 16: 663; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Le Conte"); IH 2: 442; Kew 3: 393; Langman p. 433;

417-418

	16(3): 8. 1921.

	289, 303, 332, 334, 344. 1843.

Scudder, Trans. Amer. Entomol. Soc. 11: i-xxvii. 1885.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: L. usually wrote his name John Leconte; however the full name John Eatton Leconte
is to be preferred to avoid bibliographical confusion with e.g. John LeConte (1818-1891)
(nephew), and John Lawrence LeConte (1825-1883). The family name has also been spelled
LeConte, Le Conte and Lecompte. We follow Rehn (1954) in accepting "John Eatton
Leconte". – See Barnhart (1917) for a list of L's botanical works (with precise dates) and for
the attribution of a "Catalogue of the flora in Georgia" to him.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lecontea</em> A. Richard ex A. P. de Candolle (1830).

Lecoq, Henri (1802-1871), French botanist; professor of natural history and director of the
botanic garden at Clemont-Ferrand from 1826, until 1854 as municipal professor, from then
on as professor of natural history at the Faculté des Sciences, later University. (<em>Lecoq</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Musée Lecoq, Clermont-Ferrand.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 513; BL 2: 111, 136, 680; BM 3: 1076; Bossert p.
231; CSP 3: 919-921, 8: 185-186, 12: 435; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lecoq"); IH 2: 422; Jackson p.
570; Kew 3: 393; Langman p. 433; LS 15080-15081; Moebius p. 55; PR 5121-5131 (ed. 1:
5625-5634); Quenstedt p. 255; Rehder 5: 946; TL-2/1: 809; Tucker 1: 418.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1872: 26; Bull. Soc. bot. France 3: 527. 1856; Flora 54: 303. 7 Oct 1871;
	Bot. Zeit. 29: 780. 1871; Gard. Chron. 1871: 1107; J. Bot. 9: 288. 1871; Bull. Soc. bot.
	France 17: 188. 1870, 18 (c.r.): 209, 284-285, (bibl.): 188. 1871.
Chassagne, Bull. Soc. bot. France 75: 662-670. 1928.
Cosson, H., Notice biographique sur Henri Lecoq. Paris 1874, 33 p. (bibl.).
De Vos, André, Belg. hortic. 1871: v-xxiv (portr., bibl.); La vie et les travaux de Henri
	Lecoq. [Bruxelles]. Bull. Soc. roy. Bot. Belg. 10: 325-333. 1872 (repr. p. 1-9).
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 106. 1905.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) edited <em>Revue horticole</em>, années 1857-1858.
(2) <em>Botanique</em>, in Déribier-du-Chatelet, J. B., <em>Dictionnaire statistique</em> ... <em>du Cantal</em> 1: 453-510.
1852 (see BL 2: 136).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Lecoq was also a skilled and elegant popular writer on botany: e.g. <em>Le monde des fleurs</em>,
botanique pittoresque, Paris (J. Rothschild) 1870. 508 p., see Bull. Soc. bot. France
17(bibl.): 37. 1870.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lecokia</em> A. P. de Candolle (1829, "Les bizarreries de l'orthographe m'ont obligé à
modifier un peu la désinence du nom pour le latiniser.").

HEADING: LEDEBOUR

4277. <em>Dictionnaire raisonné des termes de botanique</em> et des familles naturelles, contenant
l'étymologie et la description détaillée de tous les organes, leur synonymie, et la définition des
adjectifs qui servent à les décrire; suivi d'un vocabulaire des termes grecs et latins les plus
généralement employés dans la glossologie botanique. Par H. Lecoq, ... et J. Juillet, ... À
Paris (Chez J.-B. Baillière, ...), Londres (même maison, ...), Clermont-Ferrand (Chez
Thibaud-Landriot) 1831. Oct. (<em>Dict. rais. term. bot.</em>).

Lecoyer, Joseph-Cyprien (1835-1899), Belgian botanist; high school teacher at Neuf-
château, Wavre and Ath; retired at Beauwelz. (<em>Lecoy</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 358; BL 2: 37, 680; CSP 12: 435, 16: 665; DTS
1: 167; IH 2: 422; Kew 3: 393; Langman p. 434; MW p. 263; Tucker 1: 418.
Lawalrée, A., Natura mosana 1965: 18-19 (bibl.).

4280. <em>Monographie du genre Thalictrum</em>. Gand (Imprimerie C. Annoot-Braeckman, Ad.
Hoste, Succ.r.) 1885. Oct. (<em>Monogr. Thalictrum</em>).

<em>Pub</em>.: late 1885 (Nat. Nov. Mai(1) 1886; Bot. Zeit. 28 Mai 1886), p. [1]-249, <em>pl. 1-5</em>, [1, err.].
	<em>Copies</em>: G; IDC 1014. – Reprinted from Bull. Soc. roy. Bot. Belg. 24: [78]-324, <em>pl. 1-5</em>, [1,
	err.]. 1885.

Ledebour, Carl [Karl] Friedrich von (1785-1851), German botanist (bora at Stralsund,
then Swedish Pomerania); Dr. phil. Greifswald 1805; studied and resided in Greifswald and
Stockholm 1805-1811; professor of botany in Dorpat 1811-1836; travelled widely in Russia
and the Altai region with Meyer and Bunge; retired 1836 to Heidelberg to work at his <em>Flora
rossica</em>; ultimately in München 1844-1851. (<em>Ledeb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Ledebour's herbarium and original material for the <em>Flora rossica</em> are in
the Russian herbarium of LE. Duplicates are in many herbaria, e.g. UPS (Thunberg); the
types are mainly in LE.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 3: 383. 1856.

PAGE: 806
HEADING: LEDEBOUR

	Herder, F. G. T. M. von, Bot. Jahrb. 9: 431, 432, 439. 1888.
	Kukkonen, I., Herb. Christian Steven 66. 1971.

BM 3: 1077; Clokie p. 198; CSP 3: 921, 8: 187; Frank 3(Anh.): 56; Hortus 3: 1198
("Ledeb."); IF p. 714; IH 2: 422; Jackson p. 571; Kew 3: 394; Lasègue p. 419-420, 573;

<em>Copies</em>: G, MICH, MO, NY. – All volumes published in two parts of <em>50 pl</em>. each; the
lithographed plates are stated to be coloured in some copies (none seen by us). For artists see
NI.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Lehre (J. Cramer) 1968, ISBN 3-7682-0567-3, p. [i-iv], followed by facsimile in
	which on 1: (iv) a bibliographical note by F. A. Stafleu. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.

	Historiae naturalis classica 70 (see also Taxon 18: 458. 1969).
	Correspondence Ledebour – W. J. Hooker, at Kew.

Grisebach is the author of the Gramineae (some types at GOET) (G. Wagenitz, in litt.);
Eduard Fenzl of the treatments of <em>Gypsophyla</em>, Alsineae, Paronychieae, Portulacaceae,
Phytolaccaceae, Salsolaceae and Amarantaceae, (H. W. Reichardt, Leopoldina 18: 150.
1880); A. von Bunge of <em>Pedicularis</em>; E. H. F. Meyer of <em>Juncaceae</em>; L. C. Treviranus of <em>Carex</em>. –
Ledebour died 4 Jul 1851; parts 11-14 were prepared for the press by Grisebach (1814-1879)
and other collegues.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von et al., Bot. Zeit. 1: 402-403. 9 Jun 1843 (fasc. 3); 1: 849. 8
	Dec 1843 (fasc. 4); 2: 730-731. 18 Oct 1844 (fasc. 5); 3: 617. 12 Sep 1845 (fasc. 6); 4:
	621-622. 4 Sep 1846 (fasc. 7); 5: 871. 3 Dec 1847 (fasc. 8); 9: 199-200. 7 Mar 1851 (10);
	10: 143. 13 Feb 1852 (fasc. 11); 10: 723. 8 Oct 1852 (fasc. 12); 11: 630-631. 2 Sep 1853.
	Bourdeille, Bull. Soc. imp. Natural. Moscou ser. 2. 6: 378. 1893.
	Junk, Rara 65. 1900-1912.

Ledermüller, Martin Frobenius (1719-1769), German "Justizrath" and naturalist at
Bayreuth and Nürnberg. (<em>Lederm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 358; BM 3: 1077; DNB 32: 357-358; Dryander
1: 216, 4: 125, 5: 320; HU 581; Kew 3: 394; Moebius p. 205, 436; NI 1156-1160; Plesch p.

4288. Martin Frobenius Ledermüllers, ... <em>Mikroskopische Gemüths- und Augenergötzung</em>: be-
stehend, in ein Hundert nach der Natur gezeichneten und mit Farben erleuchteten Kupfer-
tafeln, sammt deren Erklärung. Verlegt von Adam Wolffgang Winterschmidt, Kupfer-
stecher in Nürnberg, gedruckt von Christian de Lamoy. [Nürnberg] [1759-] 1763. Qu. (<em>Mikrosk. Augenergötz.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In monthly issues, presumably of 10 pl. each, of which the precise dates are incom-
	pletely known: <em>Main work</em>: col. engr. front., p. [i-xvi], [1]-96, [1-2], 97-204, [1-2], <em>pl. 1-
	100</em>; <em>Nachleese</em>: front., [i-xvi], [1]-94, <em>pl. 1-50</em>, [1-2]. Publication took place as follows
	(information C. A. Oudemans; not complete):
	<em>Mainwork</em>: p. [1]-96, <em>pl. 1-50.</em> 1759, in five (?) parts p. [97]-206, <em>pl. 51-100</em>, in five (?) parts
	Jan-Mai 1761.

	II. Sammlung, p. 21-40, <em>pl. 11-20</em> shortly after 3 Mai 1762.
	III. Sammlung, p. 41-54, <em>pl. 21-30</em>, probably Nov 1762.
	IV. Sammlung, p. 79-94, <em>pl. 40-50</em>, probably Sep 1763.
	<em>Preface material</em> Main work: t.p. after 1 Sep 1763 [v?-xvi]: preface material.
	<em>Nachleese</em>: t.p. 1762, other p. [v?-xvi]. 1763.

HEADING: LEE, J.

<em>Dutch translation</em>: 1776, Mikroskoopische Vermaaklijkheden, zo voor de oogen als voor den
	geest, behelzende de afbeeldingen van veelerley voorwerpen, zo van dierlyke lichaamen,
	als van planten en delfstoffen, die geheel of gedeeltelijk ten naauwkeurigste onderzogt, en

	schreven zijn ... In't Nederduitsch vertaald en uitgegeven: Te Amsterdam, bij de Erven

<em>Second edition</em> of German original: Nürnberg 1802 (n.v., fide Spiess).

Lee, James (1715-1795), British nurseryman; partner with J. Kennedy at Vineyard nursery
at Hammersmith; introduced plants from America and the Cape (introduced e.g. <em>Fuchsia
coccinea</em>); correspondent of Linnaeus. (<em>J. Lee</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Correspondence with J. E. Smith at LINN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 319-320; Barnhart 2: 360; BB p. 184; BM 3: 1078;
Bossert p. 232; Dawson p. 526, 942; Desmond p. 378-379; DNB 32: 357-358; Dryander 3: 20,
100, 5: 320; Henrey 2: 726, 3: 72-73; Jackson p. 36, 571; Kew p. 395; Plesch p. 303; PR 5148
(ed. 1: 5656-5657); Rehder 5: 497; SO 453, 462, 2188-2192, 2548a.
Anon., Flora 8: 463-464. 1825; Gard. Chron. 1881(2):330-331. (in notice on Lisson Charles
	Lee. 1808-1881).
Berkeley, E. &amp; D. Smith Berkeley, Dr. John Mitchell 235-236, 241, 245-246. 1974.
Darlington, W., Memorials 395. 1849.
Fries, Th. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(3): 72, 74. 1909, 1(7): 187. 1917.
Loudon, J. C., Arbor, frutic. brit. 1: 78. 1838.
Phillips, V. T. and M. E., Guide mss. Coll. Acad. Phila. p. 567. 1963.
Smith, J. E., Memoir and Correspondence 2: 117, 183. 1832.
Webber, R., Early horticulturists 91-100. 1968 (potr.) (fide Desmond).
Willson, E. J., James Lee and the vineyard nursery Hammersmith. London (Ham-
	mersmith Local History Group) 1961 (portr.).
Witte, H., Floralia ix, x. De Fuchsia, 'sGravenhage 1882, p. 11-17 (story of Lee's acquisition
	of <em>Fuchsia coccinea</em>; very likely apocryphal).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Leea</em> D. van Royen ex Linnaeus (1767, <em>nom. cons.</em>); <em>Leeoxylen</em> U. Prakash &amp; R. Dayal
(1964). <em>Note: Leeina</em> Petrak (1923) is dedicated to Henry Atherton Lee (1894-x), American
mycologist.

4289. <em>An introduction to botany</em>. Containing an explanation of the theory of that science, and an
interpretation of its technical terms. Extracted from the works of Dr. Linnaeus, and
calculated to assist such as may be desirous of studying that author's method and improve-
ments. With twelve copper plates, and two explanatory tables. To which is added an
appendix; containing upwards of two thousand English names of plants, referred to their
proper titles in the Linnaean system. By James Lee, Nursery Man, at the Vineyard, at

PAGE: 810
HEADING: LEE, J.

Hammersmith. London: (printed for J. and R. Tonson, in the Strand) 1760. Oct. (<em>Intr. bot.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Edition 1-6, 1760-1794 by James Lee; eds. 7-8 by Charles Stewart, [9-9a] by James
	Lee Jr. (1754-1824).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: Apr 1760 (Gent. Mag.), p. [i]-xvi, [1]-320, <em>pl. 1-12</em> with text (uncol. copp.). <em>Copies</em>:
	NY, USDA.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1765, p. [i]-xv, [i]-iv, [1]-332, 449-479, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (id.). <em>Copy</em>: NY. – "The second edition.
	To which is added a glossary." London (id.) 1765. Oct. – See Jackson and Wiltshear on
	the discrepancy in the pagination.

<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1776, p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-432, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: BR, MO, NY, USDA. – "<em>An introduction</em>
	... science; extracted from the works of Dr. Linnaeus; with twelve copper-plates, two
	explanatory tables, an appendix and glossary. The third edition, corrected, with large
	additions ... " London (Printed for J. F. and C. Rivington, L. Davis, B. White, S.
	Crowder, G. Robinson, T. Cadell, and R. Baldwin.) 1776. Oct. – Contains a translation of
	Linnaeus's <em>Termini botanici</em>.
<em>Ed. 4</em>: 1788, p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-434, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY. "[as ed. 3] ... The fourth
	edition ..." London (printed for J. F. and C. Rivington, L. Davis, B. White, and son, S.
	Crowder, C. Dilly, C. G.J. and J. Robinson, T. Cadell, and R. Baldwin.) 1788. Oct.
<em>Ed. 5</em>: 1794, p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-434, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, USDA. "[as ed. 3] ... The fifth
	edition, corrected ..." London (printed for S. Crowder, C. Dilly, C. G. and J. Robinson,
	T. Cadell, R. Baldwin, S. Hayes, F. and C. Rivington, B. and J. White, Ogilvie and
	Speare, and Vernor and Hood.) 1794. Oct.
<em>Ed</em>. "<em>4</em>": "London 1796" mentioned by Jackson (p. 36), does not exist, see Henrey 957.
<em>Ed. 6</em>: 1796, p. xiii, [iii], 374, <em>pl. 1-12</em>, Edinburgh (James Symington), n.v., see Henry 957.
<em>Ed</em>. [<em>7</em>] "<em>New edition</em>": 1799, p. [i]-xii, [xiv-xvi], [1]-374. <em>Copy</em>: MICH. – " ... New edition,
	improved, corrected and enlarged; in which the arrangement of the classes and orders is
	rectified; the newly discovered genera added, from the last edition of the Systema naturae;
	the appendix is also amended and enlarged; and many trivial names supplied, parti-
	cularly of West India plants. By Charles Stewart, ..." Edinburgh (printed for Wm.
	Creech, and J. Symington; and T. Cadell, and W. Davies, London) 1799. Oct. (in fours).
	The Appendix to this edition was "amended and enlarged and many trivial names supplied,
		particularly of West Indian plants." (see also Wheldon &amp; Wesley Cat. 131, 1974, no. 1168).
<em>Ed</em>. [<em>8</em>] "<em>New edition</em>": 1806, Edinburgh (Mundell, Doig &amp; Stevenson), xiii, [iii], 400, <em>pl. 1-12</em>,
	n.v., see Henrey 957.
<em>Ed</em>. [<em>9</em>]: 20 Dec 1809 (plates), but book after 1 Mai 1810 (dedication p. iii). – "<em>An introduction
	to the science of botany</em>, ... to which are added several new tables and notes, and a life of the
	author [by Robert John Thornton] ..." Fourth edition, corrected and enlarged, by Mr.
	James Lee, son and successor to the author. London (printed for F. C. and J. Rivington;
	Wilkie and Robinson...) 1810. Oct., front, portr., p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-580, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (uncol.
	copper engr. published 20 Dec 1809; drawn by Henderson). <em>Copy</em>: Zool. Mus. Amsterdam.
<em>Ed</em>. [<em>9a</em>]. - "Ed. 4. corrected and enlarged", as ed. 9, but with cancel t.p. and a leaf with page
	numbers 'xv-xvi' and xvii-xviii, inserted in place of xv-xviii (see Henrey 961), front., p. [i]-
	xxiv, [1]-580, <em>pl. 1-12.</em> <em>Copy</em>: AMD.

The original work constituted the first treatise of the Linnaean system in England. To what
extent it was a translation, by E. W. Gray, of Linnaeus's <em>Philosophia botanica</em> is not clear to us
(see Wiltshear 1915).
<em>Ref</em>.: Sherborn, C. D., J. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 1: 141. 1760.
	Jackson, B. D., J. Bot. 53: 66-67. 1915.
	Wiltshear, F. G., J. Bot. 53: 112. 1915.

<em>Co-author</em>: John Kennedy (1759-1842).

Leers, Johann Daniel (1727-1774), German botanist and pharmacist; born at Wunsiedel
nr. Bayreuth; from 1755 owner of the academic pharmacy at Herborn, Nassau. (<em>Leers</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Part of the herbarium was acquired by G. F. Hoffman,
but destroyed in the Moscow fire of 1812.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 12; Backer p. 320; Barnhart 2: 361; BM 3: 1079;
Dryander 3: 157, 5: 320; Frank 3 (Anh.): 56; GR p. 28; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Leers"); Jackson p.
305; Kew 3: 397; LS 15089; NI 1162; PR 5149 (ed. 1: 5658); Rehder 5: 497; SO 665; Tucker
1: 418.
Jung, W., Flora des Herzogtums Nassau x. 1832.
Leers, H. P., <em>in</em> Leers, Flora herbornensis ed. 2, cura Willdenow, p. xiii-xxiv, also in ed. 1, on
	unnumbered pages.
Meusel, Lexikon teut. Schriftst. 8: 107. 1808.
Roth, Arch. Gesch. Naturw. Technik 2: 146-148. 1909.
Schmidt, Decheniana 105/106: 205-208. 1952.
Sprengel, K. P. J., Hist. rei. bot. 2: 471. 18.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Leersia</em> O. Swartz (1788, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

4293. Joannis Danielis Leers <em>Flora herbornensis</em> exhibens plantas circa Herbornam Nas-
soviorum crescentes, secundum systema sexuale Linneanum distributas, cum descrip-
tionibus rariorum in primis graminum, propriisque observationibus et nomenclatura. Acces-
serunt graminum omnium indigenorum eorumque adfinium civ, auctoris manu ad vivum
delineatae aerique incisae. Herbornae Nassoviorum (sumptibus auctoris) 1775. Oct. (<em>Fl.
herborn.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>:1775 (p. [xvi]: Nov 1774; GGA 25 Mai 1776), p. [i*], [iii*-xxxii*], [i-iii]-lix, [1x, err.],
	[1]-288, [1-4, index], <em>pl. 1-16</em> (uncoloured copper engr. by the author). <em>Copies</em>: G, MO,
	US, USDA. – published posthumously by Leers's son Heinrich Paul who provided a
	biography.

PAGE: 812
HEADING: LEERS

<em>Editio altera</em>: Berolini [Berlin] (impensis Christiani Friderici Himburgi), <em>publ</em>.: Apr 1789, p.
	[i] -lxxviii, [1]-289, [290, abbr.], [1-6, ind.], <em>pl. 1-16</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, USDA; IDC
	4010. – Biography by H. P. Leers on p. xiii-xxiv. <em>Editor</em>: Carl Ludwig Willdenow (1765-
	1812).
<em>Editio nova</em>: Herbornae et Gissae [Herborn and Giessen] (apud J. C. Krieger, Jun.) 1790, p.
	[i*-xxxii*], [i]-lix, [lx, err.], [1]-288, [1-4, index], <em>pl. 1-16.</em> <em>Copies</em>: MO, USDA. –
	Unchanged reissue of ed. 1, new t.p. only.

The plates were drawn and engraved by Leers himself; the copper plates are at the
Landesbibliothek Wiesbaden. The plates were copied by Gilibert in his edition of Latour-
rette, Demonstr. bot., ed. 4, 1796 (TL-2/4229), and by Wilbrand 1819.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., [review], GGA 1776(1): 533. 25 Mai 1776.
	Wilbrand, J. B., Handbuch der Botanik, Giessen 1819 (corrections and additions).
	Hübener, Flora 22(2): 484-488. 1839 (on localities).
	Linde, A. von der, Die Nassauer Drucke der k. Landesbibliothek zu Wiesbaden 1: 200,
	989. 1882.
	Roth, Arch. Gesch. Naturw. Technik 2: 146-148. 1909.

Lees, Edwin (1800-1887), British printer and stationer at Worcester who gave up business
at an early stage and devoted himself exclusively to the natural history of the English
Midlands. (<em>E. Lees</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at MANCH; letters in Broome corr. at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 102, 315; Barnhart 2: 361; BB p. 184-185; BL
2: 274, 319, 680; CSP 3: 925-926, 8: 189, 16: 674; Desmond p. 380 (q.v. for further biogr.
refs.); DNB 32: 394; GR p. 376; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lees"); IH 2: 424; Jackson p. 571; Kew 3:
398; LS 15091-15097; PR 5150-5151; Rehder 5: 497-498; Tucker 1: 418-419.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1888: 46; Naturalist 778: 372. 1921 (portr.); Proc. Linn. Soc. 1887/1888:
	93. 1890.
Hawksworth, D. L. &amp; M. R. D. Seaward, Lichenol. Brit. Isl. 20, 24, 109. 1977.
Kent, D. H., Hist. fl. Middlesex 22-23. 1975.
Mathews, J. Bot. 25: 384. 1887.
Riddelsdell, Fl. Gloucestershire cxxii-cxxiii. 1948.
Wade, A. E., Fl. Monmouthshire 11. 1970.
White, Ann. Bot., London, 1: 406-408. 1888 (bibl.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Lees published, under the name of Ambrose Florence, a "Strangers' Guide to the City
and the Cathedral" [of Worcester] containing <em>A catalogue of plants growing wild in the vicinity of
Worcester</em> (1820); as "Alwynus Malverine" he published popular articles on natural history
in the Malvern News and Journal of which he was the editor from 1861 onward.

4294. <em>The botany of the Malvern Hills</em>, in the counties of Worcester, Hereford, and Gloucester;
with the precise stations of the rarer plants, and introductory observations on the general
features, geology, and natural history of the district ... London (Tilt and Bogue, ...)
Malvern (H. Lamb) s.d. [1843]. Duod. (in sixes). (<em>Bot. Malvern Hills</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: Jun-Nov 1843 (Bot. Zeit. 29 Dec 1843, p. viii: 12 Mai 1843), p. [i]-viii, [1]-64. <em>Copy</em>:
	NY.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: Sep-Dec 1852 (p. ii: Aug 1852), frontisp., [i*-ii*], [i]-ii, [1]-101. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – "Second
	edition, enlarged and corrected ..." London (David Bogue, ...) Malvern (H. Lamb
	and Son) s.d. Duod.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: Aug-Dec 1868 (p. viii: 31 Jul 1868), front., [i]-vii, [viii], [1]-166. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY.

4295. <em>The botany of Worcestershire</em>, or the distribution of the indigenous &amp; naturalized plants
of that county, with descriptions of the most remarkable localities for botanical observation,
including sketches of the physical geography of Worcestershire in four botanical districts,
and a tabulated arrangement of plants, showing their frequent or rare occurrence in each
division ... Worcester: (printed for the Worcestershire Naturalists' Club.) 1867. Oct. (in
fours). (<em>Bot. Worcestershire</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug-Dec 1867 (p. [iii*]: Jul 1867), map, p. [i*-iv*], [i]-xci, [1]-147, front., [1]-48,

<em>Ref</em>.: BM 3: 1079.

Lees, Frederick Arnold (1847-1921), British physician and botanist at Leeds (1887-
1921). (<em>F. Lees</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (p.p.; 2000), CMM (main herb., 25.000). Some further material
at LCN and SLBI. Lees' library also went to CMM (now at Bradford Public Library).
Mosses at MANCH.
<em>Ref</em>.: Seaward, Naturalist 1967: 77-80; 907: 133-135. 1970; 915: 125-129. 1970; 924: 35-36.
	1973 (extensive details on Lincolnshire collections).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 361; BB p. 185; BL 2: 252, 254, 275, 276, 277,
278, 279, 680; BM 3: 1079; Clokie p. 198; CSP 8: 189, 10: 549-550, 12: 436, 16: 674;
Desmond p. 380; GR p. 403; IH 2: 424 Jackson p. 571; Kew 3: 398; LS 15098-15099, 35911;
Tucker 1: 419.
Britten, J. Bot. 60: 97-100. 1921 (portr.).
Davy, J. Bot. 31: 123-124. 1893 (criticism of Lees' <em>Outline flora of Lincolnshire</em>, publ. in White's
	<em>Directory for Lincolnshire</em>, see Comp. works).
Druce, G. C., Fl. Berkshire clxxxiii. 1897; Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isles Rep. 6(3): 358-
	363. 1922.
Gibbons, E. J., Fl. Lincolnshire 57. 1975.
Hawksworth, D. L. &amp; M. R. D. Seaward, Lichenol. Brit. Isl. 109-110, 198. 1977.
Lees, F. A., Description of the Lees herbarium and library, Bradford Public Library, 1910
	(fide Britten 1922; autobiogr.).
Spalding, D. A. E., Sorby Record 2(4): 12-13. 1967 (n.v.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Edited: <em>The London catalogue of British mosses</em>, ed. 2, 1881 (originally
issued by C. P. Hobkirk and H. Goswell).
(2) <em>Outline flora of Lincolnshire</em>, in W. White's <em>Directory for Lincolnshire</em>, Sheffield 1892, p. 37-63.
(3) Founder and editor of <em>Botanical Record Club</em>: phanerogamic and cryptogamic (1873:
founded as <em>Botanical Locality Record Club</em>, 1879 <em>Botanical Record Club</em>), reports edited by Lees
1873-1886 (six issues).
(4)	With James William Davis (1846-1893): <em>West Yorkshire</em>: an account of its geology ... and
botany, part 2, Physical geography and botanical topography. London 1878 (see BM 1:
428).

4296. <em>The flora of West Yorkshire</em> with a sketch of the climatology and lithology in connection
therewith ... London: (Lovell Reeve &amp; Co., ...) 1888. Oct. (<em>Fl. West Yorkshire</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: Jan-Mai 1888 (p.x: 31 Dec 1887; J. Bot. Jun 1888; Nat. Nov. Jul(2) 1888; Bot. Zeit.
	29 Jun 1888), p. [i]-x, [1-3], [1], map, [3]-843, [1-4, subscribers]. <em>Copies</em>: G, USDA. – <em>A
	supplement to the Yorkshire floras</em>, edited by C. A. Cheetham and W. A. Sledge, London
	[1942], iv, 134 p. provides an updated list of vasc. plants and Characeae.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten J., J. Bot. 26: 219-222. Jun 1888 (extensive review).

Lefébure, Louis F. Henri (1754-1839), French botanist; sous-préfet at Verdun until 1814.
(<em>Leféb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Some material at PC(?).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 361; BM 3: 1080; Kew 3: 399; Moebius p. 291;
PR 5155-5157 (ed. 1: 5679-5689); Rehder 5: 498; SO 805, 808; Tucker p. 419.

O., Dict. sci. méd. 5: 564. 1882.
Pritzel, G. A., Linnaea 19: 456. 1847.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: We regret that our treatment of this authur is incomplete. For a list of titles attributed
to him see PR ed. 1, nos. 5679-5689. All these titles appear to be rare.

HEADING: LEFÉBURE

4297. <em>Méthode signalementaire</em> pour servir à l'étude du nom des plantes, ou nouvelle manière
d'apprendre à connaître le nom des plantes à leur première inspection, sans qu'il soit besoin
d'avoir étudié aucun systême, et par un procédé qui exige à peine une heure d'étude. Par M.
Louis Lefébure. De 1' imprimerie de Richomme. À Paris, (chez Th. Desoer, libraire, ...)
1814. Oct. (<em>Méth. signal.</em>).

[<em>1</em>]: 1814 p. [1]-96
<em>2</em>: 1814 p. [1]-8, [9-17, glossary and index].
<em>3</em>: 1815 p. [1]-30, [1, avis]. (PR cites 80 p. text).
<em>Copies</em>: B(1), BR(1, 2), G(1-3), USDA(1). – In a note on 1: 96 the author announces
	"tablettes mobiles" to accompany part 2. We have found no copy of these tables.

4298. <em>Concordance des trois systêmes</em> de Tournefort, Linnaeus et Jussieu, par le systême foliaire
appliqué aux genres des plantes qui croissent spontanément dans le rayon de dix lieues autour
de Paris; au moyen duquel on connaîtra sur-le-champ et simultanément le nom générique de
ces plantes et leurs caractères classiques dans ces systêmes ... deuxième édition. Imprimerie
de Richomme. À Paris (Chez Th. Desoer, libraire, ...) 1816. Oct. (<em>Concord. trois syst.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1816, p. [1]-75, [1-2, poem]. <em>Copies</em>: NY, USDA. – A first edition is not known to us.

4299. <em>Atlas botanique</em>, ou clef du Jardin de l'univers. [Paris (Treuttel et Würtz) 1817]. Oct. (<em>Atlas bot</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1817 (fide PR ed. 1),p. [1]-224. <em>Copy</em>: USDA. – This copy has on p. [1] a half title. It
	lacks the t.p. cited by PR with the full title: "Atlas botanique, ou clef du jardin de
	l'univers, d'apres les principes de Tournefort et de Linné rèunis." PR also cites a plate and
	(5682) a "clef du Jardin de l'univers ... Prospectus", 4 p., <em>1 pl</em>. (n.v.).

Lefèvre, Édouard (1839-1894), French botanist and entomologist; born at Chartres; to
Indo-China 1856-1858 as civil engineer; from 1858 in the central administration of French
public works. (<em>Lefèv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Indo-China material at P.

Garnier, libraire ...) 1866. Oct. (<em>Bot. Eure-et Loir</em>).

Le Gal, Marcelle Louise Fernande (1895-x), French mycologist at the Muséum

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Mme Le Gal's thesis, defended at Paris on 19 Mai 1944, <em>Recherches sur les ornementations
sporales des discomycetes operculés</em>, published 1947 (Thèses Fac. Sci. Paris ser. A, no. 450) was
reprinted as Bibliotheca mycologica vol. 28, 1970, by J. Cramer (Lehre, B. R. D.). The
original text appeared also in Ann. Sci. nat. Bot. ser. 11. 8: 73-297. 1947.

Legendre, Charles Valentin Alexandre (1841-1935), French botanist; founder (1889)
of Société botanique du Limousin; founder and editor of <em>Le règne végétal</em> (1890-1892) ctd. as
<em>Revue scientifique du Limousin</em> (1893-1909). (<em>Legendre</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Legendre owned a large private herbarium of Limousin plants;
present location unknown. A herbarium given by "M. Legendre" was deposited at the office
of the Linn. Soc. of Bordeaux on 20 Nov 1895.

Legué, Alphonse Marie Léon (1841-1920), French botanist at Mondoubleau in Loir-et
Cher. (<em>Legué</em>).

Lehmann, Eduard (also: Leman, Eduard Eduardovich) (1841-1902), Baltic-German
(born at Riga) botanist and physician; studied at Dorpat 1860-1865; from 1866-1874
practicing physican); from 1874-1902 at Witebsk. (<em>Ed. Lehm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Herbarium specimens made by "A. Lehmann" stem
from Alexander Lehmann (1814-1842), see IH 2: 426.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 758; Barnhart 2: 363; BM 3: 1087 (Leman, partly
incorrect); Bossert p. 232; CSP 3: 935; Kew 3: 401; Lenley p. 261; LS 15117; Moebius p.
355; MW p. 264; Rehder 5: 499; TR 500, 758; Tucker 1: 420.
Ascherson, P. F. A., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 44: xxxv-xxxvii. 1903.
Kupffer, Acta Horti bot. Univ. imp. jurjev. 3: 210-215. 1902 (portr.); Korrespondenzbl.
	Naturf. Ver. Riga 45: 21-27. 1902.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: V. Mühlenbach, St. Louis, has drawn our attention to a possible confusion in various
bibliographies with Ed. Lehmann, <em>fl</em>. 1903, author of e.g. <em>Materialien zur Flora des Kreises Biisk</em>
im Gouvernement Tomsk, Kasan 1903 (copy: MO), and of the items mentioned by CSP 10:
554-555 and 16: 684.

Verbreitung der Pflanzen durch Eisenbahnen ... Jurjew (Dorpat). (Druck von C. Mat-
tiesen) 1895. Oct. (<em>Fl. Poln.-Livl.</em>).

	published as Archiv für Naturkunde Liv-, Ehst- und Kurlands, ser. 2, vol. 11(1) (journal:
	Teyler). – Kuppfer (1902) cites 27 Mar 1895 o.s. (8 Apr 1895) as date of publ. The date of
	the censor, however, is 27 Jun 1895.

Lehmann, Johann Georg Christian (1792-1860), German botanist at Hamburg; town
librarian and professor of natural history at the Hamburg Johanneum (Gymnasium
academicum); director of the Hamburg botanical garden. (<em>Lehm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lehmann's herbarium was sold in parts (per family). The greater
part is now at S. Boraginaceae and <em>Nicotiana</em> were acquired by O. W. Sonder (now at MEL,
information provided by A. B. Court); the algae are at HBG; bryophytes are at L, S and PC
(through Montagne).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 18: 208. 1860 (note on sale herb.).
	Otto, C. F., Gard. Chron. 1860: 362. (sale herb.).
	Klatt, F. W., Bonplandia 8: 143. 1860 (sale herb.).
	Steinberg, C, Webbia 32(1): 29. 1977.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 18: 143; AG 2(2): 488, 5(1): 410; Barnhart 2: 363; BM
3: 1082; CSP 3: 935-936; Dryander 3: 539, 614, 5: 53, 321; DTS 1: 167-168, 6(4): 10, 166;
Frank 3(Anh.): 56; GR p. 104-105; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lehm."); IH 1(ed. 6): 361, 2: 426;
Jackson p. 571; Kew 3: 402; Langman p. 435; Lenley p. 462; LS 15120; Maiwald p. 166,
232; Moebius p. 378; MW p. 264; NAF 28B(2): 442; NI 1165-1167; PR 5166-5177 (ed. 1:
5700-5710); Rehder 5: 499; SBC p. 125 ("Lehm."); Tucker 1: 420; Urban-Berl. p. 305;
Zander ed. 10, p. 683.
Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 6: 760. 1860; Flora 43: 143, 271-272. 1860.

HEADING: LEHMANN, J. G. C.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 31: 325-326. 1976.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Lehmann chose the name "Helianthus III" in the Leopoldina (1818).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: The etymology of <em>Lehmanna</em> Cassebeer &amp; Theobald (1847), <em>Lehmannia</em> Trattinick
(1824), and <em>Lehmannia</em> K. P. J. Sprengel (1817) could not be established. <em>Lehmanniella</em> Gilg
(1895) and <em>Neolehmannia</em> Kränzlein (1899) commemorate Friedrich Carl Lehmann (1850-
1903), German collector in Central and South America.

4327. <em>Semina in horto botanico hamburgensi</em> 1822 <em>collecta</em> quae pro mutua commutatione
offeruntur. Hamburgi (Typis Johannis Augusti Meissneri.) 1823. Qu. (<em>Sem. hort. bot. ham-
burg</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: The seedlists of the Hamburg botanical garden, issued from 1823-1840, contain notes
	with the diagnoses of new taxa by Lehmann. These names and diagnoses often precede the
	publication of the same diagnoses with extended descriptions in the <em>Pugilli</em> (no. 4328). The
	above title runs to 1829, from 1830 on the title is "<em>Delectus seminum</em> quae in horto
	hamburgensium botanico e collectioni anni ... mutuae commutatione offeruntur." <em>Copy</em>
	of complete set 1822-1840: HBG. For the continuation (1849-1852), see below, no. 4333.

	<em>pugillus decimus</em> auctore C. Lehmann. 3. Verzeichniss der Vorlesungen. Hamburg
	(Gedruckt bei Theodor Gottlieb Meissner) 1857. Qu., p. [i]-xiv, [1]-[40]. <em>Copies</em>: G.
	MICH.

(BMNH) has the original drawings of the plates and a copy of the German version published
in the Allg. Garten Zeit. no. 11.

HEADING: LEHMANN, J. G. C.

4334. <em>Über die gattun Nymphaea von</em> Prof. Dr. C. Lehmann [Hamburg 1853.] Qu. (<em>Nymphaea</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1853, p. [1]-26. <em>Copies</em>: G, L, NY.-Issued at the same time as a pamphlet (without
	title-page, with separate pagination as above) and as an article in Otto's <em>Garten und
	Blumenzeitung</em> 8: 193. Mai 1853 [actually published late April]. On 24 Apr 1853 Lehmann
	sent a copy of the "petit brochure" to W.J. Hooker (K).
	Planchon's revision of the family in the <em>Revue horticole</em> of 16 Feb 1853 antedates Lehmann's
	treatment. The delivery of an oral paper by Lehmann on this subject, in Sep 1852, does
	not constitute valid publication. Planchon's publication, however, contains hardly any
	descriptions: these were given in the <em>Ann. Sci. nat.</em> of 15 Mai 1853, and therefore <em>later</em> than
	Lehmann's article.
<em>Ref</em>.: Newman, The Phytologist 4: 952-964. Jun 1853 (reprint as "<em>Revision of the genus
	Nymphaea</em>.").
	Seeman, B., Bonplandia 1(5): 43. 15 Feb 1853, 1(4): 131-1.33. 1 Jul 1853 (rev.), 2: 50.
	1854.
Anon., Bonplandia 2: 81-82. 1854, Flora 36: 440, 558-566. 1853.

Leiberg, John Bernhard (1853-1913), Swedish-born botanist; moved to America after
1868; settled near Lake Coeur d'Alene, Idaho 1888; collector and explorer for the U.S.
Department of Agriculture (1895-1896), for the U.S. Geological Survey (1897-1903);
forestry inspector in the Phillippines 1904-1905, 1905-1906 id. in Western U.S.; made a trip
around the world in 1909. (<em>Leiberg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US. Exsiccatae:
1. <em>Musci leibergiani</em>, with E. G. Britton, nos. 1-230, New York 1890-?, sets at FH, G, NY.
2. <em>Mosses from Kootnai Co., Idaho</em>, numbers up to 266, sets at BM, FH, NY.
Written records of Leiberg's explorations in Oregon are at the University of Oregon library.
Leiberg presented a collection of flowering plants to ORE.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Gaz. 15: 158. 1890.
	Williams, Bull. Torrcy bot. Club 42: 571-577. 1915 (L's mosses from Philippines and
	Hawaii).
	Thatcher, E. P., Taxon 25: 217-218. 1976.

Leibold, Friedrich Ernst (1804-1864), German gardener and botanical explorer; at the
Cape 1835-1838 (with Baron von Ludwig); in Cuba and Mexico 1839-1844; settled in the
United States 1847; farmer in Texas, ultimately at New Orleans. (<em>Leibold</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KIEL, LZ; further material at B, E, HAL, K and W.

Leichhardt, Friedrich Wilhelm Ludwig (1813-1848), German botanist and explorer;
from 1842 in Australia; lost on a mission in 1848. (<em>Leichh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEL and NSW; further material at B, BM, P, PC. – Letters at Kew;
manuscripts at Mitchell library, Sydney.

Leidy, Joseph (1823-1891), American anatomist, parasitologist and paleontologist at
Philadelphia; founder of American vertebrate paleontology; one of the last of the great
naturalists; Dr. med. Philadelphia 1844. (<em>Leidy</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PENN. For manuscripts see e.g. Phillips and Phillips (1963).
<em>Ref</em>.: Pennell, F. W., Bartonia 22: 12. 1943.

Linnean class, Cryptogamia; compiled from Sir W. J. Hooker's English flora, vol. v; Sir J. E.

plants, and other sources ... Shrewsbury (printed and published by John Davies,...) s.d.
[1837]. (<em>Cat. cell. Gr. Brit.</em>)

<em>Publ</em>.: 1837 (p. 2: Mai 1837), p. [1]-15. <em>Copy</em>: NY.

HEADING: LEIGHTON

Leitgeb, Hubert (1835-1888), Austrian hepaticologist; Dr. phil. Graz; high school teacher
at Cilli (1855-1857), Görz (1857-1864), Linz (1865), Graz (1866); lecturer (1867) and
professor of botany (1868-1888) at the University of Graz. (<em>Leitg</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GZU (600 specimens; inf. J. Poelt). – Manuscript, morphological
and anatomical "models" and lecture posters also at GZU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 365; BJI 1: 36-37; BM 3: 1085; Bossert p. 233;
CSP 3: 944, 8: 199, 10: 558-559, 12: 439, 16: 693-694; De Toni 1: lxxvii; Frank 3(Anh.): 56;
Jackson p. 571; Kew 3: 405; LS 15171-15173; Moebius p. 123, 257, 452; NAF 2(1): 72; PR
5195-5197, 10595-10596; Rehder 5: 500; SBC p. 125 ("Leit.").
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 13: 172. 1888; Bot. Not. 1889: 29; Bot. Zeit. 46: 1888. 1888; Botanik und
	Zoologie in Österreich 1850-1900. Wien 1901 (portr.); Hedwigia 27: 180. 1888; Leopol-
	dina 24: 111. 1888; Nat. Nov. 9: 192. 1887 (election to Akademie).
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2. 26, 143. 1941.

	1889 (bibl.).

	articles by L's pupils).

Leitner, Edward Frederick [baptized: Frederick August Ludwig] (1812-1838), German
physician and botanist who studied at Tübingen and who left for the United States 1831 to
settle at Charleston, S. C.; died from shotwounds on a military expedition to Florida. (<em>Leitn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Jean Louis Cabanis (1816-1906) acquired some 800 Leitner speci-

PAGE: 830
HEADING: LEITNER

mens (mainly from Florida) which came to B (destroyed 1873; a few specimens may perhaps
have been saved). Other material not traced.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 365; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Leitn."); IH 2: 111, 428;
Lenley p. 462; ME 2: 313, 3: 614; Urban-Berl. p. 335, 368; Zander ed. 10, p. 684.
Gifford, Bull. Hist. med. 46(6): 568-590. 1972 (well documented biography, references to
	many sources not repeated here).
Graustein, J. E., Thomas Nuttall 274. 1967.

Rodgers, A. D., John Torrey 175-176. 1942.

Lejeune, Alexandre Louis Simon (1779-1858), Belgian physician and botanist; health
officer in the French army 1801-1804, from then on physician at Verviers; Dr. med. Liège
1820. (<em>Lej</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR; other material at G, GRO, H, L, LG, MW.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Also as Alexander Ludwig Simon Lejeune.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 430, 7: 165, 347; Barnhart 2: 366; BL 2: 40, 681;

IH 2: 428; Jackson p. 271; JW 1: 445; Kew 3: 405; NAF ser. 2. 2: 164; PR 5183-5186;
Rehder 5: 500; SO add. 797a; TL-2/1: 1559; Tucker 1: 421; Zander ed. 10, p. 684.

Libert (1820, <em>orth. rej.</em>). <em>Note</em>: There are about 100 hepatic generic names in which <em>Lejeunea</em> is

(journal): <em>Lejeunia</em>. Revue de botanique. 1937-1960. Ser. 2. Nro. i-x. 1961-x.

Le Jolis, Auguste François (1823-1904), French merchant and algologist at Cherbourg;
founder (30 Dec 1851) of the Société des Sciences naturelles de Cherbourg; from then on
director and archivist as well as editor of the society's publications. (<em>Le Jol</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CHE; duplicates see IH. Exsiccatae: <em>Algues marines de Cherbourg</em>, fasc.
i-xiv, nos. 1-280, Cherbourg 1863-1882; sets at AUT, BM, FH, KIEL, LG, NY, S, WRSL. –
L's library is also at CHE. Mosses at H and L.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 85. 1969, 19(3): 357. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 366; BL 2: 178, 681; BM 3: 1086; Bossert p. 233;
CSP 3: 947, 8: 199, 10: 559, 12: 439, 16: 694; De Toni 1: lxxvii, cxxxix, 2: lxxv, 4: xxxvi;
Frank 3(Anh.): 56; GR p. 286, <em>pl</em>. [<em>30</em>]; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Le Jolis"); IH 2: 428-429; Jackson
p. 571; Kew 3: 405; Moebius p. 67, 88; Nordstedt suppl. p. 9; PR 5191-5194; Rehder 5: 500;
SBC p. 125 ("Le Jol."); TL-2/4023, 4027; Tucker 1: 421; Zander ed. 10, p. 684.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1905: 56; Torreya 4: 160. 1904.

Lelièvre, J. F. (<em>fl</em>. 1838), French gardener, book-seller and seed merchant at New Orleans.
(<em>Lelièvre</em>).

Lely, Hugh Vandervaes (1891-x), Nigerian botanist and conservator of forests. (<em>Lely</em>).

PAGE: 834
HEADING: LEMAIRE

Lemaire, [Antoine] Charles (1800-1871), French botanist; specialist on Cactaceae;
edited <em>L'Horticulteur universel</em> (1839-1845) and <em>Jardin fleuriste</em> (1851-1854) at Paris; and the
<em>Flore des Serres</em> and <em>L'Illustration horticole</em> at Gent (1854-1868). (<em>Lem</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; material in C. Lemaire's library was dispersed by sale.
<em>Ref</em>.: Cretaine, Bull. soc. bot. France 18(bibl.): 48. 1872.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 366; BM 3: 1086-1087; CSP 3: 948, 8: 199, 12:
439, 16: 697; Dryander 1: 129, 5: 322; Frank 3(Anh.): 56-57; Hortus3: 1198 ("Lem."); IH
2: 429; Jackson p. 571; Kew 3: 406; Langman p. 436-437; MW p. 264-266, suppl. p. 196; NI
1169; Plesch p. 304; PR 5199-5205; Rehder 5: 501-502; Tucker 1: 421; Zander ed. 10, p.
684.
André, E. F., Ill. hortic. 18: 120-121. 1871; Gard. Chron. 1871: 844, 870.
Anon., Flora 54: 288. 1871.
Crépin, F., Guide bot. Belgique 258, 457. 1878.
Hunt, J. Mammillaria Soc. 16(3): 29-30. 1976.
Merrill, E. D., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30(1): 187. 1947.
Morren, E., Belg. horticole 21: 198-199. 1821.
Schumann, Monatschr. f. Kakteenkunde 8: 48-52. 1898.
Tjaden, Cact. Succ. J. Gr. Britain 31: 29-31. 1969 (on L. and <em>Schlumbergera</em>, the Christmas
	cactus).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Edited <em>L'Illustration horticole</em>, vols. 1-16, 1854-1869; <em>Revue horticole</em> 1858,
<em>Herbier général de l'amateur</em> 1839-1850 (see under Loiseleur-Deslongchamps), and was co-
editor of vols. 1-10 of the <em>Flore des Serres</em> (see under Van Houtte). Lemaire contributed also to
D, Orbigny, <em>Diet. uuiv. Hist. nat.</em>

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Lemaire was born on 1 November 1800 according to the birth certificate consulted by
J. A. Janse (Bennebroek, Netherlands, letter to FAS 20 Aug 1975). "L'an neuf, le dix
brumaire ou premier novembre mil huit cent, est né à Paris, Antoine Charles, du sexe
masculin, fils de Antoine Charles Lemaire et Marie Jeanne Davio." Lemaire later signed Ch.
Lemaire – Lemaire went to Belgium at the invitation of Van Houtte to edit the <em>Flore des Serres</em>.
From 1854-1868 he worked for Ambroise Verschaffelt and edited his <em>Illustration horticole</em>. In-
1869 J. J. Linden bought up the Verschaffelt Établissement and the editorship of the
journal went to E. André. Lemaire (no pension) returned to Paris in poverty.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lemairea</em> de Vriese (1854); <em>Lemaireocereus</em> N. L. Britton &amp; J. N. Rose (1909).

4372. <em>Cactearum aliquot novarum</em> ac insuetarum in horto monvilliano cultarum accurata
descriptio. Fasciculus primus. Curante C. Lemaire, ... Lutetiae Parisiorum [Paris], (apud
F. G. Levrault, ...), Argentorati [Strasbourg] (id.) 1838. Qu. † (<em>Cact. aliq. nov.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 10 Feb 1838 (p. iii: octob. kalend. 1837; BF 10 Feb 1838, Acad. 26 Mar 1838), p. [i]-
	xiv, [1]-40, [1-2, ind., notes], <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. lith., Thiollat). <em>Copies</em>: MICH, NY, USDA,
	WU.

4373. <em>Cactearum genera nova speciesque novae</em> et omnium in horto monvilliano cultarum ex
affinitatibus naturalibus ordinatio nova indexque methodicus ... Lutetiis – Parisiorum
[Paris], (apud editorem, ... et apud J. Loss, ...) 1839. Oct. (<em>Cact. gen. sp. nov.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>: Feb 1839 (TL-1/669), p. [i]-xvi, chart, [1]-115, [116, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO (photo-
	copies: NY, USDA.).

4374. <em>V Horticulteur universel</em>, journal général des jardiniers et amateurs, présentant l'analyse
raisonnée des travaux horticoles français et étrangers, et contenant: l'histoire, la description,
la culture raisonée et la figure, tant des plantes d'ornement ou d'économie, les plus nouvelles
et les plus intéressantes, que des plus beaux fruits nouvellement gagnés; des plans, coupes et
élévations de serres, de constructions ornamentales et d'appareils de chauffage; de plans de
jardins, instrumens de jardinage, objects d'ornemens, etc. Ouvrage destiné à favoriser et à
populariser en France la science de l'horticulture. Publié par une réunion de botanistes et
d'horticulteurs français et étrangers, et rédigé par C. Lemaire, ... Paris (chez H. Cousin,
libraire-éditeur, ...) 1839-1845, 6 vols. Oct. (<em>Hort. universel</em>).

HEADING: LEMAIRE

Prospectus for publication was reported on May 15, 1839. Index to vol. 5 reported on Aug21,
1844. – Dates based on the bimonthly meetings of the Société d'Horticulture de Paris where
each of the periodicals as received were reported. These were published in Annales de la
Société d'Horticulture de Paris vol. 24-36, 1839-1845.
Many plates are the same as in the second series of the <em>Herbier général de l'Amateur</em> (ed. by
Lemaire from vol. 2 onwards), see Loiseleur-Deslongchamps.

4375. <em>Iconographie descriptive des Cactées</em> ou essais systématiques et raisonnés sur l'histoire
naturelle, la classification et la culture des plantes de cette famille ... Paris (H. Cousin,
Libraire-éditeur ...) [1841-1847]. Fol. (<em>Iconogr. descr. Cact.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: <em>16 pl</em>. with text, 1841-1847. <em>Copies</em>: BR (<em>6 pl</em>.), MO (<em>14 pl</em>.; for further copies see Rowley
	1966). – Eight livraisons each containing two plates with accompanying text. In all 30
	pages of text. Fasc. 1 (<em>pl. 1, 2</em>) was published early Dec 1841 (BF 4 Dec). The initial
	announcement in BF speaks of "au moins 200 planches" (see also the note in Pritzel). Only
	plates nos. <em>1</em> and <em>2</em> are numbered (copy BM). Rowley provides a list of the plates with the
	numbers given to them in the various copies and cites the modern names. The plates are
	colour-printed engravings (finished by hand) of drawings by Maubert. – Further details of
	publication are lacking.
<em>Ref</em>.: Vriese, W. H. de, Tijdschr. nat. Gesch. Physiol. 8(2): 117-118. 1841 (livr. 1, rev.).
	Junk, Rara 68. 1902.
	Rowley, G., Cact. Succ. J. Amer. 38: 106-107. Mai-Jun 1966.

4376. <em>Le Jardin fleuriste</em>, journal général des progrès et des intérêts horticoles et botaniques,
contenant l'histoire, la description, la figure et la culture des plantes les plus rares et les plus
méritantes nouvellement introduites en Europe; publié sous les auspices et avec la col-
laboration des principaux botanistes et horticulteurs du continent, et, en particulier, d'un
grand nombre de membres de la Société royale d'agricult. et de botanique de Gand, et rédigé
par Ch. Lemaire ... Gand (chez les éditeurs F. et E. Gyselynck, imprim. et lithogr.) 1851-
1854, 4 vols. Qu. (<em>Jard. fleur.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: in parts, 24 parts per volume, issued on the first and fifteenth of each month from 1 Jul
	1850-31 Mai 1854. The plates are col. liths., some by Heyland, many unsigned. The text
	and the plates are often dated. <em>Copies</em>: MICH, NY, USDA.

Léman, Dominique Sébastien (1781-1829), French cryptogamist. (<em>Léman</em>).

Le Maout, Jean Emmanuel Maurice (1799-1877). French physician and botanist in
Paris. (<em>Le Maout</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

HEADING: LE MAOUT

4380. <em>Leçons élémentaires de botanique</em> fondées sur l'analyse de 50 plantes vulgaires et formant
un traité complet d'organographie et de physiologie végétable, à l'usage des étudiants et des
gens du monde, ... Paris (chez Fortin, Masson et Cie., ... Langlois et Leclercq, ...)
Leipzig (id. chez L. Michelsen) s.d. 1844. (<em>Leçons élém. bot.</em>).

Lemmon, John Gill (1832-1908), American botanist and plant collector; born in Mi-
chigan; involved in the civil war; from 1866 in California, first in Sierra Valley, later at
Oakland; on Calif. State Board of Forestry 1888-1892; married to Sara Allen Plummer
(1836-1929), who accompanied him on many of his collecting trips. (<em>Lemmon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC; other material at LIV and NA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 367; Bossert p. 234; CSP 12: 439, 16: 699; DAB
(by W. L. Jepson) 1: 162-163; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lemm."); IH 1(ed. 6): 361, 2: 430; Kew 3:
409; Langman p. 437; Lenley p. 262; NW p. 51 ; Tucker 1: 422; Zander ed. 10, p. 684.
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 17(1): 21. 1909.
Brewer, W. H., <em>in</em> S. Watson, Bot. Calif. 2: 558-559. 1880.
Cantelow, Leafl. Western Bot. 8: 94-95. 1957.
Copeland, Madreño 5: 77. 1939.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lemmonia</em> A. Gray (1876). <em>Note</em>: <em>Plummera</em> A. Gray (1882) is dedicated to his wife
Sara Allen Lemmon, née Plummer (1836-1923), who accompanied him on his botanical
trips. (The genus is based on a collection made by Mr. and Mrs. Lemmon in Arizona). –
<em>Mount Lemmon</em>, Arizona.

4391. <em>Ferns of the Pacific Coast</em>, including Arizona. A full conspectus of the tribes and genera,
with a classified list of the species, giving principal points of distinction and localities of
growth ... San Francisco (Bacon &amp; Company, printers) 1882. (<em>Ferns Pacif. Coast</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1882, p. [1]-13, [14-15]. <em>Copy</em>: MO.
<em>Note</em>: Lemmon mentions in his text the preparation of a <em>Manual of Pacific ferns</em> by his wife Sara
Allen Plummer Lemmon (1836-1923). This <em>Manual</em> was never published; Mrs. Lemmon's
only publication on ferns appeared in the <em>Pacific kura[fix] Press</em>, 26 March, 1881: <em>Ferns of the
Pacific Coast</em>. The only known <em>copy</em> of this fairly substantial paper is at MO. It is reproduced,
with introductory notes, by Ewan, Amer. midland Natural. 32: 513-518. 1944.

4392. <em>Pines of the Pacific Slope</em> particularly those of California. From the report of J. G.
Lemmon, botanist for the California State Board of Forestry. Published by the author
[Oakland, Calif.] 1888. (<em>Pines Pacif. Slope</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1888 (t.p.; the author forwarded a copy to Trelease in Jan 1889), p. [1]-13. <em>Copy</em>: MO.

4393. Hand-book of West-American cone-bearers. Approved English names with brief

	With 2-page appendix of changes and new matter. July, 1900."

Calif. 1902]. Oct. (<em>Conif. Pacif. Slope</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1902, p. [i], [100]-130, chart, <em>pl. 62-64. Copy</em>: MO. – Reprinted from Sierra Club
	Bulletin 4(2), June 1902.

Lemoine (Pierre Louis) Victor (1823-1911), French horticulturist; trained e.g. at Gent
by Louis Van Houtte; at Nancy from 1850; raised many new cultivars of <em>Begonia, Syringa,
Clematis, Fuchsia</em> and <em>Deutzia</em>. (<em>Lemoine</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Le Monnier, [Lemonnier] Louis Guillaume (1717-1799), French botanist at Paris, pupil
of Bernard de Jussieu, state physician, professor of botany at the Jardin du Roi (1758-1786),
sent Michaux to the Near East, Aublet to Guyana, Desfontaines to North Africa and
Labillardière to the Lebanon. (<em>Le Monn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (10.000 collected by L. himself, furthermore by Commerson
(3000), Labillardière (types Icon. pl. Syr. rar., 1000 specimens), Desfontaines, Michaux.
Further material at FI (herb. Desfontaines) and P.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: see Lasègue p. 54-65 for a description of the Le Monnier herbarium as it was bought by
Benjamin Delessert, giving details on the constituent private herbaria.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 368; BM 3: 1088; CSP 8: 201; Dawson p. 528,
943; Dryander 1: 237, 3: 552, 5: 322; DSB 8: 176-178; IH 2: 430; Jackson p. 94; Lasègue p.
54-65, 574; LS 15197; Moebius p. 347; PR (alph.) (ed. 1: 5756-5757); Rehder 5: 503; TL-
2/1: see index.
Candolle, A. P. de, Mém. Souvenirs 121. 1862.
Cohen, B., Mem. Amer. philos. Soc. 43. 1956 (657 p.; Franklin and Newton, with notes on
	L's work on electricity).
Cuvier, G., Notice historique sur Louis-Guillaume Lemonnier. Paris (Baudoin) Ventôse an
	ix [1801], 17 p.
Duprat, G., Les botanistes français en Amérique du Nord 231-252. 1957.
Fries, Th. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(4): 8, 11, 21, 1910; 1(5): 51. 1911; 1(6): 211, 301, 316,
	435. 1912; 1(7): 84, 86. 1917.
Guillaumin, A., Les fleurs des jardins xxvii-xxviii. 1929.
Hulth, J. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(1): 123, 124. 1916.
Lapeyrouse, P. P. de, Hist. abr. pl. Pyren. xxv-xxvi. 1813.
Nicolas, J. P., <em>in</em> G. H. M. Lawrence, ed., Adanson 1: 384 [index]. 1963.
O., Dict. Sci. méd. 6: 2. 1824.
Robbins, Garden J. 8(3): 80-81, 93. 1958.
Stafleu, F. A., Intr. Jussieu Gen. Pl. xxviii, xxx. 1964; Linnaeus and the Linnaeans 275, 278-
	280, 321, 324. 1971; also <em>in</em> Lawrence, Adanson 1: 140, 145, 239, 241. 1963.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Moniera</em> [sic] P. Browne (1756), <em>Moniera</em> Loefling (1758), <em>Monniera</em> A. L. Jussieu
(1789, <em>orth. var. of Moniera</em> Loefling), and <em>Monnieria</em> Linnaeus (1759, <em>orth. var.</em> of <em>Moniera</em>
Loefling) are probably commemorating him. <em>Lemonniera</em> E. De Wildeman (1894), <em>Le-
Monniera</em> Lecomte ex Baehni (1938), and <em>Neolemonniera</em> H. Heine (1960) are dedicated to G.
Le Monnier, French botanist.

HEADING: LENORMAND

Lendner, Alfred (1873-1948), Swiss mycologist. (<em>Lendn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 368; BL 2: 571, 681; BM 7: 620; CSP 16: 707;
Hawksworth p. 184; Hirsch p. 172; Kew 3: 410; LS 15207-15213, 35938-35945, suppl.
15809-15843; Stevenson p. 1249; Tucker 1: 422.

Lenoble, Félix (1867-1949), French floristic botanist; trained at the teachers College of
Saint-Cloud; high school teacher at Rennes and Valence; from 1900-1933 "inspecteur du
travail" (factory inspector) at Angoulême, Marseille, Privas, Valence and Dijon. (<em>Lenoble</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 368; BL 2: 147, 176, 681.

Lenormand, [Sébastien-] René (1796-1871), French botanist in Normandy; admitted as
lawyer 1820; practiced in Vire until 1835; retired to his property at Lénaudières devoting
himself exclusively to botany; compiled a considerable herbarium. (<em>Lenorm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CN and L (see Koster 1936), duplicates in many herbaria, see IH.
Exsiccatae: <em>Thalassophytes de France</em>, ser. 1, nos. 1-100, ser. 2, nos. 1-100, Vire 1847.
<em>Ref</em>.: Koster, J. T., Blumea 2(3): 231, 232-233. 1936; Taxon 18: 555. 1969.
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1):85. 1969, 19(3): 357-358. 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 369; BM 3: 1089; Bossert p. 234; Clokie p. 198;
CSP 8: 202, 12: 441; Frank 3(Anh.): 57; IH 2: 431; Kew 3: 411; KR p. 387-388; Lasègue p.
101, 322, 574; Lenley p. 462; PR (alph., add.); SK 1: 320; TL-2/1: see Drake del Castillo, E.;
Urban-Berl. p. 266, 271, 288, 305, 369.
Anon., Flora 55: 63-64. 1872, Bot. Zeit. 30: 168. 1872.
Jaubert, H. F. de, Bull. Soc. bot. France 19: 104-112. 1872, also reprinted, Paris, 1872, 11 p.
	(Notice sur la vie et les travaux de ...).
Le Testu, Rev. bryol. lichénol. 14: 1-6. 1944 (corr. with Husnot).
Morière, Bull. Soc. bot. France 18: 390-394. 1871; Notice biographique sur Sébastien-René
	Lenormand. Caen, 1873, 31 p. (Mém. Acad. Sci. Arts, Belles-Lettres Caen, Année 1874,
	p. 49-78).
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 106-107, <em>pl. 140.</em> 1905.
Zetterstedt, J. E., Bot. Not. 1872: 26-27.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lenormanda</em> Delise (1841, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Lenormandia</em> Trevisan (1843, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Lenor-
mandia</em> Montagne (1844, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Lenormandia</em> Sonder (1845, <em>nom. cons.</em>); <em>Lenormandiopsis</em>

Léon, Frère [Sauget y Barbis, Joseph Sylvestre], [Hermano Léon] (1871-1955), French-
born botanist; member of the Frères des écoles chrétiennes; settled at La Salle, Havana,
Cuba in 1905; author of <em>Flora de Cuba</em> (1946-1963); Dr. phil. h.c. Columbia 1927. (<em>Léon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HAC. Cuban material in many herbaria.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 210; BL 1: 225, 305; Bossert p. 234; Hortus 3:
1198 ("Leon"); IH 1(ed. 6): 395, 2: 431; Kew 3: 412; Lenley p. 262; Plesch p. 325.
Alain, Taxon 5: 125-130. 1956; Contr. ocas. Museo Hist. nat. Collegio "De la Salle" 15: 1-2.
	1956.
Anon., Torreya 83(4): 305-307. 1956 (portr.).
Leon, Hermano &amp; Hermano Alain, Flora de Cuba 4: frontisp. 1957 (portr.).
Ponce de Leon, A. et al., Homenaje postumo al Dr. José Silvestre Sauget (Hermano Leon).
	Facultad de Ciencias. Universidad de la Habana. s.d., 53 p. (bibl., portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Leon, Hermano (J. S. Sauget) and Hermano Alain (E. E. Liogier), <em>Flora
de Cuba</em>. Habana, Rio Piedras 1946-1963, contr. occ. Mus. Hist. nat. La Salle 8, 10, 13, 16,
part 5 publ. indep. at Rio Piedras. – <em>Parts 1-4</em>: reprinted Koenigstein-Taunus (Otto Koeltz)
1975, ISBN 3-87429-077-8, in three volumes of which vol. 3 is a reissue of the original sheets
of part 5 (see Taxon 24: 382. 1975).

Leonhardi, Peter Carl Pius Gustav Hermann, Freiherr von [Hermann von L.] (1809-
1875), German botanist and philosopher; at München 1831-1849; from 1849 professor of
philosophy at Praha University. (<em>Leonhardi</em>).

Leschenault de la Tour, Jean Baptiste Louis [Claude] Théodore (1773-1826),
French botanical explorer, e.g. on Le Naturaliste and Le Géographe (1801-1804) with
Baudin; in India 1816-1821, Brazil 1823-1824. (<em>Lesch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, PC; further material in FI (herb. Desf.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 325; Barnhart 2: 371; BM 3: 1094; Bossert p. 235;
Clokie p. 198; CSP 3: 967, 6: 712, 12: 442; Dawson p. 530, 943; Frank 3(Anh.): 57; Hortus 3:
1198 ("Lesch."); IH 2: 434; Lasègue p. 271-275, 430-432, 574; PR 5225-5226 (ed. 1: 5779-
5780); Rehder 5: 505; SK 1: xxvi, 321-322, 8: lx-lxi; Tucker 1: 424; Zander ed. 10, p. 684.
Alain, Hermano, Contr. ocas. Mus. Hist. nat. "De la Salle" 15(1-2): 1-2. 1956.
Anon., Mém. Soc. Linn. Paris 5(2): 626-627. 1827.

Guillaumin, A., Les fleurs des Jardins xxxix. 1929.

Urban, L, Fl. bras. 1(1): 41-42. 1906 (itin.).
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 114-115. 1903.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 31: 329-330. 1976.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lalouria</em> (Endlicher) Lindley (1847); <em>Lechenaullia</em> [sic] R. Brown (1810). <em>Note</em>:
<em>Latouria</em> Blume (1849) is dedicated to Latour (<em>fl. 1822-1826</em>), botanical artist working for
Blume.

Leske, Nathanael Gottfried (1751-1786), German botanist, professor of agricultural
economy at Leipzig (1775), ultimately at Marburg (1786). (<em>Leske</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 372; BM 3: 1094; Bossert p. 235; Dawson p. 530,
943; Dryander 5: 324; Frank 3(Anh.): 57; GR p. 105; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Leske"); PR 5228
(ed. 1: 5783); Quenstedt p. 259-260; Rehder 5: 506; TL-2/ 1790; Tucker 1: 424.
Jourdan, A. J. L., Dict. Sci. méd. 6: 22-23. 1824 (bibl.).
Roeper, Leipz. Magazin 1786: 504-520 (fide PR).
Zittel, K. A. von, Hist. geol. palaeont. 127, 130. 1901.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See BM 3: 1094.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Dendroleskea</em> Hampe (1869); <em>Leskea</em> J. Hedwig (1801); <em>Leskeadelphus</em> Herzog
(1916); <em>Leskeella</em> (K. G. Limpricht) Loeske (1903); <em>Leskeodon</em> V. F. Brotherus (1907);
<em>Leskeodontopsis</em> B. O. van Zanten (1964); <em>Leskeopsis</em> V. F. Brotherus (1931); <em>Pseudoleskea</em> Bruch
&amp; Schimper (1852); <em>Pseudoleskiella</em> Kindberg (1897); <em>Pseudoleskeopsis</em> V. F. Brotherus (1907);
<em>Sciuroleskea</em> Hampe ex V. F. Brotherus (1925).

Lespinasse, Jean Martial Gustave (1807-1876), French botanist at Bordeaux. (<em>Lesp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BORD, other material at BR and E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 562; Barnhart 2: 372; BL 2: 152, 681; BM 3: 1094;

4409. <em>Florula sebastopolitana</em> seu enumeratio plantarum anno 1855 circa Sebastopolim et

[Bordeaux] (ex typis G. Gounouilhou) 1881. Duod. (<em>Fl. sebastop.</em>).

<em>Editor</em>: Victor Félix Raulin (1815-1905).
<em>Publ</em>.: Jan-Mai 1881 (Bot. Zeit. 29 Jul 1881; Nat. Nov. Jun(2) 1881), p. [i-ii], 317-394.
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, NY. – Reprinted, with special t.p. and cover, from Actes Acad. Sci. Belles-
	Lettres Arts Bordeaux 42(2): 317-394. 1880. – We have no further data on Jules Jeannel
	except that he was chief pharmacist with the French eastern army during the siege of
	Sébastopol.

Lesquereux, Charles Léo (1806-1889), Swiss-born palaeobotanist and bryologist; to the
United States in 1848 (abolishment by the revolutionary council of the Neuchâtel academy);
first with Agassiz at Harvard; from 1849-1873 with Sullivant in Columbus, Ohio; from 1865
also working part time at Harvard. (<em>Lesq</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY; further important sets at NEU (e.g. bryophytes), OS, WTU. –
With W. S. Sullivant (q.v.): <em>Musci boreali-americana</em> ... <em>exsiccata</em>. Fossil collections, see
Darrah (1934, 1942), mainly at the Botanical Museum, Harvard; some later material also at
US. Many Lesquereux type specimens of mosses are in the Sullivant and James collections at
FH, which also holds bryophytes collected by L. himself. Many letters by L. are at Harvard
University. The corrrespondence with Thomas Potts James (270 letters) and the manuscript
of the <em>Manual of mosses</em> are at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 294-295; Backer p. 325; Barnhart 2: 372; BJI 1:
37; BM 3: 1094-1095; Bossert p. 235; CSP 3: 970, 8: 208-209, 10: 570-571, 12: 442-443, 16:
735; DAB (by G. P. Merrill); DSB 8: 263-265; Frank 3 (Anh.): 57; Hortus 3: 1198
("Lesq."); IH 1 (ed. 6): 361, 2: 434-435; Jackson p. 572; Kew 3: 419; Lenley p. 463; LS
15256-15258; ME 3: 615 [index]; Merrill p. 498-499, 704, 704; MW p. 268; NAF ser. 2(3):
38; NI 1179-1180; PR 5230-5231 (ed. 1: 5786-5788); Quenstedt p. 260; Rehder 5: 506; SBC
p. 125 ("Lesq."); TL-2/1: 312, see Bolander, H. N.; Tucker 1 424; Urban-Berl. p. 271, 305.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1890: 45; Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts Sci. 25: 320-324. 1890.
Armstrong, Ohio Naturalist 1: 35-36. Jan 1901.
Barnes et al., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 26: 504-505. 1899.
Barnes, Bot. Gaz. 14: 272. 1889, 15: 16-19. 1890.
Boone, W., Hist. bot. W. Virginia 181, 182, 186. 1965.
Clarke, J. M., James Hall of Albany 221. 1923.
Core (ed.), Wild Flower 40(3): 29-30. 1964.
Dana, J. D., Amer. J. Sci. ser. 3. 38: 499-500. 1889.
Darrah, Bot. Mus. Leafl. 2(10): 113-119. 1934.
Earle Smith, Bartonia 28: 21, <em>pl. 6.</em> 1957.
Favre, Bull. Sci. nat. Neuchâtel 18: 1-37. 1890 (bibl.).
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 11, 12, 47, 91, 92, 103, 105. 1969.
Harshberger, J. W., Bot. Philadelphia 25, 187, 352. 1899.

Husnot, P. I., Rev. bryol. 12(6): 95. 1885 (herb.).
Kellerman, W. A., Geol. Ohio, Plants 57. 1895.

Lessing, Christian Friedrich (1809-1862), German botanist, born in Polish Warten-
burg, grand son of the poet, studied in Berlin, Dr. phil. 1832; travelled in Norway and in
European and Asiatic Russia, settled ultimately at Krasnoyarsk in Siberia. (<em>Less</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CW (through Turczaninow); further material at B, FI, KIEL, L,
LE, LY, MW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 109; Barnhart 2: 372; BM 3: 1095; CSP 3: 971;
Frank 3(Anh.): 57; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Less."); IH 2: 435; Jackson p. 129; Kew 3: 420; KR p.
388; Langman p. 441; Lasègue p. 574; MW p. 268; NAF ser. 2. 2: 164; PR 5232-5234 (ed. 1:
5790-5792); Rehder 5: 506; TL-2/1: 1082; TR 774; Tucker 1: 424; Zander ed. 10, p. 684.
Anon., J. Bot. 2: 224. 1864.
Herder, F. G. T. M. von, Bot. Jahrb. 9: 439. 1888.
Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 22: 132. 1864.
Schmid, G., Chamisso als Naturforscher 170 [index]. 1942.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>Synanthereae</em> in Chamisso et Schlechtendal, Linnaea 6: 83-170. post Mar
1831, 209-260. Jul-Dec 1831, 501-528. Jul-Dec 1831.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Webbia 32(1): 14. 1977 (no. 23).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Lessingia Chamisso (1829), also dedicated to his nephew Karl Friedrich Lessing
(1808-1880), German painter, as well as to their grandfather Gotthold Ephraim Lessing
(1729-1781), German poet.

Lesson, Adolphe Pierre (1805-1888), French explorer; with Dumont d'Urville on the
voyage in <em>L'Astrolabe</em> (1826-1829); brother of R. P. Lesson. (<em>A. Lesson</em>).

Oxford; lecturer St. John's College, Oxford, 1886-1896; principal, Victoria College, Jersey
(1896-1911). (<em>Lest.-Garl.</em>).

Lestiboudois, François Joseph (x-1815), French botanist at Lille, son of Jean Baptiste
Lestiboudois. (<em>F. Lestib.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 372; BM 3: 1096; Kew 3: 420; PR 5236-5237
(ed. 1: 5794-5795); Rehder 5: 506; Tucker 1: 424.
Leclair, E., Les Lestiboudois, botanistes lillois. Lille 1908, 56 p.

4429. <em>Botanographie belgique</em>, ou méthode pour connoître facilement toutes les plantes qui
croissent naturellement, ou que l'on cultive communément dans les provinces septen-
trionales de la France ... À Lille (de l'Imprimerie de J. B. Henry, ... 1781. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Botanogr. belg.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: Jul-Dec 1781 (approb. p. [5]: 4 Jul 1781; p. [535]: 18 Jul 1781), p. [(1)]-(8), i-xlviii, 1-
	334. [335], [336, err.], 23 charts. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, U, USDA. – The 23 charts are copper
	engr. placed after p. xlii, xlviii, 14, 20, 30, 42, 56, 66, 76, 98, 116, 126, 152, 156, 170, 192,
	210, 232, 254, 256, 262, 280, 298.

<em>Ed. 2</em>: <em>Botanographie belgique</em>, seconde édition corrigée, augmentée et divisée en trois parties,
	... À Lille (chez Vanackere, libraire, ...) An VII de la République [22 Sep 1799-16 Sep
	1800]. Oct. (in fours). <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY, USDA.
	<em>1</em>: 1799, [i]-xxiii, 1-226, 1 chart.
	<em>2</em>: 1799, [i]-xiv, [1-2], chart, 1-344, class charts 1-22 (id.).
	<em>3</em>(<em>1</em>): 1800 [i*, iii*], [i]-xiv, [1-2], 1-335, [336, err.], 1 chart.
	<em>3</em>(<em>2</em>): 1800, [i], [1]-464, [1-4, add., err.].
<em>Part 3</em>, new in this edition, is also referred to (JT 14 Jun, JGLF Aug 1800) as <em>Botanographie
universelle</em>. We have seen no copies of the 1800 edition with this title. A re-issue of this
<em>Botanographie universelle</em>, was announced by JT 13 Mai 1802, and JGLF Aug 1802. This is
probably an announcement of the 1804 ed. of part 3 of the <em>Botanographie belgique</em>. This part 3
being new in the 1800 edition, was designated "seconde edition" on the title-pages of the
<em>Botanographie universelle</em> of 1804 (actually a reissue, see below). (<em>Botanogr. univ.</em>).

<em>Ed. 3</em>: <em>Botanographie belgique</em>, troisième édition, corrigée, augmentée et divisée en deux parties,
	... A Lille (chez Vanackere, libraire, ...). An XII de la République [24 Sep 1803-17
	Sep 1804]. Oct. (in fours).
	<em>1</em>: 1804, p. [i]-xxiii, 1-226, 1 chart. Simple reissue of ed. 2, part I.
	<em>2</em>: 1804, p. [i]-xiv, [1-2], chart, 1-334, class charts 1-22 (uncol. copp. "taille-douce").
	Simple re-issue of ed. 2, part 2.

PAGE: 855
HEADING: LEST1BOUDOIS, T. G.

	<em>Copies</em>: MO, NY. U.
	<em>Ed. 2, sic, of part 3</em>: issued under the title <em>Botanographie universelle</em> ou tableau général des
	végétaux, seonde édition, ..." À Lille (chez Vanackere, librairie, ...). An XII de la
	République (24 Sep 1803-17 Sep 1804). Oct. (in fours), in two parts:
	<em>Première partie</em>: Aug 1804, p. [i*-iii*], chart ("tailledouce"), [i]-xiv, [1-2], 1-335, [336,
	err.].
	<em>Deuxième partie</em>: Aug 1804, p. [i, iii], [1]-464, [1-4, add., err.].
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, USDA. – Actually a simple re-issue of parts 3(1) and 3(2) of the second edition
	of the <em>Botanographie belgique</em>. Announced as published by JGLF 26 Aug 1804. See T. G.
	Lestiboudois for the 1827 edition of this work (no. 4437).

4430. <em>Essai sur la famille des Cypéracées</em>; ... À Paris (de l'Imprimerie de Didot Jeune,...)
1819. Qu. (<em>Essai Cypér</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 29 Mar 1819 (presented to Académie), p. [1]-46. <em>Copies</em>: G, L, MO, NY; IDC 5084. –
	A continuation of Palisotde Beauvois' <em>Agrostographie</em>. Lestiboudois used Palisot's manu-
	script for the unpublished second part of the <em>Agrostographie</em>. Bentham (1881) gives a critical
	study of Lestiboudois' names and taxa.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 4: 1-7, 17-27. 1821.
	Bentham, G., J. Linn. Soc. 18: 360-367. 21 Feb 1881.

	174-180. 1819-1822 (1823); see also Bull. Soc. philom., Paris 1823: 175-176. To be cited
	from journal.

<em>Copies</em>: B, G, MICH, MO, USDA; IDC 6018. – An entirely rewritten version of part of F. J.

4441. <em>Histoire et description des champignons</em> alimentaires et vénéneux qui croissent aux environs
de Paris, précédées des principes de botanique indispensables à leur étude, et suivies de
planches représentant plus de cent espèces, lithographiées et coloriées d'après nature,...
Paris (Chez Crevot, libraire ... et chez l'auteur,...) 1826. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Hist, descr. champ.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1826, p. [1]-143, <em>pl. 1-12</em>, 4 charts. <em>Copies</em>: G (<em>pl</em>. uncol.), NY (<em>pl</em>. col.), Stevenson (<em>pl</em>.
	col.).

4442. <em>Figures des champignons</em> servant de supplément aux planches de Bulliard peintes d'après
nature &amp; lithographiées par J. B. L. Letellier ... Paris (chez Meilhac, ...) 1829-1942. Qu.
(size). (<em>Fig. champ.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In 18 parts, 1829-1842, covers contained 6 lithographs each, in black and white or
	(other issue) coloured. The set numbers <em>pl. 603-710</em> thus continuing the numbering from
	Bulliard, Herb. France (q.v., no. 905). We have seen two <em>copies</em>, at MICH and NY, with all
	plates (coloured) but with only one cover (NY) (8. livraison, 1841), which has "seconde
	édition." This would point at a second issue. Further details lacking. No text. The MICH
	copy was bought by L. C. C. Krieger, and has his annotation "extremely rare!!!" This
	copy belonged to Quélet, who made ms notes on the plates.

4443. <em>Expériences nouvelles sur les champignons vénéneux</em> leurs poisons et leurs contre-poisons par
J.-B.-L. Letellier ... et Speneux, pharmacien. Paris (J.-B. Baillière et Fils ...) 1866. Oct. (<em>Expér. nouv. champ, vénén.</em>).

PAGE: 858
HEADING: LETELLIER

<em>Co-author</em>: Speneux, about whom nothing is known to us.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1866, p. [1]-30, [1, cont.]. <em>Copy</em>: Stevenson.
<em>Ref</em>.: Letellier and Speneux, Ann. Hyg. publ. 27: 71-75. 1867 (fide CSP).
	Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France (bibl.; 14: 69-70. Mai 1867.

Letourneux, Aristide-Horace (1820-1890), French magistrate, botanist and malaco-
logist in Algeria (1851-1876, 1881-1890) and at Alexandria (1876-1881); collaborator of
Cosson. (<em>Letourn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P and PC (through Cosson); duplicates in many herbaria; see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 373; BL 1: 19, 42, 305; BM 3: 1097; Bossert p.
236; Clokie p. 199; CSP 8: 210, 10: 573, 12: 443, 16: 740; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Letourn."); IH
2: 436; Jackson p. 508; Kew 3: 421; Tucker 1: 425.
Anon., Bot. Zeit. 38: 543. 1880; Humboldt 1890 (Mai): 179.
Battandier, J. A., Bull. Soc. bot. France 37: 115-119. 1890.
Cosson, E. St.-C, Comp. Fl. Alg. 1: 59-65. 1881.
Cosson &amp; Durieu, Expl. Sci. Algérie, Bot. 2: xxxiv-xxxvi. 1868.
Letourneux, A. H., Bull. Soc. bot. France 36: 91-99. 1889 (notes on a botanical trip to
	Tripoli).
Maire, R., Progr. Conn. bot. Algérie 93, 95, 108-110. 1931.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 63, pl. 140. 1905 (portr.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tourneuxia</em> Cosson (1859, also dedicated to Henri René Letourneux de la Per-
raudière (1831-1861), who is also commemorated by <em>Perralderia</em> Cosson (1859)).

4461. <em>Synopsis der Pflanzenkunde</em>. Ein Handbuch für höhere Lehranstalten und für Alle,
welche sich wissenschaftlich mit Naturgeschichte der Pflanzen beschäftigen wollen. Mit

	<em>1</em>: 1882-1883, published in two parts, <em>part 1</em>: 1-544. Mar 1882 (Nat. Nov. Mar(2) 1882;

HEADING: LÉVEILLÉ, A. A. H.

	Mai 1885), p. [ii]-xviii, [1]-1002.

	..." Hannover (Hahn'sche Buchhandlung). Oct.

Léveillé, Augustin Abel Hector (1863-1918), French botanist and clergyman; ordained
1887; at Pondicherry (1887-1892); later at Le Mans; founder and director of the <em>Monde des
plantes</em>. (<em>H. Lév.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: E; purchased 1919. – Contains practically all Léveillé's type speci-
mens. Includes collections by e.g. E. Bodinier, J. Cavalerie, J. Esquirol, U. Faurie, E. E.
Maire, E.J. Tacquet. See Lauener and Green (under <em>General Commentary</em>) for full details. The
types of Léveillé's new French species and varieties are not at E.
<em>Ref</em>.: Hedge, I. C. and J. M. Lamond, Ind. coll. Edinburgh 103. 1970.
	Sayre, Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 359. 1975.

<sm>GENERAL COMMENTARY</sm>: A. Rehder redetermined many of Léveillé's plants at E and pub-
lished the results (which included many reductions) in a series of articles in the Journal of the
Arnold Arboretum (see below) entitled <em>Notes on the ligneous plants described by H. Léveillé from
eastern Asia</em>. The last part (18: 278-321) contains a comprehensive index to all binomials
cited, with reductions of Léveillé's species (MW 1: 409-410). Merrill and Walker also give
descriptive and critical notes on several of Léveillé's often very ephemeral publications.
	The articles by Rehder were published as follows: J. Arnold Arb. 10: 108-132, 184-196.
1929; 12: 275-281. 1931; 13: 299-332. 1932; 14: 223-252. 1933; 15: 1-27. 91-117, 267-326.
1934; 16: 311-340. 1935; 17: 53-82, 316-340. 1936; 18: 26-53, 206-257, 278-321. 1937. A
"Catalogue of the names published by Hector Léveillé" is being published by L. A. Lauener,
P. S. Green et al., in the Notes Roy. Bot. Gard. Edinburgh 23: 573-596 (1961); 24: 73-78
(1962); 26: 333-346 (1966); 27: 1-10 (1966); 27: 265-292 (1967); 30: 239-294 (1970); 31:
397-435 (1972); 32: 93-116 (1972); 34: 327-402 (1976); 35: 247-264 (1977); 35: 265-280
(1977); 37: 125-151. (1978).

4467. <em>Catalogue des plantes de Yun-Nan</em> avec renvoi aux diagnoses originales observations et

PAGE: 865
HEADING: LÉVEILLÉ, J. H.

destiné aux grands etablissements scientifiques avec nombreux dessins inédits ... Le Mans
(Chez l'Auteur ...) 1915-1916 [-1917]. Oct. (<em>Cat. pl. Yun-Nan</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1915-1917, p. [1]-299, <em>fig. 1-69</em> (fig. <em>24</em> hors texte) (prefacep. 3: 1 Dec 1915). <em>Copies</em>: G,
	MICH, MO, NY, USDA. The signatures 4-19 are dated. The receipt of various parts at
	Kew shows that distribution took place in sets of one to several signatures. There is not
	sufficient evidence that the signatures were not available soon after dates of printing (MW
	state that the book was issued as a whole after 5 Mai 1917), and publication must be
	assumed to have taken place in the two or three months after printing. The war conditions
	made shipping abroad difficult and local sources are needed for further precision.
